From NET microfiche: Playhouse #215, presents "Actor's Choice: Lewis Carroll," featuring Gwen Verdon and Cyril Ritchard reading selections from Carroll's works. "Actor's Choice: Lewis Carroll" is from a series of half-hour programs titled "Actor's Choice" and produced by Channel 13 in New York. Hal Holbrook is host for the series. In the Lewis Carroll program, Ritchard and Miss Verdon read "The Hunting of the Snark," "Jabberwocky" and selections from "Alice in Wonderland."
a presentation of National Educational Television ; produced by WNET ; producer-director, Glenn Jordan ; writer, David Novak.

From NET microfiche: Description The "miracle" was the creation of a Jewish nation - Israel - in 1948. After centuries of oppression and rootlessness, the Jews had a land of their own, though it was situated in the midst of a hostile Arab world. Eighteen years later, in this Intertel production, the Australian Broadcasting Commission has probed the nature of the Israeli people, especially the young, who are the first generation truly indigenous to this new land. The documentary concentrates on five aspects of life here: Defense: Living under a constant threat of war, Israel has been an armed state since its inception. This point has been dramatized within the past few weeks by border incident between Israel and Jordan, which have roused the saber-rattling Arabs (especially in Nasser's United Arab republic) to a new pitch. Religion: The documentary finds that most Jews here are not religious, though the orthodox minority holds the balance of power in government. Especially among young people, the country is increasingly secularized, bound rather by a common heritage and a common fate. Integration: Jews do not share a common cultural history, for the country contains people from 80 different nation, with the split especially marked between the more cultured Jews and Jews from the Orient who feel less privileged here. Development: Citrus fruits, science, and tourism are the main industries here. Science is shown helping to conquer the desert through a huge National Water Carrier. Atomic energy is being used meanwhile to desalinate sea water. The Arab Minority: Cut off from their native lands, the nation's quarter of a million Arabs has faced strict military control and a poor standard of living. Israel is shown attempting to cope with their problems. Edward, an Arab student at the Hebrew University in Jerusalem, describes the difficulty of living here as an outsider. Other young people appearing in the film include: H'ava, a 19-year-old girl serving in the national army and studying to be an artist; Yehuda, a boy who is training to be a rabbi at a rural Yeshiva; and Danny (an Algerian) and Avni (a Yemenite), two young delinquents from the poorest part of Tel Aviv. The Australian film crew visits the Mandelbaum Gate, which divides New and Old Jerusalem and separates Arabs in Jordan from their relatives. Here, the families meet briefly, then must go back to their separate lands. Program Credits NET Journal - After the Miracle is a 1967 presentation of the National Educational Television, produced for Intertel by the Australian Broadcasting Committee. NET producer: Boris Holtzman Suggested Newspaper listing: From university to Kibbutz, from Bedouin tent to hostile border, this Intertel documentary examines the 18-year-old nation of Israel especially through its young people.
Australian Broadcasting Commission for Intertel ; producer, Boris Holtzman.
National Educational Television and Radio Center

Story of a young couple, Cathy (played by Carol White) and Reg (played by Ray Brooks). Initially their relationship flourishes and they have a child and move into a modern home. When Reg is injured and loses his job, they are evicted by bailiffs, and they face a life of poverty and unemployment, illegally squatting in empty houses and staying in shelters. Cathy has her children taken away by social services. Filmed in semi-documentary style. Originally broadcast in 1966 as part of BBC's "The Wednesday Play" anthology strand. Broadcast in 1969 in the United States as part of the NET Playhouse anthology series. From NET microfiche: Description: This BBC production, written by Jeremy Sandford, made a strong impact in Britain when it was first aired there in 1966. The program dramatizes the effects of drastically inadequate housing conditions in overcrowded British urban centers. Cathy and Reg Ward are a young married couple who seemingly have everything going for them. With both of them earning good salaries, they find a nice place to live and start a family. Then Reg meets with an accident and by that time Cathy cannot work because of her three children. Soon they have to leave their apartment and move in with Reg's mother. But this doesn't work out, and they wind up moving from slum to slum until finally all that remains for them is the Home for the Homeless. Life in the institution totally destroys their marriage. Reg leaves his wife and, because she cannot house them, the children are taken from her. She is left entirely alone. "Cathy Come Home" won the 1968 Prix Italia. Background on the author Jeremy Sandford wrote this play to shock and disturb. He had long been interested in the problem of Britain's homeless families. When neighbors of his disappeared and he found that they had to go into a Home of the Homeless, he started to write articles, becoming obsessed with the injustice of the situation. He wrote "Cathy Come Home" in 1963 and as he says, "for three years could find no organization prepared to put it on." Then the BBC brought it and from its first showing, it has produced widespread shock and anger that such conditions could prevail. One positive result of the telecast has been the formation of a national campaign in Britain called "Shelter," to foster responsible concern for the victims of Britain's housing situation. The cast: Cathy Carol White Reg Ray Brooks NET Playhouse - "Cathy Come Home" is a National Educational Television presentation, produced for the British Broadcasting Corporation by Tony Garnett. Writer: Jeremy Sandford Director: Kenneth Loach Producer for NET: Kay Chessid NET Executive Producer: Jac Venza
Produced by Tony Garnett ; directed by Ken Loach ; television play written by Jeremy Sandford.
The Wednesday play. Cathy come home. [Great Britain release title].
NET playhouse. Cathy come home. [U.S. release title].

From NET microfiche: Description: Brief background: in the late 10th and early 11th centuries, shortly before William the conqueror's momentous invasion from Normandy in 1066, England was led by King Ethelred II, who, like many kings before him, was plagued by forays onto English soil by the Norwegians and the Danes. Not known for military powers, Ethelred has come down through history dubbed "Ethelred the Unready." In 994 he succeeded in buying off Norwegian invaders, and in 1012 he did the same with the Danes, thereby averting further armed conflicts at the time. Ethelred's reign was from 978 to 1016. "The Ceremony of Innocence" is a fictional drama set loosely against the historical background of Ethelred's attempt to gain peace with Danish King Sweyn by paying the enemy tribute money. The play can properly be termed "anti-war," but more specifically its focuses on the human factors that seem to make wars inevitable. The characters: King Ethelred - a compassionate man who finds the prospects of further war with the Norsemen totally senseless, but who lacks the strength to assert his will even over his own family; the Earl of Sussex - a rugged warrior-type who is galled at the thought of paying tribute to an enemy, the "hawk" in today's parlance; the Earl of Kent - essentially an understanding man who sympathizes with Ethelred, yet eventually finds war to be the only alternative; Queen Emma - blind with hatred for the Danes and scornful of her husband's way of thinking, filled with memories of her youth in Normandy when her father burned and butchered the Danes he found on his land; Queen Mother Alfreda - scheming and ruthless, a fitting ally for Emma; Prince Edmund - a skilled warrior and very much the product of his mother's attitudes, worlds apart from his father; Thulja - King Sweyn's daughter, offered to the English court for three years to insure that the Danes do not attack after the money is paid, she instantly becomes the object of incalculable hatred among the English royal family. Synopsis: For the most part the story is told in retrospect. It opens with the Earls of Sussex and Keny, Accompanied by Bishop Aelfhunen route to a monastery where Ethelred has gone into seclusion. Meanwhile, Ethelred painfully recalls how the peace he hoped he had bought was destroyed. Thulja's arrival in the English court was an immediate source of trouble. Although in effect a hostage, the 15-year-old-princess was given as much freedom as possible and lived as comfortably as anyone else. She was a symbol of Ethelred's appeasement and for that, as well as for her own Danish blood; she was hated, except by Kent and, of course, Ethelred. Edmund immediately became one of her severest antagonists, displaying his hatred irrationally. One day Edmund returned to the court after having killed four Danish farmers in an argument over who was to cross a narrow bridge first. (The fight took place on land preserved by treaty for the Danes.) Ethelred, in an effort to preserve the peace, told the Danish ambassador, Thorkill, that Edmund thought he was under attack and did not know he was on land set aside for the Danes. The king also offered monetary compensation for the widows of the farmers. Thorkill then appeared satisfied regarding Ethelred's intentions, but asked permission to question Edmund. The prince, however, offered scornful answers to all of Thorkill's queries and an argument developed. As Thorkill turned to leave, Edmund, in a sarcastic gesture, tossed his coin-laden purse at him, narrowly missing his head. Thinking for a moment that he was being attacked, Thorkill drew his knife. Edmund charged the Dane and was fatally stabbed. On the day of Edmund's funeral Ethelred and Kent realized it was too dangerous for Thulja to remain in the English court and decided to have her stay with Kent's family. As the funeral procession returned, Ethelred bid goodbye to Thulja. Emma and Alfreda demanded to know where she was being sent. Not receiving an answer and thinking the girl was being give her freedom, Emma became incensed. She accused her husband of having relations with the girl and in turn he struck her. She then attacked him with her hands and while they struggled Alfreda stabbed Thulja in the back, killing her. As the flashbacks end, Sussex, Kent, and the bishop are at the monastery awaiting Ethelred's decision on whether or not he will lead them into battle. But Ethelred condemns their willingness to shed more blood and bemoans his ruined dreams of peace. Sussex angrily storms out of the chamber with the cry "Victory to us, death to them!" The bishop follows. Kent, with ambivalent feelings, lingers for a moment and then joins the others. Ethelred is left alone, starting at the empty chamber. The Cast: King Ethelred - Richard Kiley Earl of Sussex -James Broderick Earl of Kent -Larry Gates Queen Emma -Elizabeth Hubbard Queen Mother Alfreda -Jessie Royce Landis Prince Edmund -John Horn Princess Thulja -Gilmer McCormick Bishop Aelfhun -Bob Gerringer Abbot -William Hickey King Sweyn -Ernest Graves Thorkill -Howard Green Edward -Bo White The Author: Ronald Ribman has written three off-Broadway plays - "Harry, Noon and night," "Journey of the Fifth Horse," and "The Ceremony of Innocence" - all of which were staged at the American Place Theatre. "Journey of the Fifth Horse" won the Obie award as best off-Broadway play for the 1965-66 season, and was later adapted for TV on NET playhouse. "The Ceremony of Innocence" was produced off-Broadway in 1967. Ribman has also written a play especially for television, "The Final War of Olly Winter," which was seen over CBS. The Producer: Bob Markell, who has won four Emmy awards, is producer of this play. He won three of those awards in connection with the series "The Defenders," twice as producer (1962 and 1963) and once as associate producer (1961). In 1954 he won an Emmy for set designing in the historical series "You are there." He is also the producer of "N.Y.P.D." PLEASE NOTE: We wish to bring to your attention that this play, is a few scattered passages, contains language that may be considered questionable for some age groups. We refer specifically to the word "bastard," plus the following sentences: "Do you Danes love as we English love, or do you merely copulate as animals do? "Now we have come upon a rat's den where walls slime and men find gillyflowers to piss upon." "(This) place is colder than an Irish tit." Net Playhouse #191 - "The Ceremony of Innocence" is a National Educational Television production. Producer: Bob Markell: Associate producer: David Loxton. Director: Arthur Seidelman. Executive producer: Jac Venza.
National Educational Television ; executive producer, Jac Venza ; producer, Bob Markell ; associate producer, David Loxton ; director, Arthur Seidelman.

A conversation between James Day, president of National Educational Television and Nancy Hanks, chairman of the National Council on the Arts and the National Endowment for the Arts. They discuss the difficulty in securing funding for the arts while demand for arts programs is increasing, the types of programs which receive funding from the National Endowment for the Arts and the importance of government funding for the arts.

Reporter Morrie Landsberg interviews retiring Chief Justice Earl Warren. Filmed at the Supreme Court in Washington, D.C. From NET microfiche: NET Journal - "A Conversation with Earl Warren": An exclusive hour-long interview with the Chief Justice of the United States, conducted just before his retirement in June. Interviewer: Morrie Landsberg This hour-long program comprises the only exclusive interview given by Earl Warren during his 16 years as Chief Justice. It was conducted by Morrie Landsberg, editor of McClatchy Broadcasting Company, Sacramento, in connection with Warren's retirement, and was a parting expression to his long-time constituents in California; the interview was seen in that state at the time of his retirement in June and is now being made available to a national audience for the first time. The program reviews the Warren Court's historic decisions on school desegregation, reapportionment, and the rights of suspects. It questions whether the police are now unduly hampered in their enforcement of the law; whether there is now equal justice for all men; whether the Court's decisions have undermined the principle of states' rights; and whether our government is now on trial. It probes Warren's attitudes toward pornography, his response to various criticisms of the Court, and his reaction to the black separation movement. NET Journal - "A Conversation with Earl Warren" is an NET presentation, produced by McClatchy Broadcasting Co, Producer-interviewer: Morrie Landsberg, NET executive producer: Jim Karayn. Excerpts: The following are key excerpts from the Warren interview, conducted last June by Morrie Landsberg, editor of McClatchy Broadcasting, a group of California radio and TV stations. The interview took place in Washington, D.C., and was aired over the McClatchy stations on June 24. Q. "Mr. Chief Justice, do you believe the Bill of Rights would be ratified if it came to a vote today?" A. "I think probably that there would be a great debate over some of them because we have never taught our youngsters where the Bill of Rights came from, why it is there, and what its purpose is in society. There are a lot of thoughtless people who feel that we don't need any more Fifth Amendment, we don't need any more jury trials under the Sixth Amendment, and we don't need protection as to free speech and freedom of the press and freedom of religion, but I do believe that on sober second thought after a great debate, the American people are wise enough to retain those rights which have made this country the greatest in the world. Q. "What would you list, Mr. Chief Justice, as the Supreme Court's most important decision in your 16 years here? Was it the school desegregation or reapportionment?" A. "I think the reapportionment, not only of state legislatures, but of representative government in this country is perhaps the most important issue we have had before the Supreme Court. If everyone in this country has an opportunity to participate in his government on equal terms with everyone else, and can share in electing representatives who will be truly representative of the entire community and not some Special interest, then most of these problems that we are now confronted with would be solved through the political process rather than through the courts." Q. "Would this apply mostly to the South?" A. "I remember the first case we had, the Baker vs. Carr case, came from one of our northern states and that the legislature in that state had been the same for over 60 years in spite of all the territorial changes. The group that was in power kept the legislature apportioned just exactly as it was over 60 years before, although the state constitution said that the representation should be equal" Q. "Would you say, Mr. Chief Justice, that American justice has been completely desegregated?" A. "Oh no, by no means. There aren't 20 percent of the school children in the South that are in desegregated schools. Thesame situation exists in some of our northern cities. The black people do not have work opportunities that white people have. They're still having problems in voting in some parts of the country. .. when the American people as a whole recognize that we have been wrong in depriving certain minorities of their Constitutional rights and when we make the decision to see that they will in the future have these rights, then I think we're on the way to solving most of our domestic problems." Q. "You said a while back that pornography was the court's most difficult area? Why is that?" A. " for the simple reason that we have to balance two constitutional rights with each other. Of course, the state and national government have the right to have a decent society and to make the laws and regulations that will keep it a decent society. On the other hand we have the First amendment which says Congress shall pass no laws abridging the right of speech and the press and religion, and so forth, and the question is how far can people ego under the First Amendment without offending the right of the government to maintain a decent society, and when you have those two thing coming together, you find it very difficult to write a verbal definition of what obscenity is. I know that in many communities in the past they have had boards of censorship and the experience that was had under them was atrocious." Q. "What do you say, Mr. Chief Justice, to critics who say that the Court, by its decisions, has dealt a death blow to state's rights?" A. "Oh, on the contrary, I think that the Supreme Court has established state's rights. What does reapportionment do, but establish state's rights? It establishes in the states the power to govern themselves and most of the problems that we have today in our big cities; for instance, we find that they are there because the states have done nothing about them. And the reason they couldn't do anything about them was because most of their legislatures were controlled by interests that were not interested in the preservation of our cities Most of this concentration of power that you find in the government, Federal government, comes from the fact that the states have not themselves done their job and they took to the Federal government, therefore, to do it for them. Once the Federal government does it for them of course, it has to build up a big bureaucracy in order to administer these programs.
247 (from slate on film and NET microfiche)
McClatchy Broadcasting Co. ; NET presentation ; NET executive producer, Jim Karayn ; producer, Morrie Landsberg.

From NET microfiche: Description of series: NET Journal - "A Conversation with Milovan Djilas": The former Yugoslav Vice President, who has served nine years in prison for his writings on the communist world, expounds on his life and times in an NET exclusive interview. This exclusive interview with Milovan Djilas will take place on the campus of Princeton University, where he is currently lecturing at the Institute for Advanced Studies. Djilas, who served as Head of Parliament and Vice President of Yugoslavia in the years from 1940 to 1954, was expelled from the communist Party and later imprisoned for his writings on the Tito Government and the course of international communism. His writings include "The New Class," "On the Aggressive Pressure of the Soviet Bloc against Yugoslavia," "Land without Justice," "The Leper," and "Conversations with Stalin," Released from prison in 1966; Djilas was recently accorded permission to leave the country for the first time in more than a decade. Please Note: Detailed information giving the scope of the interview and excerpts from the interview will follow.
NET ; executive producer, A. H. Perlmutter.
Conversation with Milovan Djilas at Princeton.
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche (C, N): CRIME AND PUNISHMENT, one of the greatest murder stories ever conceived and written, is the work of nineteenth century Russian writer Fyodor Dostoyevsky, a master of the psychological novel. The actual novel, CRIME AND PUNISHMENT, although containing both the story of a crime and its ensuing punishment is as one sided as its title. The crime committed is a murder by a poverty-stricken student who feels justified in killing a much hated avaricious old money lender and her sister, yet the crime plays but a small role in the novel the story is concentrated on the student's punishment -- his nightmarish visions of his crime and his fate, his emotional strain and the agony he suffers as a cat-and-mouse struggle develops between him and a relentless police investigator. The key set of the play is a 32-foot staircase which was designed to enable cameras to follow the student on his suspense-filled ascent to the apartment of the moneylender. The Cast: Raskolnikov -- David Collins Alyona Ivanovna -- Patricia Hayes Pestryakov -- Steven Berkoff Strange man -- Eric Francis Koch -- Desmond Stokes Marmeladov -- Esmond Knight Mme. Marmeladov -- Sylvia Coleridge Frau Lippewechsel -- Marie Burke Sonia -- Julie Foster Polya -- Carla Challoner Razumikhin -- Peter Bowles Nastasya -- Laurie Leigh Lisaveta -- Meg Simmons Market woman -- Nan Marriott-Watson Petrovitch -- Peter Hoar Zamyotov -- Neville Jason Porfiry -- Patrick Wymark Waggoner -- Robert Hunter Mme. Raskolnikov --Viola Keats Dunya -- Liane Aukin Svidrigaylov -- Douglas Wilmer Nikolay -- Nicholas Evans Drunken Pole -- Gabor Baraker

From video: An account of one of the most mishandled and brutal battles ever fought in Britain. An account of its tragic aftermath. An account of the men responsible for it. An account of the men, women and children who suffered because of it. From NET microfiche, file B: NET Playhouse - "The Battle of Culloden" - Peter ("The War Game") Watkins' documentary reconstruction of the last battle to be fought on British soil, and its aftermath, treated in on-the-spot newsreel fashion as though the TV camera has been invented in 1746. "The Battle of Culloden" is a documentary reconstruction of the last battle to be fought on British Soil, and its aftermath. On April 16, 1746, on a moor not far from Inverness, the Government forces, numbering some 9,000 men under William Augustus, Duke of Cumberland, engaged in battle with the Scottish Jacobites - less than 5,000 men under Charles Edward Stuart, better known as Bonnie Prince Charlie - who were making one final attempt to restore the Royal Stuarts to the thrones of Scotland, England, and Ireland. In a bloody massacre, the Jacobites were defeated. Basing it on actual record and available fact, producer-writer Peter Watkins carefully carried out a step-by-step reconstruction of this battle on the original site, using the weapons of the day, and reenacting it with the assistance of a large number of people from the neighborhood. To this reconstruction - as though the television camera was invented at the time of the battle - he applied newsreel techniques, imparting the sense of urgency and vivid occasion associated with the coverage of contemporary events. The cameras are taken to the battlefield; unseen newsmen carry out on the spot interviews with the leaders and with obscure people on both sides - before the battle to show the futile reasons for fighting at all, and after, to underline the battle battle's brutality and its ferocious aftermath. Peter Watkins, writer and producer of "The Battle of Culloden," received a 1967 Academy Award for his documentary feature "The War Game." The Battle of Culloden is a National Educational Television presentation, a production of BBC-TV. Written and produced by Peter Watkins. Make-up: Ann Brodie. Battle coordinator: Derek Ware. Sound: John Gatland and Lou Hanks. Photography: Dick Bush. Film Editor: Michael Bradsell. Historical advisor: John Prebble. Producer for NET: Rita Broder.
BBC-TV ; National Educational Television presentation ; producer-writer, Peter Watkins ; producer for NET, Rita Broder.

From NET microfiche: The uncompromising satire of America's best-known black comedian comes to television when NET Journal presents "Dick Gregory is Alive and Well." The program is an hour-long view of Gregory, built around an ironic address on racism which he gave before a mixed audience last summer at the University of Alabama in Tuscaloosa. While preparing for that performance Gregory recalls his early days as a comedian when he was "just up there to pay my rent," as well as the first years of the civil-rights movement when he began touring college campuses to employ "the strength of emerging youth" in a struggle against racism. He talks about the fear he felt before an appearance in the South: "I'd wake the kids and kiss them; I'd say goodbye like it could be the last time." And landing at an Alabama airport also brought reminiscences: "I used to get buster here as soon as I got off the plane ... 500 state police would be waiting." Much of the address Gregory gave in Tuscaloosa was subsequently recorded in an album titled "Dick Gregory: The Light Side, The Dark Side." His attack against racism and what he calls the moral pollution of the country included jibes at American history texts: "We're so numb we got nerve enough to teach the Indians that Columbus discovered America." And TV commercials, "I'm tired of hearing, Marge there's a white dove in your kitchen. How about hearing, Beulah, baby, there's a black crow on the biscuits." And to Northern liberal students he says: "Before you come down here and alienate your Southern racist brothers, take a black kid home with you and bug your mommy and daddy." Gregory hits constantly at a white society that shuts black people out and yet expects them to conform to its rules. In this vein he explains why the past year's "riot season" was so quite: "We got tired of stealing those bad products. This year we went underground to study the consumer reports. So this season when the riot season opens again we ain't gonna' be stealing no Motorolas." On the subject of "Negro" versus "black" Gregory says: "Call us whatever you want, but it's safer for you to call us black." When other nationalities came to America they retained their identities, he says, but when Africans were brought here they became Negro or colored. "Don't play games with us, play games with yourself," he advises. "Call yourself clear folks." NET Journal -- "Dick Gregory is Alive and Well" is an NET production. Producer: Harry Moses Executive Producer: Harry McCarthy
Dick Gregory is alive and well.
NET ; executive producer, Harry McCarthy ; producer, Harry Moses.

Two two-character plays by Tennessee Williams were broadcast together under the collective title "Dragon Country" on WNET-TV in 1970--"Talk to me like the rain and let me listen" and "I can't imagine tomorrow."
New York Television Theater ; directed and produced by Glenn Jordan ; written by Tennessee Williams.

Talk to Me Like the Rain and Let Me Listen was written in 1953 as part of a series of one-acts Williams wrote in particular for community theatre. Unlike the large scenic demands of his larger works (i.e. A Streetcar Named Desire) Talk Like The Rain... features a small-scale, bare-room situation. It involves an unnamed Man and Woman who are bound together in an endless cycle by their hopeless poverty. Major William's themes are explored in the Man's alcoholism and the Woman's desperation. Although not specified, the one-act can be worked in a more surrealist fashion. Monologues for both sexes, with the Woman's being substantially longer, spanning several pages. (Summary from Wikipedia Web site, viewed Dec. 4, 2014)
Talk to me like the rain and let me listen.

I Can't Imagine Tomorrow was a two-character play written for television, broadcast with Talk To Me Like The Rain And Let Me Listen under the collective title "Dragon Country" on WNET-TV in 1970. Kim Stanley plays a lonely but spirited spinster being courted by a pathologically shy teacher, played by William Redfield. "Dragon Country" is available as part of the Broadway Theatre Archive (see MAVIS 1812577). (Summary from Wikipedia Web site, viewed Dec. 4, 2014)
National Educational Television and Radio Center

Two two-character plays by Tennessee Williams were broadcast together under the collective title "Dragon Country" on WNET-TV in 1970--"Talk to me like the rain and let me listen" and "I can't imagine tomorrow." From NET microfiche: Kim Stanley and William Redfield star in the world premiere of Tennessee Williams' "I Can't Imagine Tomorrow." Its companion piece is a much earlier Williams' play, never before seen on television, "Talk to Me Like the Rain and Let Me Listen," starring Lois Smith and Alan Mixon. Together, these works comprise the NET Playhouse presentation titled "Dragon Country," produced by WNET's New York Television Theatre. Producer-director Glenn Jordan (who has directed three Emmy-winning performances for New York Television Theatre) has brought together these two plays, written 20 years apart, because of the similarity in theme - that of isolation. In "I Can't Imagine Tomorrow," Williams defines Dragon Country as a land of "endured but unendurable pain" where "each one is so absorbed, deafened, blinded by his own journey across it, he sees, he looks for, no one else crawling across it with him." Kim Stanley portrays a middle-aged woman who lives alone and has an illness from which she knows she is dying. Coming to see her each night is a shy, frightened man (William Redfield) who is unable to function normally with people and so clings desperately to his relationship with her while shutting out the rest of the world. Knowing what lies ahead she tries to weaken his bond with her. The play is set somewhere in the South. In the shorter of the two plays, Alan Mixon is a down-and-out man living on welfare in New York City who returns one night to the wife he had left (Lois Smith). The next morning he implores her to "talk to me like the rain and let me listen" and she responds by weaving a poignant fantasy in which she pictures herself living the rest of her life in peace completely uninvolved with any other human being. PLEASE NOTE: This New York Television Theatre production constitutes the world premiere of "I Can't Imagine Tomorrow" and the television premiere of "Talk to Me Like the Rain and Let Me Listen." This marks the first time that a Tennessee Williams play has received its world premiere on television. Suggested Newspaper Lisiting: "Dragon Country" - Kim Stanley, William Redfield, Lois Smith and Alan Mixon star in two plays by Tennessee Williams, including the world premiere performance of "I Can't Imagine Tomorrow." NET Playhouse #216 - "Dragon Country" is a presentation of NET, produced by the New York Television Theatre at Channel 13. Produced and directed by Glenn Jordan. Associate Producer: Virginia Gray. NET Playhouse Executive Producer: Jac Venza.
New York Television Theater ; directed and produced by Glenn Jordan ; written by Tennessee Williams.

From NET microfiche: Description #1 Every seventh child in the US attends parochial school. Here, the nun usually is his spiritual -- and intellectual -- guardian. And the aura of Catholicism pervades his educational life -- from the statues throughout the school to the morning catechism and the interpretation of such subjects as literature and history. Parents, who usually determine his presence in Catholic school, contend that he receives a better education, that he benefits from the religious guidance and absence of immoral influences, that he requires the discipline of a nun's tutelage. A study of the parochial school system, "Every Seventh Child" depicts the conflicts and contradictions within the Catholic movement. Above all, it raises the following issues: in an age of rising costs, the Catholic schools are pressing for Federal money; and in an age of enlightened Catholicism, many religious heads are questioning whether their system is consistent with the spirit of "Vatican II" (the recent Ecumenical Council). This conflict is expressed most pointedly in the film by Jacqueline Grennan, head of Webster College (Webster Groves, Mo.), who recently shocked conventionalists by leading a movement to secularize her school, thus shedding her nun's habit. The church, she says, "needs opening, if it's not a remnant ... if it really has something to share with the world, I invest my life in an open system, (believing) people become more contemplative the more you open a system." Meanwhile, parochial school teaching remains basically uncharged. "Every Seventh Child" has gone inside Catholic schools to film the nun at work and the child at prayer. Here, students learn religion by rote or practice sacramental roles (as when a boy plays the priest attending to "a dying man" and other children play mourners). Religious leaders and parents justify the continuance of the system -- and the need for Federal funds. (A flamboyant Baltimore priest describes the latest coloring exercise: "Paint God green." Another priest justifies the push for federal funds on the basis of the school's contribution to the community.) But other Catholics disagree. In Brooklyn, a slum district priest calls the church "less than altruistic" in running parochial schools, and notes that Vatican II represents "just and equal education for all children." Another view is presented by Carol Rinderer who recently left the convent after participating in a civil rights march in Chicago. Describing her shock at the crowd's insults, she noted "The worst hecklers were obviously Catholics. And I kept thinking, 'We taught you the wrong things.' It never mattered whether there was hate in their heart. We worked within a structure doomed to failure -- a system of ghetto education .. saying we're people apart." Similar criticism comes from a student at St. John's University, recalling their grammar school days: "It was almost anti-sex." "Your mother and father just throw you in there, figuring it's the safest thing." "When I announced I was for birth control, the nun said she'd pray for me." The program ends with an experimental class in comparative religion being conducted by nuns at Webster College. The pupils, third graders, are learning the roots of prejudice and the art of praying to a Buddhist god. Consistent with the questioning spirit of "Vatican II," this approach to education may represent the future of the parochial system. But the present looms as a bulwark resisting change, the program finds. "NET Journal -- Every Seventh Child" is a production of National Educational Television, produced, directed and written by Jack Willis. Associate producer; Catherine Clarke Description #2 National Educational Television goes behind the walls of the parish school to confront the crisis in Catholic education when "NET Journal" present the potent documentary "Every Seventh Child." Filmed in parochial schools from Baltimore to St. Louis, the program stresses the substance of Catholic education, a separatist system questioned by many ecumenical Catholics at a time when the church is pressing for federal funds. It is a time, too, when Catholic education has become a public issue through incidents at St. John's and Catholic universities. Among those appearing on the program are: Jacqueline Grennan, the former nun who is president of newly-secularized Webster College. Miss Grennan calls for "an open system" that is "evolutionary" in the true ecumenical sense, rather the "apologetics" that "we were all taught ... in high school ... I've never known human beings who got to know each other in a debating society." Carole Reinderer, recently relieved of her nun's vows and now teaching in a Chicago public school. Discussing Catholic secondary schools, she says, "I would certainly try, bit by bit, to close them down and in their place ... try to form Christian community, serving the ... actual felt needs that are within the community." She adds, "When you set up a ghetto kind of education, no matter what else we say, existentially we're saying we are a people apart." Brother Anthony Ipsaro, superintendent of parochial schools in Baltimore, who emphasizes the current concern of Catholic education with a graphic allusion: "Paint God green." Father Jack Powers, a Brooklyn priest who wants to close down his slum school since it can handle so few of the children needing "a just and equal education." Monsignor George Kelly, secretary of education for New York Archdiocese, and Father Satler, rector of Baltimore's St. James Church, who argue that Catholic schools are vital to the community -- especially in poor neighborhoods -- and therefore merit federal money. Attorney Leo Pfeffer, who states "you have no constitutional right for the public to pay for the destruction of their own institution" by financing the parochial, at the expense of the public school. Students at St. John's University, who describe their parochial education. Nuns in classrooms in Philadelphia, Baltimore and Rochester, New York. In addition, the program visits a progressive class in comparative religion for children of all faiths, being conducted by nuns at Webster College. "NET Journal -- Every Seventh Child" is a production of National Educational Television. Produced, written and directed by Jack Willis. Associate producer: Catherine Clarke
National Educational Television ; producer-director-writer, Jack Willis.

From NET microfiche (G): Program Description: The first film portrait devoted to the life and work of American author and art patron Gertrude Stein, this program by Perry Miller Adato (Emmy winner for NET's "Dylan Thomas: the World I Breathe") focuses on Miss Stein's Paris years from 1905 to the mid-1930s. It examines Miss Stein's relationship to the artists of her lifetime, their effect on her and her writing, and her effect upon them as fellow artist, sensitive critic, patron and collaborator. The air date coincides with the opening on December 18 of the Museum of Modern Art exhibition "Four Americans in Paris: The Collections of Gertrude Stein and Her Family." The documentary paints a portrait of Miss Stein through interviews in Paris and New York with friends and contemporaries -- sculptor Jacques Lipchitz, composer Virgil Thomson, writer Janet Flanner, couturier Pierre Balmain, pioneer cubist art dealer Daniel-Henri Kahnweiler, publisher Bennett Cerf, composer Al Carmines, writer Joseph Barry, poet Georges Hugnet; and through visits to her summer home in Bilignin, France, where Virgil Thomson, Janet Flanner and Maurice Grosser recall moments with Miss Stein, and to her Paris home at 27 rue de Fleurus where her former concierge provides a guided tour of the house. Excerpts from Stein's opera "Four Saints in the Three Acts" (composed by Virgil Thomson) and from "In Circles" (jazz-rock score by Al Carmines), recorded Gertrude Stein interviews, and rare films and photographs complete the portrait. Paintings from recent Matisse exhibit at the Grand Palais in Paris, the most comprehensive collection of works by the late painter who was aided in his early career by Miss Stein, were filmed in color for the program which also includes a great number of paintings from the original Stein collection of Picasso's, Matisse's and Cezanne's. Suggested Newspaper Listing: "Fanfare: Gertrude Stein in Paris" (tentative title) -- Gertrude Stein, American author and art patron whose Paris home was a center for artists and writers during the early 20th century, is the subject of this film portrait by Emmy Award-winner Perry Miller Adato.
Fanfare. Gertrude Stein--When this you see, remember me.

Episode: Gertrude Stein: When This You See, Remember Me
Portrays events in the life of Gertrude Stein in Paris during the early 20th century, using the author's words and the words of her friends.
Gertrude Stein : when this you see, remember me.

Widely recognized as a pioneering work of the biographical documentary genre, the film was highly innovative at the time. To create a vivid, living portrait of Gertrude Stein, it combines vintage photographs, letters, works of art, songs, archival and newsreel footage and radio. In addition, live musical and dramatic performances are based on Steins writings; interviews with surviving witnesses who were part of Gertrude Steins legendary charmed circle contribute intimate recollections. Artists, writers and a wide variety of fascinating personalities beat a path to 27 rue de Fleurus, for Gertrude Steins salon was one of the most sought-after in Paris in the early decades of the Twentieth century. This biography views Stein within the time, the place and the milieu in which she thrived, aided and abetted by her life-long companion Alice B. Toklas. The script is derived mainly from Steins cleverly mis-titled self-portrait The Autobiography of Alice B. Toklas, supplemented by candid on-camera conversations with friends and colleagues, among them Virgil Thompson, Janet Flanner, Jacques Lipschitz, Pierre Balmain, Daniel-Henri Kahnweiler, Bennett Cerf, Mrs. Jenny Bradley and Georges Hugnet. Through images and voice-over quotes by actors, other key players in her life are summoned: William James, Ambroise Vollard, Pablo Picasso, Henri Matisse, Juan Gris, Thornton Wilder, Ernest Hemingway, Ezra Pound, James Joyce, T.S. Eliot, and others. Gertrude Stein: When This You See, Remember Me includes numerous examples of Steins poetry and literature such as: Three Lives, Tender Buttons, The Making of Americans, her opera Four Saints in Three Acts and Wars I have Seen which are presented visually or dramatized by leading actors. Until recently, Gertrude Steins role as an early champion of Cubism and a trailblazing patron of Picasso and Modernism was far better known than her obscure writings. Her art collection at 27 rue de Fleurus has been called the first museum of modern art. With the publication of The Autobiography of Alice B Toklas in 1934, Steins writing finally reached a broad audience. Many lesser-known works have now achieved wide publication and her powerful literary influence is acknowledged and continues to grow. As always, Gertrude has the last word...My writing is as clear as mud but mud stays and clear streams flow on.
Gertrude Stein: When This You See, Remember Me

From NET microfiche: This program features a series of interviews with the Rev. Daniel J. Berrigan, the fugitive priest convicted of destroying draft records to protest the war in Vietnam. One of the interviews was conducted while he was a fugitive from justice and shortly before he was captured by the FBI agents on August 11. Father Berrigan, a 49-year old Jesuit and poet, was one of the so-called "Catonsville Nine" who destroyed draft files on May 17, 1968, at the Selective Service office in Catonsville, MD, by burning them with homemade napalm. Also among the nine persons arrested and convicted was Berrigan's brother, the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan, who is now serving a six-year sentence. The two refused to surrender last April 9 to serve their sentences after their appeals had been rejected by the Supreme Court. Father Philip Berrigan was arrested by the FBI on April 21 in a church in New York City. In the interviews, Father Berrigan expresses the view that peaceful protests have not been effective in ending the war and that persons with respected positions in society must risk their lives and their careers in performing acts that bring them into conflict with the law. Father Berrigan says that a person who commits civil disobedience to protest injustice is not morally obligated to submit to penal authorities. Berrigan is also seen delivering a sermon during a surprise appearance at the First United Methodist Church, Germantown, Penn., shortly before he was captured. Also interviewed are Berrigan's mother, his brother Jerry, and friends who were influenced by him. The latter include Tony Mullaney and Bob Cunnane, priests who were members of the "Milwaukee Fourteen," another group which burned draft files; and Howard Zinn, a history professor at Boston University who accompanied Berrigan to Hanoi in 1968 to bring back three American prisoners of war. NET Journal #285 -- "Father Berrigan" is a production of National Educational Television. Producer: Lee Lockwood.
National Educational Television ; producer, Lee Lockwood.

From NET microfiche (F): ARCHIVIST NOTE: This program actually originally aired on December 19, 1965 under the USA: DANCE series. (See MAVIS 1162726.) Program Description: "Four Pioneers," a film essay on the origins of modern dance, will recreate some of the excitement of that revolution. The film, originally broadcast over the national public television in February 1971, will follow "Hard Travelin'," on NET Playhouse on the '30s, over the Public Broadcasting Service. In the 1930s, in a converted carriage barn at Vermont's Bennington College, four gifted dancers with a hunger to break out of conventional molds began to experiment with an individualistic, distinctively American mode of dance. They were Martha Graham, Doris Humphrey, Charles Weidman and Hanya Holm. They discarded ballet shoes, swept aside foreign dance forms and the rigid dogmas of ballet, libeated male dancers from the status of "leading men who lifted." Their efforts resulted in an explosion of traditional concepts of dance, and the creation of a new mode of self-expression. Films of their early experiments, their comments and views of a new generation of Bennington dancers, filmed 30 years later in the same setting, compose "Four Pioneers," which was produced by NET.
NET playhouse on the '30s. Four pioneers.

From NET microfiche (U): USA: Dance launches National Educational Television's examination of the visual and musical arts in its new year-long "USA" series. Program 2: Four Pioneers Martha Graham, Doris Humphrey, Charles Weidman and Hanya Holm - leading personalities in dance in America, who have been influential and inspirational in dance throughout the world are filmed and photographed in "Four Pioneers." This program looks back to the decade of the Thirties when an artistic revolution took place in the Vermont hills. A new theater form focusing on modern dance gained a form and identity of its own at Bennington College. The program presents the locale and the four major choreographers of this period. It also features a full production of Doris Humphrey's "Passacaglia" by the American Dance Theatre at Lincoln Center in 1965. "Four Pioneers" is the second program in NET'S "USA: Dance," an examination and evaluation of that medium in the United States. Jac Venza, who produced the critically acclaimed "Carmina Burana" and "Lincoln Center: Stage Five - Three Premieres" for NET is the producer of "USA: Dance" Narrator: Alvin Epstein.

Dancers from two other Broadway hits - Buzz Miller currently in "Funny Girl," Michael Harty from "Half a Sixpence," and three dancers from the acclaimed Martha Graham troupe, Mary Hinkson, Dudley Williams, and William Louther - perform this and two other specially commissioned dances by leading American choreographers Grover Dale and John Butler. From NET microfiche: Program Description: "Once upon a time in France... men bore arms, and women made themselves beautiful," begins David Schoenbrun, distinguished journalist and reporter for NET'S FRANCE IS DEAD: LONG LIVE FRANCE. Mr. Schoenbrun - and a wide spectrum of Frenchmen interviewed on the program - describe the old France as a land of "work, family, nation, and history." There a man was his father's son. And its hero was the great father, Charles de Gaulle. But today, "that France is dead." Though de Gaulle rules, preserving a symbol of the old France, his country is "undergoing a profound mutation," and whatever offspring, it will "not be de Gaulle's France - not eternal France." Mr. Schoenbrun is author of "As France Goes" and was French correspondent for CBS from 1946 to 1962. Last summer, he and NET producer-director Paul Kaufman assessed the emerging France and the particular quality of "Frenchness" during filming in three basic locales - Sen-lis, a town more than 2,000 years old; Paris; and Sarcelles, a new, planned suburb about 15 miles from Paris. Their visits ranged from the Ecole Nationale d'Administration, a school for the civil service elite, to the Fete Humanite, a Communist workers' fair where Coca-Cola and dogma, frigidaires and freedom for Vietnam were served up equally. The people interviewed on the program (many of whom speak French, with a voiceover translation) are workers and former heroes, actors and students, middle-class commuters and Communists, young men and their fathers. Essentially, however, the contrast is between youth and age, with you representing not a fad but an emerging France. In terms of numbers, France has become a country of the very old and the very young (one-third of all Frenchmen are under 20). And, just as World War II decimated an entire generation, so it has created a chasm between the old and the new France. -- Gazeau, an 87-year-old notary, recipient of the Legion of Honor at Verdun in World War I, boasts of strict discipline and the lessons of obedience. -- Lapie is a factory foreman whom de Gaulle's values are "familiar and comforting" and who is a devotee of work. -- Lapie's long haired son, Jean Pierre, is more representative, however. Though he works with is father, he wants money and is therefore "counting on luck," since "being deserving is value that is going out of style." For Jean Pierre, says Schoenbrun, the new values are "money, leisure and pals." -- Jean Duquesne is a "man of transition." He is middle-aged and middle-class. He was born in Dunkirk, met his wife there, and knew everyone. Now a commuter living in Sarcelles, "I was not the son of my father, I was only myself . Here, a street is a street, a building a building, a man a man." The new France is seen through many of its institutions as well. The workers, for instance, have substituted the union for the political party. Even the Communists interviewed at the Fete Humanite express a sense of bourgeois comfort, and their political rally is a form of "fun fair." Many former churches have been converted - into movies, markets, garages. And the young students of administration are intent on giving a "new content to happiness." Meanwhile, France remains a country in conflict - not on the battlefield, at last, but in a struggle for values. Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET JOURNAL -- FRANCE IS DEAD: LONG LIVE FRANCE: Frenchmen talk about their country, their goals, de Gaulle, and the war in Vietnam. Reporter David Schoenbrun visits a Communist fair, a commuter city, and an ancient city for views of the new France.

From NET microfiche: Program Description #1: Girls are better behaved than boys but they're not likely to be as good at mathematics. Girls are more creative than boys but they're also more prone to tummy aches, insomnia, and poor appetite. More girls suck their thumbs and bite their nails and in general they show more fidgety nervous behavior. Such broad statements, which might infuriate those who question basic differences in the psychological makeup of the sexes, are among the findings of a British study of the children of one generation that may prove or disprove some of the basic theories of Sigmund Freud. The mechanics of this ambitious national experiment are show on "NET Journal - Freud: Man and His Mind." Utilizing not only computes but the broad application of the National Health Plan, British psychologists are working with various samples - one ten times the size of the average public opinion poll sample. The program shows the psychological tests, games, and dramas in which the children are observed. Their anxieties, dreams and fantasies during early childhood are explored with particular attention to Freud's assertion that the child is psychologically the "father of the man." In addition to studying what are generally regarded as neuroses, the psychologists get intensive information on such common aberrations as left-handedness and bed-wetting. The doctors involved in the study believe they are developing clues to things which may not make the most satisfactory baby but will insure the child of a happier adult life. An American child development psychologist, Dr. Earl Shaeffer of the National Institute of Mental Health, is interviewed by NET correspondent David Prowitt on the applicability of the British experiment to the US youth. Among Dr. Shaeffer's theories: women are as intelligent as men but social factors cause them to lose interest in intellectual attainment at a certain age in order to pursue wholly social goals. "Freud: Man and His Mind" is a joint NET-BBC production, with Michael Wiegal producing for BBC and Jack O'Grady producing for NET. Program Description #2: Freudians and non-Freudians alike agree on the vital role of infancy as a platform for later personality development. In the past researchers have relied on studying adult personalities or treating adult disturbances by probing the patient's childhood through such techniques as psycho analysis - Freud's method of having a patient relive his childhood and face the worst in himself over and over again. But this type of analysis has not curbed adult mental illness, and so, in answer to the plea of prevention, Great Britain has undertaken as part of is National Health Plan a unique project to establish the link between the experiences of childhood and later life by seeking out the correlations on a national scale. There have been several extensive studies attempting a universal analysis of England's eight million school children. One is currently documenting the moods and acts of a sample of 16,000 children born the first week of March 1958. Another documents the emotional experiences of a sample of children born in a square mile of Bloomsbury, England, 15 years ago. Still a third - the world's longest-lasting national survey - involves five thousand "war babies" born in the same week all over Britain. Tests, games, and dramas which reveal the child's innermost anxieties and fantasies are shown being used as part of the experiments. British psychologists discuss some of their preliminary findings and show some of the subjects involved in the surveys. In addition to the British material, prepared by the BBC, there are segments prepared by NET producer Jack O'Grady and correspondent David Prowitt. Prowitt talks to Dr. Earl Shaeffer, a child development psychologist with the US National Institute of Mental Health, who questions whether the British study can be fairly applied to American children, whether Freud's theories are likely to be proven by the study, and the reason behind Freud's belief in the basic psychological differences between the sexes. Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET Journal - Freud: Man and His Mind - Studies of British school children linking the experiences of childhood to with later patterns, as a test of Freud's assertion that the child is psychologically the "father of the man." NET Journal - Freud: Man and His Mind is a joint NET-BBC production. BBC producer: Michael Wiegal NET producer: Jack O'Grady NET correspondent: David Prowitt

From NET microfiche: Program Description: The new radicalism, spawned at the lunch counters of Mississippi in the early 1960s, and nurtured in the demonstrations against the Vietnam War, has changed its direction in recent months - from protest to resistance. Once geared to the "moral conscience of America" through public sympathy and legislative fiat, it now accepts the more difficult and long-term process of gaining its own power. The three young radicals featured in this program typify three approaches to the changing character of dissent. Stokely Carmichael, former director of the Student Non-violent Coordinating Committee, is a leading proponent of Black Power, the separatist movement that is intended to bring ultimate self-determination to the Negro. Mario Savio, who was jailed in 1964 for his lead in the Free Speech Movement at the University of California at Berkeley, is one of the young radicals seeking power through political aims; accordingly, he is running for the California State Senate on the Peace and Freedom Party ticket. And David Harris, who was student president at Stanford University, he has devoted his full attention to the Resistance, an anti-draft organization that advises young men on their legal - and moral - rights with regard to Selective Service. The pageantry and frustration of earlier dissent is framed during scenes from the Spring Mobilization, which drew 500,000 marchers in cities from New York to San Francisco when it was held in April 1967; and from Stop the Draft Week, a series of confrontations with draft boards during which civil disobedience was met by force from police and federal troops, especially at the Pentagon demonstration, which climaxed this week last October. These demonstrations were a way of "acting out the impotence," according to Harris. The demonstrators, however, had "no conception of political power." Savio adds: "At best, it succeeds in frightening the population" and encouraging "further repressions" by the government. However, these demonstrations indicated the deep-seated opposition to government policy and encouraged the ensuing cry - "Resist!" Harris notes that the disruption of society by "the large numbers of the most privileged members - white college students - is a sign of that society breaking up." At the time of Stop the Draft week, Harris and others called for young men to turn in their draft cards - with surprisingly positive results. Concurrently, Carmichael was forging his cry "Hell no, we won't go" among young Negroes. He explains that his mission - and that of all American Negroes - is "a fight to civilize a barbarous country." But it cannot be done "by sharing in the collective guilt of burning babies." Carmichael, on the campus of black Tugaloo College draws an emotional response with another aspect of the new dialectic - "And we are beautiful." It is this type of message that has helped the Black Power movement to gain "community and cohesion," according to the University of Wisconsin history professor William Appleman Williams. Despite the cry of separatism, Negroes are engaging with whites in some dissenting action, the program notes. At present, the Peace and Freedom Party has candidates of both races. Savio notes "the issue is political power." Only through political action, he feels, can the "movement for white liberation" reach fruition. Meanwhile, Harris and others counsel young men to resist the draft. Jail may be the outcome, though there's no attempt at "proving moral superiority by going to jail." He considers it "healthier than sitting across borders watching the world going down the drain," especially since "the rest of the world is becoming more like America If you're going to fight dragons, you might as well fight them where they live." Several young men who disagree with Harris are interviewed in their Canadian retreats. They contend that "radical politics is play a silly game" and call Canada "a very nice jail." Visually, the program takes on a spectrum of the dissenters' activities - Harris is seen at a demonstration, handing out leaflets, and riding his motorcycle; Savio, at the beach and at home with his wife and child, and on a platform addressing a political gathering; Carmichael, in a bus, on the stage, and relaxing with friends. Among all three, the voice that emerges is one of growing opposition as a true radical movement attempts to cohere. The question which remains, according to Herbert Marcuse, professor of philosophy at the University of California at Berkeley, is "whether we're in a pre-revolutionary situation." NET Journal - "From Protest to Resistance" was produced for NET by Richard Moore and Saul Landau of its San Francisco affiliate KQED. Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET Journal - 'From Protest to Resistance": The changing character of radical dissent, as typified by Black Power advocate Stokely Carmichael, political activist Mario Savio, and draft resistance leader David Harris.
KQED ; producers, Richard Moore and Saul Landau.

From NET microfiche: In this interview with NET correspondent Paul Niven, George Wallace elaborates on the growth and structure of his movement. He indicates that it is "more than a Wallace movement" and that it will definitely survive the present elections. In fact, "our party movement is so strong it'll submerge a major party in the next two to four years," Wallace predicts. His party's convention will be held sometime next month, with critics from New York to St. Petersburg, FL, under consideration. It is likely, says Wallace that his vice-presidential nominee will not be a Southerner - but issues, rather than geography, will determine his choice. He praised former Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson, but refuses to designate him as the probable choice as running mate. He asserts that he will be the next President, and that he will win a majority of the electoral vote. In his behalf, he cites "every radio poll I've ever heard of" and the enthusiastic crowds he has drawn in such states as Pennsylvania, Massachusetts, and California. Wallace rejects the idea of "making a deal" for a government position in return for his support of another candidate if the election is forced into the House of Representatives. He calls such a prospect "degrading and undignified." He denies that he is a racist, and he explains that he is opposed to government intervention since "they've used race as a lever of compulsion." He admits that he would repeal the Voting Rights Bill. "I wouldn't let an illiterate vote in the South when he can't vote in New York." If elected President, he will "reappraise the oil-depletion allowance" and consider legislative action against "multi-billion-dollar tax-exempt foundations." He would scrap almost all poverty programs, revise the welfare system which now "pays able-bodied people not to work." He would institute re-training programs through the cities and states to help ghetto residents, and he would provide tax incentives for companies that build in rural areas rather than further clogging the cities. He scorns the stance of the two parties on such issues as law and order and de-centralization, since both parties have contributed to "the destruction of property rights and the public school system and the complete takeover of public institutions."
George Wallace on his politics and the Presidency.
APT (Alabama PTV), National Educational Television ; producer, Jim Karayn.
NET journal. George Wallace on his politics and the Presidency.
National Educational Television and Radio Center
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche: This program is a penetrating report on the "new nationalism" - a German movement with heavy overtones of the old Nazism. Filmed throughout Germany, from Hamburg to Nuremberg, the program features interviews with leading German writers and journalists - several of whom describe the threat of neo-Nazism. Producer-reporter Arthur Zegart also interviews Adolf von Thadden, vice-chairman of the neo-Nazi National Democratic Party (NPD) which gained considerable support in recent Bavarian elections. In addition, German Jews explain why they have chosen - for personal or religious reasons - to remain in the country. Interviewed in Landsberg, where Hitler wrote "Mein Kampf," von Thadden contends that the NPD is not a dangerously rightist movement. Rather, he characterizes it as a symptom of the country's "normalizing" trend, which calls for "a party of the right." He adds, "You must have good patriotism in your country and we think at the moment there's not enough." Noted writer Hans Helmut Kirst states: "The most remarkable thing about this new Nazi party - and I use the word Nazi advisedly - is that it attracts people who have no idea of what Nazism is, people who were not even born and had nothing to do with that period, yet who speak, think and act like real Nazi's." Kirst warns that this group is growing and "will continue to increase." Germans, on the whole, do not consider the Hitler period as unsuccessful, says Conrad Ahlers, deputy press chief for the German government. In fact, German democracy would face "tremendous difficulties and tremendous dangers" if the country were faced with an economic crisis comparable to that of the early 1930's. Ahlers notes also that a movement similar to the Hitler youth would attract young Germans since it appeals to the "young life" and "idealism." An "enormous number of former leading Nazis" presently hold official positions in the German government, according to Gert Paczensky, editor of Panorama magazine. Paczensky notes that this fact usually goes unmentioned, since the press commonly takes the government position. The fate of today's Jewish population (less than 30,000 out of an original 600,000) is considered in three episodes - one involving Professor Horowitz, a Jew who teaches biblical languages at the University of Bonn. Interviewed in a Bonn Synagogue, where services are often cancelled for want of the necessary ten worshiping males, Professor Horowitz tells how he returned to the country to teach the young people. In a second sequence, Arno Hamburger, a Nuremberg Jew, refutes the anti-Semitism of audience members during a discussion group in a Protestant church. The film ends at the school attended by Hamburger's son - an arena for the values of the new Germany. Also interviewed on the program are Count Klaus Dohnanyi, a businessman whose father was killed in an anti-Hitler plot; Count Schweinitz, head of the North American desk of the government's press and information bureau; German writer Christian Geissler; and young Germans in cafes and at a demonstration protesting proposed government restrictions. Suggested Newspaper Listing A report on neo-Nazism throughout Germany, featuring interviews with Adolf von Thadden, vice-chairman of the National Democratic Party; writers Hans Helmut Kirst and Christian Geissler; controversial journalist Conrad Ahlers; and some of Germany's remaining Jews. Narrator: Oscar Rose
NET ; associate producer, Peter McGhee ; director-writer, Arthur Zegart.
NET journal. Germany and its shadow.
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche: General Description of Series: This program consists of a 50-minute documentary and a brief discussion of its findings. Participants in the discussion will be Bill Cunningham of the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, who produced and narrated the film, and Colin McCullouch, Peking Correspondent of the Toronto Globe and Mail. The documentary was filmed in Canton Province, under guidelines set by the Peking government. The program notes China's regimented society - from the training of a commune militia to the recognized acupuncture treatment for hearing defects, to which has been added readings from the works of Mao Tse Tung. The camera ranges from peasant household to a self-criticism session for workers; it also takes in such events as a fair for Western buyers, with its display of such Chinese wares as textile products and computers. Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET Journal - "A Glimpse of China": A seeping view of Red China's regimented society, focusing on life in Canton Provence - from communes to computers, and from Chinese medicine to bridge-building.
Canadian Broadcasting Corporation ; NET presentation ; executive producer, Harry McCarthy ; producer, Bill Cunningham.
NET journal. [No. 262], A glimpse of China.
National Educational Television and Radio Center

The Green Table is a ballet by the German choreographer Kurt Jooss and his most popular work, depicting the futility of peace negotiations of the 1930s. It was the first work to be fully notated using kinetography Laban (Labanotation). It was first performed in 1932. Lasting about 30 minutes and subtitled "A dance of death in eight scenes," The Green Table is a commentary on the futility of war and the horrors it causes. It opens with a group of diplomats (the Gentlemen in Black) having a discussion around a rectangular table covered with a green cloth. They end up pulling guns from their pockets and shooting in the air, thus symbolizing the declaration of war. The next six scenes portray different aspects of wartime: the separation from loved ones in The Farewells, war itself in The Battle and The Partisan, loneliness and misery in The Refugees, the emotional void and the atmosphere of forced entertainment in The Brothel and, finally, the psychologically beaten and wounded survivors in The Aftermath. The ballet then ends as it began, with the "Gentlemen in Black" around the green table. Throughout these episodes the figure of Death is triumphant, portrayed as a skeleton moving in a forceful and robot-like way, relentlessly claiming its victims. The dance ends with a repeat of the opening scene, a device the choreographer uses to show his mistrust in the talks of the diplomats; completely indifferent to the ravages of war, they continue their hypocritical negotiations. (Summary from Wikipedia Web site, viewed March 16, 2015)
The green table : A dance of death in eight scenes.
BBC-TV; a dance drama [choreographed] by Kurt Jooss; music by F. A. Cohen; performed by the Folkwang Ballet; produced and directed by Peter Wright.
A dance of death in eight scenes.
NET playhouse. The green table : A dance of death in eight scenes.

From NET microfiche (H, N): Program Description: The NET Playhouse series about the 1930s continues with Ralph Meeker starring in Millard Lampell's "Hard Travelin." The play is an acid indictment against those elements of society that conspired to further oppress the victims of the Depression - racism, con men, bargain-basement justice, "Jackleg" preachers, and dishonest politicians. And, says the author is commenting on his play, "If you should come up with the notion that those things still exist in America, why, that is your privilege." "Hard Travelin'" is constructed as a series of vignettes linked chiefly by the central theme of the Depression. However, there is a loose thread of dramatic continuity embodied in the travels of a young man who has become disillusioned with society. The man, played by Drew Snyder, bitterly rejects the nave visions of his poverty-ridden immigrant father. He leaves his girl, sets out across country hopping freight trains, links up temporarily with a black chain-gang fugitive who teaches him how to act like a "proper" white man, gets arrested for vagrancy with some hobos, and finally sells out his conscience and winds up in politics. Meeker appears throughout the production as a ruthless con man ready to make his fortune on the pathetic aspirations of others. Suggested Newspaper Listing: "Hard Travelin'" - Ralph Meeker stars in Willard Lampell's acid-toned play about the exploiters and the exploited during the Depression. With Joseph Bova, Susan Bracken and JA Preston. NET Playhouse #225 - "Hard Travelin" is a presentation of NET Division, Educational Broadcasting Corporation, produced by the New York Television Theater at Channel 13, New York. Producer and director: Glenn Jordan. Associate producer: Virginia Gray. NET Playhouse executive producer: Jac Venza.

New York Television Theater at Channel 13, New York ; presentation of NET Division, Educational Broadcasting Corporation ; producer-director, Glenn Jordan ; associate producer, Virginia Gray ; writer, Millard Lampell ; NET playhouse executive director, Jac Venza.
New York television theater. Hard travelin'.
