From NET microfiche: Program Description: The documentary focuses on the controversial Head Start program in Mississippi, which is under the auspices of the Child Development Group of Mississippi. There are scenes showing the operation of Project Head Start schools (which are open to pre-kindergarten youth), interviews with the Negroes who run them, and a detailed story - through interviews and meetings - of the controversy. (At present, CDGM is running the program, though funds have been suspended by Sargent Shriver, head of the Office of Economic Opportunity. OEO has claimed malpractice - nepotism, payroll-padding, and bad accounting. Other informed sources contend that the "white power structure" has a political motive here.) Operation Headstart in Mississippi employs not the usual poverty program techniques, but rather an idealization of the war on poverty, in that it employs the people themselves as teachers and leaders. The beneficiaries, therefore, are not only the pre-school children who attend headstart schools, but also their parents who gain a sense of identity. However, it is this very program that has become the subject of controversy, with the Office of Economic Opportunity stopping funds to the Child Development group of Mississippi as a result of "misuse of funds and some sloppiness in accounting." (The speaker is Jules Sugarman of the OEO.) As a result, an alternate plan has placed whites in charge, added a few Negroes to the board (disdainfully called "Toms" by the Mississippi Negroes who formerly led CDGM), cut funds in half, and directed the group to involve white children in Operation Headstart. Meanwhile, Dr. Kenneth Clark, educator and psychologist, has disputed the OEO charges, pointing out that "white children were not excluded," but remained away by choice - as they have in all parts of the country, through the poverty program is not exclusively a Negro program. "One can almost gauge the success of a program by the extent of antagonism toward it," says Dr. Clark. He credits the CDGM staff with its singular success in "realistically, engagingly involving the people of Mississippi." The controversy is the most dramatic element in the film. Much of the film, however, is devoted to the actual workings of Operation Headstart in the Mississippi Delta town of Durant. It begins with the parents at work on construction of the school. After the forming of the state-wide CDGM for parents in 80 communities, teachers must be found. In the Durant Center, none of the full-time teachers is experience - the chairman, Hattie Saffold, formerly picked cotton and did housework. But her instinct helps her with the children. For her and for the children, "the excitement of discovery was contagious." Children, discovering building blocks, "raced through years of development . Before Headstart, playing house meant fooling with tin cans and corn cobs." The involvement soon spread to the home. "Community begins with a sense of identity, and then a respect for family, and a pride in the richness of the race," the program states. In the white community, another reaction set in. Once school was burned to the ground. Soon, "the burnings and shootings and harassment got worse," for "the experience (of CDGM) attacked the assumption of racists, who could not believe that Negroes were qualified citizens, and it undermined the interests of many gradualists, who still treated Negroes like children." The remainder of the film is taken up by the controversy, which is not sparking arguments of "deal-making" by the liberal press. The film is therefore effective in two areas: as a contemporary issue, and as an evocation of the program - the excitement of a child's discovery of modeling clay, the community of singing, the respect for an interested adult. NET JOURNAL - HEAD START IN MISSISSIPPI is a National Educational Television presentation. Producer is Adam Giffard of Gifford Associates. Editor is Ellen Giffard. Harry McCarthy of NET is executive producer. UPDATE On December 17, the Office of Economic Opportunity rescinded its attack on Child Development Group of Mississippi (CDGM) and authorized an $8 million appropriation for the group's statewide Head Start program. This appropriation - less than one-half of the amount requested by CDGM - will limit Head Start to fewer counties than in 1965-1966. However, it does not clear the air of controversy. OEO previously demanded the removal of Rev. James McCree, chairman of CDGM's board of directors. Now it has decided to leave Mr. McCree's fate to an election by the board. Similarly, John H. Mudd, executive director, will be "reevaluated" at a later date. Despite the apparent whitewashing, many unanswered questions remain: Was the investigation justified? If so, what has CDGM done in recent weeks that would favorably alter its status? And, what truth is there to "deal making" claims by the liberal press? We recommend that you change paragraph two of your suggested release to read: The "NET Journal" program relates the circumstances affecting the Child Development Group of Mississippi . The remainder of the sentence can read as before. At the end of the paragraph two, the following statement should appear: Then, on December 17, OEO made a new grant of $8 million available to the Child Development Group. This figure contrasts with the $20 million needed for Head Start and will therefore limit its sphere of operation to certain counties of Mississippi. NET's Head Start in Mississippi" reviews the controversy - which is unresolved as yet.
National Educational Television presentation ; executive producer, Harry McCarthy ; producer, Adam Giffard.

From NET microfiche, file H: Program Description: Faye Dunaway, Robert Foxworth and George Rose star in William Alfred's prize-winning off-Broadway drama "Hogan's Goat" - the story of a man's destructive drive for political power among the Irish in turn-of-the-century Brooklyn. In the play, produced by NET Playhouse, Miss Dunaway recreates the role she originated when "Hogan's Goat" premiered to enthusiastic reviews at New York's American Place Theatre in November 1965. Winner of a Vernon Rice Award, the production was termed "one of the richest and finest American dramas to reach a New York stage in years" by Norman Nadel in the World Telegram and Sun. Howard Taubman of the New York Times called it a play of "scope and quality scrupulous in its regard for detail of its period and people." The story, written in verse, centers on Irish immigrant Matthew Stanton, played by Foxworth, star of the TV series "Men at Law." Stanton's long struggle for power has culminated in a chance to unseat the corrupt mayor of Brooklyn (at a time when Brooklyn was a city separate from New York City). But his pride and arrogant manipulation of those who love him, especially his wife, Kathleen, bring tragedy in place of victory. Besides his current TV role, Foxworth has performed at the American Shakespeare Festival (at Stratford, Conn.) in "Hamlet" and "Much Ado about Nothing," and appeared on Broadway in the Stratford Company's production of "Henry V." Miss Dunaway, of course, is best known for her role opposite Warren Beatty in the film "Bonnie and Clyde," which earned her an Academy Award nomination. She is currently seen as co-star of the motion pictures "Little Big Man" and "Doc." George Rose, a native of England, has had a distinguished London and Broadway stage career spanning more than two decades. His Broadway credits include major roles in "A Mann for All Seasons" (1962), "Slow Dance on the Killing Ground" (1964), "Walking Happy" (1966) and "Loot" (1968). He appeared in the motion picture "Hawaii," and has performed in nearly all the major TV drama shows. The author of "Hogan's Goat" is a professor of English at Harvard University. He has also written another play in verse, "Agamemnon." "Hogan's Goat" is being produced and directed for television by two-time (New York) Emmy-winner Glenn Jordan, whose most recent production was Clifford Odets' "Paradise Lost," telecast last winter as part of the "NET Playhouse on the Thirties" series. Suggested Newspaper Listing: "Hogan's Goat" - Faye Dunaway recreates her off-Broadway role in this acclaimed story of an Irish immigrant whose obsessive political ambition destroys the two women who love him. Also starring Robert Foxworth and George Rose.
Special of the week #2--NET playhouse #260--Hogan's goat.
Special of the week. [No. 2], Hogan's goat.
a production of NET ; directed and produced by Glenn Jordan.

From NET microfiche: Program Description: This film, shot entirely at Metropolitan Hospital in New York City, offers a cumulative impression of an institution and its problems, which often reflect the problems of a total community. There are no interviews and no narration; rather, the camera records - with unflinching detail - the daily life in a municipal hospital. " A boy who has taken mescaline cries that he is going to die, while doctors seek to purge him of the drug and to reassure him about his health; " A male homosexual who needs welfare is treated compassionately by a psychiatrist, who then meets with frustration as he attempts to deal with a welfare agency; " A woman dying of a heart attack is kept alive for a few weeks - or days - by an emergency treatment; " A small boy who has fallen from a third-story window must be sent home to his negligent family, though a nurse seeks a way of keeping him in the hospital until adequate care can be provided. These are the daily experiences of a hospital staff - the triumphs of professional knowledge and compassion, too often negated by the larger problems of a society. Sometimes these experiences become almost unbearably stark - as when a man with a knife wound must be treated, while his wife (herself covered with his blood) holds his hand. What emerges, however, is a totality of life within the city hospital, coping with lives in crisis though it is the "dumping ground" for patients without money or influence. Frederick Wiseman, who produced, directed, and edited the film, was an Emmy winner in 1969 for "Law and Order<' a documentary on the police in Kansas City which he filmed for PBL. His other credits include "The Titicut Follies," a film about a stage institution for the criminally insane at Bridgewater, Mass.; and "High School," about a middle class school in Philadelphia. NET Journal - "Hospital" was produced for NET by Frederick Wiseman, who also directed and edited the film. Cameraman: William Brayne.
Produced [and directed] for NET by Frederick Wiseman.
National Educational Television and Radio Center
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche: Program Description: "Huelga" (a Spanish word meaning "strike") documents the struggle for recognition - and survival - among Mexican and other migrant workers in Delano, Cal., in the San Joaquin Valley. The strike, which began in September 1965 against the area's 35 grape growers, has become "the longest, most important strike in agricultural history," with a few of the growers finally offering some compromises this year. The strike, however, goes on; its original demands basically unchanged - a minimum wage, unemployed compensation, the right of collective bargaining. The film, which has already won awards at three major festivals, has been described by Variety as "a very moving thing." Filmed in color, it follows the strike leaders from the genesis of the strike, depicting their efforts to enlist the workers' support, ranging their makeshift dwellings, and recording the arguments of both workers and farmers. Led by Caesar Chavez and Luis Valdez, the strikers continue their efforts to shut down the farms, exhorting workers through bullhorns and singing "We Shall Overcome." While the grape picking goes on. Then, on Christmas Eve, the strikers gain the support of students, unionists, and other sympathizers with their movement at a special rally during which "Silent Night" and "Solidarity Forever" are both songs of inspiration. One of the program's most poignant scenes involves a 38-year-old women who has just been fired after 24 years in the fields because she wouldn't sign an anti-union petition. Then, in March of 1966, the movement gains impetus with a march to the state capitol at Sacramento. As they walk along the highway with flags, crosses, and songs, the strikers are unexpectedly joined by bands of other farm workers. "Walk along the 99 - with a flag! They'd have thought you were unbalanced a year ago," says Valdez, realizing: "We have a right to be here!" Meanwhile, a group of Delano citizens called Citizens for Facts is opposing the strikers. Their arguments are familiar. They contend that Chavez is a "communist puppet" who has been "trained back East someplace." One woman, seeing "cars from Illinois," notes that she "wrote down the license numbers." Others are more sympathetic, however. A community center is formed to feed and otherwise aid the strikers. Their spirit is buoyed up by such diversions as the Teatro Campesino, which performs skits under Valdez' direction. These skits satirize the landowner and his instrument the hated "scab." But there is more active opposition to the scabs. At one point, the strikers try to stop a bus loaded with these imported workers. And, in the film's concluding scene, the strikers score a major victory as they persuade foreman and workers to leave their work and join the movement, after pleading "Are you going to sell out your race, the Mexican people?" "NET Journal - Huelga!" - is a presentation of National Educational Television, produced and written by Mark J. Harris of King Screen Productions. Director: Skeets McGrew. Narrator: Paul Herlinger. Edited by Dick Gilbert and Skeets McGrew.
King Screen Productions ; National Educational Television presentation ; producer-writer, Mark J. Harris ; director, Skeets McGrew.

From NET microfiche: Program Description: Internationally renowned Swedish actor Max Von Sydow, star of many Ingmar Bergman classics including "The Seventh Seal," "Shame," and "The Passion of Anna," probes the dark, brooding world of the playwright August Strindberg in this production entitled "In Search of Strindberg," filmed in Sweden and in Paris. Producer Jack Kuney has adapted his teleplay from the dramatic and autobiographical writings of Strindberg incorporating scenes from three of the playwright's important works - "The Father," "Miss Julie," and "The Bond." Strindberg (1849-1912) is considered the greatest Swedish playwright and was an important influence on drama in Europe and the United States. He was also a novelist, short story-writer, and poet. His life was profoundly unhappy; born prematurely, out of wedlock, the insecurities of his childhood followed him throughout his existence. Often the circumstances of his adult life became intertwined with his writings. "I don't know if 'The Father' is a fiction or if my life is a fiction," he wrote. The biography unfolds with Von Sydow as the voice of Strindberg. Under the soundtrack the actor adds visual detail to the narrative. Scenes from the plays - enacted in English by Swedish performers - are woven into the biography where Strindberg's fiction parallels his life. The tone of that life is established in childhood: "It's whispered in the family that I'm a changeling. A child substituted by the elves for the baby that was born. Are these elves the souls of the unhappy who still await redemption? If so, I am a child of an evil spirit." We look into the writer's early years of frustration and pessimism as a librarian at Stockholm's Royal Library, with his first play, "Master Olaf" - later to be recognized as a near masterpiece - already rejected. He marries the Finno-Swedish actress Siri Von Essen but, after a brief blissful episode, their relationship deteriorates, ending in divorce. His grief is intensified when he loses custody of the children. Increasingly the theme of his writings become "Love between a man and a woman is war." Strindberg goes to live alone at the cottage of a friend who had drowned himself in a nearby pond. He contemplates the same fate, but resists, "because the unconscious will continually entice men to live through the illusion of the hope toward a better life." After a time, his interest in women is revived and he suffers two more relationships that fail to last. He writes " As a poet I blend fiction with reality, and all my hatred of women is theoretical for I couldn't live without the company of women." He goes to Paris, where we follow his metaphysical thoughts as he wanders through streets and parks acknowledging "omens" and finally "waiting for the winds to blow me whither they will." Near the end of his life he says: "What I found bitterer than death was having to take the great jobs seriously and treat as holy what was coarse I want to lie with the poor not the rich. On a simple wooden cross should say: 'O Crux Avise Unica - Welcome Cross, My Only Hope.'" He died of cancer in Stockholm at the age of 63.
WNET/13 in cooperation with Sveriges Radio, Stockholm ; producer-director-writer-adapter, Jack Coney ; NET executive producer, Jac Venza.
Playhouse New York biography. [1973-08-30]. In search of Strindberg.
Playhouse New York biography. [No. 213], In search of Strindberg.
NET playhouse biography. [1972-03-23]. A search for Strindberg.
NET playhouse biography. [No. 10], A search for Strindberg.

From WorldCat: Shows that the traditional life of the Polynesians of American Samoa is being altered and challenged by its governing authority, the United States, and that a potential conflict exists between the western goals of education which stress independent thinking and the cultural values of Samoa which emphasize obedience to the family and respect for authority. From NET microfiche: Suggested Newspaper Listing: American Samoa: Paradise Lost? - A report on the Westernization of a tropical paradise, where children now learn English through educational television and tourists drink Coca Cola on the beaches of Pago Pago. Description: American Samoa, a tropical paradise in the South Pacific, is now faced with a compromise to its hereditary structure and its unhurried life. The challenge is that of progress, American-style, complete with camera-toting tourists, educational television in every classroom, and an expanding economy that may be in conflict with Samoan values of sharing and of deference to the family and the tribal core. These are the findings of NET's Intertel production, "American Samoa: Paradise Lost?" The program spans classrooms and canneries, tribal banquets and remote beaches, in its portrayal of a rapidly changing culture. The conflict between traditional and emerging Samoa is seen as a loan collector makes his rounds among people whose native huts were destroyed during storms, and have been replaced by all-weather homes, with the American bank financing the project. The natives, who have always taken from friends, cannot comprehend the fact that they must repay the bank. The school, were children are learning English and geography from a television monitor, presents another potential conflict. "Taught to respect authority very early, they do as they are told, pay attention to television and the teacher, and are learning English far more rapidly than ever before." However, the program adds, "this very attitude of acceptance may stand in the way of independent thinking. This Western goal of education is alien to a culture that expects children to be obedient, to serve, not to question, one's elders." Even among Samoan chiefs, an unquestioning stance is noted. At a meeting on family planning, they are polite listeners, though they have no intention of carrying out the Americans' program. In most areas, Samoans are accepting the American influence, recognizing a chance for new comfort and prosperity. This fact applies especially to Samoan's leading industry - tourism. One tour director, interviewed on a television program for students, strikes the dominant note - "Keep your big wide smiles up," he advises the class, for then tourists will return to the island. But one critic, High Chief Fuimaono, sees Samoa being changed to something less natural than it was before. He is critical of the message implicit to children in the cowboy movies on television. Nor does he feel that they should be taught to eat with spoons and forks in school when they will revert to their parents' way of using their hands at home. The high chief laments, "I would like us to be independent of the United States." But the program concludes, "for the present, the Samoan chooses easily - something old, something new - balancing with typical Polynesian poise between two worlds." "American Samoa: Paradise Lost?" was produced for Intertel by NET. Produced, directed and written by Dan Klugherz Editor: Dena Burger Cameramen: Bill Constable and David Meyers Narrator: Don Murrow
produced for Intertel ; by NET ; producer-director-writer, Dan Klugherz.
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From the Detroit Free Press July 27, 1969. Page 68: "The life and work of the great artist-naturalist and a glimpse of what is left of Audubon's America. Filmed throughout the North American continent; written and narrated by Lister Sinclair, with Albert Millaire as the voice of Audubon." (taken from newspaper.com search RPAR 3/8/2017). From NET microfiche: Suggested Newspaper Listing: "Audubon": The ornithological findings of America's great naturalist-artist John J Audubon, originally a "draft-dodger" from Napoleon's army, are presented with original drawings from is consummate work, "The Birds of America." Program Description: A report on the work of America's great naturalist and artist, John J. Audubon (1785-1851). The film traces Audubon's journeys in quest of unusual birds - from the swampland of Florida to the Bay of Fundy in Canada, and from the capitals of Europe to the remote Dry Tortugas island s in Mexico. "The great American naturalist was French and illegitimate," the program notes, as it recalls Audubon's youth in France, where he turned to birds rather than his father's commercial interests, and left the country when he was due to join Napoleon's army. From Mill Grove, PA, the documentary follows him on his bird-tracking course, which gained precedence even over his family life. He travelled through the "romantic wilderness of the deep south," settling in Louisiana, where he identified such exotic swamp birds as thee ivory-billed woodpecker. In 1826, Audubon visited England and Scotland, seeking backers for his printing ventures which would include "The Birds of America" and "Viviparous Quadrupeds of North America." The trip led to a 10-year period in which Audubon published in Europe and travelled to America in quest of additional specimens. The program also recalls Audubon's plea for conservation - a plea that has gone woefully unheeded. Credits: "Audubon" is an NET presentation, produced for Intertel by Canadian Broadcasting Corporation. Written and narrated: Lister Sinclair Editor: MC Manne Producer-Director: James Murray Executive producer: John Livingston
Canadian Broadcasting Corporation for Intertel ; producer-director, James Murray ; writer, Lister Sinclair.
National Educational Television and Radio Center
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche: Program Description: The British Foreign Office, like the US Department of State, is responsible for handling that country's foreign affairs. Literally going "Inside the Foreign Office," into the cumbersome and inconvenient building in which it is housed, the program examines the Foreign Office's function and operation, also showing it at work abroad, via the British Embassy. The program describes (complete with salaries) the tight hierarchy of civil servants staffing the Foreign Office, headed by Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, the Rt. Hon. George Brown, MP. Officials at various levels in the hierarchy discuss their places in the operation of the Foreign Office, where as one official puts it, "decisions are taken as low in the ladder as possible." The Foreign Office "divides" the world into "departments." The program examines closely one such department, that for South East Asian affairs. It also documents the daily conference of top officials; a press briefing session; the working of the tele-printer room, where reports from all over the world are constantly coming in; the internal message-tube system; and the preparation of diplomatic bags. Moving on to the Foreign Office abroad, the program visits the British Embassy in Jakarta, Indonesia, where British officials are busy repairing the damage done to relations between the two countries during the Sukarno regime. The life of the diplomat abroad is examined, where boredom is often a problem facing members of his family. We also see a diplomatic party, where, in a relaxed atmosphere, business is combined with pleasure. Back in London, George Brown himself describes the physical inconvenience of the present Foreign Office structure which will, in ten years' time, be replaced with a new building. Mr. Brown is interviewed about his job and the role of the Foreign Office generally. The program describes his domestic life, include an interview with his wife, and shows him doing a television appearance during the Middle East crisis. Brown, unlike his US equivalent, also serves as a Member of Parliament, and to his already difficult job is added the additional strain of attending to the needs of his constituents. Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET JOURNAL - "Inside the Foreign Office": The public face of British diplomacy, examined through the function and operation of the Foreign Office in London and the Embassy abroad. Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs George Brown is interviewed. Narrated by John Cleese.
Rediffusion Television ; presentation of National Educational Television ; for Intertel ; producer-writer, Clive Irving ; director, James Butler.
NET journal. Inside the foreign office.
Intertel/NET journal. Inside the foreign office.
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche (R): NET's "Report from Cuba" is an hour long documentary filmed inside the revolutionary hub of the Western Hemisphere. Produced for National Educational Television by Richard Moore of KQED, San Francisco the program studies Castro's efforts to overcome his two personal dragons - underdevelopment and the spectra of "Yankee Imperialism." Castro's attempt to export his revolution is demonstrated at the July 26 Organization of Latin American Solidarity meeting, which celebrates the 14th anniversary of the attack on Fort Moncada, signaling the onset of the revolution. Castro, who took control of Cuba 5 years later, is seen addressing an enthusiastic throng of 100,000 at OLAS, which includes Negro militant Stokely Carmichael and a delegation from the National Liberation Front of Vietnam. At the OLAS meeting James Reston of the New York Times, also in Cuba at the time, notes that Castro has "hypnotized this island" and has "made a good beginning here in many, many ways there is an enthusiasm a revolution within a revolution with the women and particularly the young." Cuba's youth movement is shown in action at the Isle of Youth, a former prison now used for agricultural training, military drill, and other disciplines of the [] communist. "Report from Cuba" studies Cuba's agricultural reforms, continued rationing on the island, the decline of Havana as a Western capital, the role of the intellectual, the waves of emigration to the United States, the "rehabilitation" of political prisoners, an experimental community at San Andres, and the education of the Cuban child. The program also contains footage from a festival at Santiago de Cuba and a prestigious international art exhibit, the Salon de Mai. Among those appearing on the program are economist Dr. Carlos Rafael Rodriguez, novelist Edmundo Desnoe, journalist Lee Lockwood, young Cuban militants, self-exiled Cubans and ex-prisoners.
produced by KQED-TV, San Francisco, for National Educational Television ; producer, Richard Moore.
Intertel / NET journal. Report from Cuba.
National Educational Television and Radio Center
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche, file S: This Intertel documentary probes the life of the inmate, concentrating on three Canadian prisons, Kingston Penitentiary, Collin's Bay Penitentiary, and the Joyceville Institution (all in Ontario). Filmed by Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, the program contains interviews with inmates, guards, and rehabilitation officers. The prisoners, disguised with make-up and false moustaches and hairpieces, candidly discuss such subject as brutality, homosexuality among inmates and the psychology of the prisoner. Perhaps the key subject in the film is rehabilitation: does prison prepare the inmate for a return to society; does a jail sentence act as a deterrent to future crime; and what are the inmates feeling toward society and toward his own future? These questions are debated during a group discussion among prisoners. The subject of rehabilitation becomes especially pointed in view of federal debate over reform of the correctional system. Studies have indicated that jail sentences "actually increase the likelihood that most offenders will repeat unlawful or criminal acts."

Canadian Broadcasting Corporation ; for Intertel ; presentation of National Educational Television ; executive producer, Patrick Watson ; director, Ross McLean ; conceived by Ed McGibbon and Patrick Watson ; NET producer, Boris Holtzman.
National Educational Television and Radio Center
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche, file B: Description of series: The threat of rising population and the ultimate scarcity of food are posed in this Intertel documentary, offered in color by the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation. The program takes its title - and derives its message - from Pope Paul, UN message in which he stated that "artificial control of births. . . would be irrational, in order to diminish the number of guests at the banquet of life." From the Eskimos in Northern Canada to the aborigines in Australia, the program studies man's efforts to feed himself. Tracing "the chain of life," it investigates the various sources of food - from hunting and fishing to modern day agriculture - from cattle-breeding in Argentina to new rice-growing in Costa Rica. But ultimately, "growing more food is like treating a cancer with cosmetics." In a world growing by 66 million people each year, and with a death rate dropping perceptibly, even such cataclysms as flood, drought, and war would have a relatively minor effect. (During the Korean War, the population of that country actually increased.)The answer, this program finds, is family planning - the only system by which man can control his environment. Only then can man avoid the fate of the Mayans, a civilization which thrived in Central America only to die, presumably through food scarcity. Narrators: Harry Mannis and Alan Maitland N.E.T Journal - "The Banquet of Life": Man's quest for food in the face of rising population is the subject of this far-ranging Canadian documentary.
NET journal. The banquet of life.
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche: This program charts the storm clouds of change gathering over a South Sea paradise, the Fuji Islands. Here, thought the traditional virtues are still sun, sand and simplicity, foreign enterprise has suggested new values to the Fijian. However, he finds that the same foreigner who brings change becomes its beneficiary. "The Other Side of Paradise," which was made for Intertel by Australian Broadcasting Commission, concentrates on the effect of two national groups - Indians and Australians - on the economy, of this British Commonwealth nation. Sugar, the main crop, is controlled by foreign monopoly. Land, which is owned communally, has become a source of Indian prosperity through a system of land tenure. And even the tourism on which Fiji thrives has introduced a bastard culture as the natives sell "false gods" to the visitors. The conflict between the races becomes most dramatic within government. At a recent London conference, rules were devised which would create racial balance within the legislative council. The Indians lament that this balance encourages a coalition among Fijians and Europeans. But, in any case, the film notes, the Fijians are not the prevailing force in their own land - a situation that could become crucial when they gain their independence from Britain. The film also notes the crisis in education, where the country is attempting to catch up, thought "success in education might well cut them off from village life for good." "NET Journal - The Other Side of Paradise" is an Intertel production of the Australian Broadcasting Commission, presented by National Educational Television. Produced and directed by Ken Hannam.
Intertel. The other side of paradise.
Australian Broadcasting Commission for Intertel ; producer-director, Ken Hannam.
NET journal. The other side of paradise.

From NET microfiche, file V: This program depicts the efforts of four young Britons who are serving as volunteers in the African nation of Malawi. The four are members of Voluntary Service Overseas (VSO), a British organization that was started in 1958, thereby predating the American Peace Corps. With an average age of 19, the four "volunteers," two boys and two girls, have come to Malawi for a period of one or two years, during which they will help in some way to superimpose western civilization on a primitive land. Agricultural advisors or laborers, health officers or teachers, members of VSO will serve as latter-day Livingstones, in the land where his legend still thrives. The volunteers talk about their reasons for working in Malawi, their impressions of the land, and the ways in which the experience is changing them. ("If you don't have ideals at my age you'll never have them." "I hope they won't think of me as a martyr who's giving up a year of his life, because I'm going for myself just as much as for them." "They don't understand preventive medicine. They only bring the baby to you when he's ill. To their way of thinking, he doesn't need an injection when he's well.") Malawi, formerly called Nyasaland, has been independent since 1965. A nation of four million people, it has no significant natural resources and is largely dependant on Britain for foreign aid. Members of VSO, the film notes, are helping the country to recognize its own needs and to develop in such areas as education, agriculture, and industry.
Rediffusion Television Ltd ; presentation of NET ; for Intertel ; producer-director-writer, Fred Burnley.
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche: Program Description: "In the Company of Men" a report on psychiatrists' efforts to overcome the "'boy' syndrome" in a Southern auto factory, will be seen on NET Journal. The documentary, silver award winner at the 1969 International Job Film fair, relates the role of sensitivity training in narrowing the racial gap between white foremen and blacks designated as "hardcore unemployed." Initial sessions between Dr. Walter Klavun and the foremen prepare them for the eventual confrontation with a group of disenchanted blacks. Dr. Dennis Jackson, a black psychiatrist, introduces this group to the foreman and asks them to explain why they would "rather be unemployable." Scenes in which the men and their former employers have been involved are then recast in role-playing sessions, during which the men exchange positions. "Progress can come up laughing," remarks the narrator, as a white foreman carefully amends the word "fellas" to "men." Blacks and whites then begin a more informal and pressure-fee dialogue about their ambitions. NET Journal - "In the Company of Men" is an NET presentation, produced and directed by William Greaves. Editor: William Greaves. Narrator: Lou Adler.
NET journal #264--in the company of men.
NET journal--in the company of men.

Uses the techniques of sensitivity training and role playing to explore the breakdown and the reconstruction of communication between men who have been labeled unemployable and men who are directly responsible for hiring, training, and supervising new employees.

National Educational Television and Radio Center

In 1966, a year before he rose to overnight fame in The Graduate, Dustin Hoffman won an Obie Award for his performance in Journey of the Fifth Horse, a stage adaptation by Ronald Ribman of the story "Diary of a Superfluous Man" by Ivan Turgenev. The play was videotaped for public television that same year. Setting: Late 19th century, Petersburg, Russia. Dmitri Zoditch (Dustin Hoffman) is a lower-level manuscript reader for a large publishing company, and while he's in love with the daughter (Susan Anspach) of the firm's deceased founder, he lacks the courage to court her. The diary of a second-rate nobleman who has fallen on hard times, Nikolai Alexeyevich Chulkaturin (Michael Tolan), has been submitted for publication, and the manuscript is given to Zoditch for appraisal. Told he must read the work in one night, Zoditch soon finds himself drawn into the world of the bitter Chulkaturin, whose angst is a compliment for the insignificance of Zoditch's own life. Additional cast: Charlotte Rae. Four-act play. (Summary from The New York Times Web site, http://www.nytimes.com/movies/movie/260021/The-Journey-of-the-Fifth-Horse/overview, viewed July 1, 2015) From NET microfiche: Program Description: Ronald Ribman's "The Journey of the Fifth Horse," winner of an Obie Award as the best Off-Broadway play of the 1965-66 season, was first presented at the American Place Theater. The National Educational Television production is performed by the original cast, which includes Dustin Hoffman, winner of a best-actor Obie for his performance in it. The play is based partially on Ivan Turgenev's short novel, "The Diary of a Superfluous Man," from which the title is drawn. "The fifth horse" is the equivalent of the expression "fifth wheel.' Chulkaturin, a landowner who dies young, leaves behind him a diary that tells the story of his life, which, if it had never been lived, would have made no difference to anyone. The sick man instructs his old maidservant to burn the diary on his death. At this point Mr. Ribman has added a matching story to the Turgenev tale. He has imagined that the greedy servant, instead of burning the manuscript, takes it to a publisher in the hope of selling it. The publisher's chief reader is a fussy little daydreaming bachelor, Zoditch, whose life parallels that of the man he is reading about. The play moves in three strands: the life of the reader, the fantasies of the reader, and the life of the dead man, Chulkaturin. At last the reader and Chulkaturin confront each other, and the reader insists that he has succeeded where the other has failed - in being loved. But this is not true. Both men are superfluous, though for different reasons. The Cast: Dustin Hoffman - Zoditch Michael Tolan - Chulkaturin Charlotte Rae - Terentievna Susan Anspach - Miss Grubov (also Elizaveta) Lee Wallace - Pandalevski (also Bizmionkov) Mark Hammer - Dr. Korvin Nicholas Saunders - Kirilla Marveich Ozhogin Martha Greenhouse- Anna Nikitishna Ozhogin Jack Aaron - Gregory THE JOURNEY OF THE FIFTH HORSE is a National Educational Television production, executive producer: Jac Venza, staged by Larry Arrick, television direction by Earl Dawson, costumes by Kert Lundell, settings by Charles Rosen.
The journey of the fifth horse.
a production of National Educational Television ; directed for television by Larry Arrick and Earl Dawson ; writer, Ronald Ribman.

From NET microfiche: Since 1962, New York's famous Plaza Hotel has been the home of one of America's most celebrated topical reviews, Julius Monk's PLAZA 9. The stage at the Plaza is postage-stamp size, and the company is small (from two to eight depending on the materials), but Monk's style and influence are, and have been, enormous. In fact, he has been called the creator of sophisticated caf form in the United States. Certainly, he is one of the original producers of this form of entertainment in this country. (Among notable alumni from Julius Monk reviews are Liberace, Imogene Coca, Tom Poston, Jonathan winters and Tammy Grimes.) From both his current production and from outstanding numbers from earlier reviews, Monk has assembled this hour-long color program, taped on location at the Plaza. Some of the subjects, handled with hilarious irreverence by the satiric group, are the coming political campaign; the new morality; singles' bars; psychedelic drugs; Charles de Gaulle; and the Great Society. The cast is made up of Mary Louise Wilson, Rex Robbins, Terry O'Mara, Liz Sheridan, and Alex Wipf. The host is Julius Monk, and the accompanists are Robert Colston, Otis Clements, and Baldwin Bergersen. "NET Playhouse: Julius Monk's PLAZA 9," is a National Educational Television production. Produced by Jac Venza/ Directed by Dave Geisel. Associate producer: Virginia Kassel.
National Educational Television ; producer, Jac Venza ; director, Dave Geisel ; associate producer, Virginia Kassel.

"Peri, an office clerk in Tel Aviv, recalls his time in a Nazi concentration camp and a fellow prisoner named Bach. Flashbacks reveal their suffering. He meets another fellow prisoner Gurfinkel and together they search for Bach. When they finally spot him on a street corner in Tel Aviv, he just stands there in apathy, oiling the prams of mothers passing by. He does not recognize Peri." (Summary from Cinema and the Shoah, edited by Jean-Michel Frodon, Translated by Anna Harrison and Tom Mes, pp. 303-304)
NET journal presents ; produced by Radio Bremen in cooperation with Isra-Film ; director, screenplay, Karl Fruchtmann.
National Educational Television and Radio Center

Andrzej (Leon Niemczyk) and Krystyna (Jolanta Umecka) are driving to a lake to go sailing when they come upon a young man (Zygmunt Malanowicz) hitchhiking in the middle of the road. After nearly hitting him, Andrzej invites the young man along. When they arrive at the lake, instead of leaving the young man behind, Andrzej invites him to go sailing with them. The young man accepts the offer, and, not knowing much about sailing, must learn many hard lessons from Andrzej. Meanwhile, tension gradually builds between Andrzej and the hitchhiker as they vie for the attentions of Krystyna. The title refers to the major turning point in the film when Andrzej taunts the young man with the latter's treasured pocket knife, which is accidentally lost overboard. A fight ensues between Andrzej and the hitchhiker and the latter falls into the water. Andrzej and his wife search for him, but cannot find him and assume that he has drowned, since earlier he said that he could not swim. Andrzej and his wife quarrel about what to do, and Andrzej swims to shore to fetch the police. When the young man realizes that Andrzej has gone he comes out from hiding behind a buoy on the lake and swims to the yacht. There he sees Krystyna naked drying off. He boards the yacht and Krystyna tells him he is as bad as Andrzej but sexual attraction wins out and they have sex, off screen. Krystyna sails back to the dock, the man jumps off and goes on his way before Andrzej appears and takes charge again. He wants to go to the police to report the young man missing. Krystyna tells him that the young man returned and she was unfaithful. Andrzej does not know what to believe and at the road junction the car does not move. From NET microfiche: Program Description: "Knife in the Water," winner from Poland of the International Film Critics Award at the 1962 Venice Film Festival, deals with a psychological crisis involving three forceful personalities locked together on a small boat: the boat's owner, Andrzej, a successful sportswriter who flaunts his possessions, sailing skill and ultimate physical ability; Christine, his provocative, but cool and disdainful wife; and a rebellious young stranger. Close to the end of their 24-hour cruise, tension between the men erupts over the boy's one important possession, a knife. The boy, who had earlier claimed that he could not swim, is flung overboard and disappears. After a brief search for him, Andrzej rushes off, presumably to notify the police. With the husband gone, the boy - who had been hiding - reappears. He is wet, he is cold. Angry but relieved, Christine comforts him and eventually they make love. The boat puts into shore; the boy disembarks; Christine looks for her husband to tell him the trip to the police is not necessary as the young man is safe. But he feels that she is merely trying to protect him, and so in order to convince him of the boy's safety Christine tells him of her brief affair. Andrzej is left to make the uncomfortable choice between his own guilt and his wife's unfaithfulness. "Knife in the Water" is in Polish with English subtitles. The Cast: Andrzej - Leon Niemczyk Christine - Jolanta Umecka Young man - Zygmunt Malanowicz KNIFE IN THE WATER is a National Educational Television presentation. Director: Roman Polanski Screenplay: Roman Polanski, Jerzy Skolimowski,Jakub Goldberg Director of Photography: Jerzy Lipman Cameraman: Andrzej gronau Produced by: Kamera Unit of Film Polski Released by: Kanawha Films Ltd. NET Producer: Tom Slevin
Film Polski, Warsaw; produced by Stanislaw Zylewicz ; directed by Roman Polanski ; written by Jerzy Skolimowski, Roman Polanski, Jakub Goldberg.

From Wikipedia: L'Avventura is a 1960 Italian film directed by Michelangelo Antonioni and starring Gabriele Ferzetti, Monica Vitti, and Lea Massari. Developed from a story by Antonioni, the film is about a young woman's disappearance during a boating trip in the Mediterranean. Her lover and her best friend, during the subsequent search for her, become attracted to each other. The film is noted for its careful pacing, which puts a focus on visual composition and character development, as well as for its unusual narrative structure. According to an Antonioni obituary, the film "systematically subverted the filmic codes, practices and structures in currency at its time." Filmed on location in Rome, the Aeolian Islands, and Sicily in 1959 under difficult financial and physical conditions, L'Avventura made Monica Vitti an international star.[3] The film was nominated for numerous awards and was awarded the Jury Prize at the 1960 Cannes Film Festival.L'Avventura is the first film of a trilogy by Antonioni, followed by La Notte (1961) and L'Eclisse (1962). From NET microfiche: Antonioni's Masterpiece - received by critics as a landmark in the history of the cinema. From a deceptively simple plot: (during a yachting trip off Sicily a young woman disappears. Her lover searches for her unsuccessfully, meanwhile falling in love with her best friend. She in turn finally discovers him with another woman and the film ends with her expression of pity) the film achieves in cinematic terms the subtlety and complexity of a good novel.
[presentation of National Educational Television] ; producer, Amato Pennasilico ; director, Michelangelo Antonioni ; screenplay, Michelangelo Antonioni, Elio Bartolini ; Tonino Guerra.
National Educational Television and Radio Center

The action is set in the laboratory of the American Biological Association Development for the Advancement of Brain Analysis, where curious experiments involving various mammals are taking place. Helen, a newly engaged cleaning lady, is particularly drawn to a dolphin and is shocked when she learns that, having failed to "talk" as hoped for, it is slated for brain dissection. She makes a desperate attempt to rescue the dolphin from the scientists, incurring first their indignation and then, when the dolphin does indeed "talk" for Helen, their futile pleas that she change her mind about leaving and stay on to help them in their experiments. But the gentle Helen has had enoughboth of "Custodial Engineering" and of schemes to change man's relationship to the other creatures with whom the world must be shared. (Summary from Paul Zindel Website, http://www.paulzindel.com/hisworks/synopsis/plays/letmewhisper.htm, viewed June 30, 2015)
A production of Channel 13 WNDT and NET ; New York Television Theater ; produced and directed by Glenn Jordan ; writer, Paul Zindel.
NET playhouse. Let me hear you whisper.
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche: The lion of the title is England; the eagle is the United States. Its writer and narrator, Alistair Cooke, was present as a young reporter in the White House when President Roosevelt announced the destruction of the American fleet at Pearl Harbor. Commemorating the 25th anniversary of this event, Mr. Cooke reviews the shifting Anglo-American Alliance - a relationship that has "been maintained down three centuries by an odd mixture of feelings: by affection, curiosity, envy, ridicule and admiration. For the duration of the war, the alliance was "as firm as it would ever be. For its aim was grand and simple: survival and victory." Since 1945, there have been events that strained the alliance - such as the Suez Crisis of 1956, the Cuban missile crisis of 1962, and the "desire of a renovated and recovered Europe to brush aside the protective umbrella of America's missiles and her spreading armies of occupation." This period has marked a significant change in the relative power of the two countries. Says Cooke: "1943 is a watershed, down one side of which British power declined, as up the other side climbed the new power of the United States." And yet the alliance has remained firm - a source of irritation to detractors such as President de Gaulle, a source of united strength for the West. The Cold War has underlined its political relevance; but the common roots of the two peoples have buttressed it. 1) Film clips from World War II are prominent in the program. From these clips emerge the voices of history - Neville Chamberlain, Franklin Roosevelt, Wendell Willkie, Charles Lindbergh, Winston Churchill, Douglas McArthur, Harry Truman, Joseph McCarthy, John Foster Dulles, John F. Kennedy, Lyndon Johnson, William Fulbright, Dean Rusk. Post-war significance is attached to such events as the raising of the Iron Curtain; the counter effect of NATO; the Korean war, and its twin phenomena of Eisenhower the presider and McCarthy the Commie-catcher; the Suez crisis, signifying the further decline of the British Empire and the nadir of Anglo-American relations; the Common Market; the Berlin crisis; the Cuban crisis; the assassination of Kennedy and the succession of Johnson; and now the war in Vietnam. NET Journal -- "The Lion and the Eagle" is a 1966 National Educational Television presentation, produced for Intertel by Rediffusion, London. Executive producer: Lord David Windlesham. Director: Randal Beattie. NET producer: Boris Holtzman.
For Intertel by Rediffusion, London ; NET producer, Boris Holtzman ; director, Randal Beattie ; writer, Alistair Cooke.
Intertel. [No. 40], The lion and the eagle.
NET journal. The lion and the eagle.
The lion and the eagle. (NET journal).

From NET microfiche: "NET Playhouse Biography" begins a second season with its film of "To Be Young, Gifted and Black," adapted from the immensely successful stage production depicting the life and works of black playwright Lorraine Hansberry, who died of cancer in 1965 at the age of 34. Ruby Dee, Al Freeman Jr., Claudia McNeil, Barbara Barrie, Lauren Jones, Roy Scheider and Blythe Danner comprise the NET cast. Miss Hansberry's most famous work, "A Raisin in the Sun," made her the youngest American and the first black playwright to win the New York Drama Critics Circle Award (best play, 1959). The play later became a major motion picture and she won the Cannes Film Festival Award for the screenplay. "To Be Young, Gifted and Black" is a creation of the playwright's husband, Robert Nemiroff, who calls it the story of Miss Hansberry "in her own words." Woven together from her diaries and letters, and from portions of her plays, it relates her experiences growing up as a black artist in America, and the realization that her life would be ended prematurely. In NET's version, many scenes have been filmed on location to capture such episodes as Miss Hansberry's first visit to the South, her response to the streets of Harlem, and her bittersweet memories of a high school English teacher. The work is conceived in a complex, free-flowing style, with each member of the cast in turn conveying the thoughts of Miss Hansberry and portraying the people in her life and the characters she created, including those of "A Raisin in the Sun," "The Sign in Sidney Brunstein's Window," and "Les Blancs." "To Be Young, Gifted and Black" opened off-Broadway at Greenwich Village's Cherry Lane Theatre in 1969 to virtually unanimous praise from critics. Clive Barnes of the New York Times called it "wonderfully moving One of the most provoking entertainments in New York." Since then the show has visited more than 120 American cities and campuses. Academy Award-winning producer Robert M. Fresco adapted and produced "To Be Young, Gifted and Black" for NET Playhouse. The director, Michael A. Schultz, award-winning director of New York's Negro Ensemble Company, makes his television debut with the play. Fresco and a co-producer, Denis Sanders, won an Oscar for their documentary "Czechoslovakia '68." They also made television history for NET in 1970 with "Trail - The City and County of Denver vs. Lauren R. Watson," a four-part series marking the first time that an actual courtroom trial was seen on American TV screens nationwide. Schultz (who is Lauren Jones' husband) won off-Broadway's Obie Award for "The Song of the Lusitania Bogey" with the Negro Ensemble Company in 1968. Two years later he directed the same company in "Dream on Monkey Mountain," which won the Drama Critics Circle Award for best production. Schultz was also nominated for Broadway's Tony Award for "Does a Tiger Wear a Neckties?" in 1970. Notes on the cast: Ruby Dee and Claudia McNeil co-starred as Ruth and Lena Younger in both the stage and film versions of "A Raisin in the Sun" and they recreate portions of those roles in "To Be Young, Gifted and Black." Al Freeman Jr. was nominated for an Emmy for his role opposite Patty Duke in the TV film "My Sweet Charlie." Freeman both directs and stars in his latest film "Going Down Slow," based on a play entitled "Slave" by Amiri Braka (LeRoi Jones). Barbara Barrie recently starred on Broadway in "Company." In 1964 she won best actress honors at Cannes for "One Potato, Two Potato." Roy Scheider is currently seen as co-star of "The French Connection" and plays a supporting role in "Klute." Off-Broadway he was an Obie Award-winner for his part in "Stephen D." Blythe Danner received Broadway's 1970 Tony Award for best actress as co-star of "Butterflies are Free." Lauren Jones is currently on Braodway in Melvin van Peebles' "Ain't Supposed to Die a Natural Death' and was a tony Nominee for her role in "Does a Tiger Wear a Necktie?" Credits: "To Be Young, Gifted and Black" is a production of NET Division, Educational Broadcasting Corporation. Produced and adapted by Robert M. Fresco. Director: Michael Hochberg. NET Playhouse executive producer: Jac Venza.

From MBRS Film and Television card catalog: Tells the story of a Negro mother and her ten children who live on welfare but fantasize in a world of Cadillac prestige and middle class status. Presents a commentary on poverty in a Negro urban ghetto. From NET microfiche: "Losing just the same" is the refrain that runs through the lives of the Johns family and scores of Negroes like them. Escaping the poverty of the rural South, they come to a typical Northern city, in this case Oakland, California. But the new dream turns into an old reality: they're "losing just the same." For Agnes Johns, 34 year old, with 10 minor children, twice a victim of desertion, Oakland is just another slum. She lives on a monthly welfare check of $392; a sense of resignation that is both pious and disillusioned; and a residue of idealism that is founded on her children's future. In a poignant sequence she visits a department store, realizes she is judged as a potential thief because of her color, and admires a spangled dress she can't afford. She needs money, but rejects prostitution as a solution. While shopping, she also admires a baby's outfit - and thinks of a time when Bobby, her oldest child, was an infant. Bobby, the "hero" of "Losing Just the Same,' is now 17 years old. He bears the ironic name Robert Lee Johns. Balanced between school and work, with no future in either, he dreams of a Cadillac and a comfortable home for his mother. But for the Negro of Bobby's motivation, these are only false plans. As a Negro bartender remarks, in this world the "good pimp" epitomizes success. Waiting for his "break," Bobby lunges around the house in his pajamas, watches television, and goes out only to hang around or to have his hair processed (this ritualistic procedure takes place in a processing parlor, where the kinks are removed). The big break turns out to be a job sweeping up - for which he shows up in a gold shirt. But even the job is a failure. His mother laments that it costs more to send him to work than to keep him at home. He quits the job and returns to school. But then the San Francisco riots attract him. One night he meets a group of teenage incendiaries and is jailed as an accomplice in their attempted burning of an Oakland department store. Symbolically, he is identified by a man in a Cadillac. The film's cinema verite technique leads up dramatically to the boy's jailing. In addition, producer Richard Moore has added a "subconscious" element as demonstrated in a dream sequence involving Bobby and a Cadillac. "The film's technique enables us to get at the underlying psychological realities as well as the bare facts. The film makes some of its most forceful points through juxtaposition. There is a bar fight between Joe, the bartender, and Curtis Baker, a Black Nationalist dubbed the "Black Jesus." The camera then pans to a sparring match between two children in the Johns home. Elsewhere the valedictorian of all-black McClymonds High school is making her speech with the text "No man is an island." A moment later, the school's principal is rating Bobby Johns' future in pessimistic terms. The film makes a starkly honest point about most Negroes in America - North and South. For those who live in "an urban wasteland," cries for civil rights have a "hollow sound." For the decent, hopeless Negro like Agnes Johns or her son Robert, it is harder than for Curtis Baker who can boast hatefully, "if we have to kill all whites to gain our freedom, we'll do it.' As the film ends, the Johns family is losing again: the welfare department is weighing a recommended budget cut on the basis of Bobby's detention.

From NET microfiche: In the first US television network broadcast of the BBC production, NET presents this drama by Henri de Montherland which centers around mystical disillusion with the Spanish conquest. The year is 1519 and the setting is Spain where five Knights of the Order of Santiago, one of the ancient Orders of Chivalry, meet with Alvaro Dabo and try to persuade him to take part in the conquest of the West Indies. Alvaro, who lives like a recluse and is almost a mystic, has a passionate disgust for the colonization and exploitation of the Americas. An old friend, Don Bernal, whose son is engaged to Alvaro's daughter Mariana, tries to persuade Alvaro, realizing he needs money for his daughter's dowry. But Alvaro refuses and Mariana and Bernal arrange that Count Soria, a representative of the King, shall tell Alvaro that the King wishes him to go. This almost convinces Alvaro, but when Mariana realizes that she cannot allow her father to be duped she tells him of the plot. Alvaro decides the only life he can bear is to become a monk and Mariana agrees to enter the convent, and together they find happiness.
NET festival. The master of Santiago.

"A Memory of Two Mondays" depicts the bleak, dead-end world of the blue-collar worker in the thirties. The setting is an auto parts warehouse in New York City. The central character is Bert, a youthful employee whose feelings and observations of the people around him roughly parallel those of the young Arthur Miller (who actually worked in a warehouse as a teenager). Bert is played by Kristoffer Tabori. Jack Warden portrays Gus, a hearty Slavic immigrant who spends the last 22 years of his life in the warehouse and dies with his spirit totally broken after the death of his wife. Estelle Parsons is Agnes, the company's sympathetic and unaspiring telephone operator - a middle-aged spinster apparently destined to remain where she is for the rest of her life. George Grizzard plays the role of Larry, whose one financial indiscretion - the purchase of an expensive car - further entraps the company secretary, played by Cathy Burns. There is a short introduction to the play by Arthur Miller.
Executive producer, Jac Venza ; producer, Jacqueline Babbin ; director, Paul Bogart ; play by Arthur Miller.
NET playhouse. A memory of two Mondays.

From NET microfiche: Estelle Parsons, Jack Warden, George Grizzard, Cathy Burns, and Kristoffer Tobori are featured in this NET Playhouse production of Arthur Miller's "A Memory of Two Mondays." Peabody award-winner Jacqueline Babbin is producer, and three-time Emmy winner Paul Bogart directs. "A Memory of Two Mondays" is the first in a series of NET Playhouse programs concerning life in America during the Depression years. This play, which was performed on Broadway in 1956, depicts the bleak, dead-end world of the blue-collar worker in the thirties - a world of which Miller obtained a first-hand look while working in an auto parts warehouse as a teenager. The setting, therefore, is an auto parts warehouse in New York City (the play was filmed in an actual warehouse on New York's Lower East Side). The central character is Bert, a youthful employee whose feelings and observations of the people around him roughly parallel those of the young Miller. Bert is played by Kristoffer Tabori, the son of actress Viveca Lindfors and stepson of actor George Tabori. Warden portrays Gus, a hearty Slavic immigrant who spends the last 22 years of his life in the warehouse and dies with his spirit totally broken after the death of his wife. Miss Parsons is Agnes, the company's sympathetic and unaspiring telephone operator - a middle-aged spinster apparently destined to remain where she is for the rest of her life. Grizzard plays the role of Larry, whose one financial indiscretion - the purchase of an expensive car - further entraps the company secretary, played by Cathy Burns. Miss Burns is known for her role in the film "Last Summer." Producer Jacqueline Babbin recently made three programs for the CBS Children's Hour, including "JT," which won a Peabody Award. Miss Babbin's production of "Outpost," starring Claude Rains, in the Dupont Show of the Week series, also earned a Peabody Award. Dirctor Paul Bogart's three Emmys were awarded for "Shadow Game" and "Dear Friends," both CBS dramas, and for "The 700-year-old Gang" in "The Defenders" series. He was also director of the successful "Mark Twain Tonight" program featuring Hal Holbrook.
NET playhouse. A memory of two Mondays.

From NET microfiche: More than two million women are now attending colleges and universities in this country. When they leave the school, they will have far more freedom than any generation of women before them. And yet, for those choosing marriage and motherhood, the feeling of freedom tends to shrink, the "new way" fades back into the "old way," and a sense of frustration often results. The views of women - married and unmarried, happy and frustrated - are presented on NET Journal - Modern Women: The Uneasy Life. For this candid documentary, producer Dan Klugherz has visited suburban homes, colleges, and the inevitable sand pile where children play while mothers prate. There are also interviews with an "expert" on educated women, Mrs. Esther Raushenbush, president of Sarah Lawrence College in Bronxville, N.Y. The women express a range of attitudes: among the mothers, some feel confined by "a cage of my own making," caught in "an endless car pool," and "too insular" for any new ideas; others regard the function of mother and housewife as necessary and even satisfying "because it's so busy" and because "you're responsible for how their (children's) lives come out." Some are able to work, at least part-time, either by hiring nursemaids, relying on their husbands for babysitting aid, or waiting until the children grow up. Whichever "side" the women take, however, there is a sense that the old roles no longer apply. New definitions are needed; yet some of the functions must stay the same. Interviews conducted at Bridgeport College, a coed school in Bridgeport, Conn., indicate the real gap between males and females in defining their relationships. The women are anxious for "the same choice as a man," and fear getting "bogged down" by love. The men resent having to work for a woman (as on the campus paper) and reject the idea of competing in a relationship with a woman. One male student comments: "I don't want a woman with muscles." The poignancy of the situation is brought out by a girl student of architecture whose dating habits are made difficult because "I obviously scare them."
National Educational Television ; producer, Dan Klugherz.
NET journall. Modern women--the uneasy life.

From NET microfiche, file C: Description of series: The celebrated French writer (and sometime actress) Colette recalls the joys and anxieties of her childhood in the drama "My Mother's House," based on her autobiographical novel "La Maison de Claudine" (1922). Colleen Dewhurst plays the major role of Colette's mother, Sido; Suzanne Grossman is the narrator (Colette); and Kathy Cody is Colette as a young girl. "My Mother's house," adapted by Bert Greene, was previously telecast locally in New York City on WNET. Colette (1873-1954) is the pen name of Sidonie Gabrielle Claudine Colette, who as a young girl is known affectionately in this play as Minet-Cheri (darling kitten). The play is set in and around the house where she grew up at St. Sauveur-en-Pulisaye, Burgundy. The Principal characters are the members of her family, most especially her indomitable mother, of whom Colette has drawn an affectionate, deeply incisive literary portrait. Colette had two brothers and a sister. The sister, Juliette, and the elder brother, Achille, were born to Sido by her first husband, whom she left before the children were old enough to know their father. Julliette's resentment of this was manifested in an undying hostility for her stepfather and ambivalence toward her mother which nearly tore the family apart while Colette was entering her adolescence. Much of the play focuses on this difficult period, and on the teenage years when the shy Minet-Cheri experiences her first tentative feelings of love. Colette is perhaps best known for a series of novels beginning with "Cheri," published in 1920. By this time she had considerable stage experience, which was reelected in earlier novels, "La Vagabonde" (1910) and "L'Entrave" (1913). Also among her better-known earlier work is the series of "Claudine" stories (1900-1903) Colette helped to adapt "Cheri" for the stage, and she played a major role in three productions of that work. She also wrote the libretto for Maurice Ravel's "L'Enfant et Les Sortileges," which was first performed in 1925. A number of films have been based on Colette stories, the most famous of which is "Gigi," adapted from one of Colette's final works - a short novel published in 1944.

a production of NET Division, Educational Broadcasting Corporation ; NET playhouse executive producer, Jac Venza ; producer, Glenn Jordan ; director, John Desmond ; adapted by Bert Greene ; based on the novel by Colette.

From NET microfiche: Filmed at the Nova School in Fort Lauderdale, this program investigates the learning experience of the individual child. It focuses on two children - the nine-year-old boy Gar and the ten-year-old girl Sandy - and on two teachers who form a classroom learning "team." Nova, a progressive school running from kindergarten through 12th grade, stresses the teacher pupil relationship, breaking its classes into varying sizes as an assignment dictates. The program has been filmed by William C. Jersey, producer of "A Time for Burning," one of the most highly-acclaimed documentaries in recent television history. Jersey's objective in the film is to reveal the child's growing awareness of his own nature, through a discovery of his personal source of excitement and response - whether it be dinosaurs, drama or distant planets. The entire film takes place in school, as students use the Total Resource Center (technologically advanced library); perform satire on the Trojan War; participate in a "propaganda game," which employs many of the sophisticated techniques of modern propagandists; and engage in various learning situations on an individualized and group basis. The curriculum at Nova School calls for children to begin - as early as kindergarten - a study of social sciences (beginning with "social" processes related to the life of the young child); an "audio-lingual" study of foreign languages; and from kindergarten on, learning in geometry, algebra, and arithmetic.
Quest Productions, Inc. [and] National Educational Television ; producer-director, William C. Jersey ; filmmakers, William C. Jersey, Gwen Brown ; associate producer, David Boehn.
NET journal. My name is children.

Tonight's program presents the second show profiling the complex personality and peculiar lifestyle of jazz legend Duke Ellington. The concert film, shot by the KQED Film Unit on September 16, 1965 at San Francisco's Grace Cathedral, is the first Sacred Concert by Duke Ellington and his Orchestra. The program presents the spiritual side of Duke Ellington and features the following special guests: vocalists Esther Marrow, John Hendricks, The Herman McCoy Choir, and tap dancer Bunny Briggs. Accompanied by Duke Ellington and his Orchestra, these artists perform the musical selections Come Sunday, The Lord's Prayer, In the Beginning God, and David Danced Before the Lord With All His Might, New World a 'Comin, Tell Me Its the Truth, and Overture to Black, Brown, and Beige (Stratemann, Klaus. Duke Ellington, Day By Day And Film By Film, p. 513). From NET microfiche, file D: The hour-long film is a record of the premiere performance of this offering as it took place in Grace Cathedral, the seat of the Episcopal Archdiocese at the top of Nob Hill in San Francisco. The very Rev. C. Julian Bartlett, Dean of the Cathedral, who together with the Rev. John S. Yaryan invited "the American composer, orchestra leader and pianist Edward Kennedy Ellington" to appear, wrote: "Duke Ellington has been endowed by God with the gift of genius. He is one of the giants of contemporary music, having made profound contributions to his field. He and his company of artists make an offering to God in this concert." The film presents complete performances of major portions of the concert, which Ellington based on two of his famous longer works, "Overture to Black, Brown and Beige," and the moving, "My People." Featured in addition to the orchestra and its soloists are tap dancer Bunny Briggs performing "David Danced Before the Lord" with singer Jon Hendricks supplying words, Esther Marrow singing "Come Sunday," and "The Lord's Prayer," and a special solo by Ellington, "New World A Comin'." In his preface to the concert Ellington wrote: "In this program, you may hear a wide variety of statements without words, and I think you should know that it is a phrase with six tones, it symbolizes the six syllables in the first four words of the Bible, 'In the Beginning God," which is our theme. We say it many times -- many ways." DUKE ELLINGTON: A CONCERT OF SACRED MUSIC was produced for National Educational Television by the Special Projects Department of KQED, San Francisco. Produced by Ralph J. Gleason and Richard Moore. Directed by Richard Moore. Photographed by Philip Greene, Joe Dieves and Lane Slate. Sound by Stanley Kronquest and Wally Heider. Announcer: William Triest. Executive Producer: Lane Slate.

From NET microfiche: Frederic Rossif, the French filmmaker ("To Die in Madrid") has combined cinema verite with news footage and amateur movies of historic personalities to produce this kaleidoscopic view of Paris of yesterday and today. With actor Charles Boyer, as narrator in English, the film takes the viewer behind the scenes into a Paris the tourist rarely sees -- Paris at war, Paris on holiday, the poor and the luxurious sections of Paris. Among the rare film footage Rossif has employed are strips he found in the private collection of the late Sacha Guitry: Renoir painting, Rodin at work at his sculpture, Sarah Bernhardt playing Hamlet. Among the interesting documentary segments are visits to apartments of Paris personalities, artistic and political figures, and a film showing the music hall performances of a very youthful Maurice Chevalier and a not-so-youthful Mistinguett. A particularly poignant sequence shows Toulouse-Lautrec's model, the famous Moulin Rouge entertainer "La Goulue," photographed twenty years after her great career, living in rags in a suburban slum. NET Festival #87 is followed by filler program, "A Child's Introduction to the Cosmos," to be run with "Encore Paris," is a six minute black and white animated short made by a student at the University of Southern California. This is a fantasy in which a father describes the universe and the creation of the world to his small daughter. He invents a fairy-tale explanation which he delivers as if it were real. NET Festival #126 is followed by filler program, "The unanswered question," a five-minute (approx.) film. Made by David Hoffman and Jonathan Gordon, the film tries to answer "what is brotherhood?" Cameras roam the streets and record people's answer to this question.
produced for Tele-Hachette and Four Star Television by Frederic Rossif ; NET producer, Tom Slevin ; written by Frederic de Towarnicki ; music composed by Maurice Jarre.
Interviewer asks people what is the meaning of brotherhood? Interviews: Jonathan Gordon. Camera: David Hoffman.

From NET microfiche (N): Dubbed "the high priestess of soul," Nina Simone demonstrates her highly personal vocal style in a program of jazz, blues, folk and pop music. The program, produced by London Weekend TV, was taped during Miss Simone's first television appearance in England. When it aired here, critics called it "exceptional" (The Philadelphia Inquirer); "sold pop-entertainment" (Newsday); and "very moving and brooding performance" (Boston Globe). Performing before a studio audience, Miss Simone is heard in "Backlash Blues," a poem by Langston Hughes which she adapted into a protest song; "GoLimp," a humorous song about a girl on a freedom march; "Mississippi Goddam," Miss Simone's first protest song; "Four Women," a succession of musical vignettes on how women's circumstances and outlooks vary according to their gradations of skin color; and "In the Morning." Miss Simone is accompanied by Sam Waymon, organ; Henry Young, guitar; Gene Taylor, bass; and Buck Clark, drums. Nina Simone became a top entertainer in 1959 through her recording of "I Love You Porgy." It started her on a long series of personal appearances in leading clubs and concert halls in this country and abroad. Born Eunice Waymon in 1939 in Tryon, North Carolina, she was the sixth of eight children in a very poor family. Her father was a handyman, and her mother, who worked as a housekeeper during the day, at night donned the robes of an ordained Methodist minister. At the age of four Nina was playing the piano, and by seven had attracted the attention of a woman for whom her mother worked and who paid for her to have piano lessons with a local teacher, Mrs. Lawarence Mazzanovich. When after two years Nina could no longer afford the lessons, Mrs. Mazzanovich, recognizing her talent, continued them without charge, and also established a Eunice Waymon Fund to insure advanced studies for her. With this money, she attended high school in Asheville, NC, and later studied for a year and a half at the Juilliard School of Music in New York. Her money ran out, and she returned to her family, which had moved to Philadelphia. There she gave piano lessons and worked as accompanist in a vocal studio. In 1954, when the studio closed for the summer, she got a job in a night club in Atlantic City. Though she had been hired as a pianist, she found she was also expected to sing. Having never sung before, in desperation she tried - and amazed herself at her success with the audience. It was then - fearing her parents' displeasure at her working in a night club - that she changed her name to Nina Simone. After her success in Atlantic City, she returned to the studio, but soon decided to try her luck with a show business career. From then on she gravitated to fame. "A great singer, she has also been described as a spokeswoman for morality," who expresses her personal feelings in her songs. She herself has said "I can't sing a song without meaning it." The following is the complete rundown of musical items on this program: Go To Hell Ain't Got No I Got Life Please Read Me Backlash Blues Sea Lion woman Be My Husband Go Limp In the Morning Four Women I Put a Spell on You Misunderstood The Other Woman Mississippi Goddam Peace of Mind The King of Love is Dead
NET festival. Nina Simone--the sound of soul.
