From NET microfiche: This is a repeat broadcast of the television production (edited by Nathan Kroll) of "The World of Carl Sandburg" as originally presented on Broadway. The production features Uta Hagen, Fritz Weaver and the singing group, The Tarriers (Clarence Cooper, Eric Weissberg, and Al Dana), plus folk singer Carolyn Hester. The production consists of recitations of Carl Sandburg's poetry and prose as synthesized and organized by Norman Corwin with appropriate musical interpolations from Sandburg's "American Songbag." The staging is informal - including settings which symbolize well-known aspects of Sandburg -- "a chair he would sit in if he were here; he would strum this guitar and the books are what is published of his writing." The recitations are from his novel Remembrance Rock, The People, Yes - a collection of "psalms, memoranda, sayings and yarns, " and Sandburg's biography of Abraham Lincoln. The subjects touched upon capture the range of Sandburg's writings; they include such various topics as babies, advice to the young, marriage, observations on glass, snakes and bugs, happiness, love and hate, arithmetic, war, the reminiscences of a former slave, jokes -jokes about country folk, jokes about having the last word, goofyisms, jokes about women, sociological jokes -- stories about Lincoln and Lincoln's speech to his friends upon leaving Springfield. A recording of Sandburg himself reading a poem called "Phizzog" is played while Steichen's portrait of Sandburg is superimposed. The songs sung by The Tarriers and Carolyn Hester are: "I was Born Almost Ten Thousand Years Ago," "Go To Sleep, Little Baby," "Love, Oh Love, Oh, Careless Love," "I'm Gonna Lay Down My Sword and Shield," "There's a Man Goin' Roun'," "A Hundred Years is a Very Long Time," "and By'm, By." Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET PLAYHOUSE -- THE WORLD OF CARL SANDBURG: Television version of the original Broadway production, with Uta Hagen, Fritz Weaver, The Tarriers and Carolyn Hester performing Sandburg's prose, poetry and songs. From M/B/RS Film and Television catalog card: Based on the stage presentation by Norman Corwin. Presents a tribute to Carl Sandburg and surveys the heritage that he left and the history he made. Includes some selections from Carl Sandburg's works and renditions of songs from his folk song anthologies.

From NET microfiche: Among the subjects discussed by Mr. Nixon and NET correspondent Paul Niven are the art of politics, the power of the President, the handling of war - specifically, Vietnam - the ambitions of Mr. Nixon, reminiscences on 1960 (including the allegation that he was "a dirty campaigner"), his fellow Republicans, and his critical assessment of President Johnson. Excerpts follow: On war: "There'll never be another declaration of war in my opinion." Future wars will not resemble "conventional" past wars, but will be "nuclear or guerilla in character ... The President (therefore) must be free to act as quickly as required." On Vietnam: "No Republican would accept the idea of a reward for aggression ... The Vietcong are simply a front - completely controlled and staffed by North Vietnam ... Any settlement free of North Vietnam will be honored." On public strikes: "I disagree with the idea that teachers can put up students as hostages." On appropriations: "It is vitally essential for the President to be a balancing wheel with lobbying groups." In the case of the space program, "the appropriation may be excessive" because of "public appeal." On the press: Mr. Nixon states that he was "given the shaft" by some reporters in 1960, but "never complained" about press coverage. However, a "political man should criticize the press, when necessary," but "without the heat I exhibited in 1962" after losing to Governor Brown in California. On television: "I know what TV can do to a candidate." On his candidacy in 1968: "A decision of that magnitude, involving that exertion ... shouldn't be made until the last moment." Then, "an evaluation of whether I can be the best candidate will decide ... The great events can change ... I didn't have the slightest idea I'd run again (after 1962), but the events have brought it about that I'm a potential candidate." On the primaries: "It's necessary for me to establish a winner image. Therefore, I have to beat somebody." On the image of "tricky Dick": "That's not a particular problem. I can take it and I can give it out, and at the time I will." On his campaigning: "I'll campaign on the record (not on personalities) ... for more effective leadership ... There's never been a time when we're in more trouble in more places ... I have so many disagreements with President Johnson's conduct of foreign affairs" and other matters that "it gives me enough speaking material for the next five years without getting to the Republicans."
NET journal. A conversation with Richard Nixon on the science of politics.
NET presents ; produced by Jim Karayn ; directed by Max Schindler.
A conversation with Richard Nixon on the science of politics.

From NET microfiche: This interview with Mrs. Svetlana Alliluyeva, daughter of the late Josef Stalin, will be conducted live on the publication date of her book of memoirs, "Twenty Letters to a Friend." Though no advance script will be available, it is anticipated that she and NET correspondent Paul Niven will discuss in English - the book's revelations concerning Stalin and such products of his era as Secret Police head Lavrenti Beria, Soviet head of state Anastas Mikoyan, and deputy premier Georgi Malenkov. The 41-year-old daughter of Stalin, who defected to this country in April, has already created a furor in the publishing world through the manuscript which she smuggled out of Russia on a trip to India last year. A pirated manuscript has appeared in England and the Soviet Union, and the New York Times and Life magazine will excerpt portions of the book this month. Though she does not classify herself as a writer, Mrs. Alliluyeva is a former member of the Soviet literary intelligentsia and worked as an English translator in a Soviet publishing house. The treatment of intellectuals in Russia - in particular, the sentencing of writers Andrei Sinyavasky and Yuli Daniel for publishing anti-Soviet works - has a strong impression on Mrs. Alliluyeva and was among the reasons for her defection from Russia. In coming to the United States, she was seeking "the self-expression that has been denied me for so long in Russia," and since finds "I am absolutely sure that I have done the right thing," though the move to America estranges her from her two children, at present in Russia. In an interview published last week (The New York Times, August 27), Mrs. Alliluyeva said that her father was never "the incarnation of evil," but that "perhaps the evil power conquered the good in our family." She especially noted a change in Stalin after her mother's suicide in 1932. Suggested Newspaper Listing: "NET Journal -"A Conversation with Svetlana Alliluyeva": the daughter of Josef Stalin discusses her late father's regime in a live interview with Paul Niven, conducted on the publication date of her controversial memoirs, "Twenty Letters to a Friend."

From NET microfiche, file F: For more than 150 years, Goya's painting of the naked Maya, depicting the Duchess of Alba, has been an object of interest -- and sometimes titillated curiosity -- on the part of art lovers, This BBC program studies the latest Duchess of Alba -- her riches, her family, her ancestors, and her "few castles in Spain." The Duchess and her husband, a former civil engineer who attained nobility through marriage, are interviewed by Alan Whicker in their Madrid home and at a Holy Week celebration in Seville. Whicker also tours the Alba estates, noting their opulent furnishings and works of art by such masters as Velasquez, Titian, Fra Angelico, Goya and El Greco. Scenes of the Duke and Duchess on their daily rounds include visits to a local hospital, a school, their children's riding and painting lessons, a look at the domestic side as the Duchess bathes and feeds her youngest of five sons, while another tweaks Whicker's moustache. The film ends with a view of the Seville procession, the Madonna's statue bedecked with the Duchess' jewelry, and the float bearing her candelabra; finally there is dancing in the streets, though the Duchess retires to her room before performing a flamenco of her own. Throughout the interview, Whicker presses her about her contact with the world, the morality of her opulence in a country dense with poverty, and the probable relationship of her noted ancestor with the painter Goya. The Duchess, speaking in English (as does her husband), answers all his questions with equanamity, contending that she is involved in the modern world. Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET Journal -- "A Few Castles in Spain": An intimate picture of the Duchess of Alba, her consort and her castles, as she attends a festival in Seville, enjoys her children, and defends her notorious ancestor, the "naked Maya" of Goya.
Stuart y Silva, Maria del Rosario Cayetana
NET journal. A few castles in Spain.
National Educational Television and Radio Center
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche, file H: Program Description: Peasants in Java work for 20 cents a day. Hardly any owns more than one acre of land and it is common for a family to have eight children. Because of the poverty and overcrowding, the Indonesian government offers free jungle land and a house to young, married, non-Communist men who will move to the island of Sumatra. The program follows Diyono, 28, his wife, Seppi, 25, and their three children on the nine-day, 800-mile trek from their hut in Java to their new jungle home. En route, the current conditions of Indonesia, since the deposing of Sukarno in 1966, is studied. As the couple moves from the heart of Java through Bali by truck, scenes of the instruction of a young Balinese ceremonial dancer are shown. The head dancer has been persuaded to allow birth control to be taught in the village - the Balinese are Hindus and not opposed to contraception (many Indonesians are Muslims and forbidden the practice). The program says that without drastic measure, Indonesia will have a population of 250 million by the year 2000. Barefoot pupils in a village school illustrate the problem of illiteracy in a country where 7 million youngsters receive no education at all because of lack of teachers and schools. Teachers earn $3 per month. The teeming city of Djakarta houses a "transition camp" for the family traveling to the jungle. The viewer sees Djakarta through the family's eyes. A university student, Sukalee, talks of political ferment. Sukalee, a former soldier, was part of the "generation of 1966" which ousted Sukarno from power. "Student power was the fashion in Indonesia before it became fashionable outside it," producer John Power points out. General Soesatyo, Army historian, tells of the events leading to the Army-student overthrow of Sukarno and the killing of some 300,000 Communists or suspected Communists and jailing of 80,000 more. Regular political indoctrination sessions are now held for all citizens. The program shows such a session, as well as scenes of President Suharto and the Army officers who brought him to power. Scenes of student life - initiations and rock concerts (in English with amplified instruments) - and a beauty contest sponsored by a film magazine are shown. "Everything comes a little late to Djakarta ... yesterday's pop songs, the fashions of the year before," the program notes. The family's boat trip to Sumatra with more than 1,000 persons in an old Dutch vessel built for 500 leads to an interview with the head of the government shipping agency. He complains of "mismanagement" and corruption of the 60-vessel fleet during Sukarno's reign. He has fired 400 employees and set to fire another 400. Scenes of the family's trek through the jungle to their new house, carrying the scant equipment provided by the government, are interspersed with scenes of Sukalee being congratulated on getting his Master's degree. The program points out that few college graduates get good jobs, but that there is a feeling of increased hope. "One day we can be a major nation," Sukalee says. A thatched house is waiting for the Javanese family, along with five acres of land and enough food to tide them over until rice harvest. Although the trip through dense jungle just below the equator was harrowing, the family now has something few Indonesians have - a place of their own.
NET journal. A house in the jungle.
produced by the Australian Broadcasting Commission ; Intertel production presented by National Educational Television ; executive producer, Colin Dean ; producer-director, John Power.
NET journal. [No. 277], A house in the jungle.

From NET microfiche, file M: This documentary-drama, produced for Intertel by the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, depicts the life of a cancer patient at Princess Margaret Hospital in Toronto. In this production, dramatic actor Lee Patterson plays Ted Andersen, a man under treatment for Hodgkin's disease, a form of lymphatic cancer. The other principals include two actors - Irena Mayeska as Andersen's wife, and Hilary Vernon as another cancer patient - and the actual doctors, researchers, nurses, and other hospital employees. This method combines the realism of a cancer ward with the controlled pathos achieved through a dramatic form. The program traces Andersen's care from his first day at the hospital, following the discovery of a small, painless lump in his neck. He proceeds through a round of examinations, tests, diagnoses, and radiotherapy treatments. A doctor is assigned to see him through his course of treatment, and the patient is encouraged to continue his normal work and social life. "The story moves on several levels," producer-director Vincent Tovell; "what happens to Ted; what happens in places he doesn't know about - labs, research centers, conferences; what he feels inside - fears, doubts, hopes, mental strain; and how his problem affects his relationship with his wife, children and co-workers. "We recorded a lot of material with doctors and nurses, and made a mosaic sound track of bits and pieces of many people's thoughts and reactions. Very little technical language is used. We filmed morning, noon, and night with small portable equipment, surrounded by real patients. It was an inspiring experience." No scripted dialogue or interviews are used. Instead the actors improvise their words within each scene. Throughout the drama, time - enemy or ally - is a principal character. Time is the hope of cure, the dread of pain, the specter of death; and the drama is posed against this "matter of time." Lee Patterson, who plays Ted Andersen, has appeared in more than 32 British-produced movies and 20 plays, as well as many Canadian and American television programs and stage plays. He was star of the television adventure series "Surfside Six."
NET journal. A matter of time.
NET journal. [No. 243], A matter of time.

From NET microfiche (P): The avowed purpose of this program is to publicize research and developments in chemical and biological warfare being undertaken in virtual secrecy by many nations, including all of the leading powers. Although it monopolizes public attention today, nuclear weaponry was only one of the breakthroughs in military science during World War II, the program reminds us. There were also the discovery of nerve gases and the development of germ warfare, and leading scientists believe these constitute as great a threat to the survival of humanity as does the H-bomb. There is a difference, though, it is stressed. The public is worried about nuclear war and national leaders have shown their respect for the power of nuclear weapons in their attempts to work out non-proliferation treaties. But no one speaks out about chemical and biological weapons and the public scarcely knows of their existence. Their development goes unimpeded. Cameras go to defense laboratories in England and Sweden to film the effects of nerve and psychochemical gases and germs on animals. Cooperation from English officials was limited. Swedish authorities were more open and permitted considerable more extensive filmmaking. There are painful scenes shown of the laboratories. Rabbits and other animals, including a dog, are seen in the agony of exposure to the experimental weapons. Variety, which reviewed the program after it was seen in England over the BBC, commented that "undeniably the most distressing (moment) was seeing a dog, injected with a mind bending drug, lurching about disoriented and whining pitifully for the greater benefit of science and mankind." Troops are shown attempting to tackle assault courses while under the influences of small amounts of drugs. Later they are interviewed, and are unable to tell their interviewer with certainty what day it is.
NET journal. A plague on your children.
produced by the British Broadcasting Corporation ; produced by Adrian Malone ; NET executive producer, William Weston.
A plague on your children : Chemical and biological warfare.
NET journal. A plague on your children : Chemical and biological warfare.

From NET microfiche: Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET Journal - "Appalachia: Rich Land, Poor People": An award winning study of a coal rich land and the festering poverty first publicized by President Kennedy almost a decade ago. Program Description: This program first aired on November 11, 1968. It was one of three cited by Saturday Review in its award to NET Journal for distinguished programming during the past year. This program is about the gap between a coal-rich land and its wasted people. Appalachia, a mountainous region largely centered in the southeastern United States, was the first section designated as a poverty area under the Kennedy Administration. Therefore, this program concerns the thriving germ of poverty despite the presence of federal money, as well as the area's natural resources. The documentary focuses on the Collins family, whose plight epitomizes that of the Appalachia residents of northern Kentucky and West Virginia. A miner for 10 years, Collins lost his job when the company mechanized its operation. Since then, he has had little work, and has relied on welfare to provide a meager existence for his family of five. A man of 36, he has seemingly no future, and must look to old photograph albums for a sense of the hope that he and his wife once envisioned. Unlike Collins, almost a million Appalachians have left the area since 1950. But for the 1 million remaining inhabitants, the land and the facts of industrial life offer little prospect for hope. The wealth of Appalachia is underground, and the profits accrue to the coal companies, the program notes. "Some of America's largest corporations like Bethlehem, US and Republic Steel take millions of dollars of coal annually from Appalachian counties. Yet many of those same counties are pauper counties." Contributing to this imbalance is the fact that outside coal and land companies pay relatively little in state income taxes and local property taxes. So, "there is little money for schools, park, or health services." One county tax assessor unwittingly sums up when he admits that no land surveys are made: "You just have to trust the figures of the coal companies." The coal companies themselves justify it as true private enterprise - "an example of how the country was founded . Do it any other way, it's just socialism. If we're wrong, then the country is wrong." Encouraged by VISTA volunteers, some of the local residents are attempting to organize. Their cause in some cases coincided with the abortive Poor People's Campaign of the past summer. They are especially piqued about a 45 percent cut in their welfare payments by the West Virginia State Legislature. But as yet their efforts have had little impact. Predictably, the middle class exhibited shock and fear when presented with the threat of organized demands. At one Chamber of Commerce meeting, professional anti-communist Herbert Philbrick confronts the dangers of red infiltration throughout the country, especially in Eastern Kentucky. At this meeting, which was filmed by NET, local people turn their venom against the camera crew for "treading on damn dangerous ground" with "your boots and fuzzy faces."
NET journal. Appalachia--Rich land, poor people.
a National Educational Television production ; producer, writer, Jack Willis .
NET journal. [1969 June]. Appalachia--Rich land, poor people.
NET journal. [1968-11-11]. Appalachia--Rich land, poor people.
NET journal. [No. 238], Appalachia--Rich land, poor people.

From NET microfiche, file A: Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET Journal - "Asian Prayer, Asian Sword": Two half hour documentaries: one on religion in Japan - a secular, nationalistic ritual; another on terrorism in Tibet, directed by Tibetan exiles against Red Chinese forces. Program Description: The first half-hour consists of a documentary on Japanese religion - a nationalistic, secular ritual, with considerable formalism and a high degree of striving for joy. Shintoism, founded in the sixth century, has become intermixed with Buddhism, the program notes; and since the war, a new cult has formed - the fanatical, politically-oriented Sokagakkai. This cult, with its emphasis on restoration of pre-war Japanese values, deserves a shudder of recognition, according to the program. Seen here are a variety of rites with religious overtones - some as bizarre in this context as wrestling and ceremonies for broken needles. It is noted that athletics and military performance are not incompatible with the religion of modern Japan. Christianity, which was encouraged by General MacArthur at the end of World War II, has not become popular. And traditional Zen Buddhism is a meditative religion left largely to monks. In the second half-hour, British producer Adrian Cowell lives with a band of exiled Tibetans in the mountains of Nepal. There he notes the fanatical determination of the band to strike against the Red Chinese who drove them from their land. The documentary culminates with a raid into Tibet and the shooting of Red Chinese soldiers before the band returns to its adopted land.
NET journal. Asian prayer ; Asian sword.
a National Educational Television presentation, based on film produced by Studio Hamburg, Germany and Associated Television in Britain ; NET producer, Bill Weston.
National Educational Television and Radio Center
National Educational Television and Radio Center

" "Black and White Together?" focuses on a 1969 project that gauged the development of teen-age values in Atlantic City, N.J. Black and white teen-agers participated in classroom activities and were housed together at night. Shown: classroom confrontations and counseling sessions that reflect attitudes toward interracial living."--TV Guide.com From NET microfiche, file B: This program studies Atlantic City's Project WILL in the larger context of secondary school education in America today. The project, backed by $100,000 in Title I funds, was set up for two six-week periods at the Hotel Traymore on the boardwalk at Atlantic City. Here, some 80 students, black and white, engaged in a process of "living and learning." Each of the students checked into the hotel daily after attending regular high school classes. The goals of the project: an "effort to remove students from the totality of their environment"; to foster interracial understanding and learning skills in a relaxed, though structured, atmosphere. The documentary is a report on the project - its goals and its shortcomings. It focuses on Rod MacDonald, assistant director, who comes to recognize that "to have change you must necessarily upset the static condition that exists." He is opposed in the project's regimen by director Edgar Harris. "What right have these students got to evaluate me? I've got my Master's and I'm working on my PhD," he says, defending his hardline approach. Their opposing philosophies reflect a split within Project WILL, with many of the students contesting the value of the project and of their current education. Walking along the boardwalk, a student who has dropped out of Project WILL tells MacDonald: "It's the educational system that's preparing us for the larger system. I could care less about the square of the hypotenuse. What motivation is there in high school?" A key moment in the documentary shows the furor created by one girl's statement: "I wouldn't go out with a colored boy." Students and administrators are incensed by this "bigotry," but MacDonald says: "It's the first honest thing that happened here." MacDonald begins to understand the immensity of this job when he meets with black parents and confers with Sam Sanderson, former director of the Office of Evaluation, Sate of New Jersey. But by the second half of the project, he is encouraging students to "protest and do it, then come see me," when they conduct a "sleep-in" for the right to bring in food at night. Near the end of the project, he and Harris are more obviously at odds. Harris, hardening his attitudes, interrupts an evaluation meeting to eject the NET camera crew in a climactic moment. Sanderson concludes: "The program was written by adults under the guise of letting youngsters make their own decisions, but it didn't happen that way. Blacks and whites don't live together. It's pretty impossible to live together under the present system." NET Journal - "Black and White Together?" is an NET production. Produced and written by Dick McCutchen Associate producer: Norma Davidoff
NET journal. Black and white together?
NET ; producer-director-writer, Dick McCutchen ; associate producer, Norma Davidoff.
NET journal. [No. 233], Black and white together?

Aired on NET Journal. A film by Edward Pincus and David Neuman, "A cinema verite account of the attempt to organize a black community in the Deep South in 1965 during the heyday of the Civil Rights Movement. A black leader has been car-bombed and a struggle ensues in the black community for control. A group of black men organize a chapter of the Deacons for Defense--a secret armed self-defense group. The community splits between more conservative and activist elements"--Internet movie database WWW site, viewed 2011-11-09. Includes Speeches by Charles Evers from NAACP. Interviews with locals, National Guard & Police curview. Commentary by James Jackson. NET microfiche, file B: "Black Natchez" is about a genteel Southern town and two bombings a year and a half apart. The first bombing in August 1965 injured local NAACP president George Metcalfe. The second on February 27, 1967 killed local NAACP treasurer Wharlest Jackson. The film is concerned primarily with the undercurrents within the Negro community, prior to and after the first bombing. As the film begins, local Negroes are trying to form a self-protection group, called "Deacons." Masked behind the bravado, there is apathy and some fear. Organizing isn't popular here. James Jackson, a barber who emerges as the "hero" of the film, is preparing to leave the civil rights movement out of frustration - then the first bombing occurs. The Negroes become militant. And two groups - the NAACP and the Mississippi Freedom Democratic Party (MFDP) - begin their own power struggle. But despite the turmoil, the Negroes aren't ready to affect Natchez permanently. The mayor makes familiar concessions and the Negro movement subsides. A year and a half later, Natchez has a few Negro policemen, but is it debatable whether any of them can arrest a white man. Some Negro children have tried to attend white schools, but soon stopped going. And the mayor, despite demand, has refused to denounce the Ku Klux Klan. But after the second bombing, recorded at the film's end, the mayor must make some accommodation. Black Natchez, though not strongly united, can react at a time of violence. Therefore, the mayor comes to a meeting of Negro leaders - an indication that the white power structure had decided it can live with the black power structure. Above all, however, the film is not about bombings but about people - black people. Told without narration, in the cinema verite style, it probes the decision-making process within the Negro community - between middle class and poor Negroes, between women and men.
National Association for the Advancement of Colored People
a presentation of National Educational Television ; co-produced, directed and edited by Edward Pincus and David Neuman.
National Educational Television and Radio Center
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche: Arab refugees, victims of the uneasy peace in the Middle East, are the subject of "Bridge on the Jordan," a production of National Educational Television and the United Nations. The first hour-long study of the 1 million Arabs dispossessed by the recent war, the documentary begins at the Allenby Bridge, symbol of refugee frustration, and new dividing point between Israel and Jordan. It then visits several of the refugee camps on the Jordan's east bank and bombed-out towns along the Gaza Strip, noting the efforts of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency and pondering on the monumental problem of feeding and sheltering the refugees until peace comes to the Middle East. But more impressive than the gutted tanks and other scars of war are the people themselves - some of them homeless for the third time in 20 years - many waiting stolidly for their lost families, living in over-crowded tents that are racked by sand storms, or sitting by the Allenby Bridge and hoping to be permitted to return to their former homes. UN reporter Ben Park, who returned to this country in late July after three weeks in the Middle East, elicits the views of a variety of refugees - including camp leaders, teachers, and children - as well as health officers and other representatives of UNRA.
NET journal. Bridge on the Jordan.
a production of National Educational Television and the United Nations ; director, Ben Park.
NET journal. [1967-08-28]. Bridge on the Jordan.

From NET microfiche: The first half-hour consists of a report on life behind Burma's "bamboo curtain" - the barrier to outside commercial and diplomatic interests and even to tourism since General Ne Win effected a bloodless military coup in 1962. One of the few films made in Burma since the coup, it ranges the country - from the forest where the lumber industry moves on elephant-power, to the Schwedagon Pagoda, largest Buddhist temple in the world, where the country's intellectual elite live a humble monastic life. East Asia's largest, virtually poorest, nation is seen attempting "to create a modern socialistic welfare state while retaining its old traditions." Under Ne Win, the army is "nursemaid of the nation, responsible for everything from the government to street cleaning and feeding the animals to the zoo." The advice and financial aid of foreign governments is shunned. The Chinese and Indians who once dominated trade and industry have been expropriated. And the British remain merely as junior partners in the refineries. Contrasted to Burma's halting social and economic revolution is the state of South Korea, subject of the second half-hour. Here, too, the military is omnipresent, with a government headed by General Park Chung Hee and a mobilized army of 600,000 men - fifth largest in the world. The threat of renewed hostilities with North Korea keeps the country at fever pitch. Demonstrations condemn the "straw puppet" who rules North Korea, and South Koreans apprehended from crossing "The Bridge of No Return" are dealt with severely. Meanwhile, the South Korean economy thrives - exports under General Park have risen from six million to 30 million dollars a year. Unlike the Burmese practice of xenophobia, the South Koreans benefit from the industrial expertise of the Japanese and the financial aid of America, West Germany, and other friendly powers. The program visits Panmunjom, site of the Armistice Commission, where the "demarcation line runs through the conference table." It is here that echoes of the Korean War persist, as in the recent incidents involving the Pueblo and an American plane downed over Korea last month. The program notes: "Most South Koreans have never had it so good, and the growing prosperity, even if slow, consoles many in this country for the lack of democratic process." For Korea, like Burma, is a country under military rule. Korean students "don't demonstrate - they exercise."
produced by Norddeutscher Rundfunk (North German Television) ; National Educational Television presentation ; director-writer, Hans Walter Berg ; NET executive producer, William Weston.

From NET microfiche: The program will consist primarily of footage shot within Biafra by Dutch producer Louis van Gasteren - the last filmmaker to get into Biafra - and will contain other footage of the war obtained by NET. The program will report on an international effort to relieve this starvation and on the difficulties encountered by people trying to give aid to Biafra. From NET microfiche, file C: A panel consisting of former vice president Hubert Humphrey and four college professors discuss China's position in world politics during the past decade and what to expect during the 1970's. Moderator is Harrison E. Salisbury, assistant managing editor of The New York Times. In a panel discussion, held at the University of Minnesota, four college professors who are experts in Asian affairs and former Vice President Hubert Humphrey discuss China's role in world politics during the past decade and speculate on its political future. Besides Humphrey, other panelists are: Ezra Vogel of Harvard University; James Thomson of Harvard University; John Lewis of Stamford University and Donald Zagoria of Hunter College. Moderator is Harrison E. Salisbury, assistant managing editor of The New York Times. Looking back at the events in the Communist world during the 1960's, the panelists concurred with Professor Thomson's position that "Communism as a monolithic force is no longer a world-wide terror." The Sino-Russian dispute "hopefully opens the door to a dtente in U.S.-China relations," he said. "We have a certain neurosis about China. We have to get rid of that," says Professor Lewis. On this theme, Professor Zagoria adds, "We have been creating an image of this huge country with this huge power that is going to overrun the world." The panelists are of the opinion that China would use its nuclear power only as a leverage for bargaining with the world powers and that there is no imminent threat of nuclear war with either the United States or Russia. "China is primarily occupied with its own problems," says Professor Vogel. Despite China's rapid industrialization during the past decade, Professor Zagoria believes that it doesn't have "the sources of capitalization" to become a major world power in the next decade. "For a long time to come, they simply are not going to be in the same power league as Russia and the U.S.," he avers. On the issue of Chinese membership in the United Nations, Humphrey takes a decisive stand in favor of membership. He says, "To have Asia represented only by Nationalist China is really refusing to recognize any of the world realities." Replying to a question from a member of the studio audience, Humphrey states that less of our resources should be spent on containing Chinese expansion in Asia and more on our own national problems. "There are some things we're going to have to trim back," he says. "It's a different world; it's a different China."

produced by the University of Minnesota in cooperation with KCTA-TV, St. Paul, Minn. ; a presentation of National Educational Television ; producer, John G. Stewart ; assistant producer, Susan B. Davis ; director, Donald L. Mischer.
National Educational Television and Radio Center
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche: This program is a study of the conflict between militant black students and what they claim is a traditional, bourgeois-oriented administration at Howard University in Washington, D.C. it charts the nature of the students' complaints against an "irrelevant" education and culminates with the "sleep-in" that closed down the University March 21-24. The program offers the students a rare opportunity to express themselves in creative terms. A film, made by members of the drama department with the advice and facilities of NET, is contained here. The film dramatizes their complaints against the university: Creatively, they feel more involvement with it than with the full-dress Elizabethan plays staged by the drama department; and substantively it details the feelings and attitudes of the black student at Howard. Directed by Howard student Ben Land, the film portrays a Negro boy in the process of defining his world and circumscribing his anger through his relationship with two girls - one black, one white. In a bedroom scene with the white girl, he is plagued by his black consciousness, expressed in the words of Black Power advocate Ron Karenga. The girl, meanwhile, visualizes the idyll of being with him in an open field. Ultimately, the boy returns to the other girl, with whom he is "becoming a person after 400 years" of enslavement. Prior to the film's presentation, we see it being rehearsed in a studio, at a smoke-shrouded train station, and on a freezing hill. At its conclusion, the actors and director discuss with NET producer Dick McCutchen their roles, their true feelings, and their parent's probable reactions. The crisis at Howard is also conveyed in documentary form, as the student frustration builds towards the takeover of the administration building. A scene with President James M. Nabrit, Jr., indicates that chasm separating student goals and university purpose. "There's nothing as strong as an idea whose time has come, and nothing as weak as an idea whose time has passed," explains Mike Harris, an articulate student who becomes a major figure in the documentary. Harris contends that he is "a moderate," since "I'll still talk." Placing the students' demands on a national scale, he calls the work of Stokely Carmichael "the last peaceful attempt to make things come around." Specifically, Harris says, "we want Howard to show us who we are, "especially in the context of their blackness. A source of special complaint to the Howard student is the firing of such professors as Nathan Hare, whose liberality was the apparent reason for his dismissal. Hare, seen here in a professional boxing match subsequent to his firing, explains that man must choose between "making his history and having his history make him." Also appearing on the program are Dr. Kenneth Clark, professor of psychology, City College of New York; Claude Brown, author of "Manchild in the Promised Land"; and Mrs. E. Franklin Frazier, whose late husband wrote the classic study of "The Black Bourgeoisie." Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET Journal - "Color us Black"; Filmed amid the turmoil at Howard University, this documentary studies the black militant movement on campus. Dramatizing the conflict is a film on black-white relations made by students of the University.
a production of National Educational Television ; produced and written by Richard McCutchen.
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche: NOTE: This title was a standalone 1-hour panel discussion and a 4-part series. Program Description (1-Hour Panel): Participants in this hour-long panel discussion, as announced earlier, are Milton Friedman, William Rusher, M. Stanton Evans, and Russell Kirk. Moderator is Sidney Hyman. The discussion involves a definition of "the conservative viewpoint" especially as it applies to the proper use of government authority in such areas as civil rights and urban problems; the formulation of a foreign policy; and the role of the Supreme Court in national affairs. Conservatism, according to Friedman, is based in "the value of the individual as the ultimate entity." Kirk notes that the conservative seeks "a certain balance or healthy tension between the claims of order and the claim of freedom." Throughout the program, the panelist criticizes "big government," as propounded by "the modern liberals." Friedman asserts that "most government extensions of power have added to the power of private interests and not reduced them." He argues, accordingly, that the most effective way to reduce the concentration of private power is "to reduce the role of government." Industrial competition can be fostered by removing tariffs and having free international trade, says Friedman. The panelists agree that Supreme Court justices should not be judged by usual liberal-conservative labels. Instead, says Kirk, a conservative would seek judges who prize self-restraint rather than arrogating authority to the Court. In contemporary terms, Rusher states that the Supreme Court must "make this a livable country - and they better do it." A conservative view of foreign policy, according to Evans, calls for defense of the country "against foreign enemies," not trying "to remake the world in our own image." The problems of the cities, the present welfare system, urban renewal, the minimum wage - all are listed as "the debris of failed liberal social policies" by the panelists. The subject of sex education poses a classic case of the experts versus the parents, with the parents being treated like "blobs of protoplasm," according to Evans. Friedman concludes by defining the conservative credo of freedom in current terms. It would support a volunteer army, decentralization, and a modified federal budget - all of which are supported by the Nixon Administration.
A-2581-82 (from slate at head of film)
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche, C: NET Journal will present an in-depth study of Czechoslovakia in "Czechoslovakia, The Wayward Satellite." (former title: The quiet revolution) Set against a backdrop of Soviet tanks and world-shaking headlines, the program will assess the course of Czechoslovakia's reform movement. The first portion will be devoted to films from German, British, and Czech sources. These films span the first student revolts, economic pressures for change, the ouster of President Antonin Novotny, and the liberalizing influence of First Secretary Alexander Dubcek. Films also portray Dubcek's meetings with Soviet leaders at Cierna and Bratislava, visits by Marshall Tito of Yugoslavia and Walter Ulbricht of East Germany, and the invasion of Czechoslovakia by members of the Soviet bloc. The second half of the program will consist of a panel discussion. Participants will be Professor Uri Ra'anan of the Fletcher School of Diplomacy, Tufts University, and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and Professor Paul Zinner of the University of California. Richard McCutchen will moderate. From NET microfiche, Q: This program studies the Czech reform movement, from its basis in the country's economic, social, and political life to the dramatic confrontations between newly-appointed Communist Party leader Alexander Dubcek and Russian heads of state Aleksei Kosygin and Leonid Brezhnev. The program recounts the meeting with the Soviet leaders and Bratislava, where the fate of Czechoslovakia seemed balanced, with Russian tanks standing ready for a possible conflict. It also covers Dubcek's meeting with other leaders of the Communist world - including Marshall Tito of Yugoslavia and Chairman Walter Ulbricht of East Germany. Despite Dubcek's apparent success at the conference table, the program notes that Czechoslovakia remains economically dependent on Russia, to the point where the Czechs' lucrative steelworks are worthless without Soviet iron ore. Also, the country is presently changing over from coal to oil - a mineral that it imports exclusively from Russia. However, Czechoslovakia is seen in the process of economic reform. Leaders recognize the need of installing informed economists rather than the "party hacks" who filled crucial jobs under the regime of Antonin Novotny, recently deposed as president after a 10-year rule. The program shows the liberalization working in the capital city of Prague, where free press and open meetings are two dramatic manifestations. Perhaps most striking is the existence of KAN, a political "club" which already has more than 40,000 members since it was created as the first organized opposition within the Communist world. Other signs of a new life for Czechoslovakia include the plans for rehabilitating political prisoners, victims of the Novotny regime, who may add an important dimension to the future of Czechoslovakia. The student demonstrations which helped to enunciate the country's readiness for change are also seen here. Among those interviewed in the program are Jiri Manzelka, a leading official in the Czech Communist Party; Jiri Kosta, a noted economist; Emil Zatopek, Olympic gold medalist in the 5,000 meter run, 10,000 meter run, and marathon; Professor Victor Knapp, who is engaged in the rehabilitation movement; and Rudolf Batcek, secretary of KAN. PLEASE NOTE: Unit I stations will be able to air the program on September 9, the date on which the Czech Communist Party holds a special Congress to elect a new central committee - probably ousting the last old-line Stalinists. This fact adds promotional weight to the program.

a National Educational Television production, adapted from films in by Granada Television, Nord Deutscher Rundfunk (North German Television) and Czechoslovakian National Television ; executive producer, Harry McCarthy ; producer, Gordon Thomas.
National Educational Television and Radio Center
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche: Program description This documentary, produced by the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, recreates the historic voyage of Charles Darwin aboard the British ship Beagle to the remote Galapagos Islands, some 600 miles west of Ecuador in the Pacific Ocean. The program utilizes still photographs of Darwin and his times as background to the actual voyage taken by a team of ornithologists, biologists, and CBC crewmen aboard Beagle II, a square-rigged brigantine that retraced Darwin's route. The original trip was begun in 1835 when Darwin was a divinity student with a bent for scientific research. On Galapagos, he found rare species of flora and fauna that sparked his subsequent evolutionary theories, which were formulated in the book, "The Origin of the Species." Undertaking this same journey 130 years later, the CBC team found many of the flora and fauna first observed by Darwin -- land tortoises, Darwin finch, the world's only sea-going lizard, flightless cormorants, penguins, a unique fork-tailed gull, cactus and sunflower trees, inhospitable and moon-like volcanic landscapes. To Darwin, they had been a "living laboratory of evolution," sights unprecedented and inspiring. The documentary records some of these same sights, unaltered after more than a century. Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET Journal -- "Darwin": A recreation of Charles Darwin's historic voyage in 1835 to the Galapagos Islands, a natural laboratory of evolution, in the equatorial zone of the Pacific.
produced by Canadian Broadcasting Corporation ; a National Educational Television presentaiton ; producer, James Murray ; writer, Lister Sinclair ; NET producer, William Weston.
National Educational Television and Radio Center
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche, file D: Program Description: On June 6, 1944, the Allied Forces began a massive invasion of thee European mainland, striking at Normandy, France, and changing the course of World War II. This documentary recounts the event 25 years later with news footage and filmed interviews. Its focus is two American Airborne Divisions -- the 101st and 82nd -- which first dropped onto the French coast in the dawning hours of June 6. The Dutch made film looks at the invasion not only as a major military event, but as a human experience as recalled by its survivors. General Pat Cassidy, then a colonel with the 101st, narrates the program. Also appearing are General Maxwell Taylor, who was commander of the 101st, and has more recently served as US ambassador to south Vietnam; Madame Renaud, wife of the mayor of Sainte Mere Eglise in Normandy, the first French village to be liberated; Father Sampson, the chaplain who is now Head of Chaplains in the Pentagon; and various American soldiers and French natives who recall D-Day. They include John Steele, a paratrooper of the 82nd whose parachute became snagged on the steeple of the Sainte Mere Eglise church; retired Colonel Hank Plitt, the first man dropped behind enemy lines as a pathfinder to mark off drop-zones; Aaron Corper, a munitions carrier abroad the Dutch gunboat HM Flores, the first ship to fire on the Normandy coast; Harrison Summers, sergeant of the 101st who singlehandedly stormed a number of German barracks; Jean Bertot, the first Frenchman born in liberated France on June 6, 1944; Dr. Best, the American paratrooper physician who delivered Bertot under shellfire; and Mrs. Beal, the widow of Colonel Robert Cole, the only American soldier awarded the Medal of Honor in Normandy. Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET Journal -- "D-Day": A retrospective view of the Normandy invasion after 25 years, focusing on the 82nd and 101st Airborne Division. With Generals Pat Cassidy and Maxwell Taylor, paratroopers, other survivors.
produced by NCRV (Dutch Television) ; a National Educational Television presentation ; director and compiled, Jan van Hillo ; NET execuvtive producer, William Weston.
National Educational Television and Radio Center
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche, file D: This program reveals the views and actions of two contemporary opponents: the radical student and the college president. the program was filmed over a ten-day period just prior to Christmas vacation at the University of Connecticut in Storrs, where students had mobilized to protest campus recruitment by outside industry. One film crew stays with the SDS students, recording their views and strategy meetings as they seek self-determination. Another crew remains with the president of the university, Dr. Homer D. Babbidge, Jr., throughout the ten-day period. A month earlier, two demonstrations had been directed against the recruiting activities of the Dow Chemical and Olin Mathieson corporations, resulting in on-campus bloodshed and arrests by the State Police. In December, when the film begins, the action is joined again, with the onset of another recruitment period. The program intimately follows the course of events, detailing the anger, frustration, and opposing attitudes which are fomenting in the period from December 8 to 18 -- not only involving the SDS students and the university president, but other "moderate" and "conservative" students as well. Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET Journal -- "Diary of a Student Revolution": Ten days of confrontation at the University of Connecticut between members of SDS and the president of the university reveal the philosophies of two forces on a collision course over the issue of on-campus industrial recruitment. NET Journal -- "Diary of a Student Revolution" is an NET production. Written and produced by Morton Silberstein ("What Harvest for the Reaper?" and "The Poor Pay More") with Barbara Gordon and Lynne Littman. Edited by Eric Albertson Executive producer: AH Perlmutter
NET journal. Diary of a student revolution.
NET production ; executive producer, AH Perlmutter ; written and produced by Morton Silberstein with Barbara Gordon and Lynne Littman.

Introduction of black & white film by moderator Richard McCutchen. Film is "End of a revolution?," an episode of the television series "World in action" produced by Brian Moser of Granada Television Ltd. and originally broadcast in Great Britain. The film shows events in Bolivia after Che Guevara is killed in a jungle ambush. The questions posed include: Does Che Guevara's death signal the end of a revolution? What is Bolivia's future after the death of Guevara? The film is followed by a discussion with Juan D'Onis (of the New York Times), Normal Gall (journalist who has covered Latin America extensively), and Lee Lockwood, author of "Castro's Cuba, Cuba's Fidel." From NET microfiche (E): This program will be presented in two parts. The first half hour will consist of a documentary filmed in Bolivia at the time of the death of Cuban revolutionary Che Guevara. It will delve into the movement headed by Guevara and will concentrate on the trial of Regis Debray, cohort of Guevara, who was sentenced to a 30-year prison term for allegedly plotting against the Bolivian government. The documentary, which goes inside a Bolivian courtroom where Debray's defense plea is shouted down by spectators, also contains an interview with Debray inside his prison cell. The documentary and the case will be discussed in the second portion of the program. In that portion, panelists are Juan D'Onis of the New York Times, journalist Lee Lockwood, and South American affairs specialist Norman Gall of the Woodrow Wilson School at Princeton University. Moderator is Richard McCutchen.

From playing fields to poetry reading, and from tutorials to tea, this BBC production studies England's most distinguished preparatory school and finds much to recommend it -- notable an independent spirit, fostered by private rooms, an intellectual atmosphere, fine teachers, and freedom to make one's friends (which has, in turn, developed "old boy" network of social and political authority in Britain over the past 500 years). Ranging from Eton during a single day, the program notes many vestiges of tradition: the Eton collars and gowns, which engage the attention of tourists visiting the town; compulsory chapel; the undergraduate hierarchy, which stresses the subservience -- and even corporal punishment -- of new boys by seniors. Tradition notwithstanding, the program finds Eton "The right sort" of school and laments that its example is not nationwide. The program visits a variety of classrooms and tutorial sessions; hears from Eton's critical voice -- the school paper; observes the changing curriculum, with its new emphasis on science; visits the living quarters and dining halls; and follows the boys through numerous social and athletic pursuits -- including cricket and rowing practice, a debating society where the Vietnamese war is the subject, a folk rock a band , and a tea-time discussion of what it means to be an Etonian. "NET Journal -- "Eton" is a presentation of National Educational Television, produced by the British Broadcasting Corporation. NET executive producer: William Weston. Commentary by Rene Cutforth. Sound: David Simpson and Peter Richardson. Photography: Dick Bush. Film editor: Eric Brown.
produced by the British Broadcasting Corporation ; a presentation of National Educational Television ; NET executive producer, William Weston.
National Educational Television and Radio Center
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche, file F: This German-made documentary examines the political and economic state of Taiwan and Thailand -- two countries "Face to Face with China" and confronted with the Chinese Communist problem. Taiwan, under the leadership of Chiang Kai-shek and the Chinese Nationalists prepares to reconquer the homeland while maintaining an island fortress to prevent invasion by the Communists; Thailand, under the leadership of King Pumiphol, simply fears invasion from China. Each depends on the United States for a solution to the Communist problem and each is haunted by the question: "What will happen if the Vietnam War is finally settled and the Americans pull out of Southeast Asia?" The film's first segment looks at the Taiwan government, ruled by General Chiang Kai-shek since 1949 when he fled the mainland; the industrial and technological progress made since the Chinese Nationalist rule; and the resulting general prosperity and advancement of the nation. The film also visits Quemoy, an island much smaller than Taiwan and much closer to the China coast. In addition to its strategic military value, the island which is called "Freedom Fortress" by the Nationalists is used for carrying on a propaganda war with mainland China. Chiang Kai-shek and his family are seen strolling through the palace gardens and there is also an interview with one of his sons, General Chiang We-go, who discusses the prospects of invading the mainland. The second segment focusses on Thailand, which also counts on the United States for support in a resolute stand against Communist China, should it come. It points out that the Communist Chinese have been conducting a program of infiltration and subversion against Thailand for many years, and only with substantial American assistance have the Thais been able to control it. Thailand has also experienced tremendous economic expansion, due mostly to the Vietnam War, increased American aid, and greater world demand for Thai silk, rice, and tin. Increased prosperity and the presence of Americans have disrupted old Thai traditions and mores, but nevertheless, Thais fear life without Americans in Southeast Asia. Narrated by: James Fleming
NET journal. Face to face with China.
North German Television ; NET presentation ; NET executive producer, William Weston ; English adaptation by Arthur Lodge.
NET journal #270--face to face with China.

"A comprehensive report on our snarled airports and hazard-ridden skies, as air traffic grows disproportionately with existing facilities." -- sumamry taken from page 177 of the Jan 12, 1969 The Tennessean (RPAR 2/3/2017). From NET microfiche: This program puts into perspective the problem of increasing air traffic which reached staggering proportion during the hectic tourist season last summer. It examines the difficult role of air controllers faced with jammed airports and skies. And it looks into the reasons air crashes have occurred -- and may continue to occur. From out of the debris of ruined planes and burnt corpses, it reconstructs the events leading to accidents, as seen by survivors, observers, and representatives of both pilots and the airlines. One woman recalls that a stewardess "brushed the flames out of my hair" and led the way to the emergency exit, while her husband perished inside the plane. The accident is diagnosed by a representative of the Airline Pilots Association, who contends that certain positioning of the plane's power controls could force it into a sudden dive, which soon became uncontrollable. In another accident, the absence of a cockpit voice recorder proved fatal. And in a third case, a misreading of the altimeter's small type led to the crash that killed everyone on board. But even if these flaws are overcome, the chance of human error remains. And looming in the future is the threat of such recurrent horrors as mid-air collisions. Other problems facing the airlines are poorly designed airports and sonic boom, a noise from high speed jets that even the best public relations campaign cannot minimize. Airlines are therefore faced with a continuing discrepancy between its dangerous profession and its glamorous image, the program finds. In fact, controllers interviewed on the program stress that airport crowding and delays comparable to last summer's congestion will occur again as the holiday season approaches.
NET journal. Fasten your seat belts--a report on the crisis in the air.
a co-produiction of National Educational Television and the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation ; producer-director, Douglas Leiterman ; associate producer, Ene Riisna.

For viewing purposes, the order is as follows: 1. Reel 1 (371-08-04, MAVIS 2437756, component 1) Cut A-1 is a brief introduction to the film "Fidel" by Paul Niven (approximately 1-1/2 minutes). 2. Reel 2 (371-08-05, MAVIS 2437758, component 1) Cut B-2 is the hour-long film "Fidel." 3. Reel 1 (371-08-04, MAVIS 2437756, component 1) Cut A-3 is the hour-long panel discussion about the film, shown immediately after the film. From NET microfiche, file F: Program Description: This program provides a personal view of Fidel Castro and his attitudes toward government. He is seen as he traverses Cuba in a jeep and a helicopter, stopping to advise farmers, address throngs, confer with leaders, and pause for such diversions as a recollection of his old school days and a game of baseball. In one scene, Fidel commiserates with village people who have been deprived of bus transport and agrees that a new highway is needed. "Where do the women go to give birth?" he asks, and learns that the midwife is away, working in the fields. In another scene, he visits a cattle farm and talks about agriculture. With an old man he recalls the former Batista regime. School teachers treat him to a revoutionary song to the tune of "Glory Glory Hallelujah." And at a rally, sugar cane cutters chant: "Fidel! We will get the 10 million tons!" As he crosses his country, Fidel commutes on his government and his people. He speaks of "the new man" who senses "the importance of collectivity" and says that "he who needs more should receive more; he who needs less should receive less." He explains that he has always been against office methods and spends "most of my time touring the country, informing myself about the people." He recalls his early days, when teachers used "medieval punishments," such as placing weights across a child's knees. Despite his frequent school boy transgressions,he confesses that he received special treatment because his father was a large land holder. Later, at the university, he became "a utopian socialist. Being a Marxist, you have to have a revolutionary vocation." It was only later that "I began to understand imperialism," just as young westerners are doing today, according to Castro. He also reminisces about the revolution -- "a sacrificial fight and a hard one" with his guerrillas in the Sierra Maestra. "At times we were close to complete annihilation." He kept no diary; "I kept everything in my head -- a diary can be dangerous. Most men don't think of their role in history, they think of history as a sub-product of deeds." But at the end of the revolution, he found his most formidable task -- "beginning the revolution from power ... Instinctively, the people knew there would be politics for them. But we ourselves didn't know the magnitude of underdevelopment -- the ocean of necessities." He stresses such government priorities as "getting society off a single crop" -- sugar is now being joined by cattle, citrus fruits, and coffe, Castro says. The program notes the number of emigres waiting to leave Cuba; however, Castro argues that for them America is "not a country of liberty," but "a country of consumer goods" and material advantage. Also seen in the program is a sequence filmed in a rehabilitation prison-farm featuring political prisoners convicted of such crimes as conspiracy and sabotage. Prisoners speak of their crimes, and one charges that he has not received a fair trial. Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET Journal Special - "Fidel": An hour-long profile of Fidel Castro and his personal -- and peripatetic -- government. The Cuban leader is seen advising farmers, addressing throngs, visiting his old school, conferring with his leading spokesmen, and engaging in a game of baseball. Because of station interest, NET is presenting a panel disucssion to follow the hour-long documentary, "Fidel." Participants are: Saul Landau, producer of "Fidel" and co-producer of the 1967 NET Journal "Report form Cuba"; Paul D. Bethel, former CSIA official in Cuba, who is now editor of Latin America Report, and critic of Castro's Cuba; Richard Fagen, professor of political science, Stanford University, who has made extensive visits to Cuba in 1966 and 1968, and who is author of "Cuba: The Content of Political Education" and editor of "Cubans in Exile: Disaffection and Revolution"; and Andres Suarez, professor of political science, University of Florida and author of "Cuba: Castro and Communism," who was formerly chief of the vocational education department, Cuban Ministry of Education, and assistant secretary, Ministry of the Treasury, before the Castro takeover. The discussion, to be taped in Washington, DC, will be moderated by NET correspondent Paul Niven. It will be presented during the second hour of the program.
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche: Program Description: This hour consists of two 30-minute documentaries on India. The first portion of the program scans India at the time of its most recent general election (February 1967), in which Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Congress party was accorded its narrowest majority since the nation's introduction to democracy in 1951. "Experiment in Freedom," produced by North German Television, examines the country's adoption of the democratic system and the problems which that system must cope in an over-populated, underfed nation. The program notes several factors that impede India's experiment in freedom. Primary among them is a conservative attitude based on rigid religious codes, an educational system that discourages questioning, and a hereditary caste system that has been formally abolished without actually losing its hold on the public mind. Adding to these difficulties are the massive red tape of Indian bureaucracy, the slow progress of industry, and the rural conservatism that is symbolized by the sacred cow. In a nation with a multiplicity of languages and religions, only the army has achieved "the mingling of all elements of Indian society - the long-time goal of the government." In a nation rife with superstition, even a progressive village mayor must consult the local astrologer before making policy decisions, the program notes. The program ranges the rural and urban life of modern India, visits schoolrooms and Parliament sessions, and shows the political life of Mme. Gandhi, daughter of the late Prime Minister Nehru, who has led her country's precarious experiment since 1966. "Famine," produced by Rediffusion Television Ltd., is an unstinting report on the Indian State of Bihar, where thousands die during an arid season. Lacking adequate irrigation, the Indians can only grow crops if the bi-annual monsoons come on schedule. In a dry season, there is nothing but the searing heat and the inevitable death of the famine-stricken natives. Shot during a time of famine, this documentary focuses on the suffering children, pot-bellied and spindle-legged, and the ever-present beggars; the farmers waiting for rains that never come; and the pregnant women whose deliveries will only add to the list of underfed. Variety called the program "a harrowing, tragic account ... that deserves the widest currency." The Sun of London asked: "Has television ever produced such an unforgettable scene?" And the Daily Sketch stated: "Jack Gold's production was both unemotional and brilliant. Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET Journal - "Freedom and Famine": Two perspectives into India - one on the state of Bihar, ridden with drought and disease; the other on the country's attempt to function of the democratic system.
National Educational Television and Radio Center
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche (G): Program Description: This program examines the life and influence of Mohandas Karamchand (Mahatma) Gandhi (1869-1948) 100 years after his birth. The first portion of the program utilizes archive photographs and films of the Indian prophet of nonviolence, with narration provided by the celebrated British actor Sir Alec Guinness. The second portion examines Gandhi's revolutionary teachings, as they affect India today. The program contains interviews with: Indian Prime Minister Mrs. Indira Gandhi, who states that Gandhi would "be very deeply upset by the treatment of the Harijans' (untouchables) for whom he did so much." Lord Mountbatten of Burma, the last viceroy to India, who remembers Gandhi's involvement during the conflict between Hindus and Muslims in Bengal, when "his personality saved" the area from further bloodshed. According to Lord Mountbatten, Gandhi was "a saint with a sense of humor." Dr. E. F. Schumacher, economic advisor to the British National Coal Board, who says: "faced with the reality of the poor countries, which have plenty of labor but very little capital, I think Gandhi can be considered the most important economic teacher today." Acharya Ramamurti, one of thousands of Indians now implementing Gandhi's precepts, who describes the transformation of his country from power politics and centralized planning to the prophetic teaching of Gandhi; 'in its attempt to rediscover its soul, India is going back to Gandhi." Paddy Quinn, Gandhi's jailer on three occasions, who remembers the prophet as "a wonderful chapa very shrewd man. You never tried to pull a fast one with him." The film opens in 1931 when Gandhi, "in loin cloth and sandals,' arrives in London for the Round Table Conference as the representative of India's Congress party. His objectives; a struggle against British rule in India, and relief from the nation's overwhelming poverty. The film then retraces his career to his earliest arrest for civil disobedience in 1908, his next years as a lawyer in South Africa, and his efforts to transform the Congress Party into a mass movement. The Salt march in 1930, in which nearly 100,000 people, including Gandhi, were arrested, dramatized his attacks on India's ills. The program then carries forward his quest, through village reform, and through non-violent protest, which mobilized Indian women for the first time. "But Gandhi's greatest struggle and perhaps his greatest defeat was for Hindu-Muslim unity," narrates Guinness. In East Bengal, during the religious conflict, he is seen walking from village to village. He was still seeking unity between the religions when he was shot by a young Hindu in 1948. Twenty-one years after his death, Guinness reports: "Gandhi touched Indian life at so many levels-Hindu-Muslim unity, education, abolition of untouchability. Above all he believed in a decentralized village society, free of exploitation and hatred. How far has India achieved these ideals?" The second half of the film notes the problems that remain, above all, widespread poverty manifested in "the stagnation of village life." But "the position of women has changed dramatically as a result of Gandhi's' leadership;" Gandhi's followers have collected five million acres of land for cultivation by the people; village cooperatives are planned; and through Gandhi's influence, the country is learning that "the aim must be to have production by the masses, not mass p0roduction," according to Dr. Schumacher. In addition, "his ideas on the place of machinery in village life are being developed" (we see mechanical plows at work in the village of Sevagram, Gandhi's last home). And Gandhian principles of education, based on practical training, are being implemented in some schools. 'I think the future lies with Gandhi,' concludes Dr. Schumacher. Suggested Newspaper Listing: - NET Journal-"Gandhi's India:" Commemorating the 100th anniversary of the birth of the late Mahatma Gandhi, the documentary records his contribution to Indian independence and to non-violence worldwide. Includes additional interviews with principals in the Gandhi movement and Gandhi's associates: G. Hamachandran (co-worker), Dr. Sushila Nayar (Gandhi's personal physician), Donald Groom, Asha Devi Aryanayakan, and Pyarelal (Gandhi's secretary), and The Reverend R. R. Keithahn, an American missionary who has worked in India for forty years..
produced for Intertel by the British Broadcasting Corporation ; National Educational Television presentation ; producer, Jonathan Stedall ; writers, Hallam Tennyson and Jonathan Stedall.
National Educational Television and Radio Center
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche, file G: Program Description: This hour-long documentary has been culled from three German-made films tracing the reconstruction of Germany in the years 1945-49. It focuses on the economic, social, and political life of the West German people, who were left with tons of rubble and the weight of their collective guilt at the end of World War II. In personal terms, there were 20 million homeless people in the Allied sectors alone. Another 12 million soldiers and civilians became prisoners of war, remaining in concentration camps for as long as 11 years. The Germans had also to bear the full truth about the concentration camps in which nine million people had died. Their entire nation was, in fact, on trial at Nuremberg and in denazification proceedings that followed. But buoyed by their own spirit and by Allied assistance, the Germans, as the program illustrates, dug out from the rubble, rebuilt their own schools and universities, and restored their own press and their own industry. There are ingenious ways of overcoming a shortage of materials: old helmets are converted to colanders, and kilns are used to burn charcoal for emergency heat. At the same time, the conqueror's will weakens. Originally designated as an agricultural nation only, the Germans are helped to restore their industrial prowess, and finally Allied support grows to epic proportions with the Berlin airlift - "the first favorable world attention Germany has had in years." Political self-determination returns at about the same time. Germans are seen lining up for the polls in a manner reminiscent of their earlier queues for the scanty food rations of 1945 and 1946. Finally in 1949, the process is restored with the appearance of a new constitution and the Federal Republic of West Germany, headed by Konrad Adenauer. The shadow of World War II remains, however, in a divided Germany. In personal terms, there are the split families and the hordes seeking entry into West Germany from the far side of the Iron Curtain. Suggested Newspaper Listing "Germany After the Fall": The economic and social reconstruction of Germany from the ashes of World War II is seen thorough German eyes.
NET journal. Germany after the fall.
NET presentation, based on documentaries produced by Nord Deutscher Rundfunk ; NET executive producer, William Weston
NET journal. [No. 241], Germany after the fall.
