Building the bomb segment statement of responsibility: BBC-TV ; for NET ; producer, RW Reid ; writer, Anthony Jay. From NET microfiche: Program Description: The first segment of the program will feature pictures from the "Hiroshima and Nagasaki" Exhibition, held at the New York Cultural Center from May 12 to June 21, 1970. The exhibition commemorated the 25th anniversary of the bombings. Visitors to the exhibition will offer their comments and reactions to the bombings. The segment will consist of excerpts from the five-year-old BBC film, "Building the Bomb." About a half-hour of this hour-long documentary, originally broadcast by NET December 6, 1965, will be shown. The film examines the development of the first atom bomb, probes the consciences of the scientists who worked on it, and shows the actual mushroom cloud over Hiroshima 25 years ago. This film - the only record of the first wartime atomic bombing - was taken by a young scientist, Harold Agnew, who flew with the Hiroshima mission and took along his 16mm camera. "Building the Bomb" explores the political and military strategy behind the construction of the bomb. Since Germany was the scene of the world's most advanced atomic work, it soon became clear that a race was on to beat Hitler to the atomic bomb. A project known as Manhattan District, which utilized many Jewish physicists fleeing Nazi rule, was set up at an eventual cost of $2 billion. Hitler was defeated before the bomb was completed and the decision had to be made whether to use it against Japan. The physicists, of whom five are interviewed in this documentary, tried to make politicians see the consequences of using the bomb. The physicists interviewed are: the late J. Robert Oppenheimer, head of the Los Alamos laboratory of the Manhattan Project; Edward Teller, the Hungarian emigrant who later became the "father" of the Hydrogen Bomb; Harold Agnew; Emilio Serge, an Italian who fled to America; and Werner von Heisenberg, who continued to work on the German uranium project during the war. Bulinding the bomb credit: Narrator: Rene Cutforth The program closes with a 16-minute film, taken by the Japanese, showing the death and destruction caused by the bomb and the incredible suffering of those left maimed in the ensuing days. It was confiscated by the US Army, held for 20-years, and was released only several months ago. NOTE: The film shows many harrowing scenes of maimed and burned bodies. The bomb, dropped on Hiroshima on August 6, 1945, killed 100,000 people, and injured another 100,000. "Near the center people became nothing. Near the center, there was no sound." At the center, the temperature was as hot as the sun. Three days later, another bomb was dropped on Nagasaki, killing 50,000. A Japanese girl who witnessed the suffering comments: "I think if I'm in hell it's like this . Many people run . Many people looking awful. Skin come off . No faces, no eyes . Many people going to the river. I watch them. Many people drinking water. But they fall in and die." The camera captures unbelievable scenes, scarcely bearable to watch - devastated buildings; the desperate, expressionless faces of children receiving medical care; the skulls and skeletons of persons burned to death when a trolley derailed and burst into flames; the dead melted eyeballs of a middle-aged woman seen when the doctors pry open her eyelids. The funeral narration lists the statistics of casualties and ghastly descriptions of the human suffering. Events, almost preternatural in character began to occur after the twelfth day when the effects of radiation on human and plant life set in. Wounds began to open wider. People who had not seemed sick before became violently ill. "Women saw their hair come out in handfuls in their combs . Their skin fell off in glove-like pieces." Lush, green vegetation grew wildly in the center of the city. "As people were dying of radiation sickness, the cities were blanketed with flowers." NETJournal #283 - Hiroshima-Nagasaki" is a production of National Educational Television. Producer: William Weston Narrator: Richard McCutchen Suggested Newspaper Listing: The 25th anniversary of the bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki will be commemorated in this hour-long program. The human suffering brought about by the bomb, captured on film by the Japanese and shown for the first time on American television will form a portion of the program.
National Educational Television ; producer, William Weston.
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche: The BBC-TV documentary, widely hailed in Britain, examines the development of the first atom bomb, probes the consciences of the scientist who worked on it, and shows hitherto unseen film of that first, fantastic mushroom cloud over Hiroshima 20 years ago. This film - the only record of the first atomic bomb - was taken by a young scientist, Harold Agnew, who flew with the Hiroshima mission and took along his 16mm camera. BUIDLING THE BOMB spans a crucial decade in man's history - beginning in the 1930s with the growing scientific realization that vast amounts of energy could be harnessed from the atom, and ending with the failure of the physicists to draw politicians' attention to the consequences of the use of the bomb - and finally Hiroshima. During the 1930s, Germany was the scene of some of the world's most advanced atomic work and it soon became clear that a race was on to beat Hitler to the atomic bomb. But many of Hitler's top physicists were Jews and they began fleeing to Britain and the United States (taking their nuclear know-how with them) to escape the terror of the Nazis. In the United States, a project known as Manhattan District was set up to beat Hitler - at an eventual cost of an unprecedented $2 billion. The NET presentation contains contemporary newsreel clips, reconstructed events, and interviews with such scientists as J. Robert Oppenheimer, Edward Teller, and two Nobel prize winners - Emilio Serge, an Italian and Werner von Heisenberg, a member of the German team. "Building the Bomb" is a 1965 public affairs presentation from National Educational Television, produced by BBC-TV. Its producer is RW Reid and its writer Anthony Jay. Rene Cutforth narrates it.
BBC ; producer, R.W. Reid ; writer, Anthony Jay.
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche, file H: Program Description: Haroldson LaFayette Hunt is the American success, a grandfatherly Horatio Alger with a Dallas drawl. He was born in Illinois, son of a Confederate war veteran. Later he drifted west, worked at odd jobs, began speculating in cotton farmland, went broke, then arrived in the Southwest in time for the oil boom. There, after several failures, a single well in the East Texas oil fields became the basis of his success. Now, almost forty years later, he is perhaps America's richest man. His business interests extend from food products to football, and from property to propaganda. It is in the latter area that he has earned his second reputation - as the "rightest" man in America. He has backed a number of self-announced right-wing political causes, and he uses the media to make known his views (on liberty, freedom, piety, Americanism, and the constant threat of Communism). Such programs as "Facts Forum," "Life Line," and "Answers for Americans" - all bear the HL Hunt sponsored trademark from sponsor's message to political analysis. The views of HL Hunt? He has seldom voiced them publicly - despite his fervor and his interest in the mass media. However, in a rare interview with James Fleming for KUHT, Houston, HL Hunt expresses himself candidly on his wealth, his politics, and his view of history in the following manner: About the John Birch Society: "I am quite generally in favor of anyone that is fighting Communism and as they have weaknesses, as they do things that I don't approve of, why then I still don't want to be critical of them." About President Johnson: "...since he has been elected...he has been dominated by the Negro contingent...and labor and just three or four important minorities." About the mass media: "...the line should be drawn between people that love liberty and are for the freedom system and the society which has made America great and the newspapers, radio, TV stations, networks are largely in the hands of, we'll say, the enemy of that system." About the Warren Commission: "...it was set up three days after the Daily Worker ... called for it to be set up. So that is a very unfavorable start for it." About the presidency: "... he (Calvin Coolidge) turned in the last successful administration and then when asked why I say that, there was no subversive build-up during (his) seven years in office." Also appearing on the program are Dr. Franklin Littell, president of Iowa Wesleyan College and chairman of the Institute of American Democracy, and Charles Baker, executive director of IAD - an organization "devoted to opposing extremism of the right and left," according to the program. Mr. Baker discusses a derogatory advertisement placed in a Dallas newspaper on the day of President Kennedy's visit. "One of the persons paying for the publication of this ad was a member of Mr. Hunt's family ... (This ad) helped contribute to the atmosphere in which we have unsavory developments instead of healthy debate and healthy disagreement. The same member of the family also owns a portion of Robert Welch, Incorporated, which published 'American Opinion,' the John Birch Society magazine." Says Dr. Littell: "... Mr. Hunt, if he didn't have so much money, would be a rather eccentric old gentleman. The thing that makes him so dangerous really is the kind of persons he supports, the kinds of organizations who are much more extreme, much more dangerous than his opinions would ever be. Reporter: James Fleming Suggested Newspaper Listing: "NET Journal - HL Hunt - The Richest and Rightest": Oil mogul HL Hunt speaks out on his wealth, his political patronage, the John Birch Society, and the Communist threat in a rare and revealing interview with reporter James Fleming.
NET journal. H.L. Hunt--the richest and the rightest.
KUHT, Houston ; for National Educational Television ; producer, William Weston ; director, James Bauer ; script by Arthur Lodge.
H.L. Hunt--the richest and the rightest.

From NET microfiche, file H: This documentary probes the effect of the Vietnam War on one community - Charlottesville, VA. The program, produced for the weekly "NET Journal" series, studies the attitudes and emotions of a single American city towards the war in Vietnam. From an American Legion meeting to a ministers' conclave, and from a University of Virginia teach-in to the mother of a dead soldier, the documentary grasps one community's range of feelings and widespread uncertainty about the war. The strongest pro-war feelings are voiced at a meeting of the American Legion. Elsewhere, the Junior Chamber of Commerce is planning to "adopt" a unit in Vietnam. Members of the local reserve unit support the war but prefer to continue at their jobs at home. The mother of a dead soldier also justifies the war's continuance. And, throughout the town, most of the residents accept the country's commitment abroad. The war's most eloquent opposition is voiced at a University teach-in and a meeting between local ministers. Elsewhere, dissent, confusion, and frustration prevail - at a cocktail party, between high school government classes, even between two veterans of Vietnam.

a production of National Educational Television ; taped through the facilities of WETA and Logos Limited ; executive producer, A. H. Perlmutter ; producer-writer, John O'Toole ; associate producer, Lisa Zucker ; director, Robert D. Squier.
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche: Program Description: In this program, filmed at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge, the BBC takes a highly critical look at America's foremost engineering school. It includes interviews with students, who describe the pressures and impersonality of MIT, a school that they "respect" rather than "love," a kind of "machine," they maintain, where there is "an amazing amount of work, and an amazing amount of competition." One student charges: "They pound math and science into your head six or seven hours a day. They don't care how much emotion, how much creativity you have left." Another says simply "Tech is hell." But BBC admits that the school succeeds in its aims: two-thirds of MIT students go on to graduate school, thus preserving the "vitality of American science"; its involvement with military projects has become big business; and its prestige has drawn hundreds of electronics firms to the Boston area. Yet, says the BBC, the school has "a sense of urgency, rather than a sense of history ... It runs on freedom, wealth, and overwork. Beyond that, the only pattern is that there is no pattern." Implicit in these statements is a critical view of American science which, the BBC feels, may outrun itself in its race for progress. Commentator Derek Cooper remarks: "For the engineer, the biggest problem is what people need" - while a mlange of neon signs appears on the screen, and a babble of disc jockeys is heard. The symbol of this world is the computer which can even make music. In fact, says the narrator, "MIT seems to be drowning in a sea of computers." Even the students' pastimes are described in hectic terms: dancing frenetically, going through and ROTC drill, using the student ration station. The latter is a refreshingly giddy interlude.
NET journal. How to be first.
produced by BBC-TV, England ; a presentation of National Educational Television ; NET producer, William Weston.
National Educational Television and Radio Center
National Educational Television and Radio Center

"Study of a young woman's moral confrontations with reference to accepted standard of conduct in today's society." --- taken from Detroit Free Press 25 May 1969 (RPAR 9/20/2016). From NET microfiche, file I: Program Description: This program studies a young Canadian woman who challenges established mores while living with a filmmaker in New York's East Village. The protagonist is a practicing Catholic, who attended a convent before studying at the University of Toronto. But despite her religious conviction, she wishes to live with a man without considering marriage. In the documentary, she revisits scenes of her youth - the convent school, the college, and her parents' home in Quebec City - weighing tradition against her present life. She also visits with her former parish priest. In New York, she discusses her "new morality" with three "spiritual counselors" - anthropologist Margaret Mead, sociologist Jessie Bernard, and militant feminist Ti-Grace Atkinson. As narrator, Margaret Mead also seeks to present her thoughts while the film ranges New York City, form the streets of the East Village to the Cloisters and their surrounding woods.
NET journal. If I don't agree, must I go away?
NET, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation ; NET executive producer, Harry McCArthy ; producer-director, Peter Pearson.

From NET microfiche, file I: Program Description; The program draws an intimate profile of Dr. Achmed Sukarno, liberator and dictator of Indonesia, who now, the program sees as, "a puppet ... who will dangle from strings held by a couple of his generals." The story encompasses the past two years in Indonesia, during which Sukarno's grandiose schemes have virtually bankrupted the country, and during which the "new order" has emerged, committed to a strong, militantly anti-Communist nation with Sukarno as its figurehead. Led by Generals Suharto and Nasution and backed by a politically-rabid student body, the new order took over in counter-revolt against the Communists in late 1965. A Communist coup, backed by Red China and apparently tolerated - if not encouraged - by Sukarno - failed after two of the eight key anti-Communist generals escaped assassination. The people then martyred the murdered generals and the five-year-old daughter of Suharto, who was also killed by the Communists, and ignited a popular - and bloody - assault against the revolutionaries. (Note: Page 2 is missing from the NET microfiche.)
National Educational Television and Radio Center

"NET DOCUMENTARY 64: NET JOURNAL: "Justice and the Poor" surveys criminal justice system and its structural shortcomings 20-9D"--J. Fred MacDonald inventory. "The legal double standard---the gap between justice for the wealthy and the poor. Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas is interviewed in this 1968 report. "--Tvguide.com From NET microfiche: Program Description: For the poor, "justice" too often means arbitrary, even brutal, treatment by the police; long periods of detention as a result of an inequitable bail system; and lawyers who are less qualified or less involved than those who represent wealthy clients. These are the findings of NET's "Justice and the Poor," an hour-long report on inequities - and reforms - in the justice system. The first portion of the program is devoted to the issue that has resounded through the summer riots - police brutality. In Washington, DC, a Negro boy recreates the killing of a friend, Clarence Booker, after a policeman had apprehended him in the act of stealing cookies. In a New York City youth house, other boys describe their experience with the police. The behavior of police during the Newark riots is shown in a film sequence, following which the police commissioner of Oakland, California, argues that there has "not been one proven case of police brutality," and, quite the contrary, in Oakland, one out of three police officers has been assaulted in the line of duty. In Palo Alto, California, NET visits a meeting at which the police and youths discuss attitudes and conditions. Lt. Moran of the Palo Alto police force explains that by establishing trust, the officer may eliminate a potential riot. The next section of the film, devoted to the bail system, depicts detention facilities in both New York and Columbus, Ohio, and presents opinions from attorneys, a prison priest, and other legal authorities. Herbert Sturz of the VERA Foundation notes that many poor people, for whom the smallest bail outlay is impossible, "spend more time in jail before trial than after." Prior to the trial, says Sturz, "their crime is that they're poor." Unfortunately, according to Bernard Botein, head of the New York Appellate Court, the system remains unchanged because "judges sit on their status quo." Under the leadership of VERA, some bail reforms have been instituted in New York City. Many youths are freed from detention without bail after promising to report regularly to a minister or other temporary guardian. New York Department of Correction Commissioner McGrath notes that "we'll always need some kind of detention facility" for "individuals who are a menace to the community," but "we should have more natural facilities - not these monkey cages." NET then hears form Supreme Court Judge William O. Douglas who observes that "many of the laws have a built-in bias against the poor," since the "establishment writes the laws" and "the poor aren't articulate" to their legal needs. The poor, however, are getting some assistance from anti-poverty groups - such as Mobilization for Youth, which has a roving truck advising New York City residents of their legal rights. MFY is also working with slum area tenants who are now entitled to take over their dwellings for the purpose of making repairs not provided by the landlord. In Houston, all lawyers are available to the poor thorugh an IBM system which designates the counsel for a given case. Other projects seen in the film include the Ombudsman in Nassau County, New York; the Public Defender System in Philadelphia (NET actually goes inside the courtroom here to film a policeman's testimony); and the Lower East Side Action Project, which oversees the activities of local youths and is often successful in gaining their release from jail. NET JOURNAL - JUSTICE AND THE POOR is a production of National Educational Television, produced and written by Morton Silverstein. Executive producer: A. H. Perlmutter. ?
NET journal. Justice and the poor.
a production of National Educational Television ; producer-writer, Morton Silverstein ; executive producer, A. J. Perlmutter.

From NET microfiche, file K: Program Description: BBC reporter Alan Whicker visits the oil-rich country of Kuwait on the Arabian Peninsula, where 500 air-conditioned palaces stretch across the desert and the ruling sheikh must ask for his country "How do you spend 600,000 pounds a day?" The answer, Whicker finds, is in an "ultimate welfare state," where school children are even provided with free pocket money, and where their families pay no taxes, and are accorded free health services, and even free telephones. With the exception of the Bedouins, hereditary nomads who still live in the inhospitable desert, everyone has some share in Kuwait's gushing wealth. The modernizing of Kuwait has been achieved since the government paid exorbitant prices for old dwellings and replaced them with the sort of "pink, mauve, and blue space-age monsters" that stretch across a new suburbia. Whicker questions whether the sudden infusion of wealth is good for the Kuwaiti people, who have absorbed the wealth derived from oil, but who have been forced to import technicians and laborers in order to keep the country moving forward. Basically, he contends, Kuwait is an idle society, "floating on an ocean of oil." (Its fields are the source of fuel for two of every three cars in Britain alone, and its investments are vital to the stability of the British pound, according to Whicker.) Despite this sybaritic atmosphere, Kuwait has recently prohibited the sale of liquor, a fact that distresses cabaret owners and increases bootlegging multifold. In a country with a thousand millionaires among a population of 450,000, Whicker notes opulence everywhere. He conducts interviews with some of the wealthy sheiks, the rich young men of Kuwait, an economic advisor, and a British widow who compares the two Kuwait's - before and after the discovery of oil at the end of World War II.
produced by the British Broadcasting Corporation ; a presentation of NET ; producer-director, David S. Rea ; NET producer, William Weston.
National Educational Television and Radio Center

Surveys the accomplishments of the civil rights movement during the one year after the dramatic Selma-to-Montgomery march and the ensuing voting rights act of 1965, as observed in the status of tenant farmers whose average earnings are less than $1,000 per year, and who live in constant debt to white plantation owners and the company store. Explains that the rural Negro is no less hungry, no better educated and no more powerful politically than he was then. Urges that the Federal Government create more jobs, allocate poverty-funds more equitably, and police the agriculture department more effectively.
NET journal. Lay my burden down.
National Educational Television and Radio Center
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche, file L: Members of today's student generation, subject of constant analysis by the nation's media, depict their own lives in this unique film. The setting is the University of California at Berkeley, where the Free Speech Movement began in 1964, and where frequent demonstrations have since convulsed the campus. But the emphasis in this documentary is not political but personal - despite the People's Park War which rages during the action of the film. The students on whom the film focuses are themselves involved in the production of the film, and accordingly, they are seen with cameras, tape recorder, and editing equipment at they seek to "Heighten the experience of what goes on at Berkeley." Each of the students was a member of a class in broadcasting and political thought which was taught by Paul Kaufman, NET executive producer on leave to the university. It was during this class that he students challenged media coverage of their generation and were given the opportunity by NET to shape their own experience on film. Within the film, students probe the gap between themselves and their parents, the quest for a more private existence, black-white relationships, and politics and the police. The extra-marital relationship of Irl and Cindy, a pair of Berkeley seniors, is featured in the documentary. Their lives involve a quest for freedom within an equal relationship which shuns the rigidity of marriage. Finally, in a reaction against their environment they consider an unimpeded life in the woods. Cindy remarks: "Ecology is the key answer. People aren't going to accept politics anymore." Charles, another of the principals, finds himself turning from revolution and seeking to "lose my identity." This state is probed during a psychedelic dream, in which Charles goes backwards through the "tunnel of time." But even in the dream there are images of riots and the antagonistic faces of National Guardsmen; thus, the fantasy world merges into the real world. The gap between students and their parents is also probed as Ava is seen filming her parents in San Francisco. "The Ava they know isn't me," she notes, explaining that they want her to marry a nice doctor and are unable to identify with her own interests. Sam, a black Nigerian who has lived in Georgia and California, argues against violence, citing the "lessons of history." Sam also discusses his earlier life in Georgia and his relationships with white girls. "I'm through with a propaganda crusading trip, trying to prove the humanity of the black man," he explains, recalling girls who sought to make him acceptable to their parents. He notes that his present involvements with white girls avoid any such patronizing attitudes. Dave, a sixth protagonist, is seen in relation to the People's Park War, as he seeks to define his own political stance - especially after he goes to Santa Rita detention center and interviews students who have been beaten by police.
National Educational Television and Radio Center
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche, file L: This program is a three-sided study of Buddhism in Asia, conducted by Adrian Cowell of ATV, London. Buddhism, one of the world's great religions with an estimated 150 million adherents, is centered in the Asian culture, following the teachings of its original prophet, Gautama Buddha. In the main, these teachings involve an intense meditation through which the believer destroys the idea of self and, as Cowell notes, "his mind merges with the life principle of the universe." This selflessness is demonstrated through the daily ritual of a farmer in Thailand, meditating in the hour before dawn, engaging in a conscious act of eating his rice, and talking to the trees as he drives off to till his filed. The film then depicts the more festive aspects of Theravada Buddhism: a "fare from peaceful" water festival, a "meaningless but harmless" ritual of presenting gifts to the Buddha as a form of spiritual savings club," and a ceremony of pouring water on the Buddha. The next segment studies Tibetan Buddhism, a religion in exile since the Chinese Communists overthrew the Dalai Lama in 1959. Here, Buddhism is centered in the bodhisattvas, or monks, who appease the suffering of mankind by their good deeds, it is a passive religion, epitomized by the great bodhisattva, the Dalai Lama. However, the film questions whether this religion is "an asset or hindrance to government" since it can only survive in isolated valleys when faced with a concrete threat such as communism. The segment contains film clips of the Chinese Communist attack on the monasteries of Tibet and on the exiled Dalai Lama leading the faithful in Nepal. The third segment reveals a totally different kind of Buddhist - the Sokagakkai of Japan, followers of the thirteenth-century disciple Nichiren. A religion that "sprang from the docks and factories of Tokyo," Sokagakkai has become a political force in Japan, rallying its fanatical believers through such materialistic beliefs as the promise that "faith can cure your ulcer and get you a promotion." The Gakkai are seen on a pilgrimage to Mount Fuji at a Tokyo rally where Cowell remarks that "religious fervor can carry "What could the Gakkai do if they were to organize Japan the way they organize themselves?
produced by ATV, London ; a presentation of National Educational Television ; director, Adrian Cowell ; NET producer, William Weston.
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche: On the campus of Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge, head guru Timothy Leary and MIT communications physiology professor Jerome Lettvin debate the psychological, physiological, and moral value of LSD. Leary, a former Harvard professor of psychology, has been experimenting with LSD and other psychedelic drugs for more than four years. He now brands himself as the leader of the League for Spiritual Discovery, appears in the attire of a mystic, and discourses from the Yoga position. Leary speaks in darkness and his presentation is given visual emphasis by a combination of films, which attempts to recreate the observer's view of a "trip' from the outside, and slides which attempt to anatomize the actual LSD experience from the inside. Leary's message, given a witty and compelling presentation while lights whirl and colors become contorted on the screen, is the familiar: "Drop out, turn on, and tune back in again." Leary describes "turning on" as the true sacrament, involving a change in the sensory equipment as practiced by prophets for thousands of years. In the past, sensory change has involved such means as flagellation, solitude, music, sexual abstinence, or fasting; today, "the sacrament is a series of chemicals A sacrament is always a risk What isn't?" Leary asks, calling LSD "the safest Russian roulette in the house" - preferable to such "Russian roulettes" as "television waves, Vietnam, and polluted air." The ultimate challenge, says Leary, is "dropping out." Madison Avenue, he says, "tells you to tune in and turn on but don't drop out." Leary calls on the college students to drop out on the current educational system, which "does damage to your neurological system," and on other "menopausal games," such as voting and work. "What difference does it make?" he asks. "Remember that peace candidate (Lyndon Johnson) we voted for?" Leary concludes, "This is the age of consciousness Men have finally caught on - it doesn't matter as much what goes on out there as what goes on in here." "What goes on in here" is an irreparable "loss of judgment," according to Lettvin, who offers a dramatic rebuttal to Leary when he takes over the debater's podium. Lettvin, roaming around Leary's grinning cross-legged form, describes his adversary as "a vicious tool of the devil." The crisis, says Lettvin, is "not scientific but moral." Countering Leary's Russian roulette metaphor, Lettvin says, "Does the navel really replace TV?"
NET journal. LSD: Lettvin vs. Leary.
produced by WGBH-TV for National Educational Television ; producer, Austin Hoyt.
NET journal. [1967-11-20]. LSD: Lettvin vs. Leary.
WGBH Media Archives and Preservation Center

Summary3: Live debate on drug use, the devil and dropping out between Timothy Leary (A Former Harvard psychology professor) and Jerome Lettvin (chemist, physician, MIT professor). Included the short film "The Psychedelic Experience" with music by Ravi Shankar. 1967. Won the Tom Phillips Award for Best Television Public Service competition sponsored by the UPI Broadcasters Association of Massachusetts.

From NET microfiche, file M: This program charts the rise of El Cordobes, "illiterate millionaire" and daredevil of the bull ring. The film, made by the British Broadcasting Corporation, captures the reckless art of this Spanish idol, who has "often suffered face down in the sand beneath the bull's horns." His falls educe gasps; his passes call forth floods of "oles"; and his kills are celebrated with a waving of handkerchiefs and cries of "Manolo." Narrator Alan Whicker comments on the Algeresque rise of Manuel Benitez, the poor boy from Seville who became the celebrated El Cordobes after his first "desperate leap" into a bull ring. On that occasion, he appeared in the Madrid ring illegally and was rewarded with a night in jail. Since then, he has "broken through the melancholy mystique surrounding all matadors in and out of the ring" and has become "a public fetish and an industry." He has also been "the product of his publicity," says Whicker. The adulation that attends this most feted of Spaniards is also conveyed in the film, as El Cordobes returns to his home district in Seville and ranges the great bull-fighting cities of Spain.
produced by the British Broadcasting Corporation ; NET presentation ; producer, Kevin Billington; scrpipt by Alan Whicker.
National Educational Television and Radio Center
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche: This documentary focusses on the men working to combat cancer in England today. Made by Redifussion Television, Ltd., it observes them in their laboratory studies with mice, rats, beetles, computers and microscopes; at their weekly seminars, exchanging their findings on various aspects of cancer research; and in informal discussions of causes, symptoms, and occasional cures. The program investigates the work of Dr. Denis Burkitt, which has led to the conclusion that at least one cancer is virus-induced. It visits the Chester Beatty Research Institute of Sutton, where experiments in immunizing rats and sheep may lead to a cancer cure for humans. It also notes British research with other drugs that may help to cure some forms of cancer. Above all, the documentary is about the men who perform cancer research: their successes and failures, their hopes and the limitations imposed by this fatal disease. These doctors include Lazlo Lajtha, Peter Alexander, Robert Harris, Richard Bulbrook, and John Hayward. Cancer, which is responsible for one in every five deaths remains an overwhelming challenge to the medical researcher. However, the film notes considerable success in the fields of virology, chemotherapy, and immunology; it is on these facets that the film concentrates.
National Educational Television and Radio Center
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche (M): This program is a special report on riots in Newark and other American cities. It consists of two parts: the first is a 90-minute dialogue between Negro spokesmen and white community leaders, organized by NET in Newark just after the riots in an effort to relieve continuing tensions and to work toward solution of the city's festering problems; the second part is a 30-minute interpretative discussion taped in Washington, DC, one week later and enlisting leading authorities on problems in urban affairs and civil rights who place the Newark meeting in the larger perspective of national problems. Part I presents the Newark meeting itself which was attended by 20 panelists and an audience of some 200 local residents - many of whom participate in the heated exchanges on such subjects as police brutality, housing, education, unemployment, and racial attitudes. Leon Lewis, station director of radio station WLIB, moderates this section. Panelists include: Donald Malafronte, assistant to the mayor of Newark; Albert Black, head of The Human Relations Commission; City Councilman Frank Addonizio; Timothy Still, head of the Newark antipoverty program; Robert Curvin, former head of Newark CORE; Richard Lynch, vice president, New Jersey AFL-CIO; Phil Hutchins, Student Non-Violent Coordinating Committee; Allan Sagner, president of Beth Israel Hospital; Malcolm Talbot, vice president, Newark-Rutgers University; the Reverend Kim Jefferson, Council of Churches; and Msgr. Thomas Carey, Queens of Angels Church. Part II consists of a discussion taped in Washington, DC and moderated by Richard McCutchen of NET. Participants are John Field, director, Community Relations Service of US Conference of Mayors, and former executive director of the President's Commission on Equal Employment Opportunity; and John Buggs, deputy director of Model Cities Administration, US Department of Housing and Urban Development, and former executive director, Human Relations Commission of Los Angeles.
National Educational Television ; executive producer, A. H. Perlmutter ; producers, Jack Willis, Jim Karayn ; director, Robert Squier.
National Educational Television and Radio Center
National Educational Television and Radio Center

Debate between UCLA and Dartmouth teams on serving in Vietnam. From NET microfiche (M): Program Description: Here is information based on the taping yesterday of the debate between Dartmouth College and the UCLA at UCLA's student union on the topic "Resolved: Opponents of the war in Vietnam should refuse to serve if drafted." On the affirmative were Tom Brewer and John Isaacson of Dartmouth, on the negative were Claude Fischer and Elden Rosenthal of UCLA. Dartmouth's case was founded on the individual's right in a democracy to rely on his own conscience in making a moral decision. The affirmative maintained that a significant number of people believe that the government should not force them to kill in a particular case of Vietnam. "These individuals believe that to serve is something less than human," Isaacson said. He charged that objectors "must choose to act against their conscience with full knowledge of the consequences." UCLA's team maintained that US citizens have joined a society basically for physical protection and that they owe a return protection for that shelter. "Our position in Vietnam is vital to the stability of Southeast Asia," Fischer said. Unless young people of draft age support our military position, Fischer charged, "then military in the communist world will be encouraged." Dartmouth's team received a unanimous decision for skill in constructive speeches, cross examination, and rebuttal. Judges were debate coaches John De Bross, University of Southern California; Robert Shrumm, Boston College; and Tom McClain, Northwestern University.
a production of National Educational Television ; producer, Ned Schnurman ; director, Allan Muir.
Opponents of the war in Vietnam should refuse to serve if drafted.
Resolved: Opponents of the war in Vietnam should refuse to serve if drafted.
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche (N): This program, filmed during the Liberal Party Convention in Ottawa on April 4-6, offers a profile of Pierre Elliott Trudeau, the man chosen to replace Prime Minister Lester Pearson who is due to retire. Trudeau, alternately described by the press as a playboy and as a flaming liberal, states some of his goals for Canada in interviews both before and after his nomination. "I'd rather be the man for tomorrow," he says, "today's half-past." He promises radical solutions to new problems, but suggests that Canadians "stop being hypocritical" in hoping to censure America's involvement in Vietnam while preserving their present standard of living through contract with America. Trudeau, who was once denied entry into the US after a visit to Moscow, credits "this time, this people, this party" for giving a chance to "a little orphan," who was "a political outcast for 15 years." This program also captures the excitement and in-fighting of a convention and contains an interview with Mr. Pearson.
NET journal. New leader in Canada.
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche: On a day in 1963, Ruth First, South African journalist and mother of three children, was suddenly detained while leaving a Johannesburg library. After a search of her home, which revealed one banned magazine, she was taken to jail and sentenced under the "90-day" law. Here began a solitary confinement lasting 117 days, during which Mrs. First endured the mental torment of being held for an unstated crime, attempted suicide, and was eventually released. Under the 90-day law, the police can incarcerate a person and hold him without benefit of attorney, right to trial, or even formal charge. At the end of the 90-day period - as in Ruth First's case - the person may be freed, then immediately re-arrested for an additional 90 days. (This law, incidentally, was instituted in 1960 under the authority of South Africa's current Primer Minister Voerster.) NINETY DAYS, a BBC production now being presented by NET, recreates the horror and the outrage of Ruth First's confinement. In this film, Ruth First plays herself, enduring the 117 days as she did in 1963. Again, she lives in a cell which the camera probes while she speaks for her troubled thoughts of three years ago. Again, she marks the days off one-by-one on her cell's stone wall as she tries to retain a vestige of control. She does not know what she will be interrogated for, though she is aware that several of her friends and colleagues have been jailed after meeting in Rivonia to discuss their anti-government sentiments. Mrs. First, who visited Rivonia prior to the arrests, resists questioning during her first 90 days though the interrogators ply her subtly and persistently. Finally, after her release and re-arrest, she answers a few questions about her friends. Then, she becomes "overwhelmed with guilt that they could use the beginning of my statement to demoralize others." But after a suicide attempt, she refuses to complete her statement and is ultimately freed. She and her children are then about to join her husband in England. But other South Africans are less fortunate. For them, the 90-day law has been replaced by a new 180-day law (or, as Voerster has defined the state's sway over the individual: "this side of eternity"). Old newspaper clippings and portraits of other political prisoners help to enlarge the sense of South African "justice" beyond the case of Ruth First. But the story, most immediately is hers. Narrator: John McGavin.
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche: The program ranges from community meetings to barber shops, and from pool hall to playground in its assessment of Mount Vernon, suburbia with "a split personality." Standing on a rooftop overlooking the town, Professor Bert Swanson describes the geographic and racial split within the community and the tensions created by deteriorated housing and racial imbalance in the schools. The program then follows him and other community leaders who seek to bring reasons to emotional issues. Swanson, political sociologist at Sarah Lawrence College and director of the school's Institute of Community Studies, encourages dialogue between black and white at such functions as the meetings of the Pelham (NY) Human Rights Commission. Other key figures in the program include Charles Silberman of Fortune magazine, a Mount Vernon resident and author of "Crisis in Black and White"; local NAACP president Lloyd King, who lives in an integrated block but resists the easy acceptance accorded to those who adopt middle class uniformity; and Alderman Guiseppe Ragno, who pledges his effort to bring legislative justice, but notes the more difficult task of changing attitudes. The dangerous split between Mount Vernon's Negroes and the Italian community, which is strong both numerically and politically, is summed up by Johnny, an Italian barber. He resists the idea that his children will have to grow up in fear, and remarks "we need a politician brave enough to put the instigators in their place." To some, an integrated block such as King lives on represents "the ultimate resolution" of a "world without labels." However, Mount Vernon is a long way from such integration, with whites inhabiting the North South, Negros the South Side, and a railroad track running down the middle. The program ends on a poignant note with a ceremony for the late Dr. Martin Luther King. A gathering is addressed by Floyd King, Silberman, and Mayor August Petrillo. Then, each of them is seen departing along to their separate duties.
National Educational Television and Radio Center
National Educational Television and Radio Center

"A 1968 study of North Vietnam, recording the results of U.S. bombing. Films show Ho Chi Minh visiting with villagers; interviews with a captured American flier and a North Vietnamese farmer (who describes a bombing attack). Also: a discussion of war in general by newsman David Schoenbrun and political scientist Robert A. Scalapino."--TV Guide.com From NET microfiche: In the first portion of this 90-minute program, NET will present an edited version of Felix Greene's film, "North Vietnam - A Personal Report," which premiered December 10, 1967, at the Carnegie Hall Cinema in New York. The second portion of the program will be a discussion of the film and the war by David Schoenbrun, noted journalist and professor of Vietnamese history at Columbia University; and by a partisan of the war effort, soon to be announced. In reviewing "North Vietnam - A Personal Report," Cue Magazine began: "The most jolting film in town is available this holiday season for anyone who gives a damn about what's being done in his name The film's overall power comes from detailing, often exquisitely, the everyday heroism of a beautiful, courageous people." The New York Times calls it "ominous" and "startling." And the New York Post called it an "impressive" film, "important for us to see." The undisputed heroes of the film are the people of North Vietnam, rebuilding their bombed towns and roads and bridges, mourning their dead, and conducting their simple lives with "amazing unconcern" for the constant roar of bombers. The film - which has been produced, written, photographed and recorded by British journalist Felix Greene - depicts a country of ruined cities and deep bomb craters; a country that "can be destroyed," in the words of the producer, "but never conquered." The determination of the people interviewed by Mr. Greene is supported by his film sequences. There is the Volunteer Youth Brigade that repairs roads, hauling hundreds of pounds of stones on their bicycles. There are fishermen who go out in their boats each night, since they must work to feed the country under cover of dark. There is the makeshift hospital, where doctors conduct "surgery by flashlight." There is the armed nations: guns are everywhere, and each air-raid siren mobilizes a crudely-appointed anti-aircraft squad of men who fire their rifles at the US bombers. The film contains interviews with North Vietnamese Prime Minister Pham Van Dong, a captured major (USAF), a bereaved family, and other North Vietnamese natives. The Prime Minister tells Greene "what the American people must understand" is that "we will fight 10, 15, even 20 or more years to maintain our independence." The American flyer resting at a hospital, admits that he has dropped CBU (anit-personnel) bombs, and state that our country "needs another look at our foreign policy." The film climaxes with a visit of the nation's canonized leader, Ho Chi Minh, to one of the villages of North Vietnam. The additional panelist on this program will be Robert Scalapino, professor of political science at the University of California (Berkeley), a leading supporter of the Administration's Vietnam policy within the academic community. He is author of "The Communist Revolution in Asia" and "North Korea Today" and editor of "Asian Survey." With him will be previously-announced David Schoenbrun and Dick McCutchen, moderator. Based on a film by Felix Greene.
a production of National Educational Television ; executive producer, Paul Kaufman.
National Educational Television and Radio Center
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche, file P: National Educational Television will create a dialogue between top-level government and grass roots America when it presents "The People Question Vice President Humphrey" on October 1. The hour-long live confrontation between the Vice President and groups of citizens in four cities will be broadcast on NET's network of more than 100 affiliated stations. Originally scheduled for June 6, the telecast was postponed because of the Middle East Crisis. Mr. Humphrey, who will appear from the Washington anchor studio with NET's Washington correspondent Paul Niven, will be questioned by members of the League of Women Voters in Philadelphia; Junior Chamber of Commerce members in Athens, Georgia; student from the University of Wisconsin's Milwaukee campus; and member of a Los Angeles local of the United Auto Workers. Discussion will focus on three areas: Vietnam and foreign relations, domestic issues, and politics. Neither the Vice President nor NET will have prior knowledge of the questions to be asked. "In addition to representing four sections of the nation geographically, the four groups reflect a wide variety of American opinion," says Jim Karayn, producer of the broadcast. "The 66 questioners come from all party affiliations and many political camps with business and labor, housewives and students all represented. We have left the selection of participants entirely to the organization themselves."
NET journal. People question Vice President Humphrey.
National Educational Television ; producer, Jim Karayn.
National Educational Television and Radio Center
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche (G): Program Description: This program examines the Philippines, a "feudal society" with heavy overtones of American military and economic influence. The program will air here just six days after the November 11 national election, in which it is expected that President Ferdinand Marcos will be elected to his second four-year term. Despite this anticipated vote, there is ferment for change in the Philippines, the program notes. Crime runs high; poverty is general. And a "tight control of the Philippine hierarchy (is) held by the traditionally conservative" Catholic church. Above all, reformers decry the military presence of the U.S. army, 24 years after the country achieved independence. Some 50 thousand American servicemen are stationed in the Philippines - "more than there are in the Philippines' own armed forces." A Leftist slogan reads: "Americans undermine Philippine decency." But the government promotes the presence of the American military, since it offers economic relief for the islands. The program spans the country's economic life, from its expanded wheat and rice production to its major hemp and copra output. American presence also dominates the economy--an issue on which Marcos' opponent, Senator Sergio Osmena, traded. The program finds, however, that the political system is likely to remain unchanged while so few Filipinos are truly represented. This is a country with a virtual oligarchy and a narrow middle class. Its embodiment, according to the program, is General Menzi, personal advisor to the President. A man with vast wealth, Menzi runs the Manila Bulletin and radio and television stations-all of which tout President Marcos. In an interview during the program, Marcos discusses the Philippines' claim to Sabah, the northern portion of Malaysia's island of Borneo. Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET Journal - "Guns Before Bread": In the aftermath of a national election, this program examines the Philippines' economic, political, and military health, especially in terms of American influence.
adapted from two films by Studio Hamburg, West Germany and Radio Eireann (Ireland) ; NET presentation ; NET executive producer, William Weston.
National Educational Television and Radio Center
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche, file P: General Description of Series: This program roams the "feline world" of high fashion during the late summer, as the new fall-winter collections are being introduced to the press, the Paris elite, and the members of the fashion industry. BBC reporter Alan Whicker tours such Paris fashion houses as Christian Dior and Nina Ricci. There, he interviews leading designers, among then Gerard Picard and Pierre Balmain; members of the press, who include John Fairchild, publisher of the New York "fashion bible," Women's Wear Daily; manufacturers bent on adapting their new lines to the highest in haute couture; and rich women "who've seen it all and now say 'surprise me, delight me.'" Whicker also observes leading fashion photographers such as David Bailey as they work with their "acquiescent" models - "girls who can wear fur in August, swim suits in December ... and look snooty and dead-pan even with sand in their shoes." The program goes into the dressing rooms of Paris, where models are preparing for their appearance before a discriminating audience; it follows them on the fashion floor, then backstage for the congratulations and relief. And it comments sardonically on a world that helps rich women to "cheat" the ravages of time and encourages less elegant manufacturers to "pirate" the latest fashions. Whicker concludes that this "hothouse of frivolity and vanity" is actually "reflective of the mood of the day" with its "economic, political and sexual pressures."
NET journal. Plumes for my rich aunt.
produced by the British Broadcasting Corporation ; a presentation of National Educational Television ; producer-director, Michael Tuchner.
National Educational Television and Radio Center

Franklin McMahon's artist report on the political scene of 1968. His artistic renditions are set to sound recordings, music and his own narration. McMahon follows the 1968 presidential campaign and the candidates, including George W. Romney, Richard Nixon, Nelson Rockefeller, Eugene McCarthy, Hubert Humphrey, Robert Kennedy, and George Wallace. He also reports on the death of Martin Luther King, Jr., the protests over the Vietnam War and the Republican and Democratic Presidential Conventions.
NET journal. Politics, '68 : An artist's report.
a Rocinante production in association with WTTW-Channel 11, Chicago ; produced and directed by Jack Klawitter ; artist-writer, Franklin McMahon.

From NET microfiche: This hour-long documentary, filmed on an August day in New York City, focuses on the people and pageantry, the vocal opposition and the organized chaos of a peace march. The particular demonstration, staged on August 6, 1966, the anniversary of the bombing of Hiroshima, brings together marchers who have gathered at six locations in New York City - from Harlem to the Lower East Side. The program follows them as they proceed toward midtown Manhattan, where they converge in Times Square, then proceed to an improvised rallying place nearby. Meanwhile, the program records their arguments against the war as well as the statements of hostile onlookers ("these people are garbage"; "napalm burns, but a knife in the back kills"). The marchers include housewives and hippies; representatives of the Old Left and the New Left; Negro leaders such as Lincoln Lynch (CORE) and Ivanhoe Donaldson (SNCC) and such intellectuals as poet Allen Ginsberg; veterans of the Vietnam and earlier wars, and a marine who has gone AWOL and will soon be jailed. In addition to their chanting, signing, and placard-bearing, there is the performance of the grotesquely-masked members of the Bread and Puppet Theater. And, at a rallying point, there are the speeches by Lynch and Donaldson, by the late pacifist AJ Muste, deserted Marine Corporal John Jordan, a Japanese native, who is a survivor of the Nagasaki bombing, and a woman from the ghetto. Meanwhile, the "anti-anti-war" demonstrators - including members of the Nazi National Renaissance Party - direct attention to themselves.
NET journal. Profile of a peace parade.
a production of National Educational Television ; executive producer, William Weston ; producer, David Weiss.
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche: This program is a documented plea for privacy in an age of bulging files. It investigates the use of computers, lie detector tests, pre-employment personality tests, and other means of categorizing the individual. And it suggests that the establishment of a proposed National Data Center would be "the end of privacy," opening a man's private life to public scrutiny. (The issue of privacy resounded today, September 5, 1967, when a group of authorities on international law and world politics, titled the Commission to Study the Organization of Peace, called for a United Nations study of "The potential threat to individual freedom posed by computers, wiretap and eavesdropping devices and genetic controls.") The NET documentary begins with the birth of a baby at Mt. Sinai Hospital in New York City; there, the baby is foot printed and his first confidential information is put on punch cards, tape and microfilm, to join the 500,000 hospital files already available for perusal by insurance and credit companies and government agencies. Other invasions of privacy are seen on the program: an actual lie-detector test; a field investigation of an insurance applicant, during which neighbors assess such matters as the man's drinking habits; and the much publicized case of Ralph Nader and General Motors. Two men denied employment on the basis of polygraph tests described their experiences: one telling how he was called a liar when he denied any homosexual inclinations; the other recounting his firing without explanation after a lie detector determined that he was "a Black Muslim." Among those appearing on the program are: " Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas, who notes the "terrifying aspects" of computerized files; " Senator Sam Ervin of North Carolina, who decries such "insulting questions on government tests" as "have you had sexual intercourse with an animal?" " Congressman John Moss of California, who warns of potential blackmail through the availability of personal records; " Ralph Nader, who recounts his secret investigation by General Motors; " Martin Gross, author of the "Brain Watchers," who notes that questioning by guidance counsellors effects "an early conditioning of children into confessionals"; " Dr. James Farr, psychologist and management consultant, who argues that "personality testing per se" is not an invasion of privacy; " Congressman Cornelius E. Gallagher of New Jersey, who warns against a "fish-bowl society"; " Dr. Carl Kazin of the Institute for Advanced Studies at Princeton, who states that the current trend invites such a generality as "that peg is Carl Kazin,' with "statistical conclusion" as its only justification. Narrator: Philip Sterling.
a production of National Educational Television ; executive producer, Alvin H. Perlmutter ; producer-writer, Warren Steibel.
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche (R): Dynamic young poet Andrei Voznesensky, the later writer Ilya Ehrenburg, and Nobel Prize winning physicist Igor Tamm discuss their nation's strengths and shortcomings on "NET Journal - Russia: The Unfinished Revolution." On the eve of the November 7 celebration, the NET program concentrates on the cultural, scientific and economic changes in Russia since the Bolshevik revolution of 1917. It also focuses on the "growing interest in the personal life, and the desire for material possessions," which producer Henry Morgenthau III noted on his recent visit to Russia. During a month of intensive filing this summer, Morgenthau found "surveillance but cooperation" on the part of the Novesti Press Agency, which helped to arrange his visit. Officials of Novesti accompanied the crew on its various filming assignments and provided sound men for the film. The program represents a rare electronic "thaw" in a summer which saw Russia discourage various exchanges on the basis of international crisis. In fact, it was during this period that Voznesensky's scheduled reading of his work at New York's Lincoln Center was cancelled. NET filmed the poet at the Taganka Theater on the night of his most pointed outburst against the government censorship. Later, in an interview with reporter Colette Shulman, Voznesensky discussed his craft, the relationship between science and the arts, and the young generation, which is "better, more free, more brave, more strong" than its predecessors. A retrospective look at Russian literature is provided by Ehrenburg in one of the last interviews given before his recent death. Though he noted that the literary "picture is greyer today," Ehrenburg decried the tendency of Westerners to view "our literature in a political context, using our internal difficulties for your own purpose." Mrs. Shulman, former Moscow correspondent for UPI, also interviewed economist Alexander Birman, who notes that the pace of reform has been slowed by "the international situation"; children's writer and essayist Kornei Chukovskey; a female doctor who discusses family life, abortion and the changing role of women and contraception; young students and men on the street. The film visits a commemorative photo exhibit in Moscow where the Russians look at themselves. There are also scenes from a peasant wedding, a collective baptism under state auspices, downtown Moscow with its stories and standardized apartments, and the Taganka Theater where the entertainment includes singing sailors and a mock strip tease based on a poem by Voznesensky.
Produced by National Educational Television in association with WGBH-TV, Boston ; producer-director, Henry Morgenthau III.
National Educational Television and Radio Center
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche: SEARCH FOR THE LOST SELF, a drama about children in the nightmare world of mental illness, is presented on National Educational Television's documentary series, "NET Journal." Filmed on the premises of the League School for Seriously Disturbed Children in Brooklyn, NY, SEARCH FOR THE LOST SELF is the second of two hour-long documentaries devoted to the subject of mental illness by "NET Journal." The school, founded in 1953, was the first day-treatment center in the country for seriously disturbed children. At the time, it challenged the premise that the millions of children generally classified as "schizophrenic," "autistic," "psychotic," or "retarded," were basically uneducable. The school's founder and director, Dr. Carl Fenichel, had worked with disturbed children at Kings County Hospital in Brooklyn. The vast majority of these children had been recommended for psychotherapy and were eventually consigned to institutions. Dr. Fenichel, however, believed in the therapy of education. "Through teaching them to read and count and listen, we can reach many of these children. They begin relating to people and see that the world is an organized predictable place," Dr. Fenichel explains. "We don't talk in terms of cure, but we feel we can reduce the disability and permit them to function in the real world." At the League School, producer Murray Lerner has filmed many types of children - hyperactive and lethargic, mute and loquacious, insatiable readers and virtual idiots. What they share upon entering the school is an inability to relate - to others, to inanimate objects, even to their own bodies. The program traces their tortuous learning process that often disintegrates into tantrums of withdrawals. For some children, however, there are signs of hope, and their partial recovery is the film's "message." The League School has become the prototype for many recently-established centers for mentally-disturbed children. Increasingly, education is being recognized as a valid treatment for mental illness in children.
NET journal. Search for the lost self.
a National Educational Television production ; producer, Murray Lerner.
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche (S): Senator Eugene McCarthy stated that, if elected president, he would appeal directly to the people when he felt the urgency of gaining passage of legislation over the heads of Congress. McCarthy, interviewed in the office of the president of American University explained, however, that the most effective way of dealing with Congress was to encourage that body to identify itself with a legislative program. He added that the current conflict between President Johnson and the House Ways and Means Committee results from the President's limited understanding of the committee's function. McCarthy credited the current campaign with restoring the two-party system to American politics; there will, he continued, be a clear choice between the Republican and Democratic candidates. He felt, however, that there would be a concerted move toward a three-party system by 1972. He ruled himself out as a third-party candidate for the present election, noting that he intends to test his system of New Politics within his own party. He defined his New Politics as a major change in the party on a fundamental issue, which in this case earned support of non-politicians and non-organization people. He rated the late Senator Kennedy as his main competitor prior to the assassination, and explained that the Senator's popularity with minority groups was based on 10 years of exposure and an ability to talk directly to them. Based on his own record and understanding of the problems of the minorities, Senator McCarthy felt that he did not have to compete with Richard Nixon or anyone else for minority support. The Senator indicated that rioting - and violence in general - were not new reactions by underprivileged people. He called for a change in the nominating procedure to allow more responsible decision making at conventions. He said that he was prepared to give an equal share of the delegates his own state of Minnesota to the opposition, and he indicated that he had legitimate reasons for protesting the party's assigning of delegates in this campaign. If elected, Senator McCarthy said that he would view the presidency as an office rather than as a job. The presidency, he explained, should not be personalized or handled possessively, since it is - like a Senator's position - a public charge.
NET journal. Senator McCarthy on 'The New Politics' and the presidency.
NET journal presents ; facilities by WETA-TV, Washington, D.C. ; producer, Jim Karayn ; director, Max Schindler.
NET journal presents. Sen. McCarthy on 'The New Politics' and the presidency.
NET journal. McCarthy and the presidency.
Senator McCarthy on 'The New Politics' and the presidency.

From NET microfiche: This rare interview with controversial Black Panther leader Bobby Seale, filmed during his incarceration in San Francisco's City Jail, profiles a man whose revolutionary zeal is undeterred by prison life. Prison for Bobby Seale is merely a microcosm of the real world, where the revolution must be continued or even intensified. But pleasures are relegated to the realm of dreams. "You analyze society, when you're in jail, if you're a political person," says Seale. "You analyze what's happening. You know. You begin to see things naked You can see cops, man, look like punks. See what I mean? And you look at 'em, you see - can't forget 'em - mess their minds up, you know. And you desire to be home." Seale minces no words in describing his opinion of prison guards ("mad dog, mad ex-policeman, ex DA's you know. They're kind of rejects.") And he describes the brutality to which he has been subjected. He relates an occasion on which he was reading a Black Panther Party newspaper. As a result, a prison guard then threatened to revoke Seale's visiting privileges, though he contended that the paper was given to him by another guard. He responded by calling the guard a "pig." The next morning, he says, they took him to "the hole," which he describes as "just a box. There's no bed in there; you have no blankets in there; you have no toilet." He relates in detail how the guards strangled him until he was unconscious, and when he awoke, his throat was so hoarse he couldn't speak." He contends that these brutal measures did not weaken his resolve or break his morale. "You see, this is the way you beat the cat. See, when you're a revolutionary you don't - you know, they can't break your spirit that way They are the ones who really couldn't stand to be in there. That's why they create that kind of thing." Seale discusses his childhood in the Oakland ghetto and explains how he was discharged from military service ("'cause I got in an argument with a white colonel who thought he was God.") He reveals how he used to work as a punch-line comedian and displays his gift as a mimic in a short monologue about Marshall Dillon and Chester, of TV's "Gunsmoke." At that time, however, he met Huey P. Newton and committed his life to revolution. "I used to create some jokes. But you can't tell jokes about the revolution; the revolution is real. And you can't tell jokes about life all the time, 'cause life is real. You got to solve it, you know." The show, "Staggerlee" bears the name of Seale's son, Malik Nkrumah Staggerlee Seale. The name, taken from black folklore, refers to a character named Stagger Lee who lost all his money and his Stetson to "a cat named Billie" in a New Orleans poker game. Enraged, he shot Billie dead. "Staggerlee" subsequently has become a legendary figure identified with the black man born in the ghetto, where vice and evil are everywhere. "That's life. All the little young Staggerlees, a lot of 'em, millions of 'em - you know what I mean? The poor, oppressed black American and I named that brother little boy Staggerlee because that's what his name is." "Staggerlee - A Conversation with Bobby Seale" is a NET presentation, produced by KQED, San Francisco. Producer and interviewer: Francisco Newman. Cameraman: Allen Willis. Sound Alex Prisadsky. NET Producer: William Weston.
NET journal. Staggerlee--a conversation with Bobby Seale.
KQED, San Francisco ; NET presentation ; producer, Francisco Newman ; NET producer, William Wetson.

"NET DOCUMENTARY 48: NET JOURNAL: "Still a Brother--Inside the Negro Middle Class" is from NET JOURNAL series (host is Ossie Davis--2 reels) William Greaves film (4/29/68)"--J. Fred MacDonald catalogue. From M/B/RS Film and Television catalog: Discusses the behavior and aspirations of the Negro middle class, the nature of the society which parallels but is completely separate from the white counterpart, problems of housing in prestigious communities and resorts, the risk of black culture, and the role of religion in a period of black nationalism. From NET microfiche (S): NOTE: A note by Bob Freedman dated May 27, 1968 states, "Foreign and audiovisual rights to the NET program STILL A BROTHER have been returned to the producers, William Greaves Productions; 157-10 Riverside Drive West, New York, New York. This documentary is about the Negro and his two-way odyssey - into the white middle class and back to filmmakers - William B. Branch and William Greaves - providing it with a special viewpoint as it moves among the various strata of Negro life. The program begins with scenes from a world that is black in only one regard - skin color. On the golf course or on a yacht, at a beauty contest or a cotillion, the Negro is seen as he adopts the white norm. Usually the function is attended by Negroes alone, except in the case of the integrated Annual Evening of Elegance, which is shown here at the Westchester estate of Mrs. Sidney Poitier. It is this society which sociologist E. Franklin Frazier described in his book "Black Bourgeoisie," and which the documentary parodied in a dream sequence inhabited by Negro polo and tennis players cavorting affectedly with a buxom blonde Negress. In this portion, the program also explores the source of the Negro's upward mobility - better job opportunities and some access to suburban housing. The program notes that five million Negroes - one in four - have attained middle class income, and that the Negro market now totals $32 billion. But being "middle class" is not merely a matter of income. It is a question of behavior, of aspirations, of respectability, according to sociologist St. Clair Drake of Roosevelt University. And it is here that the break occurs. Though many Negroes remain committed to the suburban, basically white, aspiration, others have become affected by the black movement. Ralph Featherstone of SNCC contends that "there is no black middle class." A social habit such as the evening of elegance "hinders the struggle for modern genuine radicalism," says Featherstone. The viewpoint emerges most poignantly in the case of Horace Morris, associate director of the Urban League in Washington, DC, and former footballer at Syracuse University. Morris recounts his presence in Newark at the time of riots, when the police irresponsibly opened fire on his car, mortally wounding his stepfather and injuring his brother as well. Until then, Morris had accepted the "fallacy that ability is enough." But, he realized, "no matter how far up the economic ladder you climb, there's still the oppressive prejudice of the white man You're still a brother." Morris notes that his son, a high school senior, suffers fewer illusions. The program depicts the young Negro, especially at a traditionally conservative school such as Howard University as taking the forefront of the new militancy. This militancy takes its most severe form in the riots, seen here briefly. But its most profound expression is the "mental revolution," ranging from a new kind of religion ("Jesus isn't in that bag," explains a preacher, denouncing the "white nationalist" drift of historical Christianity) to a campaign that "black is beautiful." The latter trend involves a pride in one's African heritage, ranging from hair styles to art collections, and from an appreciation of "soul" food to a rejection of the television image with its "Nordic standards of beauty." In its wide-ranging study of the Negro in American society, the documentary recapitulates such recent events as the Washington march of 1963, the President's civil rights program in cities like Newark and Detroit. It helps, thereby to chart the Negro's drive not merely for middle class status, but for self-definition. Among those appearing on the program are John H. Johnson, president of Johnson Publishing Co.; Robert Johnson, editor of Jet magazine; Julian Bond, Georgia legislator; Bayard Rustin, director of the A. Philip Randolph Institute; Dr. Percy Julian, Chicago millionaire; Dr. Dennis Jackson, summer's Newark Black Power Conference; and Mrs. Millie Jackson, Atlanta psychologist.
NET journal. Still a brother: Inside the Negro middle class. [90-minute version].
a production of William Greaves Productions and National Educational Television ; co-producers, William Branch, William Greaves.
Still a brother: Inside the Negro middle class.

From NET microfiche (T): Program Description 1: This program presents highlights from a panel discussion on television news coverage at the White House. The discussion will take place February 14, at the New York Hilton Hotel, under the aegis of the New York Chapter of the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences. Participants include three former presidential press secretaries: James C. Hagerty (under Eisenhower), Pierre Salinger (under Kennedy and Johnson) and Bill D. Moyers (under Johnson). Also on the panel are Frank McGee of NBC and Dan Rather of CBS. Moderator is Edward P. Morgan of the Public Broadcast Laboratory of NET. Program Description 2: This program, much of which was carried live on WNDT Channel 13 and other Eastern stations, features the recollections of three former Presidential press secretaries on the growth of television coverage of the White House and its uses (and occasional abuses) by the President. Participants are ex-secretaries Pierre Salinger, James Hagerty, and Bill D. Moyers; and newsmen Dan Rather, Frank McGee, and Edward P. Morgan. Highlights follow: Salinger: "Both the Kennedy and Johnson administrations have tried to put the best possible face on Vietnam, even at times when the facts would show to the contrary. I think that some of the predictions that were made about how soon the war would end ... have led to the serious problems that the current administration has with the American people on Vietnam. " Moyers, questioning "whether or not it is right or fair or wise for one man to have to work within an inherited situation," elaborates: "Mr. Kennedy was a superb performer before television; Mr. Johnson is not... I just don't think television is suited to every President's using it." Among the program's highlights are Moyers' recounting of the day when LBJ was being admitted secretly into Bethesda Hospital upon closing of the stock market; Salinger's explanation of the handling of the Cuban crisis; and Hagerty's recollections on the inclusion of television correspondents in the Presidential pool. Additional Description from NET Press Release: Three former Presidential press secretaries reveal reasons for the deepening ''credibility gulch" on NET Journal -- "Television and the White House," __ at ___ on Channel ___. Pierre Salinger, who served under Presidents Kennedy and Johnson, concedes that both Administrations contributed to the present dissatisfaction over Vietnam by trying "to put the best possible face on Vietnam, even at times when the facts would show to the contrary." Bill Moyers, a more recent Johnson aide, stresses the need for secrecy in many major policy matters. In the aftermath of the Pueblo incident, "the Administration permitted the press to hustle its priorities and ... succumbed all too quickly to the appetite of the press for comment." Other panelists are former Eisenhower aide James Hagerty and newsmen Dan Rather of CBS, Frank McGee of NBC, and moderator Edward P. Morgan of the PBL of NET. The program was taped February 14 at the meeting of the New York Chapter of the Television Academy of Arts and Sciences, held in the New York Hilton. Moyers is critical of the fact that one man must "work within an inherited situation." Specifically, "Mr. Kennedy was a superb performer before television; Mr. Johnson is not.... I don't think television is suited to every president's using it." Moyers also recounts the day when Mr. Johnson waited until the stock market closed before admitting that he was entering Bethesda Hospital. Salinger describes the subterfuge involved in President Kennedy's movements on the weekend prior to the Cuban missile crisis. And Hagerty elaborates on his decision to include television correspondents in the President's regular news pool. Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET JOURNAL -- "Television and the White House": Television news coverage at the White House, is discussed by former Presidential press secretaries James C. Hagerty, Pierre Salinger, and Bill D. Moyers, and newsmen Edward P. Morgan, Frank McGee, and Dan Rather.
NET journal. Television and the White House.
