From NET microfiche, file T: Thailand, "America's future bastion against any future Chinese aggression" in Southeast Asia, is studied in this half-hour adaptation of a film made by North German Television. The film views Thailand's growing complex of roads and air strips, from which the U.S. is mounting most of its air strikes against the enemy in Vietnam. According to the film, Thailand has allowed this build-up because the Thais are "fiercely anti-Communist" and "are certain that Communism threatens their independence." The film ranges Thailand from tourist-happy Bangkok to the country's industries in rubber, rice, and silver - three fields that make up most of Thailand's exports. It includes a traditional parade on Buddhist New Year and other religious rites. It also views a funeral for Thais killed by Communist guerrillas, and shows how the people are being indoctrinated against Communism by radio and television programs. Noting positive effect of the U.S. build-up in Thailand, such as hydroelectric dams and a better standard of living, the program concludes: "We will be able to go on working with these proud, independent people in preventing the further spread of Communism only so long as we keep hands off their domestic policies. Our job in Thailand is not reform, it is to help save Southeast Asia from the threat hanging over it from the North. In that effort, the people of Thailand are our strongest, staunchest, most dependable allies."
Presentation of National Educational Television ; adapted from a film by North German Television ; NET prodcuer, William Weston ; English adaptation by Arthur Lodge.
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche: Senator Barry Goldwater and Congressman William E. Miller discuss the humorous -- and serious -- aspects of their 1964 campaign for the presidency in an interview with NET correspondent Paul Niven and Joseph Sterne of the Baltimore Sun's Washington bureau. Reflecting on the convention, Goldwater reveals that "we had every cable of every television company and every radio company marked up in the loft of the Cow Palace. If anybody got a little too obnoxious to us, they could always have cable trouble... We had all kinds of things planned." Goldwater also recalls counter-espionage. During the campaign, Goldwater remarks that both sides practiced "counter-espionage" with the Democrats planting a "spy" on their train, and the Republicans having "entree into the Democratic plans." Goldwater notes that he was not humiliated by the election results. In fact, he relates to Miller, "the day of the nomination -- I didn't tell you about this because I didn't want to lose you -- our polls had shown us ... it was 80 per cent for Johnson-Humphrey and 20 per cent for Goldwater-Miller." On the campaign, Goldwater recalls instances which confirm his opinion of President Johnson as "probably the cutest, smartest, throat-cuttingest political operator I have ever run into." On one occasion during the campaign he and the President agreed -- at his suggestion -- to avoid the issue of civil rights, since "the laws are on the books, the people know that both you and I are concerned in this field, although he (Johnson) wasn't at the time... He agreed, and I hadn't even walked out of the Rose Garden and he had sent out a press release. Had it already written. " Some of Goldwater's reflections from the campaign to the present political scene, include: " High praise for Vice President Humphrey: "a man that is humorous, that is genuine, that is readily accepted by Republican and Democrat alike, and who can sound plausible where the President just can't sound plausible." " On his pre-campaign strategy: '"All we did was read the Kennedy book. And improved on it ... our electronic techniques were the best." " On press coverage during the campaign; "I think you are beginning to see a realization that from the top newspapers on down, there was bad handling on both sides. A conservative paper would be unfair to Johnson. The liberal paper like the New York Times would be unfair to me." " On our political system: "I think we ought to give consideration to whether we ought to have a Republican president and a Democratic congress, or vice versa." " On fellow Republicans: "The Republican candidates were caricatures -- let's face it -- Rockefeller and his cohorts had painted. I was a Social Security cutter and I was going to bomb the kids." " On his present lack of speaking engagements: "They probably feel Goldwater is a 'kiss of death,' that if he comes into Ohio or Illinois or some other state that the crowds are going to stay away." Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET JOURNAL -- "That Was The Election That Was": Barry Goldwater and Bill Miller recount the human and humorous elements of their 1964 presidential campaign with NET correspondent Paul Niven and Joseph Sterne of the Baltimore Sun.
NET journal. That was the election that was.
a production of National Educational Television ; producers, Jim Karayn, Paul Niven ; director, Max Schindler.

From NET microfiche, file B: Description of series: NET Journal - "The Battered Child"; Children recovering from home abuse are studied at the University of Colorado Medical Center by a special team of psychiatrists, pediatricians, and social workers. The battered child, victim of abuse in the home, is subject of this compassionate documentary, filmed primarily at the University of Colorado Medical Center in Denver, where an experimental "Battered Child" team has been formed. This team, consisting of psychiatrists, pediatricians and social workers, studies the causes of such abuses and provides therapy for the children affected mentally. The idea of the team is a direct result of the findings of two University pediatricians, Dr. C Henry Kempe and Dr. Ray E. Helfer, who developed the battered child syndrome in their revealing book "The Battered Child," and who are seen in the documentary. Dr. Kempe reports on several cases at the Medical Center and holds intensive conversations with some of the mothers who have abused their children; he also talks to the few children who are old enough, and sufficiently receptive, to comment on their feelings. Judges in Denver County are also asked to discuss the legal ramifications of the battered child syndrome. The reporter on the program, who also interviews therapists in this area, is Pulitzer Prize-winner Lois Wille of the Chicago Daily News.
produced by WTTW, Chicago, for NET ; executive producer, William Weston ; producer, Al Binford ; director, Bob Kaiser.

From NET microfiche: The first half of this two-part program is a film on the development of the fetus, produced in color by Swedish Broadcasting Corporation. The second portion will be a discussion of the film and such related subjects as the advisability of sex education for school children. Discussants include Dr. Mary Calderone, executive director, Sex Information and Education Council of the U.S.; the Rev. George Hagmater, associate director, Paulist Institute for Religious Research; and a third panelist to be announced. "The Beginning of Life" first charts the journey of a sperm to the female ovum, overcoming such obstacles as the mucus lining (visualized here in a succession of brilliant crystal patterns), and merging into an embryonic shape. The film then shows the minuscule changes of the human fetus as it develops various characters and becomes, by the middle of the fifth month, a complete human being. Slowly, the film builds to the moment of delivery, when it shifts abruptly from its artistically-rendered fetal study to a hospital room, where a birth is recorded. 'NET journal - The Beginning of Life' is a National Educational Television production, based on a film by Swedish Broadcasting Corporation, which was produced by Lars Wallen, written by Claea Wirsen and Brent Bernholm, photographed by Lennart Nilsson. Music by Karl Birger Biorndahl, performed by Swedish Radio Orchestra under conductor Stig Westerberg. NET producer: William Weston, Moderator of the NET discussion will be Richard McCutchen.
NET journal. The beginning of life.
a National Educational Television production based on a film by Swedish Broadcasting Corporation ; NET producer, William Weston.

From NET microfiche: An examination of the brain and its mysteries, this program looks at the brain's evolution, how it learns and how science may help us to gain more control over it. A mass of nerve cells and nerve fibers, the brain controls every human function. The film points out that the Greeks and Arabs recognized the importance of the brain early in history, but neither had any conception of its anatomy. It is only in the last few decades, with the development of the electron microscope and the electroencephalograph that scientists have begun to know the brain. By knowing it, man can hope to understand the origins of illusions, misconceptions, prejudice, and aggression. The human brain has 12 billion cells, branching and touching, woven into a complex fabric of interconnections (more than the entire telephone system of North America). The program illustrates the fact that the brain cannot cope with the quantity of information modern life requires, and thus, modern man has developed extensions of the brains - computers. The film shows how computers help architects, for example, to project their designs and how doctors use them to locate misfiring brain cells that cause Parkinson's disease. The film also examines the sleeping brain and the phenomenon of rapid eye movement (REM), which results from interruptions of deep sleep by increased brain activity, called "brainstorms." During brainstorms the body relaxes, but the eyes begin scanning and dreams occur. PLEASE NOTE: Sketches of nudes are shown in several portions of the film.

produced by the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation; presented by National Educational Television ; NET executive producer, William Weston ; producer-director, Vincent Tovell ; writer, William Whitehead.

Description of series: This program was originally broadcast November 3, 1969. It was scheduled to be rebroadcast July 6, 1970, but was preempted. NET Journal - "The Conservative Mr. Buckley": The personal vision of William F. Buckley, Jr., is seen through a series of film statements encompassing crime, the ghetto, capital punishment, patriotism, communism, and the arts. A renaissance man of American conservatism, William F. Buckley, Jr., is editor of the National Review, syndicated columnist ("On the Right"), host of his own television program ("Firing Line"), and political gadfly (he ran for mayor of New York in 1965). This program is a series of film statements reflecting Buckley's concerns and perceptions about life in America today. The areas include crime and violence, communism, capital punishment, patriotism, the arts, the ghetto and its evolving leadership, and the beauty of unspoiled America. His remarks - whether from a podium at Rice University or in a private discussion with Whitney Young of the Urban League - are urbane, analytical, often biting. Representative quotes follow: After a tour of the ghettos arranged by Young, Buckley notes that the leaders in Watts (Los Angeles) are "bright a little cynical with a dawning consciousness of the political way up the ladder." Commenting on the black masses, Buckley says: "Some choose the neo-nonsense of Ron Karenga; many engage in efforts that distinguished the white man at his best in Los Angeles 100 years ago." Of Karenga, director of a self-help group titled "Us," Buckley says, "He affects the manners of an Oriental Satrap." He describes Karenga's rhetoric as "an agglutination of social clichs." On a visit to death row in Trenton, N.J., Buckley says "Capital punishment is a dead letter Not even the John Birch Society would fault the Court's reasoning" if the Supreme Court were to abolish the death penalty. Buckley is himself involved in the case of Edgar Smith, who has been on death row in Trenton for 12 years since he was convicted of homicide. During a televised debate with author Norman Mailer, Buckley deprecates Castro-style communism, nothing that under the Batista government (which he opposed) "at the worst you could found an opposition newspaper, found a union, go to church, go in and out of the country." He calls Mailer's interpretation of Cuba today "Mailer melodrama you're a wonderful writer, but a terrible witness." Buckley reacts with venom to the remark made by a Los Angeles high school student that Johann Sebastian Bach - "that old dead punk" - should not be taught. "That is the champion effrontery," says Buckley. "Music has done more to elevate mankind that all the black student unions." He derides "the rhetorical escalation, which is totally out of hand." A case in point: with a group of Tulane University students, Buckley cuts short a discussion on violence in the ghetto, saying "you use the word violence with such slovenliness to render yourself unintelligible." In another scene, Buckley visits his family home in Sharon, Conn., and comments on the satisfactions it afforded him. "it was hewn out of a single pleasant dream," he says.
NET journal. The conservative Mr. Buckley.
NET production ; executive producer, A. H. Perlmutter ; producer, Warren Steibel.

From NET microfiche, file D: This hour long is composed of two cases from a Canadian series devoted to psychological disturbances. The first half hour, subtitled a "case of school phobia," delves into six-year-old Tommy and his reluctance to attend school. The program shows clinical sessions between Tommy and his parents and Dr. Statten, a psychiatrist. It develops that Tommy was born a month after the death of his parents' oldest daughter and was later introduced to death when his cousins were victims of a fire. Through the use of puppets, Dr. Statten also reveals Tommy's desire for more discipline: Tommy who is manipulating the puppet Tom Thumb succumbs to the puppet who represents his parent. Shortly, thereafter, the real Tommy begins attending school. The second case study, "girl in danger," relates to Susan, a 13-year-old, who has begun to invite hazardous situations as a means of reacting against her parents. Her rebellion includes running away from home, joining bands of boys, and neglecting her school work -- though she is regarded as a bright girl. Having been adopted by an upper middle class family, she is apparently reacting to their own vacillations, as when she boasts that she "used to wrap father around her middle finger," though he has now become "mean." However, after seven months at a psychiatric hospital for adolescents, she has become aware that she is "mixed up," and that she can't act out her problems by flirting with danger.
produced by the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation ; a presentation of National Educational Television ; director, Robert Anderson.
National Educational Television and Radio Center
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche: The horror and the soiled hope of life in a German concentration camp are evoked in this French-made drama, which won first prize at the Cannes Film Festival. It is set in the spring of 1944 in the imaginary camp of Tatenberg, where a German officer, SS Obersturmfuehrer Scheller, devises an insidious game that will prove the camp's moral and physical dominion over the men. The game: to pen two men into a single enclosure for 24 hours. The object is to encourage the two men to seek each other's life in the false hope that the survivor will then be freed. One of the men is Karl Schongauer, a political prisoner for the past 11 years who has reportedly identified Scheller's part in illegal sugar trade. The other is David Stein, a French Jew. Much of the action is contained within the enclosure, where the two men test each other, feinting and dodging in words and acts. After David has revealed the plot by which they will eventually seek each other's life, the two men actually begin to pummel each other during an argument involving Karl's German heritage. But by morning they have become truly sympathetic -- though they do not know each other's name. In fact, David helps Karl to escape the enclosure when two of his comrades bring a battered corpse that they hope to pass off as the beaten Karl. The exchange, which takes place during an air-raid, culminates a sub-plot in the drama. The next morning, when David is discovered with the dead man, he is sentenced to the gas chamber, for he has "spilled German blood." Karl, meanwhile, is being hidden by the men in the camp. Karl is played by Hans Christian Blech, a noted German actor who worked closely with playwright Bertold Brecht, appearing in many of his plays. He created the title role of "The Physicist," a play by Frederic Duerenmatt, which premiered in Zurich, and portrayed a German officer in the film "The Longest Day." David is played by Jean Negroul, who was co-founder of an Algerian theater group with Nobel Prize winning Albert Camus.

Co-produced by Clavis Films, Paris and Triglav Films, Djubljana ; NET presentation ; producer, Luch Ulrych-Mirel ; director, Armand Gatti ; original story by Armand Gatti and Pierre Joffrey ; screen play by Armand Gatti and Pierre Lary.
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche, file L: Through the skillful photography of Frenchman Andre Gazut, "The Last Campaign of Robert Kennedy" documents the grueling tension of the 1968 California presidential primary race and captures the terror that swept through the Ambassador Hotel ballroom in Los Angeles as the Kennedy campaign climaxed in the Senator's fatal shooting. The program illustrates the physical and mental ordeals to which Kennedy and his wife, Ethel, were subjected during the campaign, and offers viewers many insights into the nature of a political blitz, epitomized by the Kennedy effort in California. The camera records the frightening ferocity of a crowd welcoming the Kennedy cavalcade along a business street in Los Angeles as people struggle to touch the senator and bodyguards and police prevent frenzied enthusiasts from swamping the Kennedy automobile. Former track star Rafer Johnson is seen propping Kennedy up from the rear to prevent him from tumbling over as the car creeps along. Kennedy's triumphant tour of the streets of Watts is also depicted. In other segments: Viewers gain an insight into political canvassing as a young Kennedy worker gets an unsympathetic reception from a cynical voter he meets in the street; Mrs. Pierre Salinger organizes a fundraising party and Hollywood's Raquel Welch, Kim Novak and Jerry Lewis are among the stars who show up and voice their allegiance; a portion of the Kennedy-McCarthy TV debate is repeated; and an old-fashioned campaign train carries Kennedy through whistle-stops in Central California farm country. A little more than midway through the program the scene shifts to the Ambassador Hotel where Kennedy has just acknowledged victory over McCarthy and the celebration is underway. The abrupt turn of events that follows is recorded chiefly in the dazed expressions, tears, and aimless wanderings of people in the ballroom. Television reporters corner a man who said he witnessed the shooting. "He was mad, he was a lunatic," the man excitedly tells the reporters, describing the gunman and relating what he saw. Emotions build within him as he later repeats the story for another TV network, and finally, recounting his words still another time for some newspapermen, he collapses in hysterical tears. The reporters, suddenly numbed, appear almost in tears themselves as they offer the man assistance. The program includes scenes outside Good Samaritan Hospital, where Kennedy died, and especially poignant views inside St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York City where Gazut's camera studies the faces of persons who came to visit the bier. The material described above totals about 52 minutes. The remaining portion of the program, now in preparation, will consist of a review of the Sirhan Sirhan case. Details will be provided as soon as available.
NET journal. The last campaign of Robert Kennedy.
produced by TV Fernsehen, Zurich, Switzerland ; producer-director, Jean-Jacques LaGrange ; executive producer for NET, William Weston.
The last campaign of Robert Kennedy.

Contents: Brief introduction by Paul Niven -- Seventy-five days / producer, Jim Karayn ; writer, Frank Fletcher -- Paul Niven -- Richard Nixon inauguration speech (excerpt) -- Paul Niven -- panel discussion -- [break for station identification] -- Paul Niven -- Joseph Kraft analysis / producer, Edward Magruder Jones -- panel discussion -- Joseph Kraft analysis (continued) -- panel discussion -- Niven closing remarks -- credits. From NET microfiche: The program will be a report on the transfer of power from one administration to another. There will be a transition film (approximately 35 minutes), containing exclusive films of the briefing of a new cabinet members and task forces for President Nixon, the meetings of advisory councils, the concluding of old business by members of the new regime, and the changeover taking place within the White House. The program will then devote roughly 15 minutes to the inauguration ceremony and Mr. Nixon's speech, given that day in Washington. In the main part of the program, NET correspondent Paul Niven will discuss the next four years with a distinguished panel. He will concentrate on problems and possible solutions by the Nixon Administration in the areas of urban affairs, foreign affairs, and the economy. Panelists include: Walter Heller, Chairman, Council of Economic Advisors and Professor at the University of Minnesota; Milton Friedman, University of Chicago economist and columnist for Newsweek magazine; John Collins, Professor of Urban Affairs at MIT; Clinton Rossiter, professor of American Institutions at Cornell University and author of such works as "Conservatism in America" and "The American Presidency"; Alistair Cooke, chief American correspondent for the Guardian British newspaper; Foy D. Kohler, former ambassador to the Soviet Union, Deputy Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs and Professor of Advanced International Studies at the University of Miami; and Richard Hatcher, mayor of Gary, Indiana. Syndicated columnist Joseph Kraft also provides an analysis of the Nixon administration. Host/Moderator: Paul Niven.
a National Educational Television production ; producer, Jim Karayn ; director, M. Arthur.

Contents: Brief introduction by Paul Niven -- Seventy-five days / producer, Jim Karayn ; writer, Frank Fletcher -- Paul Niven -- Richard Nixon inauguration speech (excerpt) -- Paul Niven -- panel discussion -- [break for station identification] -- Paul Niven -- Joseph Kraft analysis / producer, Edward Magruder Jones -- panel discussion -- Joseph Kraft analysis (continued) -- panel discussion -- Niven closing remarks -- credits. From NET microfiche: The program will be a report on the transfer of power from one administration to another. There will be a transition film (approximately 35 minutes), containing exclusive films of the briefing of a new cabinet members and task forces for President Nixon, the meetings of advisory councils, the concluding of old business by members of the new regime, and the changeover taking place within the White House. The program will then devote roughly 15 minutes to the inauguration ceremony and Mr. Nixon's speech, given that day in Washington. In the main part of the program, NET correspondent Paul Niven will discuss the next four years with a distinguished panel. He will concentrate on problems and possible solutions by the Nixon Administration in the areas of urban affairs, foreign affairs, and the economy. Panelists include: Walter Heller, Chairman, Council of Economic Advisors and Professor at the University of Minnesota; Milton Friedman, University of Chicago economist and columnist for Newsweek magazine; John Collins, Professor of Urban Affairs at MIT; Clinton Rossiter, professor of American Institutions at Cornell University and author of such works as "Conservatism in America" and "The American Presidency"; Alistair Cooke, chief American correspondent for the Guardian British newspaper; Foy D. Kohler, former ambassador to the Soviet Union, Deputy Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs and Professor of Advanced International Studies at the University of Miami; and Richard Hatcher, mayor of Gary, Indiana. Syndicated columnist Joseph Kraft also provides an analysis of the Nixon administration. Host/Moderator: Paul Niven.
a National Educational Television production ; producer, Jim Karayn ; director, M. Arthur.
National Educational Television and Radio Center
National Educational Television and Radio Center

Approximately the first 45 minutes of the two-hour program are missing -- the opening introduction by Paul Niven, the film "Seventy-five days" (about the transition) and the excerpt from Nixon's inauguration speech. From NET microfiche: "This film is about the narcotic path from opium to heroin ... how the white Yunan poppy is cultivated in Burma to yield raw opium, and how this is packaged and retailed for smoking. It shows where opium is converted in Thailand into a morphine brick designed purely for smuggling; and how this is transformed into heroin powder in Hong Kong; then further packaged and adultered with barbitone for sale in the streets." The words of producer-narrator Adrian Cowell, from the introduction of THE OPIUM TRAIL, sum up a documentary which the British press has called "exceptionally fine," "arresting and close-packed," and "sharp as a hypodermic needle." One critic described the photography as "little less than angelic .... Moonlight on water. Sunlight on woman. The cold white poppy black against a whiter, colder moon." The program begins in Burma's Shan State, where - along with neighboring Thailand, Laos, and China's Yunan Province - three-quarters of the world's illegal opium grows. In Shan, "the poppied dream is the entertainment, and the economy of most of the poor villages." Farmers and peddlers are seen at the beginning of the heroin trail, gaining their small luxuries from the product, which will later sell for 1,000 times its original price. The cameras then show a professional smuggling army, which had its origin when the defeated soldiers of Chiang Kai-shek fled to Burma in 1950 and helped to develop the opium business. THE OPIUM TRAIL follows a convoy crossing illegally into Thailand. "We waded over with half a ton of opium and 270 Shans. They were armed with carbines and machine guns, and not a Burmese soldier or Thai policeman dared approach." Repeatedly, the film points to the corruption along the opium trail. "Opium's oldest name means 'rejoicing' and in the opium trail's wake of bribery no police force lacks the man who will choose to 'rejoice.'" After the product has been converted into morphine bricks at Maesai, a Thailand border town, it is taken by bus to Bangkok. There are many check points on this long road, but few arrests are made. From Bangkok, the product is taken by ship to Hong Kong, "the city that grew on opium." Here, to facilitate smuggling, the morphine bricks are transformed into heroin. The films shows the methods of sale, the operation of syndicates, police raids, and the practices of addicts. In Hong Kong, the police are active, but "terror protects the heroin syndicates." In fact, addicts and pushers permitted the film crew to shoot footage of their transactions, since "there just aren't enough police to watch every seller." In fact, "profits so exceed the risk of capture that the dens insure their smokers by paying the bail and fines of those who are caught." Cowell relates the theory that Red China is the leading recipient of opium trade. However, nowhere along the opium trail has Peking's fine hand been detected by Cowell and his crew.
Independent Television Corporation ; presentation of National Educational Television ; producer, Adrian Cowell.
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche: This program examines one-third of the citizens of this nation for whom high prices are not a cyclical phenomenon. It finds that the poor pay more - for less - everyday of their lives. They pay higher prices, are subject to greater exploitation, receives poorer quality merchandise and lack the legal means of remedying their plight. NET JOURNAL - THE POOR PAY MORE gives a graphical portrayal of the special hardships faced by the poor of our society in the area of consumer purchasing. There are reports on studies conducted by anti-poverty and other government agencies charging that neighborhood supermarkets raises their prices on the days that welfare clients receive their checks and set higher prices for the same goods in impoverished neighborhoods than in high income areas. Through the use of concealed cameras the viewer is actually shown the standard "pitch" by a door-to-door food-freezer salesman who characteristically promises prime quality goods but delivers commodities that are little more than junk - freezers that rapidly break down (often they are secondhand) saddling the purchaser with high repair costs in addition to the exorbitant finance charges. The techniques of encyclopedia salesmen, misrepresenting themselves as school board representatives and capitalizing on their customers' concern for their children's' future are described by a victim. The film shows the questionable methods of the furniture and appliance stores in the business of selling to the poor on time. It also reveals their association with the finance companies which reportedly clear as high a profit on the financing of the goods as the retailer makes on the sale. For the poor, credit buying is a way of life and thus tens of thousands of persons each year find themselves caught in the twin traps of payroll garnishment and repossession of goods. The program describes how the odds are stacked against the purchaser who, if dissatisfied with his purchase, finds it virtually impossible to gain an adjustment but who, if he misses a payment, stand to lose the goods, his credit rating, or his wages in attachment. Experts form anti-poverty programs such as the Harlem Consumers Council, Mobilization for Youth, Massive Economic Neighborhood Development (all from New York City) and the San Francisco based Bay Area Neighborhood Development delineate the problems of the impoverished American who, lacking bargaining power or workable channels of recourse, is prey to the unscrupulous businessman. The program shows how some social agencies are now attempting to alleviate this situation through the establishment of consumer education courses and food-buying cooperatives. But, the program finds, much more needs to be done in the area of protective legislation, but government agencies involved with the problem, by the courts, and by the poor themselves.
NET journal. The poor pay more.
a presentation of National Educational Television ; producer, writer, Mort Silverstein ; executive producer, Alvin H. Perlmutter.
NET journal. [1967-01-09]. The poor pay more.
National Educational Television and Radio Center
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche, file Q: This program, presented five days after the assassination of Senator Robert F. Kennedy, examined the nature of violence and its roots in American life. It also studied the innate character of aggression and its relation to overt acts, to neglect, and to example - such as the depiction of violence in the media. The program included the case of hostile child in a Detroit class for preschoolers. It showed his behavior with other children, depicting his parents' visit with a psychiatrist, to whom they revealed their bewilderment and resulting anger. Another segment, at the Children's Hospital in Detroit, dramatized the effects of "an act of omission" - in this case, an eight-month-old who was the victim of severe neglect, resulting in physical and psychological disorientation. The program also provided a historical view of violence in America - the assassinations of leaders, the rise of the Ku Klux Klan, the brutal squelching of strikes and other demonstrations, and the code of the gun (the latter celebrated in such current films as "Bonnie and Clyde," which was excerpted here). A seminar on violence, held in Los Angeles just before Robert Kennedy's death, elucidated various aspects of the subject. Among those present were anthropologist Margaret Mead, who indicated television for its predilection for violent events; psychiatrists Ralph Greenson of UCLA Medical School and Alvin Poussaint of Tufts University; and writer Paul Jacobs ("The New Radicals"), who noted the necessity of violence in a society that resists non-violent reform. The program concluded with the assertion by Harvard psychiatrist Robert Coles that a society can spur - or control - both the act of violence and the direction of individual aggression. He cited the example of Nazi Germany, "One of the most well-educated and enlightened nation as in the history of the world," at a time that predated television.
NET journal. The question of violence.
NET production ; executive producer, Paul Kaufman ; associate producer, Penny Bernstein.
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche, file S: Pope Paul VI, is seen in this documentary as a man torn between the realities of change and a spiritual tradition with vast pomp and subtle hierarchy. Previously known as "an intellectual with a polished social manner but cool and remote," the present Pope began practicing a "militant Christianity" in his role as Archbishop of Milan in the years from 1955 to 1963. At the same time, Pope John XXIII was presenting Catholicism with its great challenge: the need to change. This program assesses the extent to which John's successor, Pope Paul VI, has lived up to this challenge, especially in view of his directive on birth control and the resulting schism within the Catholic Church. Ecclesiastical authorities interviewed on the program comment, often critically, on the Pope's stance in this area. The program also views the Pope engaged in the traditional function of conducting an audience in St. Peter's and breaking from tradition as he travels to the Holy Land, the United Nations and South America. In personal terms, the program notes that "Pope Paul has tried to cut down on the pomp and pageantry .... His own manner is simple, when he speaks to people and blesses them he is diffident, he almost whispers. But he can't escape from tradition, from having to ride in a portable throne of velvet and gold." Meanwhile, "the world's Catholics look to him and wait for his decisions. Can he hear what they're saying beyond the Vatican in countries far from Rome? Does he understand why they're calling so loudly for change? Can he give the leadership that is needed? Appearing on the program are Cardinal Cicognani, Papal Secretary; Cardinal Suenens of Brussels, leading liberal at the Vatican Council; conservative Irish Cardinal Browne; Archbishops Benelli and Pignedoli; Anthony Spencer, Catholic sociologist; Peter Nichls, Rome correspondent of the London Times, and author of "The Politics of the Vatican." Commentary by George Scott, author of "The RC's." ADDITIONAL INFORMATION: In updating this program to reflect the Pope's "Humanae Vitae" ruling on birth control, NET has interviewed Bishop James Shannon of Minneapolis, spokesman for the recent Bishops' Conference in Washington, DC; James Finn, member of the Council of Religion and International Affairs; and Philip Sharper, editor of Sheed & Ward, a Catholic-oriented publishing house.

Adapted from a program produced for Intertel by Rediffusion Television Ltd., London ; an NET presentation ; executive producer, Jeremy Isaacs ; director, Randal Beattle ; NET executive producer, William Weston.
National Educational Television and Radio Center
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche, file S: On January 24, 1967, three years after the Surgeon General's report on the harmful effects of smoking, NET sent nine remote crews to San Diego, New York, London, Washington and Lexington, KY, for a documentary on the "man-made epidemic." Filmed in a single day, the program asks: What have men done in the past three years to protect themselves - and others - from such smokers' disease as lung cancer and emphysema? It addresses itself to Congressmen, to tobacco industry officials, to heads of smoking clinics, and to victims of emphysema. For Charles Cowan in a London suburb and Albert Sloan in San Diego, smoking is an accreting pain. Both are victims of emphysema, a disease that virtually immobilizes them; both have continued smoking, though its effects make their condition even more painful; and both have children who are already smokers. Contrary to all evidence, Cowan feels "the only vice I have is smoking. Surely I can afford to hold onto this one." Sloan more realistically observes: "Somebody's going to have to declare war on smoking." But the notion is disputed by J. Henry Ramm, a spokesman for the Tobacco Institute: "If there is something (harmful), the cigarette industry wants to know. To date scientists have found nothing." Senator Thurston Morton of Kentucky, a state rife with tobacco processing plants, concurs: "Man wants to enjoy life. Why, you could ban driving too." Morton describes as "a nave and juvenile approach" the suggestion by Senator Robert Kennedy (NY) that cigarette commercials be banned on television. Commercials are a target of several people interviewed on the show, from former Surgeon General Luther Terry to Cowan, who remarks that ads "create a vision that smoking is a part of the active life." The program visits a clinic in San Diego devoted to fighting the "chronic insult," and a similar smoking clinic in London. But as the day - January 24 - ends, there still remains "the conflict between the public good and the smoking machine." And despite all health warnings, the tobacco industry had its most profitable year in 1966. Among those appearing on the program are John Gardner, secretary of Health, Education and Welfare; former New Jersey governor Robert Meyner, administrator, Cigarette Advertising Code; California Congressman John Moss; and Dr. Daniel Horn, president of the Interagency Council on Smoking and Health.
a production of National Educational Television ; executive produceer, A.H. Perlmutter ; producer, Richard McCutchen ; associate producer, Dale Bell.
National Educational Television and Radio Center
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche: Program Description: The Spanish Civil War - a testing ground for the political ideologies and military armaments of the 1930s - is relived in this BBC documentary. The program examines the spirit of the times, which encouraged thousands of young men from England, America, and other countries to fight in the Civil War. In a historical vein, the program reviews earlier political upheavals in Europe in terms of the climate that led to the ouster of King Alfonso XIII, the brief ascendancy of the anarchists, and the eventual triumph of the nationalists, backed by German weaponry and manpower. Finally, the program looks at Spain today - with its materialistic emphases, imitative of other European nations.
produced by the British Broadcasting Corporation ; a presentation by National Educational Television ; compiler, producer, Therese Denny ; writer, James Morris.

"Traces the succession of political upheavals leading to the Spanish Civil War, the events of the war and Franco's rise to power. Shows how the forces of Germany and italy on the one side and of Russia on the other used this battlefield as the testing ground for political ideologies and warfare techniques to be used in World War II. Discusses the Spain which has emerged out of the ruins." (NICEM Index to 16mm educational films, vol. IV, Q-Z, p. 198)
produced by the British Broadcasting Corporation.
National Educational Television and Radio Center
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche (U): The "unknown war" involves Burmese guerillas in the Shan Valley as they prime themselves for a rebellion against the current military government of Burma. British producer Adrian Cowell lived with one troop of Shan guerillas during their preparation for combat and followed them with his film unit as they made a brief raid on a critical location. Cowell observes the rebels as they eat, gamble, plow their fields, and encourage their oxen to fight. He notes that the motivation of the Shan people is that they are basically farmers defending their land against nationalism. But they must have an effective leader before they can hope to overthrow the existing government. The film studies one Shan warlord as he drills his army and makes plans for rebellion. The film ends with a question rather than a resolution. At present, Burma is still ruled by the military government, while the rebels gather in separate bands in mountainous areas of the country.
produced by ATV, London ; a presentation of National Educational Television ; producer, Adrian Cowell.
National Educational Television and Radio Center
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche, file W: As the allies attack Berlin, "the madman in the bunker flings out his last orders" to an "army of old men and boys," then puts a gun to his head as the city falls... So ends THE WAR RELIVED, a German look at World War II. The madman -- Adolf Hitler -- and his extravagant dream of world domination are the subjects of this frank documentary which NET has adapted from a German feature film. Extensive newsreel footage, taken from the first days of glory through the final days of holocaust, enable the Germans to look at themselves 25 years after the beginning of World War II and to ask: "Who cheered? Who obeyed? Who is guilty?" From scenes of the Nuremberg war trials, the program goes back to the German preparation for war in summer of 1939 and the first attack on Poland that September. The dive bombers strafing Poland, the burning of Warsaw, and the boastful German headlines set the film's tone. But those first celebrations were all "very pompous and a bit premature," the program notes. The battles continue - the invasion of Holland, the fire consuming Rotterdam, the paratroops cracking Belgium's defenses at the Albert Canal, and the army driving the allies back through the Forests of Ardennes to within 16 miles of the sea. But "the miracle of Dunkirk" is the first of several tactical blunders by Hitler, according to the film. Soon to come is "his biggest, most foolish venture" - the attack on Russia in 1941. From this point, the film directs itself to three areas - the Russian campaign, the battle of the Atlantic, and the African front. The winter of 1941 is seen as the war's turning point, as German soldiers face "the searing sun of Africa" and the brutal cold of Russia. The "hour of the Red army" comes. Russians, often fighting on skis, counterattack. Stalingrad - decisive battle of the war - is still a few months away. Suddenly it is the German army which staggers - and German headlines must announce chauvinistically: "They died so that Germany may live." In Africa, Montgomery attacks, Hitler's tactics fail, and a whole army is captured. Finally comes "the bitterest phase as the mightiest invasion fleet the world has ever known" lands on D-Day - June 6, 1944. Still, the Germans "fight as if Hitler had ordered each and every one of them not to give an inch." German strategy increasingly turns to super-weapons - inventions that invariably fail, such as the retaliation bomb, the buzz bomb, the V2, the double torpedo, and "little Goliath," an anti-tank explosive charge on wheels. But there is no miracle for Germany. Now it is the German cities that burn. Paris is freed. And the Stalin tanks advance inexorably toward Berlin. In the end, there is just Berlin and its last defenders - the sick and the old, men in overcoats and children of 14 sporting "their decorations and their destroyed youth." NET JOURNAL - THE WAR RELIVED is a National Educational Television presentation based on a film by Planet-Film Production, Germany. NET executive producer: William Weston. English version: Dominic Capezza. Narrator: Norman Rose.
Planet-Film Production, Germany ; National Educational Television presentation ; executive producer, William Weston ; English version [translator], Dominic Capezza.
National Educational Television and Radio Center
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche: At the end of this session, Chief Justice Earl Warren will retire from the Supreme Court of the U.S. after 16 years in office. His departure marks the end of an era in which the Supreme Court has revolutionized the law and the conscience of America. Through the lead of the Warren Court, the other two branches of government have acted in such areas as civil rights legislation and reapportionment. As a symbol of this court, vast controversy has gathered about Earl Warren himself. Many believe that it is unlikely that the Court will maintain its present impact on American life under new leadership (Warren Earl Burger, President Nixon's appointee, will soon assume the role, pending Senate approval). Information on participants in the program is forthcoming. The format of the program is as follows: 1. A biographical look at Earl Warren, as Chief Justice, recalling his earlier service as Governor and Attorney General of California, and his role as leading contender for the Republican nomination for President. (A biography of Mr. Warren follows.) 2. The record of the Warren Court in three broad areas: a.) the school desegregation ruling and the civil rights decisions that followed; b.) reapportionment, an aspect that Warren calls his Court's greatest achievement; c.) criminal procedure rulings, which further defined the rights of suspects and the behavior of legal authorities. 3. The men of the Warren Court: Outstanding justices such as Felix Frankfurter, Hugo Black, William O. Douglas, and William Brennan, probing both their influence on Warren and the effect of his personality upon their decisions. 4. The final portion of this program will consist of a panel discussion on the role of the Warren Court in American society. Participants are Alexander Bickel of Yale Law School, Senator Sam Ervin (D-NC), and Edward Bennett Williams, celebrated defense attorney. Moderator is Paul Niven, NET's national correspondent. The program will include excerpts from Judge Warren's two forthcoming commencement addresses at Lincoln University, an all-black school in Lincoln Park, Pa., and at Norwich University in Northfield, Vt. There will also be an interview with Earl Warren Jr., himself a judge in Sacramento, Calif, and eight of Warren's law clerks will reminisce on the Chief Justice and his 16 years of service. NET has been chosen to receive a 1970 Gavel Award from the American Bar Association for its June 1969 program "The Warren Years." Suggested Newspaper Listing: "The Warren Years": Marking the end of a judiciary epoch, this 90-minute documentary examines Earl Warren, his imprint on the Supreme Court, and his impact on American society.
National Educational Television production ; producer, Jim Karayn ; director, Max Schindler.
National Educational Television and Radio Center
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche (W): In September 1966, a major metropolitan university took on a major problem in secondary education - the ghetto school. Backed by a Ford Foundation grant, New York University's Clinic for Learning focused its attention and talents on Junior High School 57 in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn. At the same time, producer Harold Mayer and his crew arrived for a documentary study of the ghetto school. Original impressions were far from encouraging. The NET film begins with some of these impressions. During a special meeting, members of the NYU project describe the reigning mood of each classroom - bedlam, disinterest, no reading skills. How can you make them hear? asks Jack Robertson, project director. The camera moves abruptly to a series of classrooms, where children play tic-tac-toe, drum on their desks, shout at each other, shove, fall off chairs, dance, or sit on a radiator in an attitude of withdrawal. Nowhere is there a sense of attention. As one teacher laments: "These kids just don't believe in words." Confronted with this chaos, the NYU group and individual teachers try various approaches to "reach" the children. Working separately with a troubled boy, an English teacher encourages him to deal with language. A Negro teacher of arithmetic shouts "I challenge you" to a boy engaged in a problem at the blackboard. Members of his class are permitted to sing and to argue among themselves - as long as their subject is arithmetic. In another class, students read "Black Boy" by Richard Wright and a detective story, in two attempts to make them relate to the material and to view it without their usual disdain. Meanwhile, community leaders attempt to engage the local mothers. The camera follows them into a grocery store, a church, and a schoolroom where some mothers appear. However, apathy is the prevailing mood in the ghetto. While educators debate the best way to proceed, little success is noted at Junior High School 57. NYU will devote another 18 months to the project. It has already lost five of its original 15 members. At this point, in one teacher's words, "we've just learned what questions to ask." But the teacher can't simultaneously function as psychologist, cop, mother, father - and teacher, says Mayer. "There's a mechanism at work in the ghetto situation. And until you get at it - until, in effect, you do away with the ghetto - you can't really talk about education. The simple fact is that these kids will be five years behind by the time they get out of high school - if they get out. And this is the reality of all urban ghetto education." Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET Journal: The Way It Is: At a ghetto school in Brooklyn, this documentary traces an experimental project and some traditional resistance.
NET journal. The way it is.
a production of National Educational Television ; producer-director, Harold Mayer ; writer, Lynne Rhodes Mayer.
NET journal. [No. 133], The way it is.
National Educational Television and Radio Center
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche, file W: This program looks at the faces within the welfare rolls, and echoing them, finds defeat, degradation, and "an aura of illegitimacy" engendered by "cumbersome and paternalistic" rules. Welfare is treated as a "privilege" rather than as a "right" recipients feel. There is not enough money for a decent existence -- each request for money to clothe a child is an act of self-abasement. Work is discouraged, since a woman can keep only a negligible share of her earnings while she remains on welfare. And, in the case of deserted or unmarried women with dependent children there is almost no chance of a decent relationship with a man, because the system permits that an apartment to be searched at any time of the day, and that she be deprived of her welfare check if a man (even the children's father) is found on the premises. It is against this system that the clients' group are directing their energies, banded together into the nationwide Welfare Rights Organization. And the film dramatizes the movement, which had its beginnings in a 250-mile march from Cleveland to Columbus, Ohio, last June 30. This year, on the same date, the film follows an anniversary march by the members of the Rights organization in Cleveland, where demands are presented to the county welfare department. Much of the film takes place in Cleveland. Here, the conditions of families on ADC (Aid to Dependent Children) are depicted, and mothers describe how they raise large families on inadequate checks. When the welfare check arrives late, one mother explains, there is often no food. When children need clothing, she must "get down on hands and knees" and ask for money from the welfare department. The difficulty of welfare is compounded by such human insults as food stamps, the film notes. Since woman on welfare have their needs categorized, they must often improvise -- such as Cleveland women have done in organizing a soap cooperative. At school, welfare children face "constant and subtle discrimination." Their free lunches set them out at "cases." They lack money to engage in regular school activities. They must seek outlets when they can find them cheaply - on the streets, in dancing, in sex. And each attempt to "break out of the welfare trap" leads back to the same place. A girl named Brenda, who became pregnant shortly after high school, explains that it is an economic necessity for her to remain single so that she can be a candidate for the welfare rolls until her boyfriend has become well established in a job. A widower with a young family, "one of the worthy poor," is then seen as he engages in computer training and waits on his children at home. Later, in a phone call to the welfare department, he makes an itemized plea for additional help. The paradox of his situation is that welfare funds can readily provide a homemaker for his children's care, but that their basic clothing needs are more difficult to obtain. Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET JOURNAL - "The Welfare Revolt": A stark look at the faces within the welfare rolls and a dramatic movement now agitating for change, led by the National Welfare Rights Organization.
National Educational Television ; executive producer, Harry McCarthy ; producer-writer, Herbert Krosney.
National Educational Television and Radio Center
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche (W): This program gives an unflinching view of the "mean streets" of El Barrio, a section of New York City otherwise known as Spanish Harlem. The many strains of El Barrio are evoked through the experiences of one of its most noted residents, Piri Thomas. A lifelong inhabitant of the section, Thomas has known many of the frustrations of his people in this alien land. He was born into the poverty that most Puerto Ricans experience here. And failing in his hopes, Thomas has descended into the abyss of crime and drug addiction. But Thomas has been able to "beat the rap" impressed upon him by his environment, and his book "Down These Mean Streets" records this triumph over circumstance. Most recently, Thomas has been engaged in founding the East Harlem Creative Writing Workshop. In this documentary, Thomas is the ubiquitous voice, commenting on his own life in the Barrio and on the fate of his people. He also reenacts key incidents in his life - such as his shooting by a policeman after he had held up a nightclub, and the agonies that accompanied his drug addiction. With a keyhole-like effect, the camera intrudes on the bare room where Thomas first inserted the needle, then thirsted for another "fix" in a "cold, shivering sweat," his "pride as a man blown away by a hell of shame." Then, still experiencing his "hell-filled concerto," Thomas punches a wall before offering "a eulogy for the amigos who didn't make it." The effect of life in the Barrio is conveyed first through a montage of faces, sounds, and moods. Later, through juxtaposition, it indicates how quickly the dream of a young Puerto Rican bride fades into the drudgery of a life with too many children and too few escapes; her husband, beaten by poverty, must fear his children's plaintive requests for circus tickets or new shoes. Again, later in the program, there is a juxtaposition of a fat rat, squatting triumphant over a Barrio garbage can and a funeral mass for a local resident killed in war. Children are also used to convey the moods of El Barrio, as they are asked to choose between New York and Puerto Rico and describe the lives of their parents. In their drawings, the children depict the schizophrenia of ghetto living, as roaches and rats lurk over darkened bedrooms. It is against this background that Piri Thomas must climb to a rooftop, ignoring the garbage and the refuse of lives, and boast "I am my majesty, Piri Thomas... I am a human being." And it is here that he can remember the feelings that helped him survive a prison term: "My life shall be an enchantment. I will bring my people off these mean streets into fresh clean air." A portion of Thomas' narration consists of dramatized readings from his book.
NET journal. The world of Piri Thomas.

From The Morning News (Wilmington, Delaware) 7 April 1969 page 13: "The hour long documentary follows student-administration accord reached after recent University of Pennsylvania campus protests. Some students objected to government research contracts which would 'foster the war effort' and the university's expansion into a neighboring ghetto. With the aid of faculty mediators, a three-fold resolution was defined: suspension of all university research deemed 'destructive to human life;' a $10 million indemnity for 'ghetto damage;' and provision for neighborhood residents to sit on the board which will consider future university expansion. Footage of the student movement, which features the University's 'Day of Conscience' discussion of the uses and misuses of knowledge, includes interviews with administrators, faculty members, students and area residents." (RPAR 9/20/2016). From NET microfiche (T): This program examines a break in the inflammatory campus scene - at the University of Pennsylvania, where agreement was reached after demonstrations just two weeks ago. The protest at Pennsylvania centered around government contracts for research that would foster the war effort, and expansion by the University into neighboring ghettos. One solution reached by the administration, with the aid of faculty mediators, involves the suspension of all research deemed destructive to human life. In addition, the University settled on a $10 million indemnity for damage already done in the ghetto and arranged for local residents to sit on a board that will consider any future expansion. Administrators, faculty members, students, and local residents are interviewed on the program. There is also footage of the University's Day of Conscience, at which the uses and misuses of knowledge are discussed. For the second half of this program, a panel of college presidents will address themselves to the issue of campus demonstrations. Panelists are Dr. Andrew W. Cordier of Columbia University, Dr. Douglas M. Knight of Duke University, and Fred H. Harrington of the University of Wisconsin. Interviewer is Peter Schrag, editor of Change, a journal of higher education, and author of "Village School Downtown" and "Voices in the Classroom." The panelists will appear live in New York City.
NET journal. To calm a troubled campus.
a production of National Educational Television ; producer, John Richard Starkey; field producer, Gordon Thomas ; executive producer, Ned Schnurman ; director, Max Schindler.
NET journal. [No. 231], To calm a troubled campus.

From NET microfiche: An American-Canadian student debate, taped on the campus of New York University during the recent (April 24-28) celebration of Canada Week. The subject was the war in Viet Nam, and the debate, in which no formal sides were drawn, resulted in an anti-war stand by the American students, with the Canadians arguing for the U.S. involvement In Vietnam. Among the institutions represented are the University of Toronto, Dartmouth, Columbia, Harvard, and Smith College. The moderator is Laurier La Pierre, a noted CBC television personality and a member of the faculty of McGlll University. The debate took up such issues as what role Canada should play in the Viet Nam dispute, i.e., should it try to be an intermediary, and if so should its method be that of quiet diplomacy or direct negotiation. Or should Canada assume a more activist form of protest against the war. Should Canada risk alienating Washington by such protest? Should Canada allow itself to be a haven for young Americans fleeing the draft? And should it allow American anti-war groups to ship supplies to North Viet Nam through Canadian channels? Suggested Newspaper Listing: On the campus of New York University, American and Canadian students debate the war in Vietnam, with the former virtually unanimous in their condemnation of American policy and the latter generally in favor of U.S. involvement. Program Description (Additional Information): American students call on Canada to be "more condemnatory" of US involvement in Vietnam during a "Canada Week" celebration at New York University. National Educational television presents highlights from this campus discussion in the hour-long program, "Two Views: A Canadian-American Student Debate." The "NET Journal" program is moderated by Professor Laurier La Pierre of McGill University and features students from several American and Canadian universities - including Dartmouth, Columbia, Harvard, University of Toronto, and Smith College. The students asks: Should Canada take an independent stand on the Vietnam War, or would its economic reliance on the US be endangered by criticism? And should Canada provide a haven for young American "draft dodgers?" Virtually all of the American students deplore the American military effort and call on Canada to "break more ties" with the US and to shed its "subservient position." Canadian students feel that their country "fears a hostile Washington" and question whether most Canadians "give a damn about what's going on in Vietnam." The students also debate whether Canada should be used as a shipping point by Americans wishing to help the North Vietnamese people, and whether the protest movement in either Canada or the United States is a significant political weapon.
co-production of National Educational Television and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation; producer, Harry McCarthy; director, David Ruskin.
NET journal. [No. 141], Two views--A Canadian-American student debate.

From NET microfiche, file U: Program Description #1: Clark Kerr discusses the role of the university in relation to the student, the community and the government in an interview with Joseph Russin on the campus of Harvard University. Kerr, former President of the University of California, notes that today's students are helping to create reforms in society and to broaden education on campus. But the student, Kerr says, should have no more than "an advisory role in the university." He feels that the university should not engage in "secret research" for the government, but should leave the decision of its "morality" to the individual faculty members (i.e. in A-bomb or biological warfare research). Kerr also notes the "undesirability" of public influences on the university (an apparent reference to his conflict with the California Board of Regents). The difficulty, Kerr says, is that "the university has become so important to all of society ... that everybody's got an interest in it ... Somebody ought to be the protector of its permanent purposes." Discussing the difference between student morality and adult morality, Kerr says, "the minds don't meet." Youths "charge society with being immoral" for its espousal of war and prejudice, whereas youths are condemned as immoral for their attitudes on sex and drugs. Kerr warns, however, that it is dangerous to consider the protesting students as a single entity. "The university ought to adapt to the students' role to self-determination." They are "part of the community, not transients." But Kerr adds: "Protest can't go beyond the law." Kerr does not believe in "selective conscientious objectors." A young person can't "choose which war" he's going to protest. He also notes an "abuse" in the deferment of college students because they can afford to continue in school. In returning to teach at the University of California, Kerr says, "I wanted to declare ... my confidence in the long-range future of the University." Program Description #2: "Student power" must not extend to "determining the curriculum" or deciding "who gets hired and fired" on the university campus, former University of California president Clark Kerr said in a National Educational Television interview last night (Monday, May 22). "The student can give good advice," but he remains "an apprentice in the academic world," Kerr explained on "NET Journal - University Power: A Conversation with Clark Kerr." The program was carried locally on WNDT/Channel 13. Though commending the students' interest in "a broader orientation toward the world," Kerr said they should be limited to a "judicial" or "legislative" role in the handling of campus affairs. Given "an executive role," he said, "they'd turn it over to bureaucracy too, and not give it very good supervision." Kerr also discussed the students' new interest in "moral rhetoric." Comparing the current student protest with his own involvement with the great issues of the 1930's, Kerr said, "For every person like myself in the '30s, there'd be ten or 100 today." Kerr also discussed the relationship between the university and society: "The university has become so important to all of society that nobody wants to leave it alone any more ... Everybody's got an interest in it ... Somebody ought to protect its permanent purposes." Asked about his firing, Kerr said: "The Regents felt they had an obligation to the people through the Governor," on the basis of Ronald Reagan's large plurality. Though the Regents have an obligation to be a "buffer" between the public and the university, Kerr said, "in the end it was less than it should have been." Kerr was asked if the university should engage in secret research that fosters the war effort. He said: "Secrecy is quite inconsistent with the purpose of the university on campus." However, the individual faculty member should have the right to decide, Kerr said. Concerning chemical research that's not secret, Kerr supported the discovery of new knowledge, regardless of its eventual purpose. "If you don't discover it, someone else will." He added: "The University is really concerned with the true, not the good." Returning to the subject of student protest, Kerr said: "Protest should not go beyond the law," nor "into the classroom." The university, however, should be "a moral voice" in a subject such as the draft. He strongly opposed the idea of selective conscientious objections. "You can't say people can pick and choose which war they're going to fight in. Either you're against war or you aren't." He added: "The biggest abuse is the deferment of college students, since they can afford to remain in school."
NET journal. University power--a conversation with Clark Kerr.
a production of National Educational Television ; produced through the facilities of WGBH, Boston ; producer, Howard Spergel.
University power--a conversation with Clark Kerr.

From NET microfiche: THE VANISHING NEWSPAPER (Part 1) examines the metropolitan press on its road to monopoly and merger. It relates the financial dilemma of the big-city press to its failure to deal with the problems of its cities - such as the spreading Negro ghettos and the disappearing white middle class. This portion of the program focuses on the changing character of the city of Baltimore and the role played by Baltimore papers, which have only recently devoted adequate space to the problems of the Negro. Tracing the exodus of the middle class to the suburbs, THE VANISHING NEWSPAPER goes into the Chicago suburb of Arlington Heights, IL where Marshall Field Enterprises has opened a daily paper in competition with the community weekly. The program discusses the trend toward daily supplemental papers which must become complete newspapers to survive in a country where one-paper families abound. Among those featured on the program: " Ralph Ingersoll, former editor of PM, who laments that advertising forces newspapers to direct themselves to the affluent. " W.H. (Ping) Ferry, of the Center for the Study of Democratic Institutions, who calls the press "an arm of the establishment," and criticizes its tendency to ignore the festering of problems in areas like Watts until the rioting breaks out. The press, says Ferry, should be "an early warning system" on national and community problems. " Frank Conniff, managing editor of the World Journal Tribune, who disputes the contentions of Ingersoll and Ferry. " Baltimoreans Paul Banker (managing editor of the Sun), Phillip Heisler (managing editor of the Evening Sun), Sterling Noel (managing editor of the News-American), and George Collins (city editor of the Afro-American), who discuss financial survival and civic responsibility. The local sit-ins of 1959 were ignored by the dairy press; however, the papers are all beginning to vie for the interest of the Negro reader. Three principals in the Arlington Heights readership battle, who discuss the need for balancing world and local coverage in a suburban paper. Additional Description from NET Press Release: National Educational Television begins a two-part study on the decline of the American press in "N.E.T. Journal -- The Vanishing Newspaper -- Part I." This first hour is devoted to "the metropolitan press on the road to monopoly and merger." Over a 15-year period, one metropolitan paper has either merged or disappeared on an average of every three months. The result has been a number of one-publisher and even one-paper cities. Recently, this fact was dramatized by the creation of the New York World Journal Tribune, which left a city of eight million people with four daily newspapers. "The Vanishing Newspaper -- Part I" relates the financial dilemma of the press to its failure in dealing with the problems of its cities -- notably, the plight of the Negro and the exodus of the white middle class to suburbia. W. H. (Ping) Ferry of the Center for the Study of Democratic Institutions cites the Watts section of Los Angeles, "a festering sore" that was ignored by the press until the riots of 1965. Then, "people were being killed, property was being destroyed -- and the press did an illustrious job." According to Ferry, the press should be "an early warning system" on national and community problems. Instead, it acts as "an arm of the establishment." Frank Conniff, managing editor of the World Journal Tribune, argues that the newspaper is doing "what it functions at best, which is reporting the news and interpreting it. " N. E. T. Journal's examination will continue with "Vanishing Newspaper -- Part II," a study of the small-town press and "the news small-town America isn't reading."
a National Educational Television production; producer, writer, John O'Toole ; executive producer, Alvin Perlmutter.
National Educational Television and Radio Center
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche: This program examines the role of the small town press. Is it a bulletin board a vehicle for advertisers or a responsible journal that reports and interprets both world and local news? NET JOURNAL. -- THE VANISHING NEWSPAPER (Part II) analyzes the performance of the press in four small towns -- only two of which meet a "balance between profit and public service." The Bennington (Vt.) Banner and the Berkshire Eagle in Pittsfield, Mass., are owned by Pete and Don Miller, two brothers whose papers contain many non-local stories, syndicated columns, and a high ratio of news to ads. A monopoly paper, the Eagle is criticized by some, praised by others for "speaking its mind" on major issues. The paper's low profit -- six percent -- is attributable to such "frills" as a large news staff and a critic of the lively arts (a true rarity in a small-town paper). The Okmulgee (Okla.) Daily Times and the Fort Smith (Ark.) papers -- the Southwest-American and Times Record -- belong to a chain of 14 newspapers, three television stations, and several radio stations belonging to the Don Rey Media Group. Its president, Don Reynolds, is "visible only in portrait. " The Okmulgee paper is conspicuous for the news it doesn't cover. The ad ratio is high. Most of the editorials are "thinly veiled promotional pieces." The death of a cow is covered on page one, a canned horoscope runs under the masthead; national news, such as the shooting of James Meredith is either ignored or reported in capsule form. The Fort Smith papers do run syndicated columns and some national news. But despite Don Rey's monopoly of all media in this Arkansas city, the papers avoid controversial stands. Among those appearing on the program are: " Pete and Don Miller " Doyle Rainwater, general manager, and Johnny Johnson, editor, of the Okmulgee Daily Times. " Rosa Pendergraft, general manager of the Fort Smith papers. " Rex Fall, managing editor of the Berkshire Eagle. Additional Description from NET Press Release: Most small-town readers are paying more for and getting less from their local paper. This view of "the news small-town America isn't reading" is seen in "The Vanishing Newspaper --Part II. " The second of two hours being devoted to the American press on the "NET Journal" series, this program consists of interviews with local editors and an assessment of the performance of papers in Bennington, Vt. ; Pittsfield, Mass.; Fort Smith, Ark.; and Okmulgee, Okla. -- only two of which meet "a balance between profit and public service." Each of these papers has a virtual monopoly. The Southern papers belong to the Don Rey Media Group whose owner, Don Reynolds, is "visible only in his portrait. " Don Rey controls the television and radio stations and even the billboards in Fort Smith, a city of about 70,000. Yet the Fort Smith press avoids controversial stands. In Okmulgee, the one paper tends to avoid news -- unless it is the death of a cow, the phenomenon of a piano obtained with trading stamps, or a local auto wreck. Its editor admits "the editorial is our weakest page." Canned editorials -- often espousing an advertiser's view --are frequent. In Pittsfield, the monopoly situation has encouraged news. Pete and Don Miller, owners of the Berkshire Eagle, maintain a large staff for a wide range of assignments. A girl covers the lively arts -- a true oddity in the small-town press. The result of such "frills" is a paper with a low-profit margin but a diversity of information. Yet some readers complain that the paper is too controversial in its liberal stands and too national in character. "Today too many small-town newspapers are bulletin boards. Too many publishers have become sellers of advertising space," observes Henry Butler, narrator of "The Vanishing Newspaper." There should be room for at least as many pages of political comment as there are of comic strips. There should be room under the masthead for editorial leadership."
a National Educational Television production; producer, writer, John O'Toole ; executive producer, Alvin Perlmutter.
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche, file W: Program Description: From Saigon, four leading correspondents view Vietnam's battles and bulletins on "NET Journal -- Warfront '68." Participating in this National Educational Television production are Robert Shaplen of The New Yorker, Pulitzer Prize winner Peter Arnett of the Associated Press, William Touhy of the Los Angeles Times, and R. W. Apple, Jr., of The New York Times. A. H. Perlmutter, the program's executive producer, also acts as moderator. The men focus on various aspects of the information war, such as alleged Administration efforts to discredit the widespread pessimism of press reports. Shaplen contends that the President has "painted himself into a corner" by refusing to acknowledge the extent of this country's commitment throughout Southeast Asia. Other subjects include pacification, the recent Vietnamese elections, growing anti-Americanism in South Vietnam, and the difficulty of molding national spirit in a "non-nation" where corruption is rife. Touhy notes: ''The great horror is that posed against this government milieu of corruption and unresponsive government, you have the Vietcong, and one of their hallmarks is that they, by and large, are not corrupt." The men also give their assessment of the battlefield, where General Westmoreland and his command are "mistakenly looking at Vietnam, at the war, in conventional terms." Arnett explains that one Vietcong objective, as evidenced in the recent Dakto battle, is to "pull Americans out of populated areas, and get them into a no-man's land where ... it was just pure fighting and no pacification." Additional Information: The correspondents participating in this program will be Robert Shaplen of The New Yorker, Peter Arnett of Associated Press, William Touhy of the Los Angeles Times, and R. W. Apple Jr. of The New York Times. Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET JOURNAL -- "Warfront '68": From Saigon, an assessment of the Vietnamese War and its coverage, by leading correspondents (insert names when available).

From NET microfiche, file W: This program is an NET adaptation of the Japanese-made film which won first prize in the "Prix Italia -- Documentary Division." It recounts the Japanese investigation of possible causes for the worst single airplane crash in history which led to the death of all 133 persons aboard. The plane, a Boeing 727 jet, operated by Japan Airlines, suddenly fell into Tokyo Bay as it approached Tokyo International Airport on February 4, 1966. In presenting the Japanese film, NET has included an interview with Bobbie R. Allen, director of the Bureau of Safety of Civil Aeronautics Board. These questions relate primarily to the performance of the 727 and CAB's research into the three other 727 crashes -- all occurring in the United States within a period of a year and a half. The Japanese film asks the most basic of questions: "What happened up there? Loss of speed, an explosion, engine failure?" One by one, as the plane is photographed underwater by frogmen and wreckage is raised from the sea, the investigation rules out strictly mechanical explanations. Tests indicate that number three engine did not apparently fall; that a bolt did not suffer metal fatigue, as had been suspected; and that a Boeing 727 can tolerate a descent of 5,000 feet per minute, as is proven in subsequent re-runs of the same course. However, the plane was making its descent at dusk, forcing the pilot to adjust suddenly from bright light to semi-darkness. Loss of control thus becomes the apparent reason for the crash. And the Japanese film climaxes with the ominous note: "There is a growing imbalance between the efficiency of a jet plane and man's navigational ability ... A machine which mankind cannot control can only destroy man... The question arises: is man sophisticated enough to withstand the confrontation between himself and the super-civilization he is creating?" Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET JOURNAL -- WHAT HAPPENED UP THERE: Winner of the "Prix Italia," this Japanese-made documentary investigates the worst air crash in history using the framework of an examination of wreckage removed from Tokyo Bay.
NET journal. What happened up there.
NET journal. [No. 121], What happened up there.
