Documents the experiences of a group of farmworkers who became trapped in a system that kept them perpetually in debt. Shows methods of recruitment, labor camps on Long Island, and types of work involved. Presents opinions of growers and processors and a refutation of their views. From NET microfiche: WHAT HARVEST FOR THE REAPER is an unflinching study of the exploitation of migrant workers, filmed at a labor camp on Cutchogue, Long Island. (Cutchogue is a community less than two hours drive from New York City and half an hour from the Hamptons and other pleasure beaches of Long Island.) There, the migrants come from Southern backwaters under the promise of wages they could never receive at home -- and which they never collect in Cutchogue. The program follows two groups -- one brought in for summer strawberry and string-bean picking, the other imported for the potato season in the fall. Cameras follow them as they work in the fields, live in the mean camps, and learn some economic facts of life as taught by Andrew Anderson, crew chief and camp manager. It is Anderson who goes to Arkansas to recruit workers, promising "extra money for Santa Claus," and returning with the men on a bus ride for which they will later be billed; it is Anderson who rents them blankets, charges for the fuel that warms the shacks, bills them for the bus ride to the fields each morning, and provides the credit for room, board, gambling, and small loans; and it is Anderson who keeps the books and deducts his portion from each check. Though the men resent Anderson and attempt to challenge his hold over them, their efforts are futile. They've been down too long and most of them back out of a planned confrontation. Similarly, during the potato harvest, they pay their union dues but don't know how the money is used or why they can't gain representation. To farmers who own and operate the labor camp, the workers are "destructive," "not men but two-legged animals" who are "interested in what they can get out of you, not what they can do for you"; who "like this type of travel, this type of work, and don't want responsibilities." To the potato processor, who also gains from their labor, they are men "exploited" not by the potato industry, but "by their own kind." The workers express their fear and their disillusionment. Some lament the lack of money to get back home. Others wish for a better life for their children. But most will be forced on to the next migrant camp, where the "economics of exploitation" await them. (These economics provide, for instance, that the landowner collects $200 for a product which reaps $12 for six workers.) The Rev. Arthur Bryant, head of the migrant committee of the Suffolk County Human Relations Commission, deplores the fate of the migrant ("He is us") in a society that values the "health of industry, not human life." In conclusion, the program notes that in the 10 years since Edward Murrow's 'Harvest of Shame," the migrant worker remains victim of a system he never made. Narrator: Philip Sterling. Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET JOURNAL -- "What Harvest for the Reaper": An unflinching study of the exploitation of the migrant worker, filmed during a six-month period in a migrant camp at Cutchogue, Long Island.
NET journal. What harvest for the reaper?
National Educational Television and Radio Center ; executive producer, A. H. Perlmutter ; producer, writer, Morton Silverstein.

A report on where the three presidential candidates (Vice President Hubert Humphrey, Richard Nixon and George Wallace) stand on the issue of "law and order." The program explores each candidate's attitude about and strategy for dealing with increasing violence and crime. In the second part of the program, four correspondents discuss the voters' attidues about each candidate and make predictions about the outcome of the election. Contents : Humphrey / producer, Hal Kirn ; writer, Frank Fletcher ; narrator, Peter Thomas -- Nixon / producer-writer, Ned Schnurman ; narrator, Richard McCutchen -- Wallace / producer, Harry McCarthy ; narrator, William Prince -- Law and order / producer-writer, David Prowitt -- Regional reports / producer, William Weston ; correspondents, Jack Mabley, Neal Maxwell, Sylvan Meyer, Richard Reeves.
Executive producer, Jim Karayn ; director, Max Schindler.

A report on where the three presidential candidates (Vice President Hubert Humphrey, Richard Nixon and George Wallace) stand on the issue of "law and order." The program explores each candidate's attitude about and strategy for dealing with increasing violence and crime. In the last portion of the program, four correspondents discuss the voters' attidues about each candidate and make predictions about the outcome of the election. Contents : Humphrey / producer, Hal Kirn ; writer, Frank Fletcher ; narrator, Peter Thomas -- Nixon / producer-writer, Ned Schnurman ; narrator, Richard McCutchen -- Wallace / producer, Harry McCarthy ; narrator, William Prince -- Law and order / producer-writer, David Prowitt -- Regional reports / producer, William Weston ; correspondents, Jack Mabley, Neal Maxwell, Sylvan Meyer, Richard Reeves (ca. 20 minutes).
Executive producer, Jim Karayn ; director, Max Schindler.
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche: In France, the "upper crust" makes the decisions, sets the style, and reaps the rewards. Known as the "Two Hundred," France's aristocrats have maintained - and improved - their position over the past 200 years, after surviving the French Revolution. In Germany, however, the upper crust lost power in 1918. Since then, no group has filled the void. In contrasting the two countries, this documentary asks: "Who needs an upper crust?" Produced by North German Television and adapted by NET, the program contains rare films of French aristocrats at work and play: Baron Rothschild at his chateau, the Lanvins discussing perfume and playwriting, the Polignacs and their wine-aging caves, and editor Ferniot at his L'Express office. The film then turns to French institutions which help to perpetuate the aristocracy's elite position - the French Academy, and the Grand Ecoles ("great" schools, which are government-administered, such as St. Cyr, Polytechnique, and the Ecole Nationale Administrative). The graduates of these schools will someday assume the highest positions in government, business, and the military. There will be a few "outsiders"; but they will probably be led by sons of the Two Hundred. In Germany, the program finds wealth but no wit, enterprise without elegance. Social functions lack the bright, sophisticated talk of a French soiree. The German gentlewoman may attend a charm school, but her "most important role is still that of the hausfrau." From the kitchen, the film moves to the German school for which "the primary qualification is not ability but money." The film notes the lack of a controlled system, "as in France, seeking out the best brains and polishing them to a maximum of brilliance for service to the country." The film indicates this shortcoming in three professions - the law, the civil service, and politics (where there is a lack of the "old school tie" and where prominent positions are tenuous). Educators are the rare exception, since they have both permanency and prestige. The program concludes: "The German people would undoubtedly be better able to fulfill their important role if they had a unifying, moderating, elevating force such as the French have in their elite ... There are no arbiters at work creating and improving standards of literature, art, language or even behavior. Germany is a pragmatic world, with each individual cutting his own path, making his own mistakes ... Who needs an upper crust? Germany, for one, definitely needs it."
NET journal. Who needs an upper crust.
a presentation of National Educational Television ; produced by North German Television ; NET producer, William Weston ; English adaptation by Artthur Lodge.

This first program in an international series of dramas reflecting the gap between generations stars British actor David Silver and popular radio personality Jean Shepherd in an unconventional drama about a young man who sets out on an odyssey to discover what America is like beneath the facades.

Telelcast as a New Year's special, this program is composed of segments produced by various public television stations around the country. Each segment represents a different aspect of the arts. Among the featured artists are Lawrence Ferlinghetti, Robert Cromie, Dick Gregory, George Carlin, Mason Williams, Taj Mahal, Fred Rogers, and a complete performance of Edward's Albee's "The Sandbox," produced by the New York Television Theatre.
Thoughts of the Artist on Leaving the Sixties

From NET microfiche: A number of NET affiliate stations are contributing items to this New Year's Day special ranging the art and entertainment world of the sixties. The items naturally reflect areas with which these stations have become especially identified. The run-down is as follows: 1. KQED, San Francisco: This segment reflects the role of the poet as social critic in the sixties. Well-known San Francisco poet Lawrence Ferlinghetti reads a selection from his recently published satiric poem "Tyrannus Nix" over a filmed animation of images - President Nixon and others - suggested by the words. 2. WTTW, Chicago: Robert Cromie, popular host of "Bookbeat," comments on a major loss of the sixties: the death during the past decade of many of the great names who created and shaped modern American literature. Chicago-based author Nelson Algren reads from Ernest Hemingway's "The Sun Also Rises" and "A Farewell to Arms."; actress Jessica Tandy reads from Flannery O'Connor's "The Violent Bear It Away"; and Ira Rogers reads from Langston Hughes* ("the O. Henry of Harlem") "The Best of Simple. 3. WITF, Hershey: A comedy sketch satirizing a media coverage of a fictional Senate investigation on humor in the sixties. Guests include Dick Gregory and Al Feldstein (editor of Mad magazine). 4. KLRN, Austin: A group of young Texas filmmakers is producing a film piece satirizing the cliches of the "new cinema" of the sixties, such as the Andy Warhol film, the "sincere" Western, "Bonnie and Clyde," etc. 5. WGBH, Boston: Three short segments illustrate the sound of the sixties: the development of the Beatles is shown by a sound collage of Beatles music played over an animated collage of pop imagery. Different versions of Bob Dylan's "Times They Are a Changing' (sung by Dylan, Nina Simone; Peter, Paul and Mary; and the Brothers and the Sisters) are played over a montage of newsreel footage illustrating the lyrics - peace rallies, campus dissidents, the Moratorium, black protest. Musician Taj Mahal talks about the emergence of "soul," and his group performs before a studio audience. They play "Six Days on the Road" and "You're Going to Need Someone on Your Bond." 6. KCET, Los Angeles: From the West Coast center of film and television, a piece on the media by Smothers Brothers' writer Mason Williams. He reads from his own privately printed "FCC Report." 7. WNDT, New York City: Edward Albee's "The Sandbox" produced by WNDT's New York Television Theater. This short play, first presented in 1960, indicated the major new directions theater would take in the following years. A critical view of the American Dream, it has John C. Becher as Daddy, Sudie Bond as Grandma, Alice Drummond as Mommy, Hal McKusick as Musician, and Christopher Walken as Young Man. 8. WQED, Pittsburgh: Fred Rogers is creating a special piece on the 10-year-old, whose only world has been that of the sixties. Additional Program Description from NET Press Release 12/3/69: Edward Albee, Dick Gregory, Lawrence Ferlinghetti, Bob Dylan, the Beatles, Nelson Algren, Jessica Tandy, Mason Williams and Mister Rogers are some of the artists whose talents are featured on the NET Playhouse New Year's Day special "Thoughts of the Artist on Leaving the Sixties." NET affiliates around the country were asked to contribute to this ninety-minute color variety special which ranges the art and entertainment world of the past decade. The items commissioned by NET drama department director Jac Venza reflect areas in which eight public television stations have become specially identified. Humor in the sixties, as presented by Hershey station WITF, features entertainers Dick Gregory and George Carlin, and Mad Magazine editor Al Feldstein. Another humorist, Smothers Brothers' writer Mason Williams, reads from his own privately-printed "FCC Report" when KCET, Los Angeles takes an amusing look at the media. Theater trends of the sixties will be seen in Edward Albee's "The Sandbox," presented by WNDT's NewYork Television Theater. This short play, first staged in 1960, indicated many of the major directions theater would take in the following years. A critical view of the American Dream, "The Sandbox" is performed by John C. Becher, Sudie Bond, Alice Drummond, Hal McKusick and Christopher Walken. WGBH, Boston, looks at the exploding music scene and pop culture of the sixties, with rock, folk, and soul music by the Beatles, Bob Dylan, and Taj Mahal. And the film explosion of the sixties is satirized by young filmmakers for KLRN, Austin, Texas, as they do a take-off on the cliches of the "new cinema." On the literary scene, KQED, San Francisco, examines the role of the poet as social critic in the sixties, with poet Lawrence Ferlinghetti reading a selection from his recently-published "Tyrannus Nix." WTTW, Chicago's Robert Cromie, popular host of "Book Beat," comments on the loss during the past ten years of some of the great authors who shaped modern American literature, as Nelson Algren, Jessica Tandy and Ira Rogers read selections from Hemingway, Flannery O'Connor, and Langston Hughes respectively. And then there is that special group of children who have only known the world of the past decade. Fred Rogers of "Misterogers' Neighborhood" fame is creating a special piece on the world through their eyes. "Misterogers" producer is WQED, Pittsburgh.
Thoughts of the artist on leaving the sixties.
a National Educational Television production ; executive producer, Jac Venza.

From NET microfiche, file N: From today's standpoint, the year 1984 is just sixteen years ahead of us, almost in sight on the horizon. Although the great problems of the world may not finally be solved by then, most of us believe that there is a fair chance of society surviving in a tolerable form. For George Orwell, however, 1984 represented a dark period, the year when the last spark of human dignity would be extinguished. When he wrote "1984," Orwell was sick and near the end of his life. He had seen the Spanish Civil War and the betrayal of "progressive' ideals. He had seen the Second World War, in which populations, even on the non-totalitarian side, had seemed to accept a regimentation which he found monstrous; and he was dying amid the great austerity of post-war Britain. He believed that ideology had become corrupted in to the pursuit of power for its own sake, and that people had been conditioned to accepting such power unquestioningly. So he imagined the character of Winston Smith, the hero of "1984" and Britain's last rebel. Britain has become a province of "Oceania," one of three tyrannical world super powers, locked permanently in a state of war, and Winston works in the Oceanian Ministry of Truth, whose function is to rewrite history into lies for the glory of the mysterious Big Brother. Big Brother is ever watchful; he gazes down from posters and from the ubiquitous, two-way television screens alert for "crime-thought" (one of those Orwell coinages like "newspeak" and "double-think" which have become part of the language. But Winston, although a junior member of the Outer Party and not expected to think for himself, dares to doubt the party leader's benevolence. Worse, he dares to fall in love with Julia, another would-be free spirit, and together they go in search of "the Brotherhood," a shadowy underground resistance group. And the consequence of their impious rebellion is a horror of torture, brainwashing, and total betrayal. The television version of "1984" was written by Nigel Kneale, who has updated his original script (which caused a sensation when it was first produced in 1953) to bring the narrative more into line with our times. The Author: George Orwell was the pseudonym of Eric Blair, an English essayist and novelist, who died of tuberculosis in 1950 at the age of 46 after having contributed two of the most influential works of political satire of this century, his novels "Animal Farm" and "1984." Described by the British writer and critic VS Pritchett as "the conscience of his generation," Orwell himself said that he had been forced by the age in which he lived into becoming "a sort of pamphleteer." He was born in Motihari, Bengal, into an Anglo-Indian family, and was educated as a scholarship student at Eton in England. He served for five years with the Indian Imperial Police in Burma, but after his health was affected by the climate, he left for Paris to begin his writing career. In 1936 he went to Spain and fought on the Republican side, but within four months was badly wounded and was forced to return to England. NET Playhouse - "1984" - a television dramatization of George Orwell's novel projecting the dark period of the year 1984, when the last spark of human dignity would be extinguished by international totalitarianism.
British Broadcasting Corporation ; director, Christopher Morahan ; [adaptor], Nigel Kheale ; by George Orwell.
Theatre 625. [1965-11-28], The world of George Orwell. 1984.
National Educational Television and Radio Center
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche: Program Description: "Acquit or Hang" is a play by Stanley Miller, based on actual records, about the five-and-a-half day court martial of ten of the "Bounty" mutineers, held aboard the HMS Duke in Portsmouth harbor from September 2, 1792 - three years and four months after the mutiny. The ten men being tried were the group left in Tahiti by Fletcher Christian and the others who went to Pitcairn Island. According to the naval regulations at that time any man who made no attempt to prevent a mutiny was as guilty as an active mutineer - and there was only one penalty: death. William Bligh, captain of the Bounty, has accused midshipman Peter Heywood and certain of his officers and men of mutiny. As witnesses and the men themselves take the stand, the true story of the terror and confusion aboard the ship unfolds. It is then for the court to determine - out of this confusion - which of the men did in fact mutiny and whether the actions of the others represented opposition to or encouragement of the mutiny. Six men are eventually sentenced to death. One man, Muspratt, successfully appeals. Recommendations of mercy are entered on behalf of two others, Heywood and Morrison, and they are pardoned. Indeed Heywood is given a post under Hood, the chairman of the court. The other three men - Burkitt, Millward and Ellison - are to be hanged.
a National Educational Television presentation ; a production of Rediffusion Television, London ; director, Cyril Coke ; writer, Stanley Miller.
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche, file A: Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET Playhouse - "Across the River": a feature film starring veteran Broadway actor Lou Gilbert in the story of a gentle rag picker on the Manhattan waterfront whose attempt to help an abandoned girl leads to his own destruction. Program Description: The scene is the waterfront "across the river" from New York City. There, in the shadow of the Queensborough bridge, in a rickety, cluttered shack, lives a cheerful bearded old rag picker named Obadiah, who has created a comforting little hermit world of his own. His companions are his pushcart, a goat that gives him milk, a strawberry patch, and above all, his blissful innocent dreams. Life for Obadiah is a fragile, though contented, withdrawal from the harsh realities of the outer world. But into his simple and apparently happy life comes a girl, a poor young abandoned creature whose entrance into his existence unwittingly admits disaster. Obadiah rescues her when a man in a car tries to molest her, and he takes her home to his shack. They live idyllically side by side until the basic things she needs exceed Obadiah's meager earnings. Then slowly, inexorably, the world intrudes in the tenuous fabric of his life. Because he looks suspicious, a policeman takes his money, gotten from junk sales, and he steals a coat for the girl. One thing leads to another until one night, a band of neighborhood derelicts, who have become increasingly hostile to the old man and his ward, attack the girl and the goat as the two take a short walk outside the shanty. The girl escapes, but the goat is slaughtered and Obadiah watches in mute anguish. The veteran character actor Lou Gilbert plays the role of the almost inarticulate, unworldly old man Obadiah, and Kay Doubleday plays the girl, Monica. NET Playhouse - "Across the River" is a National Educational Television presentation. It is a Debema Production, directed by Stephen Sharff; written by Mr. Sharff and Ed Sherin. It was produced by Noel Marechal. Music is by Charles Gross. Producer for NET is Kay Chessid.
National Educational Television and Radio Center
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche: General Description of Series: This program launches an eight-part series of plays under the title of "A Generation of leaves." It was announced by Jac Venza, executive producer of NET Playhouse. The weekly series includes original commissions, presentations by such distinguished American authors as Marya Mannes and Thornton Wilder, productions from NET affiliate stations, and the pick of foreign television programs focusing on this theme. 'There is a consistency of theme in these dramas from a wide variety of sources," says Venza. "The younger generation questions its inheritance, the older generation questions the values of the younger generation - and herein lies the communications gap. Which is, by the way, nothing new." Its central theme is the seemingly world-wide breach between youth and elders. The title is derived from Homer's "Iliad," Book VI: "A generation of men is like a generation of leaves: the wind scatters some leaves upon the ground, while others the burgeoning wood brings forth - and the season of spring comes on. So of men one generation ceases and another springs forth." "A Generation of leaves" opens February 19th with "America, Inc.," an NET-commissioned work produced at WGBH-TV, Boston, with a highly experimental format; includes two one-act plays by Thornton Wilder, dramas from the Canadian Broadcasting corporation, the British Broadcasting Corporation, north German Television and WQED, Pittsburgh; and concludes in April with NET"s production of "They," a TV adaptation by Marya Mannes of her novel dramatizing a near future ruled by the young. Some of the plays in this series can be described as "off-beat" or "experimental" while other are conventional drams. "America, Inc." is in the former category. Suggested Newspaper Listing: "Generation of Leaves" - an international series of dramas revolving around the growing rift between generations. "America, Inc."--the premiere program offers three clashing views of our nation today. Starring British actor David Silver and radio personality Jean Shepherd. Episode description: The play is comprised of three elements woven together, each element offering a different outlook on American society. David Silver plays himself - a young family man (26 years old) who temporarily leaves home in what he calls a "search for feeling" about America. His aim is to get underneath the images and facades and experience what America is truly like. Together with friend Ed Beardsley, he sets out on an odyssey that exposes them to variety of situations in today's subculture. For example: in Boston they attend a Hare Krishna "love feast;" in New York they go to the Bowery area and establish acquaintanceships with derelicts who live there, and on Ellis island they visit the place where countless thousands of immigrants entered America in the early 1900s. After Beardsley returns home to Boston, Silver goes on to Washington, D.C., for the November moratorium, gets involved in the march and meets Yippie (Youth International Party) leader Abbie Hoffmann. Then he himself returns to Boston and reflects upon his experiences. Most of the events described above were neither scripted nor staged. All were filmed cinema verite on location. Interwoven with the presentation of Silver's odyssey is the commentary of Jean Shepherd, the veteran late-night personality. Shepherd, in his 40s, provides his own ironic and personal vision of America and the result is a very different view of the events portrayed on film. Shepherd has won four of the last five Playboy awards for best American humorist. Finally, there is the third element in this program - the "sponsor's" commercials. The "sponsor" of the play is a mythical non-profit corporation, "America, Inc." and its commercials are seen periodically throughout this production. America, Inc. is something in the nature of a large private philanthropic organization seeking to promote peace, love, and help for theneedy. Its commercials are public service spots (parodies of the real thing) about brotherhood, urban blight, and freedom of expression, etc., and they always project a positive view. At first these commercials seem to relate to Silver's experiences, but as the program develops the relationship grows more and more distant, demonstrating the clash between the 'corporate" and the "personal" outlooks, however benevolent both may be. This split reaches its climax in the Washington moratorium segment. There is no cast as such for this production. Silver is an actor-producer and a member of the WGBH (Boston) Rockefeller Artists in Television (a group co-sponsored by the Rockefeller Foundation and WGBH). At the Boston station he was co-producer of the experimental series "What's happening Mr. Silver," which won a 1969 NET affiliates award in the field of cultural affairs. Silver's friend, Beardsley, plays himself, as does Shepherd.
NET playhouse. A generation of leaves. [No. 1], America, Inc.

National Educational Television production ; produced through the facilities of WGBH, Boston, in cooperation with WGBH Rockefeller Artists in Television ; executive producer, Jac Vanza ; created by David Silver, David Loxton, and Fred Barzyk ; produced by David Loxton and Fred Barcyk ; director, Fred Barzyk.

"A Generation of leaves" opens February 19th with "America, Inc.," an NET-commissioned work produced at WGBH-TV, Boston, with a highly experimental format; includes two one-act plays by Thornton Wilder, dramas from the Canadian Broadcasting corporation, the British Broadcasting Corporation, north German Television and WQED, Pittsburgh; and concludes in April with NET"s production of "They," a TV adaptation by Marya Mannes of her novel dramatizing a near future ruled by the young. Suggested Newspaper Listing: "Generation of Leaves" - an international series of dramas revolving around the growing rift between generations. "America, Inc."--the premiere program offers three clashing views of our nation today. Starring British actor David Silver and radio personality Jean Shepherd. Episode description: "Yesterday the Children Were Dancing" was adapted for television by the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation from a successful Canadian stage play of the same name, written by playwright-actor Gratien Gelinas. The CBC production is based on an English translation by Mavor Moore. It is an evening in Montreal in 1964,, during a period of terrorism by French-Canadians who advocate the separation of Quebec province from the rest of Canada. Pierre Gravel is a prominent Montreal lawyer, played by Gelinas himself, who is being sought by the Liberal Party as successor to the federal minister of justice, a recent stroke victim. Opposing his father's federalist ambitions is Gravel's older son, Andre, who now reveals himself to be the leader of a youthful band of separatists who are responsible for the bombing of a monument in Quebec City the day before. And what's more, Andre says, the group has planned more terrorist incidents to coincide with the federal elections. What follows that night is the collapse of the family, brought on by the uncloseable breach between father and son. Gravel's two sons are played by his real sons, Yves and Alain. The Cast: Pierre Gravel - Gratien Gelinas Louise Gravel - Huguette Oligny Andre Gravel - Yves Gelinas Nicole Chartier - Suzanne Levesque Paul O'Brien - Jacques Auger Raoul Roberge - Yvon Dufour Larry Gravel - Alain Gelinas Miss Leroux - Colette Courtois

"A Generation of leaves" opens February 19th with "America, Inc.," an NET-commissioned work produced at WGBH-TV, Boston, with a highly experimental format; includes two one-act plays by Thornton Wilder, dramas from the Canadian Broadcasting corporation, the British Broadcasting Corporation, north German Television and WQED, Pittsburgh; and concludes in April with NET"s production of "They," a TV adaptation by Marya Mannes of her novel dramatizing a near future ruled by the young. Suggested Newspaper Listing: "Generation of Leaves" - an international series of dramas revolving around the growing rift between generations. "America, Inc."--the premiere program offers three clashing views of our nation today. Starring British actor David Silver and radio personality Jean Shepherd. Episode description: This play was produced by WQED, Pittsburgh, and written by Robert Wickersham, a Pittsburgh author who died in 1966 while in his early 40s. Ed and his girl companion, Tracy, are a couple of drifters who are heading across the country to a commune in California. Both are college drop-outs, both very disoriented. While passing through a small Pennsylvania manufacturing town they are detained by the sheriff who impounds their auto on a technicality, forcing them to find work so they can earn enough money to reclaim the car. The impounding was in fact an act of harassment on the part of the sheriff who resents the youngsters and feels it his duty to "straighten the kids out." Tracy becomes a go-go dancer at a local bar, while Ed finds a job as a photographer's assistant. As it turns out, the photographer is a man who went through a period of alienation similar to Ed's, and gradually an important relationship develops between the two men. In the end, Tracy leaves town with a local hippie while Ed has apparently "stopped running." This play was televised last June over WQED and in a review in the Pittsburgh Press TV editor Vince Leonard said: "The play concerns today's youth but it isnot preachy; yet there is preachment, a message that the viewer gets by osmosis rather than the sledgehammer. Above all, the acting is excellent, particularly by Craig Bovia and Terry Evans, who play, respectively, Ed the drifter and Neil the photographer." The Cast: Ed - Craig Bovia Tracy - Elayne Heilveil Neil - Terry Evans Sheriff - Don Brockett Hippy - George Gerdes Case worker - Ann Gladmon Original music composed and performed on guitar by George Gerdes.
NET playhouse. A generation of leaves. [No. 3], Stopped running.
A generation of leaves. [No. 3], Stopped running.

"America, Inc."--the premiere program offers three clashing views of our nation today. Starring British actor David Silver and radio personality Jean Shepherd. Episode description: From NET microfiche, N: "Walls" ("Mauern"), from north German Television, depicts a similar problem in another country. Written by Gunther Lys, whose "Nur Ein Tag" recently presented NET audiences with a harrowing German look at Hitler's concentration camps, "Walls" depicts two World War II veterans who once held widely separate goals but now face a common problem. One had been a Nazi, the other a Communist. Today they have sons the same age; both sons try to free themselves from their parents' legacies and work out their own ideology. From NET microfiche, W: "Walls" is a German play written by Gunther Lys and dubbed in English for NET Playhouse. The story begins with the killing of an East German trying to escape to West Berlin. As West German police investigate the incident, the story unfolds through flashbacks: The year is 1931. A Communist printer named Koslowski is at work in his shop in a German village when a man bursts in seeking a hiding place from the police. His name is Nast. He's a Nazi sympathizer and he's been shot during a street battle between left and right forces. Koslowski and Nast quarrel briefly but the printer, rather than turn Nast out into the street and certain death, gives him a hiding place and cleans his wound. Then a friendship develops. Several years later the situation is reversed. Hitler is rising to power and now it is Koslowski and his family who are being hidden by Nast. Both men have held fast to their respective ideologies, and Nast now occupies a position of growing importance among the Nazis - a position which he feels is threatened by the presence of the Koslowskis. Nast sends them away and Koslowski becomes embittered toward his friend. Some 30 years pass and the Berlin Wall has gone up. Koslowski and Nast are bitter enemies and still cling to their old ideologies. But Koslowski's son, Walter, and Nast's son, Hans, are best friends and they reject the rigidity of their father's viewpoints. In both families a serious breach has developed between father and son. However, the two young men, while recognizing the mistakes of their parents, have nevertheless inherited different outlooks. Hans wants to escape to the West, where his fiance who has just fled is awaiting him. Walter, who is a border guard, retains his socialistic ideals and feels it is wrong to abandon East Germany, though he is not happy there. Hans wants his friend to come with him and forces the issue by attempting his escape at the point where Walter is on guard duty. Walter is torn between his friendship and his sense of duty to the state, which dictates that he shoot the escapee. He does not shoot, and failing to do so he realizes he must now also flee. Walter makes it, but Hans is killed by another guard.
NET playhouse. A generation of leaves. [No. 4], Walls.
Studio Hamburg ; NET producer, Jac Vanza ; writer, Gunther Lys.
NET playhouse. [No. 180], A generation of leaves. [No. 4], Walls.

Viewers see a mysterious hand picking cards out of a file -- each card labeled according to subject, and each subject representing one of the world's great problems. Every card that is picked out leads to an animated satire of that particular subject. At the end of the film the hand is revealed to belong to a robot that is indexing the remnants of our destroyed civilization.
[NET playhouse. A generation of leaves. [No. 4], Walls ; Card file].

Episode description: From NET microfiche, G: This passion play, based on the Gospels of Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John depicts events in the life of Christ, including the crucifixion and the resurrection. The unusual aspect is that the play is set to blues music. The play has previously been performed in the Boston area, and portions of it comprise a record on the Epic label titled "Night of the Blue Commission." The play was written by Tim Mayer, with music by Peter Ivers. From NET microfiche, J: This passion play, based on the Gospels of Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John depicts events in the life of Christ, including the crucifixion and the resurrection. The play written and directed by Tim Mayer, draws most of its dialogue from the King James Bible, but is performed in causal modern dress, accompanied by blues music, and set in the ghostly corridors of an abandoned warehouse in Boston to achieve special effects. Much of Peter Ivers' music and lyrics is recorded on a disc titled "Knight of the Blue Commission" on the Epic label. The performers are young professional actors and drama students. The role of Christ is played by Andreas Teuber "a young actor with a strong, sensitive face and rich voice who brought intelligence and sensitivity to the role," according to the New York Times. Other important parts are played by Laura Esterman as Mary Magdalene, Steve Kaplan as Lazarus, and Asha Puthil, a young actress from India, as Salome.
NET playhouse. A generation of leaves. [No. 5], Jesus, a passion play for Americans.

National Educational Television production, produced through the facilities of WGBH, Boston ; producer, Christopher Sarson ; executive producer, Jac Venza ; directed and written by Tim Mayer, music by Peter Ivers.

Episode description: From NET microfiche, G: "Infancy" and "Childhood," the first two works in a projected seven-play cycle, "The Seven Ages of Man," which Thornton Wilder began in 1961, were received with critical enthusiasm when they were first produced off Broadway in New York City. This production was their television premiere. Although these two one-act plays are written in a serio-comic vein, Wilder has employed the same theme of the University of Man which runs through so much of his work. Both plays are about the lack of communication between children and their parents, but the two plays differ distinctly in style and production technique. INFANCY: The first play, "Infancy" as its title implies, is about babies. It is set in the 1920s in Central Park in New York City and is performed in "Keystone Cop" style. Two adults in baby bonnets (played by the British comedy team Hendra an Ullet) are crammed into perambulators. They are being wheeled through the park on their daily airing, and the conversation of the babies with each other makes more sense than that of adults in their "grown up" talk. The Cast: Millie - Eileen Brennan Officer Avonzino - Fred Gwynne Mrs. Boker - Evelyn Russell Tommy -Tony Hendra Moe - Nic Ullet "Infancy" is a National Educational Television production. Producer: Jac Venza Director: Joe Layton Associate producer: Virginia Kassel Scenic designer: Tom John Costume designer: Theoni Aldredge CHILDHOOD: The action of "Childhood" takes place in the early 1930s at a home in the suburbs. It is a more gentle play than "Infancy," with its theme the lack of communication between generations. The three children in the family, indulging in a fantasy, imagine that their parents have died. They decide to take a trip to celebrate their freedom. But their surprise at seeing a bus driver who looks just like Daddy, and meeting a fellow passenger who looks just like Mother, is matched by their relief at being able to return to the security of their parents. The Cast: Mother - Frances Sternhagen Father - George Rose Caroline - Julie Herrod Dodie - Audrey Price Billie - Michael Kearney "Childhood" is a National Educational Television production. Co-Producers: Jack Landau and Jac Venza Director: Jack Landau Associate producer: Virginia Kassel Scenic designer: Tom John Costume designer: Frank Thompson
NET playhouse. A generation of leaves. [No. 6], Infancy and childhood.
National Educational Television ; producer, Jac Venza ; written by Thornton Wilder.

Co-Producers: Jack Landau and Jac Venza Director: Jack Landau Associate producer: Virginia Kassel Scenic designer: Tom John Costume designer: Frank Thompson Filler information: The filler for this program is titled "Les Mistons '67" ("The Brats '67") by noted French filmmaker Francois Truffaut. It is approximately 20 minutes long and it is the same filler used when "Infancy and Chldhood" was aired for the second time on NET Playhouse in April 1969. "Les Mistons" is about a group of young boys in France who have a crush on an older girl. The film has English subtitles, althought there is little dialogue. Some of Truffaut's best known films are "Shoot the Piano Player," "The 400 Blows," and "Stolen Kisses."
[NET playhouse. A generation of leaves. [No. 6], Infancy and childhood ; Les mistons].

"Five young boys in pre-puberty are collectively attracted by a beautiful, young woman, Bernadette Jouve. She awakes in them the springs of luminous sensuality. As they are too young to love her, they decide to hate and torment her instead. Wherever Bernadette and her sweetheart Gerard turn up, the five boys are there, disturbing them. They also start drawing arrow-pierced hearts with the names of the two lovers everywhere, but Gerard and Bernadette hardly notice it. The boys' failures make them more aggressive. A day in August Gerard says farewell to Bernadette. He'll be away for three months. When he comes back he hopes the wedding bells will toll for them. When the five boys' vacation is near the end, they resort to a very shabby method. They buy a postcard showing two scantily-dressed lovers sprawled on a bed. On the postcard they write wanton words about Gerard and Bernadette, and undersign it The Brats, before sending it to Bernadette. Some days later they read in the newspaper that Bernadette's fianc had died in a mountain-climbing accident." (Summary from Internet movie database Web site, viewed Jan. 17, 2017) Based on a short story (Virginales) by Maurice Pons.
Les Films du Carrosse ; produced by Robert Lachenay ; directed and screenplay by Franois Truffaut.
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche, N: From the BBC comes "The Bond," a disturbing picture of woman in modern marriage. A fashion designer and a rising young architect - a swinging, attractive couple - are married with all the trappings of tradition. Their future looks assured. When the wife stops working, she feels that she has lost her identity. Her husband leaves on a business trip and she embarks on a search for examples of happiness in marriage. Everywhere she looks she finds emptiness: with her best friend, even with her mother. Eventually she discovers that she has always fulfilled the expectations of society and of the older generation. She decides that she and her husband can make a go of their marriage and work out their own destiny only if they throw off the shackles of the past.
NET playhouse. A generation of leaves. [No. 7], The bond.
NET playhouse presents ; British Broadcasting Corporation ; written by Dawn Pavitt and Terry Wale.

Summary from NET microfiche: The film shows a three-year-old boy, walking through the thick undergrwoth of a wild place. He is going there to play, but on his way, he has experiences which have overtones of violence--he encounters a Howitzer, a machine gun, a hand grenade. But his innocence protects him, just as the recognition of the audience informs them of the evils he meets.
Rabbits are the friends of toads.
Timothy Pictures ; produced, written and edited by Dorothy Knowles.

From NET microfiche, N: "A Generation of Leaves" ends on the frightening note struck by Marya Mannes in her novel, "They." NET commissioned Ms Mannes and Charles LeMay to adapt "They" for television. It will be produced in New York by Jack Kuney. "They" is set 20 years hence when a group of celebrated artists, over forty years old, have been exiled to live out their lives in isolation from "They," the young who have taken over the world. Each artist expresses his own personal credo; each one laments what is lost to his particular art in today's rush to embrace the youth cult. As a time capsule for unknown future generations, the doomed artists leave a testament in which they reaffirm their belief in traditional standards of excellence and in the cherished values of civilization. From NET microfiche, T: This final program in the "Generation of Leaves" series is an adaptation of Marya Mannes' novel, "They," published by Doubleday in October 1968. It is an original NET Playhouse production and features an impressive list of veteran performers. The story takes place in the year 1990 in and around a beachfront home in a deserted area somewhere on the Northeastern coast of the U.S. The inhabitants of this home are five people in their sixties who have been exiled from civilization because of their age. For the young are in control of the world, and most people over 40 are sent to special camps where they are expected to take their own lives when they become seriously ill or reach the age of 65, whichever occurs first. Yet these five have been treated somewhat differently. Because they were famous in the arts before the young took over they have been permitted to choose exile with each other rather than go to the camps. The same rules of self-extermination apply, and whoever disregards these rules is put to death anyway. The exiles manage to find some contentment in being able to live together, sharing as they do, a common outlook. But essentially they live in anguish, not only because of their isolation, but because of what has happened to their respective arts in the new world. As a representative from the year 1990 explains: "Individual and subjective criticism in all the arts has been supplanted by our infallible computer value scales." Art, in other words, has been totally depersonalized. Eventually, the time appears to have come for one of the exiles, Barney, to take his life or be taken from his friends and put to death. The others decide that instead of letting him be taken away, they will commit mass suicide, and after drugging themselves they are all killed when the house is set afire. But unknown to them, the government had been toppled some weeks before and the laws regarding age had been repealed. Cornelia Otis Skinner plays Kate, a novelist, who has kept a written record of the events at her place of exile; Gary Merrill portrays Barney, a painter; Carmen Mathews is Annie, Barney's wife, and a former model; Jack Gilford plays. Joey a songwriter; and Joseph Wiseman is Lev, an erstwhile orchestra conductor. There is one other important part in this play, that of Michael, a young mute who comes upon the exiles under mysterious circumstances and lives with them until the suicide, finally setting fire to the house in accordance with their wishes. Robert McLane has been cast in the part of Michael. The play will be taped on location later this month at a house designed by architect Stanford White in Bridgehampton on the south shore of Long Island, N.Y. Suggested Newspaper Listing: "They" Cornelia Otis Skinner and Carmen Mathews head the cast in this adaptation of Marya Mannes' novel about a world in which the young control everything and old people are herded into camps to await death. Also starring Gary Merrill, Jack Gilford, and Joseph Wiseman. NOTE: Aggravation of a back injury has forced Maureen O'Sullivan to drop out of the cast of "They," an NET Playhouse production scheduled for airing on April 16, 1970 (in New York, April 17). Miss O'Sullivan's role in the play has been filled by veteran stage and television actress Carmen Mathews. Additional information on Carmen Mathews: Miss Mathews, a native of Philadelphia, began her stage career in the early 1940's after having attended the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art in London. Her Broadway credits include "Richard II," 'The Moon is Down," "The Cherry Orchard," "Man and Superman," and "Candide," and she has appeared in the films "A Rage to Live" and 'Rabbit Run." Her TV credits include "The FBI" and "Crisis Clinic." Additional Information on Cornelia Otis Skinner: Miss Skinner, daughter of the late actor Otis Skinner, is known not only as one of the great stars of Broadway, but also as a playwright and author of such non-fiction as the Sarah Bernhardt biography "Madame Sarah." She is co-author of the popular "Our Hearts Were Young and Gay," and has written such famous humorous essay collections as "The Ape in Me," "Bottoms Up," and "Nuts in May." Her greatest Broadway successes include performances in Wilde's "Lady Windermere's Fan," Lillian Hellman's "The Searching Wind," Shaw's "Major Barbara," and in a play which she co-authored with Samuel Taylor, "The Pleasure of His Company." On radio she was heard for several seasons in the popular "William and Mary" series. Miss Skinner studied classical and modern acting in Paris before returning home to America to take her first professional role - a small part in Blasco Ibanez' "Blood and Sand," in which her father was starring. After this engagement she went off on her own accepting secondary roles in a succession of plays, including "The Wild Wescotts" and "Will Shakespeare." Then she began writing character sketches which she performed solo on tours in the U.S. and Canada. Encouraged by the popularity of these sketches, she wrote "The Wives of Henry VIII," in which she portrays each of Henry's six queens. The work was first performed in England where it was an instant success and established her as a performer of international stature. Additional Information on Jack Gilford: Gilford, perhaps best known for his stage and film role in "A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum," also counts among his Broadway credits the prize-winning musical "Cabaret," in which he starred (1967-68), "Romanoff and Juliet," "Once Upon a Mattress," "The Diary of Anne Frank," and "The Tenth Man." Among his better-known films are "Enter Laughing" (1967), in which he co-starred with Elaine May, Shelley Winters, and Jose Ferrer, "Who's Minding the Mint" (1967), "The Incident" (1968), and "The Fixer" (1968). In 1950, Gilford set a precedent by becoming the first non-singing performer to play an important speaking role with the Metropolitan opera when he portrayed the comical Frosch, a drunken jailer, in Johann Strauss' "Die Fledermaus." Born on New York's lower East Side and raised in Brooklyn, Gilford began in show business by enrolling in amateur nights and writing his own material which consisted of imitations of Rudy Vallee, Laurel and Kardy, George Jessel, and split-pea soup coming to a furious boil. He then played vaudeville and night clubs all over the United States. He has also appeared on all the major television shows. Additional Information on Gary Merrill: Merrill, a native of Hartford, Conn., is perhaps best remembered for his stage portrayal of the persistent reporter who makes trouble for Judy Holliday's gangster boyfriend in "Born Yesterday." This success led him to a seven-year contract with Darryl F. Zanuck, resulting in such acclaimed films as "All About Eve," "Twelve O'Clock High," and "Decision Before Dawn." Merrill began his career on the stage, with his first important performances coming in "Brother Rat" on a national tour and in "Morning Star" on Broadway. In the meantime, he played roles in radio soap operas and other dramatic series, including "Young Doctor Malone," "The Right to Happiness," "Gang Busters," and "Counterspy." Merrill recently toured Florida in a production of Arthur Miller's "The Price." A resident of a suburb of Portland, Maine, Merrill now enjoys reading the poetry of Frost and Sandburg to students in the Maine public school system. Additional Information on Joseph Wiseman: Joseph Wiseman, better known to millions of James Bond fans as the diabolical "Dr. No," is one of the stars who will play leading roles in the NET Playhouse adaptation of Marya Mannes' novel, "They." Wiseman, a native of Montreal who grew up mostly in Detroit, has a long list of stage, screen and TV credits both in the U.S. and Canada, and has also appeared on the London stage. Some of his best known movies, besides "Dr. No," are "Detective Story," in which he had performed on Broadway, "Viva Zapata," "The Unforgiven," "Bye, Bye Braverman," and "The Night They Raided Minsky's." He made his Broadway debut in support of Raymond Massey in Robert Sherwood's "Abe Lincoln in Illinois." Subsequently, he appeared with Helen Hayes in "Candle in the Wind," with Ingrid Bergman in "Joan of Lorraine," with Louis Calhern in "King Lear," and with Katherine Cornell in "The Three Sisters," "Anthony and Cleopatra," and "That Lady." Wiseman was a member of the original Lincoln Center (N.Y.) Repertory Company, with which he created the roles of LeDuc in "Incident at Vichy" and Chu Yin in "Marco Millions." On the Los Angeles stage he played the father in The Theatre Group production of Pirandello's "Six Characters in Search of an Author." On TV Wiseman has appeared in "Producer's Showcase," "Desilu Playhouse," "Kraft Theatre," "Twilight Zone," and "The Untouchables."

From NET microfiche: John Gilliam is a serious young composer who, to earn a living, plays a piano in a night club. There he meets Mary O'Hara who has the charming but unstable ne'er -do-well Colin in tow. Colin gets drunk and John helps Mary to take him home. John reluctantly falls in love with Mary. Although he knows that Mary and Colin are literally "just good friends," he has doubts about their relationship since Colin is constantly getting into trouble and being helped out of it by Mary. It is about as much as John can take when Colin is thrown out of his lodgings and Mary gives him asylum for the night in her apartment. When John persuades Mary to go away with him for a few days' vacation, they get a letter saying that Colin is in trouble again. This time it is serious for he has burgled a mutual friends' apartment. Colin soon arrives in person and ruins their idyll. Desperate and drunk, he goes for a swim and gets into difficulties. John's first reaction is to let him drown, but humanity prevails and he pulls Colin to safety. Back at the hotel the police are waiting. Alone at last on the train back to London, Mary accepts John's offer of marriage, but soon they realize that Colin will be with them forever. The Cast: John - Norman Rodway Belle - June Ellis Colin - Barrie Ingham Mary - Valerie Gearon Andrew - Sidney Bough Otto Adrian - Milo Sperber Myra Adrian - Hana Pravada Raoul - Roy Patrick Eileen - Jo Rowbottom 1st Youth - Douglas Ditta 2nd Youth - Anton Darby Detective - John Baker NET Playhouse - "A Man on Her Back" is a National Educational Television presentation produced by Peter Luke for the British Broadcasting Corporation. It was adapted by Mr. Luke from a novel by William Sansom. Director: Warris Hussein; designer: Roger Andrews; music by Max Harris. NET producer: Kay Chessid Filler Information: The filler for NET Playhouse - "A Man on Her Back" is a black and white short form Poland without dialogue entitled "Lines and Dots," which runs 6:17. It is a play of graphic forms, dashes and dots which appear among the signs of the Morse alphabet causing havoc and eventually destruction of the alphabet. The lines and dots combine and recombine in a variety of patterns, some totally abstract, others suggesting animals and people. The victorious signs soon start fighting among each other. In the course of this conflict, the dots and dashes suggest a line of planes with bombs dropping from them, and the curving signs are destroyed.

From NET microfiche: "A Mother for Janek" was the initial award winning play in the Alcoa-WQED-TV, Pittsburgh's Playwrights' Contest. Players of the American Conservatory Theater, and community talent are combine din the cast. Director of the production was William Francisco, director of the American Conservatory Theater. "A Mother for Janek" received an NET Achievement Award in 1966. The awards are presented annually by NET for excellence in programming produced by local affiliate stations. The play is Victor Ullmans, and is adapted from an original story of his which appeared in "Colliers" magazine. "A Mother for Janek" concerns the plight of Dusik, whose nephew, Janek, is orphaned in the Hungarian Revolution of 1956, and so comes to the United States. Dusik feels that as a bachelor he cannot properly bring up the twelve-year-old boy who suddenly comes into his life and the poignant story of the play concerns his search for a mother for Janek. A waitress, Teresa, who has been teaching English to Dusik, eventually winds up as wife to Dusik and mother to the boy - with some help form young Janek, who has to fake a stomach ache to bring them together. The Cast: Dusik - Ray Reinhardt Pete - David Margulies "A Mother for Janek" is a National Educational Television presentation. A production of WQED, Pittsburgh. Director: William Francisco. Producer and television director: Jay Rayvid. Music: Duquesne Tambaritzans.

From NET microfiche: Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET Playhouse - "Anatol" - the romantic comedy by the 19th century Austrian playwright Arthur Schnitzler about three episodes in the love life of a Viennese man-about-town at the turn of the century. Program Description: The play is made up of three episodes in the love life of Anatol, a rich man-about-town of Vienna at the turn of the century. His friend, confidant, and adviser is Max, who tells the stories. In the first episode, Anatol is giving his mementos into Max's safe keeping. A bundle of letters, a scrap of a veil, a photograph, a pressed flower; through these he recalls his past loves. He recalls a romance of only a few hours which he remembers as having a lasting mark in the heart of a little circus artiste. What he doesn't remember is that she is a friend of Max's. When she happens to arrive at Max's rooms for a visit and sees Anatol again, she doesn't remember him at all and has entirely forgotten their enchanted evening. Another memory: Anatol has organized a farewell supper for his then current mistress. He is leaving her for a younger, less extravagant woman. But when the mistress, during a very healthy meal, forestalls him, he is furious. She announces that this is positively their final supper together because she has fallen madly in love with a man from the back-row of the chorus. But Anatol gets caught in the end. It is his wedding morning. Btu old habits die hard and an old flame has spent the night with him. The problem is how to get out of the house to his wedding without letting his girlfriend know why he must rush out. Background on the playwright: Arthur Schnitzler was born in Vienna in 1862 and died in 1931. He made his reputation, as a Viennese wit with "Anatol," an early play, along with his two, bets-known works, the play, "La Ronde," and the short novel, "Leutnant Gustl." His style in all of these works is characterized by a lighthouse of touch, a gaiety and delicate irony, reminiscent of "Old Vienna" itself. "Anatol" has been translated by Harley Granville-Barker, the famous Shakespearean scholar, dramatist ("The Madras House"), and producer, who introduced many continental dramatists to England, among them Ibsen and Schnitzler. The cast: Anatol - Robert Hardy Max - John Wood Mimi - Moira Redmond Bianca - Priscilla Morgan Lona - Elvi Hale NET Playhouse - "Anatol" is a National Educational Television presentation produced for the British Broadcasting Corporation by Bernard Hepton. It was directed by Christopher Morahan. Producer for NET is Kay Chessid.

From NET microfiche, file E: Arthur Miller's adaptation of "An Enemy of the People" by Henrik Ibsen is a new and up-to-date version of this drama. The author of "Death of a Salesman" brings to bear his deep concern for the individual's responsibility to the society in which he lives. A small Norwegian town has just begun to earn fame and wealth through its medicinal spring waters. Dr. Stockmann, resident physician in charge, discovers that the waters are poisoned. On receiving proof of this he immediately reports to his associates, the town officials most immediately affected. But because of their selfish "practical" interests, they refuse to do anything about his findings. The press will not report them; the officials will not give him a hearing; he loses his position; the townspeople boycott him; ultimately his wife and children are cut off from all contact with their friends and neighbors. The family is blackmailed, slandered and evicted from their home. Only a sea captain stands by them and agrees to take them to America, but Stockmann's antagonists buy the ship and the family is refused passage. In the final dramatic moment of the play, Stockmann, deserted by all but his immediate family, stands firm in the house he must leave as an angry mob assaults it. "Remember now, everybody, you are fighting for the truth," he tells his family, "and that is why you are alone. And that makes you strong." The Cast: Peter Stockmann -- Philip Bosco Dr. Thomas Stockmann -- James Daly A Drunk -- Lou Gilbert Nansen -- William Hansen Billing -- Ken Kercheval Howstad -- James Olson Aslaksen -- William Prince Mrs. (Catherine) Stockmann -- Kate Reid Morton Kill -- George Voskovec Morten Stockmann -- Timothy Daly AN ENEMY OF THE PEOPLE is a National Educational Television production. Executive producer: Jac Venza. Producer: Jack Landau. Director: Paul Bogart. Settings designed by Charles Rosen. Costumes by Noel Taylor.

From NET microfiche: The Pulitzer Prize-winning poet-playwright Archibald MacLeish has contributed this new play, "An Evening's Journey to Conway, Massachusetts," to NET. Described by MacLeish as "one of the most exciting ventures I've been involved in," the work is a tribute to his hometown of forty years, Conway, Mass. It was specially written for the town's bicentennial in June 1967 and was performed by the townspeople during the celebrations. The NET production represents not only the work's first broadcast, but its first major exposure. The play concerns a boy who hates living in the town and wants to leave it. By leading him into an examination and evaluation of the town's past, MacLeish recreates major events from Conway's actual history. The play opens with an introductory sequence filmed in Conway itself, setting the mood of the play, in which Archibald MacLeish himself appears. The action of the play begins with the boy in front of the local food shop where the kids hang out, bored, watching the cars go by. As he thinks about his hatred for the town, the boy is led backwards into an examination of its history: Conway as it was when the survivors came back from the Civil War; as it was when the citizens had dreams of it becoming an important center, possibly even a city' as it was back in the 1830s, and at the time of Ticonderoga during the Revolutionary War, when, though it was the year of the great sickness, all the men that were able marched off to join General Stark at Bennington; as it was when Emerson's uncle, the Rev. John, came up to the hills, against his inclination to become the first minister of the Congregational church. There was much poverty, suffering, sickness and death as the people struggled to establish the town. And why? What was the idea of the town? This town or any town? Why did those men and women leave the meadows at Deerfield and move into the forested hills? Was their dream to build a town in the wilderness where men could live with God and even with each other? These are the boy's questions as he makes his way back -- angry at first, then sullen, then bewildered, and finally regaining faith in the town and in himself. The Cast: John Beal -- The Rev. Charles Rice Gary Burghoff -- The Boy Howard Lemay -- Marsh (Marshall Field) George Mathews -- William Warren (a farmer) Lou Polan -- Capt. Lucius Allis, of the Green Mountain Boys Edgar Stehli -- The Rev. John Emerson John McQuade -- Burke, an industrialist Royal Beal -- Malachi Maynard (a town treasurer) Harriet Rogers -- A Pioneer Woman Charlotte Glenn -- Mrs. Howland Paul Benedict -- Orator Townspeople of Conway Filler Information The filler for AN EVENING'S JOURNEY TO CONWAY, MASSACHUSETTS is WAITING FOR MAY. This is a mood piece about an old lady in a large city recalling her youth. "AN EVENING'S JOURNEY TO CONWAY, MASSACHUSETTS" runs 49:13 fades to black, then comes up on the filler "WAITING FOR MAY" which runs to 57:22 and ends with the NET logo. AN EVENING'S JOURNEY TO CONWAY, MASSACHUSETTS is a production of National Educational Television and WGBH, Boston. Producer: Gregory Harney Director: John J. Desmond NET producer: Virginia Kassel Sets: Fran Mahard Film segments: Peter Hoving and Boyd Estus Music composed and conducted by Joseph Raposo

From NET microfiche: Program Description: Under the direction of Bob Livingston (director of the off-Broadway success "The Me Nobody Knows"), a special company of improvisational actors, most of whom were members of Chicago's famed Second City troupe, performs a program of improvised satiric sketches about life in New York City. Composer Gary William Friedman and lyricist Will Holt, who wrote the songs for "The Me Nobody Knows," have written a score for this production. "A Nice Place to Visit..." represents a new approach to television satire. To help capture the free-flowing spontaneity of improvised comedy, cameraman Al Maysles ("Primary," "Yanqui No," "Salesman," the Beatles' "What's Happening") employs his famed hand-held camera technique in scenes that are all shot on location throughout New York. The locations include the Brooklyn Bridge, Wall Street, Fifth Avenue, and Central Park. Among the cast is Marion Mercer, winner of a Tony award for her supporting role in the Broadway hit "Promises, Promises"; and Anthony Holland, currently seen in the films "Midnight Cowboy," "The Out-of-Towners," and "Lovers and Other Strangers," and whose Broadway credits include the Joseph Heller play "We Bombed in New Haven." Holland was a member of Second City; Miss Mercer was not. The cast also consists of Barbara Dana (Mrs. Alan Arkin), Christopher Guest, Paul Dooley, JJ Barry, Jon Korkes, Mina Kolb, Judy Graubart, Paul Benedict, and Andrew Duncan. Benedict, Guest, and Korkes has roles in off-Broadway hit "Little Murders" at Circles-in-the-Square; and Holland, Barry, and Benedict again were in "The White House Murder Case," also at Circle-in-the-Square. (Both productions were directed by Alan Arkin, who rose to stardom from his participation in Second City.) Korkes plays small roles in the films "Catch-22" "The Out-of-Towners," and the not-yet-released "Little Murders." Miss Dana is seen in the motion picture "Popi," and her Broadway credits include the recent revival of "Room Service," "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf," and "Enter Laughing." Mina Kolb is in the film "Loving," and Miss Graubart was a regular on CBS-TV's summer variety show "Comedy Tonight." The material in the program includes the following: A door-to-door salesman tries to interest a young couple in switching to a brand new phone company; a bridge-painter and a painter of bridges compare the relative artistic merits of their work in the middle of the Brooklyn Bridge; a TV commentator gives an on-the-scene report on pollution in the East River; a middle-aged couple consults masters and Johnson about an unusual sexual problem; novelist and women's lib advocate Rhoda Shapiro discusses her life from her swank apartment for the program "Women Want to Know"; a jogger in Central Park is accosted by a drug peddler, a hooker, and an autograph seeker; a novice panhandler gains some valuable expertise from an experienced colleague; a boy-girl relationship is born near the bear cage in the Central Park Zoo; a woman unwittingly finds herself in the men's boutique of a leading department store; and a company tries to improve worker efficiency by bringing live music into its factory. NET Playhouse #218 - "A Nice Place to Visit..." is a production of NET. Producer: David Loxton. Director: Bob Livingston. Associate producer: Matt Herman. Editor: Victoria Hochberg. Film; Al Maysles and Alan Raymond. Sound: Hugh Liddel. NET Playhouse executive producer: Jac Venza.

From NET microfiche: Program Description: Oscar Wilde wrote this comedy-melodrama, which features a host of distinguished British performers including Margaret Leighton, Jeremy Brett, Keith Michell, and NET's Emmy-winning star of "The Forsythe Saga" - Susan Hampshire. The story concerns a British politician (Michell) whose spotless reputation is threatened by a blackmailing society woman (Miss Leighton). Her plans are thwarted by a nobleman (Brett) who is in love with the politician's sister (Miss Hampshire). Suggested Newspaper Listing: "An Ideal Husband" - Margaret Leighton and Emmy-winner Susan Hampshire star in this Oscar Wilde comedy-melodrama about a blackmail scheme. With Keith Michell, Jeremy Brett, and Dinah Sheridan. Note: Includes a five-minute filler.

From NET microfiche: EM Forster's famous novel is the basis of this play by Santha Rama Rau about Anglo-Indian relations in the nineteen-twenties. Although the India the book depicts no longer exists, the novel is a fascinating record of its period and is regarded by many as the best novel ever written about the country. Mrs. Moore, an elderly English lady, has just arrived in India for the first time to visit her son (by her first marriage), Ronnie Heaslop, resident magistrate in Chandrapore. With her is her son's fiance, Miss Quested. Roaming around a mosque one night, Mrs. Moore meets Dr. Aziz, a young Indian, and immediately a mutual appreciation develops between them. Dr. Aziz is a friend of the English principal of the local Government College, a liberal by the name of Fielding who tends to get on better with his Indian colleagues than with the very British members of the Indian Civil Service community. Mrs. Moore and Miss Quested meet Dr. Aziz again at Fielding's house, and the doctor, eager to show the two ladies India, invites them to a picnic in the nearby Marabar Caves. Heaslop is furious that the women have accepted this invitation from an Indian. Nevertheless, the picnic takes place. Then, when she and Dr. Aziz are separated in the caves from the rest of the party, Miss Quested experiences some form of emotional crisis and flees in panic form the scene. In her delirium she is persuaded by various compatriots back in Chandrapore that she has been victim of an outrage by Dr. Aziz. The local authorities are only too willing to make an example of this "upstart" Indian, and Dr. Aziz is brought to trial. Just at the moment when things look worst for him, Miss Quested comes to her senses and declines to proceed with the charge. The broken Aziz suddenly becomes triumphant, and his friend Fielding joins in his pleasure until he discovers that in revenge the doctor intends to sue him for damages. Fielding sees that it is Miss Quested who is not the loser all around, and he is torn between loyalty to his friend and pity for the girl who has lost the respect of both the Indian and the European communities. The play ends with the admission on both sides that the friendship between the liberal Fielding and the onetime Anglophile Aziz is now at an end. This production stars one of Britain's most distinguished actresses, Dame Sybil Thorndike, with Virginia McKenna (star of the film "Born Free"), Cyril Cusack, and Zia Mohyeddin. EM Forster (1879- ), the British novelist, often deals in his work with the interaction of two types of character and the intersection of two planes of living. He brings into conflict those who live by convention and those who live by instinct. Among his novels are "Where Angels Fear to Tread" (1905), "The Longest Journey" (1907), "A Room with a View" (1908), and "Howard's End" (1910). He is well known also for the volume of criticism "Aspects of the Novel" (1927) and for his more recent collaboration with Eric Crozier on the libretto of Benjamin Britten's opera "Billy Budd." Cast: Mrs. Moore - Sybil Thorndike Dr. Aziz - Zia Mohyeddin Mr. Fielding - Cyril Cussack Adela Quested - Virginia McKenna Professor Godbole - Michael Bates Mrs. Collins - Helen Ford Mr. Hamidullah - Saeed Jaffrey "NET PLAYHOUSE - A PASSAGE TO INDIA" is a production of the British Broadcasting Corporation, a presentation of National Educational Television. Producer: Peter Luke. NET Producer: Kay Chessid. Directed by Waris Hussein. Television adaptation by John Maynard. Form the novel by EM Forster and the play by Santha Rama Rau.

From NET microfiche, file S: Produced by the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, this play won an International Emmy Award in 1969. The story proceeds on two levels. In the present, a young girl named Zoe has committed suicide and her family is preparing for the services and burial. While this is taking place, Zoe appears and relives her tragedy in scenes with the people who were close to her but could not help her - her stepbrother and stepmother, her father, uncle and priest. Zoe, a deeply religious Roman Catholic, was in love with a married man and it was this conflict that led her to suicide. Martha Henry, who plays the leading role, is established as a star of Canada's renowned annual Shakespeare festival at Stratford in Ontario. The Cast: Zoe - Martha Henry The priest/Scrivens (dual role) - Jack Creley David - Paul Hardin Sid - Gerard Parkes Uncle Edgar - Joseph Shaw Agnes - Aileen Seaton Godfrey - Garrick Hagon Fred - Nicholas Simons Grandmother - Nan Stewart NET Playhouse #209 - "A Scent of Flowers" is an NET presentation, produced by the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation. Produced and directed by the late Melwyn Breen. NET Playhouse executive producer: Jac Venza. Story editor: Alice Sinclair. Designed: Edgar Krumins. Costumes: Shirley Mann.
