From NET microfiche, file S: A Sleep of Prisoners (1965) This program is a complete performance of the dramatic play, A SLEEP OF PRISONERS, by the noted English playwright, Christopher Fry. It is a National Educational Television production, produced and directed by Karl Genus. Fry's A SLEEP OF PRISONERS takes place during a fictional contemporary war and concerns the inner conflicts of four soldiers - men form different stations in life - who have been captured by the enemy "Towzers" and imprisoned in a bombed out church. This is a war play in which the enemy never appears. Guns echo across the countryside but the Towzer troops that captured Private David King, Private Peter Able, Private Tim Meadows, and Corporal Joe Adams do not intrude into the strange prison where they have left their captives. And yet there is no absence of enemy. For a war is raging within the church walls as well as without; the wartime buddies are each other's enemies. "There's strange divisions in us and in everyone," as Tim Meadows puts it. The playwright examines these "divisions" as he engages his four characters in a series of dramas in which each is forced to confront his own destiny. Slowly they - and we, as audience - come to understand their hostilities. And when the cleansing furor of their battle with life is over there is rest to soothe their weariness and a brutal message of universal harmony to lead them from their former discord. After the prisoners have gone to war with each other as dreamers they can live at peace with each other as men. Credits: A SLEEP OF PRISONRES by Christopher Fry is a 1964 production of National Educational Television; produced and directed by Karl Genus; and starring Barry Morse as Private Tim Meadows, Paul Stevens as Corporal Joe Adams, Ramon Bieri as Private David King, and Jon Voight as Private Peter Able. The associate producer is jerry Karpf. The associate director is Jim Hartzer. The lighting director is Danny Franks. The art director is Leif Pedersen. John Natale is technical director, and audio is by Dennis Maitland. Gail Gilman and Arks Smith are assistants to the producer. Music was arranged and composed by Martin Barrzt. The stage manager is Chet O'Brien. Stage Manager: Chet O'Brien Background: The American public first came to know A SLEEP OF PRISONERS in 1951, when, soon after its premiere in England, it opened in the St. James Episcopal Church in New York City. On that occasion Christopher Fry, an important and popular playwright - who's "The Lady's Not for Burning" has been in a hit on Broadway the previous season - made the headlines once again with a new play, this one written specifically for production in the sanctuary of a church. A SLEEP OF PRISONERS was first performed by the Religious Drama Society in England. The NET production of the play was done on a location on Welfare Island in New York's East River, where the Manhattan skyline could be used as a backdrop and two abandoned churches could be used for interior shooting. The entire performance was recorded as a videotape remote. The Plot: (The play's entire action takes place inside the church and the time span represented is exactly the same as the time it takes for the audience to see it.) It is night, and each of the four prisoners of war, incarcerated in a church, is about to go to bed. On the church organ Pvt. Peter Able picks out "Now the Day is Over" with one finder while Pvt. David King looks at the memorial tables on the wall. Feeling edgy, David becomes irritated by Peter's playing, and is further provoked when Peter goes to the lectern and starts to read from the bible and deliver a sermon. Unable to restrain the consuming hostility he feels for Peter (whose sense of the mystery of the universe - "I know I do not know - makes him an appeaser and a bad soldier), David, "an example of bestial passions that beset mankind," leaps on the pulpit in a rage and grabs at his comrade's throat. The two grapple and are finally pulled apart by Pvt. Tim Meadows and Cpl. Joe Adams. Just before he collapses onto the bunk, Peter muses about his inability to feel committed to a cause, the same acquiescence that infuriates David: "I never remember I ought to be fighting until I'm practically dead. Sort of absent-fisted " He soon falls asleep, as does Dave, and Tim and Joe are left to talk. Tim tells Joe how he got into the war, then they too drop off to sleep. Presently the hallowed environment begins to play on the sleeping prisoners, and the drama becomes a series of four dreams in which the men take on a number biblical roles. The first dream is the story of Cain and Abel in which David King is Cain, Peter Able is Abel, Joe Adams is Adam, and Tim Meadows is God. In their dream version of the bible account David and Peter re-enact the hostility which had caused their struggle on the pulpit earlier. While their father looks on, powerless to separate his two sons. Cain and Abel lock in a fatal battle over the question: which of their respective philosophical outlooks is favored by God? They are driven to determine which of the brothers is "justified." Is it Cain, the materialist, who sees man's goal as the state of being "content and full," as a "two-footed prosperity?" Or is it "analgesic" Abel who sees a destiny far beyond corporal man, though he cannot name it? The two roll dice to resolve the issue, and Abel wins. But Cain, fearing his brother has cheated him by loading the dice, and his God has betrayed him by siding with his brother, is so enraged he kills Abel. God sends Cain into flight, telling him that he will always be branded in society as a murderer and will never know peace. As he runs, Cain calls on the Lord to explain why he was never told that God's preference was not for the "government of flesh" that he, Cain, represented and his slain brother opposed. "How was I expected to guess that what I am you didn't want?" he asked. The answer from heaven is cryptic: "They shall never kill you." In the second dream, David and Absalom, Peter as Absalom returns to prey on Pvt. David King's strength (David King is King David of Israel in this dream). Absalom, who openly consorts with the King's enemies, challenges his father with: "Do you think I care?" King David is frustrated by his son's indifference and pleads with him: "Absalom, come alive. Living is caring." But Absalom keeps up his taunts, arrogantly defying authority and refusing to take a man-made society seriously. David charges his lieutenant Joab to teach his son obedience, but Absalom's reaction to Joab's harsh treatment is to betray the king and to join with David's enemies. David goes to war against Absalom; Absalom is killed; and the king is left along with an empty victory. The next dream concerns Abraham and Isaac, the story of the near sacrifice of Isaac, at God's bidding, on Mt. Moriah by his father Abraham. In this dream, as in the last, David is the father (Abraham) and the figure of strength, and Peter is the son (Isaac), and the one who ultimately at the mercy of the strong. But this time the outcome is not death and dismay, but an affirmation of life, albeit a qualified affirmation. The Angel of God (played by Joe Adams) comes to free Isaac from the cords that bind him to the sacrificial rock, warning Abraham that his son will still be bound, like all men, to the trials of society. Happy at Isaac's salvation, Abraham sacrifices a ram in his boy's stead, and Isaac is taken down the mountain on a donkey, guided by the Donkey-man (Tim Meadows). In the fourth and final dream Joe Adams, David King, and Peter Able are Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego, condemned to die in a fiery furnace for not worshipping King Nebuchadnezzar's golden idol. As the flames encircle them, they find themselves touched by neither fire nor heat. Discovering their ability to withstand destruction, they are filled with wonderment and hope. "I can think of life," says Adams. "We'll make it yet." Looking out through the flames they see Meadows looking in at them. They call to him to identify himself. "Man," he replies. "Under what command?" they ask. "God's," he replies. They ask him how they can get through the wall of fire. He tells them it will take patience, love, and "the honesty not to say we do a thing for all men's sakes when we do it only for our own." And most all, he explains, it will take a new kind of quest and negation of the old cures, the old measures. "Expedience and self-preservation can rot as they will The human heart can [now] go to the lengths of God. Dark and cold we may be, but this is no winter now. The frozen misery of century's breaks, cracks, begins to move, the thunder is the thunder of the floes, the thaw, the flood, the upstart spring. Thank God out time is now when wrong comes up to face us everywhere, never to leave us till we take the longest stride of soul men ever took. Affairs are now soul size. The enterprise is exploration into God where no nation's foot has ever trodden yet." The stirring message brings them out of the furnace. Soon after the last dream is over, the prisoners fall back into a dreamless sleep, the church clock strikes, a bugle sounds in the distance, and the play ends. "In this play," Karl Genus says, "Christopher Fry presents his audience with numerous levels and ironies and, thereby sets the imagination to work . It is a very rich script with the kind of vivid visual possibility that lends itself naturally to the creative techniques of television art." That this is designated a "verse play" may be misleading. While the playwright conceived of and wrote his drama as poetry, it is no way formal or stiff. On the contrary, the meter is varied, the lines unrhymed, and the tone natural. Indeed, it is often considered Fry's great gift as a playwright that he so beautifully uses poetry to intensify the reality of true-to-life conversation. This is surely the case with A SLEEP OF PRISONERS which, for all of its soul-searching, is sprinkled with the lively and witty dialogue one might expect of four dogfaces. Biographies: CHRISTOPHER FRY was born in 1907. One of England's foremost twentieth century dramatists, he has spent most of his life in the theater - acting or directing when he is not writing. Among his best known plays are The Boy with the Cart (1939), The Firstborn (1946), A Phoenix Too Frequent (1946), The Lady's Not for Burning (1949), Thor, with Angels (1949), Venus Observed (1950), A Sleep of Prisoners (1951), The Dark is Light Enough (1954), and Apollo, Curtmantle (1962). He is also responsible for noted English translations of Anouilh's Ring around the Moon and The Lark, and Giraudoux's Tiger at the Gates and Duel of the Angels, and the film scripts of Ben Hur and Barabbas. BARRY MORSE, who will be recognized by US viewers as the co-star of "The Fugitive," began his dynamic career at seventeen playing the title role of "Henry V" before King George VI and Queen Elizabeth in honor of their coronation. A veteran of some 2000 stages and television parts in England, Canada, and the United States, Mr. Morse is a 1932 graduate of the Royal Academy, and product of fifteen vigorous years as a leading British actor, appearing in plays in London, the provinces, and on BBC television and radio before moving to Toronto with his family in 1951. In Canada, his contributions to television have been applauded five times with the "Best Actor in Canadian Television" award - 1954, 1956, 1959, 1961, and 1962. On the stage his most recent major assignment was his starring role in the National tour of Harold Pinter's "The Caretaker." PAUL STEVENS has appeared on all the major network television series in New York and on the West Coast. In fact, his first association with Mr. Morse came when the two appeared together with Ingrid Bergman in "The Turn of the Screw," with Mr. Stevens playing Peter Quint. Outside of television, Stevens has extensive credits as well - on and off Broadway, in stock, and in the New York Shakespeare Festival where he has played Prospero, Romeo, Orlando, and a number of other leading parts. He has been featured in such motion pictures as "Exodus" and "Advise and Consent." RAMON BIERI, a leading actor in Joseph Papp's New York Shakespeare Festival, has played classical and contemporary roles for the McCarter Theater in Princeton, New Jersey, the San Juan Drama Festival, the Akron, Ohio, Playhouse, the Boston Summer Theater, and the Emerson Players. He was featured off-Broadway in "Mr. Simian" and was a member of the touring company of "Gypsy" in which he played the Jack Klugman role. On television he has been seen in such series as "East Side, West Side," "Hallmark Hall of Fame," "DuPont Show of the Week," "Naked City," and the "Armstrong Circle Theater." JON VOIGHT made his Broadway debut as Rolf Gruber in "The Sound of Music." A new face on the stage and television, he has already become a nationally recognized talent through his appearances on "Naked City," "Camera Three," and "The Defenders." During the past summer he played Mordred in the Guber Gross and Ford Production of "Camelot" with Howard Keel as King Arthur.

From NET microfiche, file A: Program Description: "Auto Stop" is the story of a young Englishman's coming of age through the means of a hitchhiking trip across the European continent. The time is the beginning of summer; the place is London; and the setting a lady's apartment late at night. Federika, a beautiful, continental woman-of-the-world has just told a callow young Englishman, who is enamored of her, to go out and see some of the rest of the world. When he has the "great European experience," then he can come back to her. So young Henry, with a knapsack on his back and not much money in his pocket, begins his summer odyssey. But, unlike Homer's voyage, this young traveler heads for Greece, hitchhiking by way of Paris, Rome, southern Italy and the island of Corfu. Most of the time, though, his guide book is neglected, for he is preoccupied in meeting, loving, and breaking the hearts of the beautiful and willing girls he meets along the way - blonde Norwegian Karen, Moya from Australia, and the modern American, Rosaleen. In Athens he finally receives a message from London, from Frederika - an empty envelope. Mystified and disillusioned, he heads back home, this time traveling through Belgrade, Budapest, Vienna, Munich, Dachau and Strasburg, meeting people and seeing the countries with new understanding. At the end of summer, back in London, he calls on Frederika only to find that she has forgotten all about him. But to his surprise, he finds that he doesn't care, for the trip has indeed been a success - he has grown up. British actor David Hemmings (star of Antonioni's prize-winning film, "Blow Up"), makes his American television debut in this production of "Auto Stop," in the role of Henry. Starring with him are Delphi Lawrence as Frederika; Kevin Stoney as Marcello; and Janice Dinnen as Moya. The Cast: Henry - David Hemmings Aryan - John Trigger Federika - Delphi Lawrence Ernie - David Lander Pietro - Gino Melvazzi Rosaleen - Catherine Griller Jed - Hal Hamilton Marcello - Kevin Stoney Domenico - Gino Cola Karin - Katherine Schofield Maria - Bettine Le Beau Bruno - Jonathan Burn Dimitrious - George Zenios Moya - Janice Dinnen Gingo - Ken Wayne Greek girl - Doola Economou Milos - Adrian Drotsky Janos - David Pinner Austrian - Gertan Klauber Kreuz - Michael Ritterman Waitress - Deirdre Turner Music by Eric Rogers Bazould dancing arranged by Andrikos Adonis Graphics by Ken Brazier Lighting: Gerry Millerson NET Playhouse: "Auto Stop" is a National Educational Television presentation, produced by James MacTaggart for the British Broadcasting Corporation. It was directed by Brian Parker. Written by Alan Seymour. Producer for NET was Kay Chessid.

From NET microfiche, file A: Filler for Auto Stop Description: The filler to be run with "Auto Stop" is a black-and-white animated short from Yugoslavia entitled, "Tamer of Wild Horses," running 7:48. A mall, club-wielding man meets, on a vast deserted open space, a huge immobile horse. Climbing on its back, he attempts to ride it. The horse is transformed (while still retaining its form) into a gigantic mechanism, a power engine every inch of which is covered with gears, bolts, etc. It tries to destroy the man even as the man tried to tame it. The man continues, eventually finding a trap door on the horse into which he climbs. He finds the horse hollow. Again he mounts the horse which becomes transformed into a white winged Pegasus, and the two ride off into the night skies. "Tamer of Wild Horses" was made by Zagred animation studio, directed by Dragic, written by Mimica, and produced by Matko. This is the film's first television showing.
Zagred animation studio ; producer, Matko ; directed by [Nedeljko Dragic] ; writer, [Vastrolav Mimica].

From NET microfiche: Principal dancers from the Bolshoi Ballet, the Royal Ballet of London, the Royal Danish Ballet, and the Paris Opera Ballet perform excerpts from Swan Lake, Don Quixote, and Romeo and Juliet, and other great Ballets. "Ballet Gala" features solo dancers from some of the world's greatest ballet companies - the Bolshoi Ballet of Moscow, the Royal Ballet of London, the Royal Danish Ballet, and the Paris Opera Ballet. These dancers perform segments from well-known works. The excerpts performed are the following: Melody Music: Christoph Willibald Gluck; Choreography: Asaf Messerer Performers: Maya Plisetskaya and Nicolai Fadeyechev of the Bolshoi Ballet, Moscow "Black Swan" Pas de Deux Music: Piotr Ilich Tchaikovsky; Choreography: Marius Petipa Performers: Maya Plisetskaya and Nicolai Fadeyechev of the Bolshoi Ballet Dying Swan Music: Camille Saint Saens; Choreogrpahy: Fokine Performers: Maya Plisetskaya of the Bolshoi Ballet Blumenfest in Genzano Music: Holger Simon Paulii; Choreography: Harold Lander after Bounonville Performers: Josette Amiel of the Paris Opera and Flemming Flindt of the Royal Danish Ballet "Swan Lake" Pas de Deux Music: Piotr Ilich Tchaikovsky; Choreography: Marius Petipa Performers: Svetlana Beriosova and Donald MacLeary of the Royal Ballet, London Romeo and Juliet (3 excerpts) Music: Serge Prokofiev; Choreography: Lavrovsky Performers: Maya Plisetskaya and Nicolai Fadeyechev of the Bolshoi Ballet Don Quixote Music: Ludwig Minkus; Choreography: Marius Petipa revised by Alexander Gorsky Performers: Maya Plisetskaya and Nicolai Fadeyechev The Dancers Maya Plisetskaya joined the Bolshoi Ballet School when she was eight years old and made her debut in 1943. Since then she has danced the leading roles in such works as "Romeo and Juliet," "Don Quixote," and "The Little hump-backed horse," and has also added teaching to her schedule at the Bolshoi. "Of all the dancers in the Bolshoi," wrote critic John Martin, "Plisetskaya appears to be the most individual" Nicolai Fadeyechev joined the Bolshoi Ballet School while still in elementary school. During his second year after his stage debut, he was given the leading role of the prince in Swan Lake. An ideal dancer for classical roles, since then he has danced with unfailing success the leads in many ballets, as well as in two film ballets - "Giselle" opposite Ulanova and "Swan Lake" opposite Plisetskaya. Josette Amiel is the premiere danseuse etoile of the Paris Opera Ballet. She began her ballet studies with Alexander Volinine, went to the Opera Comique in Paris, and subsequently the Paris Opera Ballet. She was engaged at the Paris Opera in the corps de ballet, but after only three years she was designated premiere danseuse and has been hailed for her performances in "Oberon," "La Belle Helene" and other works. Miss Amiel's quest appearances have included the Chicago Opera Ballet, the Royal Danish Ballet, and the Rome Opera Ballet. Flemming Flindt started dancing at age seven, and at age nine joined the Royal Danish Ballet School as one of its most promising students. When he was 18 he was invited to join the London Festival Ballet and spent two years with them, coached and assisted by Anton Dolan and performing in many lead roles. In 1957 Flindy joined the Royal Danish Ballet as solo dancer. In 1966 he became its General Director, the youngest in the company's more than 250-year history. Svetlana Beriosova is Lithuanian-born and comes from a family involved in ballet. She began dancing at age eight, continuing her studies with Balanchine in New York, Olga Preobrajenska in Paris, and Vera Volkovan in London. She became associated with the Royal Ballet of London after experience with the Grand Ballet de Monte Carlo, the Sadler's Wells Theatre Ballet and other companies. Donald MacLeary trained at the Royal Ballet School, London, and joined the company in 1954. The following year he was promoted to soloist and in 1959 he was made a premier danseur. He has partnered Svetlana Beriosova on most of her appearances abroad, and they have created many modern roles together. Performances by Maya Plisetskaya and Nicolai Fadeyechev recorded by O.R.T.F., Paris, and directed by Pierre Viallet. Performances by Josette Amiel, Svetlana Beriosova, Fleming Flindt, and Donald MacLeary recorded by Bavaria Atelier, G.M.G.H., and directed by Kurt Jacob.
a National Educational Television presentation ; NET producer, Tom Slevin ; director (for O.R.T.F.), Pierre Viallet ; director (for Bavaria Atelier, G.M.G.H.), Kurt Jacob.

From NET microfiche: Ken Russell's third and final contribution to the biography series is a film which, having been telecast previously on NET Playhouse, represents one of the most highly acclaimed programs ever shown by NET. "A Song of Summer," said Life magazine film reviewer Richard Schickel, "may be television's finest hour of drama." (And in a recent article for Harper's, Schickel referred to the film as "the best dramatic television program I've ever seen.) The New York Times television critic George Gent said the film was "easily the best dramatic portrait of the contradictions of the artistic temperament that this viewer has seen on television." English composer Frederick Delius (1862-1934) was blind and paralyzed in the final years of his life. Nevertheless he wrote several of his major works during that period (including "A Song of Summer"), thanks in large measure to the aid of a young musician - an organist named Eric Fenby - who came to the composer's side upon learning of his afflictions. Fenby today is professor of harmony at London's Royal Academy of Music. He is the author of the book "Delius as I Knew Him," upon which this film is based. "A Song of Summer," starring Max Adrian as the composer, tells the story of the final years of Delius' life as seen through the eyes of Fenby. Learning that Delius, who was living in France, was unable to continue work, Fenby felt an almost mystic calling to go to him and offer help. The film portrays the dream of the years which Fenby spent in the strange and sometimes frightening Delius household, and of the handicaps which both men had to overcome before the composer could make use of his talent again. The Cast: Frederick Delius - Max Adrian Eric Fenby - Christopher Gable Jalka Delius - Maureen Pryor Percy Grainger - David Collings Suggested Newspaper Listing: "NET Playhouse Biography: Frederick Delius" - Max Adrian stars in "A Song of Summer," Ken Russell's highly acclaimed film about composer Frederick Delius who, with the aid of a friend, overcame blindness and paralysis in his final years to write some of greatest works. "NET Playhouse Biography: Frederick Delius" ("A Song of Summer") is a presentation of NET Divisions, Educational Broadcasting Corporation, produced by the British Broadcasting Corporation. Produced and directed by Ken Russell NET Playhouse executive producer: Jac Venza FILLER INFORMATION: The filler material for NET Playhouse #143 - "A Song of Summer," is a black and white short from Poland entitled "People of the Road," running a litter over 10 minutes. It is a mood piece - a series of impressions of a traveling circus. We see performers sleeping in their caravans as they approach the next small town; bears being fed in the early morning light; an acrobat standing on his head, cigarette between his lips, practicing a feat of drawing on another pair of pants on his upended torso. There is no dialogue, only a lyrical harmonica accompaniment. The tent is put up, town children stare with awed fascination at the monkeys, and the performers put on their makeup. The film ends as the music begins to signal the start of the circus.

From NET microfiche: General Description of Series: Anthony Hopkins plays the title role in this play about French Revolutionary leader Georges Jacques Danton, who was executed during the reign of terror after rejecting Robespierre's extreme radicalism. Danton (1759-1794), a lawyer by profession, was elected to the national Convention in 1792, supported the execution of King Louis XVI the following year, and was elected president of the Jacobin Club, the aim of which was national unity and creation of a stable republican form of government. But he and his followers were overcome by Robespierre and the leaders of the Reign of Terror. Danton was imprisoned, and on April 5, 1794, he was guillotined. The play relates the last few hours in Danton's life, as he shares a cell with some of his closest friends. As his execution draws nearer, flashbacks recall the events leading to his imprisonment and bring aspects of his character to light in dramatic fashion. His humanity, vulgarity, and extroversion are contrasted with the cold detachment of Robespierre. The defiance he displayed during the farcical trial in which he was condemned re-emerges as he and his companions are led to the guillotine. Cast: Danton Anthony Hopkins Robespierre Alan Dobie St. Just David Andrews Sanson Michael Robbins Fabre d'Eglantine Terry Scully Herault John Quentin Suggested Newspaper Listing: "NET Playhouse Biography" - Anthony Hopkins stars as 'Danton," the French Revolutionary leader who met his death at the hands of the radical Robespierre during the reign of Terror. "Danton" is a presentation of NET Division, Education Broadcasting Corporation, produced by the British Broadcasting Corporation. Written by Arden Winch. Producer: Mark Shivas. Director: John Davies. NET Playhouse executive producer: Jac Venza. This program is transmitted nationally by PBS, The Public Broadcasting Service.

From NET microfiche, file G: General Description of Series: George Washington as a young officer facing his first command decisions in battle is portrayed by Rene Auberjonois, winner of Broadway's Tony Award for best supporting actor (opposite Katharine Hepburn in "Coco"), in this program produced on location in Western Pennsylvania by WQED, Pittsburgh. Auberjonois, who is currently starring in the Lincoln Center production of "Twelfth Night," is supported in this play by Lyle Bettger and George Montgomery. The former plays the role of James Mackay, commander of a South Carolina armed force that joins Washington in a battle against the French; the latter is seen in the role of Christopher Gist, an English plantation owner who represents a peace-seeking faction. The time is 1754. Washington, a young lt. colonel in the provincial forces fighting for English interests, assumes his first command in what is today Western Pennsylvania. He is leading the First Virginia Regiment - 300 hastily recruited volunteer militiamen, poorly trained and poorly equipped - in a military maneuver against the French forces who have erected the strong Fort Duquesne at the Forks of the Ohio (now the site of Pittsburgh). The Virginia regiment comes from the southeast, across the mountains, and its men are exhausted as they reach a point some 50 miles east of the Forks. The last mountain ridge lies between them and Fort Duquesne. It is here, at Fort Necessity, that Washington will face his first major battle and the first mental anguish of command. Washington is portrayed as an impetuous young man, eager for command and glory, confident that his men, reinforced before battle by the South Carolina company, will defeat an enemy whose forces are reported to number 1,500. His confidence has been bolstered by his defeat of a small French detachment, taken by surprise on Laurel Ridge. The battle of Fort Necessity is revealed as a character-building episode in the life of Washington. For the first time he makes decisions that mean life or death to the men under him, knowing he is outnumbered by forces that are better equipped and more experienced than his own raw recruits. During this encounter, Washington begins to change from the brash, self-confident young man, dubbed the "Virginia firebrand," to a more introspective, cautious leader, learning the responsibilities and burdens of command. He receives opposing counsel from his subordinates and begins to realize decision-making processes are awesome and lonely. Major Cast (in order of appearances): Rene Auberjonois as Lieutenant Colonel George Washington Michael Miller as Captain Jacob Van Braam Ned Schmidtke as Lieutenant John West Special Guest Appearance by: Lyle Bettger as Captain Jame Mackay Suggested Newspaper Listing: "NET Playhouse Biography: George Washington" - Broadway Tony-winner Rene Auberjonois ("Coco") stars in "Portrait of a Hero as a Young Man," depicting Washington as a youthful officer facing his first command decisions in battle at Fort Necessity. Co-starring Lyle Bettger and George Montgomery. "Portrait of the Hero as a Young Man" is a presentation of the national programming division of WNET/13, produced by WQED, Pittsburgh. Producers: Mat von Brauchitsch and Thomas Cherones Directed by von Brauchitsch Written by Leon Katz Associate producer: Charles Altman Associate director: Stephen Dick Cinematography: Paul Goldsmith and Norris Brock Editor: Norris Brock Executive producer: Jay Fayvid NET Playhouse Executive Producer: Jac Venza Transmitted nationally by PBS, the Public Broadcasting Service.

From NET microfiche, under "H": Program Description: Cannes Film Festival award-winner Kitty Winn plays the title role in this NET adaptation of the 1943 Broadway drama "Harriet," based on the life of Harriet Beecher Stowe, author of the momentous novel "Uncle Tom's Cabin." Co-starring are Richard Dysart as Harriet's husband, the scholarly Calvin Stowe, and Madeleine Sherwood as her benevolent but domineering sister, Catherine, along with Barnard Hughes, Paul Hecht, Kendall March, and Gretchen Corbett. Miss Winn, named "best actress" at Cannes last year as co-star of "Panic in Needle Park," fills a demanding role that requires the 27-year-old star to portray her subject as a young, middle-aged, and elderly woman. The same role afforded Helen Hayes one of her greatest triumphs in the Broadway production, directed by Eliz Kazan. "Uncle Tom's Cabin," published as installments in an anti-slavery paper in 1851 and as a separate volume a short time later, is perhaps unrivaled in its impact on the American people. As a graphic depiction of the tragedies of slavery, the story fired up an era already made turbulent by the slavery issue, and its publication is sometimes described as an important step toward the Civil War. "Harriet" centers its drama upon the long-standing inner conflict which had preceded and accompanied Mrs. Stowe's writing of "Uncle Tom's Cabin." By nature a woman who dreaded controversy and public censure, she finally undertook the novel after her own terrifying encounter with "slavers" who wrenched a runaway Black woman from her home. "Harriet" has been adapted for television by Peabody Award-winning producer Jacqueline Babbin from the original script by Florence Ryerson and Colin Clements. Directing for TV is Tom Donovan. Miss Babbin last year produced Arthur Miller's "A Memory of Two Mondays" for the "NET Playhouse on the Thirties" series. She won a Peabody Award as producer of "Outpost" in the Dupont Show of the Week series, and in 1970 her production of "JT," a CBS Children's Hour special, won a Peabody for its screenplay by Jane Wagner. Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET Playhouse Biography - Cannes Festival award-winner Kitty Winn stars as "Harriet" in this drama about the life of Harriet Beecher Stowe, adapted from the 1943 Broadway hit. Co-starring Richard Dysart, Madeleine Sherwood, Barnard Hughes, Paul Hecht, Kendall March, and Gretchen Corbett. "NET Playhouse Biography' is a production of NET Division, Educational Broadcasting Corporation. The series has been made possible in part by grants from the National Endowment for the Humanities and the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation. Transmitted nationally by PBS, the Public Broadcasting Service. From NET microfiche: Program Description: "The Biggest Dancer in the World" - about dancer Isadora Duncan - is the first of three films in the "Biography" series by British director Ken Russell, whose "Women in Love" and "The Music Lovers" are currently being seen in American movie theaters. Isadora Duncan (1878-1927), an important American dancer and major influence on the development of modern dance in Europe and America, unfortunately attained as much or more fame in her day for her tragic and scandal-ridden personal life as for her art. Russell's film portrays Isadora as the free spirit who abandoned not only the classical forms of dance but most of the moral conventions of her time as well. The script was written by Russell and Sewell Strokes, who was a close friend of Miss Duncan. Isadora was in a literal sense a big woman, and even in this respect she was unconventional as a dancer. Born in San Francisco, she attained her major success abroad, first in London and Paris, and later in Vienna, Budapest and on tour in Germany. She opened a dance school for children near Berlin in 1904, and, after having been invited to Russia, started a similar school in Moscow in 1921. She also married a Russian, but was subsequently banished from his homeland for her outspoken and radical ideas. Flamboyant behavior and wild love affairs made her headlines across the United States and Europe, as did the tragic accidents that claimed the lives of her two children and her husband, and the grotesque incident in which she herself was killed. Riding in an open-air car, Isadora was strangled when the long scarf she wore became caught under a rear wheel. Isadora Duncan is portrayed by Vivian Pickles, who will be seen in the forthcoming films "Nicholas and Alexandra," with Laurence Olivier and Michael Redgrave, and "Harold and Maude" with Ruth Gordon.
NET playhouse biography. Isadora Duncan--the biggest dancer in the world.

From NET microfiche: Description of series: This series focuses on the private vision of the creative person. Each program is devoted to a 20th century artist whose special qualities of imagination, taste, originality, intelligence, craftsmanship, and individuality have marked him as a pace-setter in his field. These artists --- whose fields span the entire gamut of the art world --- include film maker Jean Renoir, poet John Ciardi, industrial designer Raymond Loewy, Hollywood producer-director King Vidor, noted Broadway couple Ossie Davis and Ruby Dee, artist Leonard Baskin, humorist James Thurber, satirist Robert Osborn, Indian musician Ravi Shankar, poet P. G. Wodehouse, painter Georges Braque, former ballet star Olga Spessivtzeva, Rudolf Bing, and Marni Nixon. The format for each program has been geared to the individual featured; Performance, interview, and documentary technique are employed interchangeably. Program 49: Anna Pavlova This program examines the magic of Anna Pavlova and the reason why, thirty-five years after her death, her name remains synonymous with ballet. Miss Pavlova was born in St. Petersburg (now Leningrad), Russia, in 1881. She studied dance at the Imperial School of Ballet there until 1905, and later began a series of foreign tours which included her first London appearance in 1910 and her New York debut the same year. In 1911 she founded her own dance company and, until her death in 1931, devoted her entire life to bringing ballet and dance to remote regions of Asia, Africa, Latin America, and Australia. Included in the program are excerpts from films showing the range of Pavlova's work from classical roles such as "The Immortal Swan" to variety pieces such as "Californian Poppy" as well as informal footage of Mme. Pavlova at her home in Hampstead, England, and on tour with her company. Interspersed with this footage are exclusive interviews made specifically for this program with close associates of Miss Pavlova, such as Sol Hurok, manager of Pavlova's later American tour who discusses her from an impresario's point of view; Madame Butsova, a leading dancer of the Pavlova dance company who accompanied Pavlova on her world-wide tours; and Aubrey Hitchens, one of Pavlova's last dance partners. These and other interviews build a composite picture of Anna Pavlova and attempt to analyze her both as a personality and as one of the major contributors to the world of twentieth-century dance. The program is highlighted by footage of Pavlova on tour in Egypt in 1928. The existence of this film was only discovered within the last two years and it has never before been viewed by the public.
National Educational Television ; producer, Jac Venza ; writer, Joseph Hurley.
The creative person. The legend of Anna Pavlova.

From NET microfiche: Program Description At the close of his life, John Adams said "the foundations of American independence were laid on March 5, 1770." The date is that of the infamous "Boston Massacre" - an incident which inflamed anti-British sentiment and precipitated one of the most significant trials in American history. This drama explores the consciences and motivation of two men who played major roles in that trial - John and Sam Adams. Laurence Luckinbill, co-star of the film and off-Broadway productions of "The Boys in the Band," is featured as John, and James Karen portrays Sam. The play was produced by M. Von Brauchitsch of WQED, Pittsburgh. John Adams and his second cousin, Sam Adams, are seen in sharp contrast. John is a young man of 32 - a farmer and a lawyer with a keen legal mind, an unmovable respect for the law, and an abhorrence of violence. Sam, a clerk of the General Court and a representative to the legislative assembly in Massachusetts, holds more radical views. He believes that bloodshed is necessary to dramatize the developing conflict between the British troops and American patriots. This drama then is also a study of the moral man in politics - the man who is attempting to keep his idealism beyond the taint of practical politics and violence. That man here is John Adams, the central character in the drama. The facts of the riot are quickly developed. During a confrontation between an angry crowd and a British garrison force in Boston, five men are killed by the British. The citizens, led by Sam Adams, demand that the British soldiers involved be brought to trial. Gov. Adams agrees to the trial. Eight soldiers and their commanding officer are ordered to stand trial for murder. John Adams and Josiah Quincy agree to defend the soldiers; Samuel Quincy is appointed the prosecuting attorney. During the course of the trial, John Adams is offered a seat on the legislative assembly by Sam Adams. This sharpens the personal conflict which has developed within John Adams during the course of the trial. Although he suspects that the riot was incited by Sam Adams and the Sons of Liberty, he does not develop these facts during the trial. Instead, he carefully cross-examines the witnesses and brings out other evidence that supports his suspicion. John Adams was learning to play the political game. The soldiers are acquitted of murder; two of them are found guilty of manslaughter. The tactics that Sam Adams employs to arouse the public against the King's government are clearly developed in the drama. His use of - in fact, his creation of the incident - results in the governor's decision to order the troops out of Boston - one of Sam Adams' primary goals. Sam Adams emerges as a man with an event to be commemorated - one that he pursues passionately in the years ahead. John Adams emerges as the young idealist in search of identity, who in the process of finding this identity gets his hands dirty. Although his case is won and his principles are not too tarnished, as Sam Adams says, the American people would never see the case his way. Among the players in this drama are many non-professional actors, most of whom were cast because of their actual experiences in confrontations between demonstrators and authorities in Cleveland, Chicago, Pittsburgh, and Kent State University. The Cast: John Adams - Laurence Luckinbill Sam Adams - James Karen Gov. Hutchinson - Liam Sullivan Samuel Quincy - James Cromwell Harrison Grey - Robert Benedetti Molineaux - Tom Erhart Suggested Newspaper Listing: "NET Playhouse Biography: John and Sam Adams" - The Boston Massacre and the subsequent murder trials of eight British soldiers provided the setting for this drama about the ideological conflict that separated John and Sam Adams. Starring Laurence Luckinbill ("The Boys in the Band") and James Karen. "NET Playhouse Biography: John and Sam Adams" ("The Boston Massacre") is a presentation of NET Division, Educational Broadcasting Corporation, produced by WQED, Pittsburgh. Produced and directed by M. von Brauchitsch Associate Producer: William Thompson NET Playhouse executive producer: Jac Venza

From NET microfiche: "The Trail of Tears" was originally telecast as NET Playhouse #186 in April, 1970. "The Trail of Tears" represents one of the most ambitious productions ever undertaken by NET Playhouse. It was written, produced, and directed by Lane Slate, who assembled an outstanding cast, including Johnny Cash in his dramatic debut. The program was filmed on location in the Southeastern United States, except for a small portion filmed in Massachusetts. Cash, who is one-eighth Cherokee Indian, plays the key role of Cherokee Chief John Ross, who is believed also to have been one-eighth Cherokee (and seven-eighths Scotsman). Jack Palance portrays President Andrew Jackson. The voice of Joseph Cotton is heard in the role of a reporter who serves the dual function of narrator and of catalyst as he questions the characters (in the style of "You are There"). William Redfield and Pat Hingle also co-star. "The Trail of Tears" is a dramatization of the events leading up to the Cherokee Nation's terror-filled journey from it Southeastern homeland to the Oklahoma Territory in 1838-39; the journey itself, on which thousands dies; and the resulting inner-tribal conflict that divided the Cherokee people for decades. The story: The state of Georgia, seeking to include within its boundaries the land occupied by the Cherokees, passes legislation declaring all Cherokee laws null and void in Georgia and denying Indians any legal recourse. The Georgia law violates a treaty between the US and the Cherokee Nation committing the US to protection of the national integrity of the Cherokees. President Jackson is deaf to the pleas of Chief John Ross despite the fact that George Washington himself had strongly influenced the Cherokees to develop their farmlands and adopt the methods of the white man, which the Cherokee did. (In fact, contrary to the popular concept of Indian life, the Cherokees of the 1830s were living on ranches, and some families even had black slaves.) Jackson, very ill, is preoccupied with his own miseries, and the Georgians who want the Indians drive out are his strong political allies. Meanwhile, the Georgia Mounted Volunteers harass the Cherokees with acts of terror. Eventually, an important Cherokee tribesman, John Ridge, Speaker of the Council of Chiefs, announces that he favors removal of the tribe to Oklahoma. Nevertheless, Ridge's decision is in conflict with the Cherokee Blood Law - giving up lands belonging to the Cherokee Nation must be punished by death. This is the beginning of a split between the Cherokee people that causes bloodshed for many years to come because many Indians side with Ridge, incurring the bitterness of the other tribesmen. Meanwhile, Georgia conducts a lottery which divides up the Cherokee farms among white farmers. Ross comes home one day to discover that his farm has been taken away from him. He gathers his family and leaves. In 1835 a US Indian agent calls on the Cherokee to vote on a proposed treaty providing for the removal of the Cherokees to the Oklahoma Territory. He rules that any tribe member who does not appear is to be counted as favoring the proposal. The treaty is approved, opening the schism among the Indians. Ridge and his father will later be murdered, as will many of their followers. Before resettlement takes place, US soldiers under Gen. Winfield Scott and members of the Georgia Mounted Volunteer begin the brutal process of rounding up the resisting Cherokee farmers and placing them in stockades prior to deportation. The Cherokees are place in 12 ill-equipped stockades. Ross and his family surrender themselves from their Tennessee encampment and join the other tribesmen. The Indians' journey begins in the fall of 1838. Winter arrives and plagues the poorly-dressed and virtually unsheltered travelers. Game is scarce and the food supplies dwindles. Diphtheria and pneumonia become commonplace and before the trip is over some 4,500 Cherokees, including Ross' wife, dieon what comes to be known as the trail of tears. The play ends despairingly, with a look at the barren modern-day Cherokee country in Oklahoma. It points out that after the Cherokees had restored their Civilization on their new lands, Oklahoma became a state and took virtually everything away from them again. In addition to the obvious injustices suffered by the Cherokees, the play seeks to emphasize a point in reference to forced migrations that is generally obscure to white Americans. It is most clearly presented in a passage spoken by John Ridge: "Whether we become Methodists or Catholics or Hindu - or whatever - underneath that contemporary ceremony is a continuous, generation-to-generation, inherited belief that the land - not the buildings on it - but the land is our church. Because our fathers are interred in it, and their fathers. It is out link to them. It is our belief the land of our birth - because it is out link to them - is especially holy. That is why it is our church." Some notes about the supporting cast: Many roles have been filled by Cherokees who are not professional actors and actresses. Chief Ross' full-blood Cherokee wife, Quatie, is played by Paulette Smart of Cherokee, North Carolina; Johnny Cash's wife, singer June Carter, appears in a cameo role as the wife of the farmer who appropriates Ross' land. Bobby Wooten, guitarist in Cash's troupe, plays a white scout; and Arthur Junalusha claims the distinction of being the world's only professional full-blooded Cherokee actor. The following is a list of other supporting players: Governor Gilmer - Harry Davis Senator Lumpkin - John Randolph George Washington - Pat Hingle Reverend Samuel Worcestor - William Redfield John Ridge - Vic Mohica Elias Boudinot - Mike Crow BF Curry - Tom Klunis JE Schermerhorn - Ramon Gordon Gen. Winfield Scott - Kent Smith Martin Van Buren - Kurt Freed Col. Kenen - Ed Cope White Farmer - Ralph Henry White Farmer's wife - June Carter Col. Sanford - Frank Needham Doctor - Frank Goften Indian Who Tells Story - Richard Crowe Georgia Officer - Ben Hornbuckle Officer's Assistant - Irving McCoy NET Playhouse - "The Trail of Tears" is a production of NET Division, Educational Broadcasting Corporation. Written, produced, and directed by Lane Slate. Associate producers: Ann Delaney and Peter Scarlet. Film editor: David Hanser. This program is transmitted nationally by PBS, the Public Broadcasting Service.

From NET microfiche, file T: "'The Trail of Tears," written by NET producer Lane Slate, is Playhouse' most ambitious production for 1970. An outstanding cast has been assembled, but of extra significance is the fact that this play marks the dramatic debut of Johnny Cash, the country music singer and guitarist whose soaring popularity over the past two years has placed him unquestionably number one in his field. (The Evelyn and Arthur Barron documentary "Johnny Cash! The Man, His Music, His World," originally seen on PBL, has now been released to commercial theaters.) Cash, who is one-eighth Cherokee, plays the role of Cherokee Chief John Ross, who was also one-eighth Indian (and seven-eighths Scotsman). Jack Palance portrays President Andrew Jackson. Joseph Cotten is not seen, but his voice is heard throughout the play in the role of a reporter who serves the dual function of narrator and catalyst, presenting facts for the audience and eliciting comments from the characters. "The Trail of Tears" should properly be described not as a drama, in the strict sense, but rather as a dramatization of the events leading up to the Cherokee Nation's horror-filled journey from their Southeastern homelands to the Oklahoma Territory in 1838-39, including the journey itself, and the resulting inner-tribal conflict that divided the Cherokee people for decades. The story: The State of Georgia, seeking the land occupied by the Cherokees within its boundaries, passes a law declaring all Cherokee laws null and void in Georgia and denying Indians any legal recourse. No Cherokee, in fact, is entitled to a trial, nor can he testify in court. The Georgia law violates a treaty between the U.S. and the Cherokee Nation - a treaty that commits the U.S. to protection of the national integrity of the Cherokees. But Jackson is deaf to the pleas of Chief Ross, despite the treaty, despite the fact that Ross and many other Cherokees played a major part in helping Jackson defeat the Creek Indians, and despite the fact that George Washington himself had strongly influenced the Cherokees to develop their farmlands and adopt the methods of the white man (which the Cherokees did. In fact, contrary to the popular concept of Indian life, the Cherokees of the 1830's were living on ranches, and some families even had black slaves.) Jackson is very ill. He suffers from dropsy and possibly from consumption; he has a bullet lodged in his chest and another in his left arm which has rendered the limb useless. He is preoccupied with his own miseries, and adding to his callousness toward the Cherokee plight is the fact that the Georgians who want the Indians driven out are strong political allies of his. Meanwhile, the Georgia Mounted Volunteers harass the Cherokees with acts of terror. Eventually, an important Cherokee tribesman, John Ridge, Speaker of the Council of Chiefs, announces that he favors removal of the tribe to Oklahoma. As Ridge's father later explains: "The white man is coming here. With his rudeness. With his whiskey. With his prostitutes. It is as certain he is coming as it is we are going. It is only that my son is the first to clearly see that" Nevertheless, Ridge's decision is in conflict with the Cherokee Blood Law - giving up lands belonging to the Cherokee Nation must be punished by death. This is the beginning of a split between the Cherokee people that will cause bloodshed for many years to come because many Indians sided with Ridge, incurring the bitterness of the other tribesmen. Meanwhile, Georgia conducts a lottery which divides up the Cherokee farms among white farmers. Ross comes home one day after a fruitless meeting with Jackson only to discover that his farm has been taken away from him and his family is holed up in the pig shed. He gathers his family and leaves. Early in 1835 a U.S. Indian agent calls a meeting of the Cherokees to vote on a proposed new treaty, one that provides for the removal of the Cherokees to the Oklahoma Territory. He rules that any tribe member who does not show up is to be counted as in favor of the proposal. The treaty is approved, opening the schism among the Indians. Ridge and his father will later be murdered, as will many of their followers. In fact, the anti-removal faction, headed by Ross, and the pro-removal faction were to battle long after the Cherokees resettled in Oklahoma. But before resettlement takes place much is yet to happen. U.S. soldiers under Gen. Winfield Scott, and members of the Georgia Mounted Volunteers begin the brutal process of rounding up the resisting Cherokee farmers and placing them in stockades prior to deportation. (The play opens, before credits, with a preview of this as two Georgia Volunteers rout an Indian family off their ranch and murder a black slave.) The Cherokees, or as many as can be found (some managed to elude the soldiers and hid in the Smoky Mountains, later to resettle in North Carolina) are placed in 12 ill-equipped stockades. Ross and his family surrender themselves from their Tennessee encampment and join the other tribesmen. The Indians' journey begins in the fall of 1838. They have been paid a nominal sum for the farms they gave up, and most of this money goes to pay exorbitant fees which they are charged on Appalachian toll roads. Winter arrives and the convoy is barely half-way to its destination. Cold rains, sleet and snow begin to plague the poorly-dressed and virtually unsheltered travelers. Game becomes scarce and the food supply dwindles. Diphtheria and pneumonia become commonplace, and before the trip is over some 4,500 Cherokees, including Ross' wife, die on what comes to be known as the trail of tears. In the meantime, Jackson's successor, President Martin Van Buren, reports to the press: "It affords me great pleasure to apprise the nation of the entire removal of the Cherokee Nation of Indians to their new homes west of the Mississippi. The measures authorized by Congress have had the happiest effects their removal has been principally under the conduct of their own chiefs, and they have emigrated without any apparent reluctance." The play ends despairingly, with a look at the barren modern-day Cherokee country in Oklahoma. It points out that after the Cherokees had restored their civilization on their new lands, Oklahoma became a state and took virtually everything away from them again. In addition to the obvious injustices suffered by the Cherokees, the play seeks to emphasize a point that is generally obscure to white Americans. It is most clearly put forth in a passage spoken by John Ridge: "Whether we become Methodists or Catholics or Hindu - or whatever - underneath that contemporary ceremony is a continuous, generation-to-generation, inherited belief that the land - not the buildings on it - but the land is our church. Because our fathers are interred in it, and their fathers. It is our link to them. It is our belief the land of our birth - because it is our link to them - is especially holy. That is why it is our church." Some notes about the supporting cast: Many roles have been filled by Cherokees who are not professional actors and actresses- the most important of these roles, that of Chief Ross' full-blood Cherokee wife, Quatie, is played by Paulette Smart of Cherokee, North Carolina. You will receive shortly from Greg Vitiello a feature about her with pics (in addition to feature and bio material on other players). Johnny Cash's wife, singer June Carter, plays a cameo role. She appears as the wife of the farmer who appropriates Ross' land. Bobby Wooten, guitarist in the group The Tennessee Three, which is part of Cash's troupe, plays the role of a white scout who travels with the Indians to Oklahoma. Arthur Junaluska (Ridge's father) claims the distinction of being the world's only professional full-blooded Cherokee actor. Following is a list of other supporting players: Governor Gilmer - Harry Davis Senator Lumpkin - John Randolph George Washington - Pat Hingle Reverend Samuel Worcestor - William Redfield John Ridge - Vic Monica Elias Boudinot - Mike Crow B.F. Curry - Tom Klunis J.F. Schermerhorn - Ramon Gordon Gen. Winfield Scott - Kent Smith Martin Van Buren - Burt Freed Col. Kenen - Ed Cope White Farmer - Ralph Henry White Farmer's Wife - June Carter Col. Sanford - Frank Needham Doctor - Frank Goften Indian Who Tells Story - Richard Crowe Georgia Officer - Ben Hornbuckle Officer's Assistant - Irving McCoy Suggested Newspaper Listing: Johnny Cash and Jack Palance star in this tragic story of the Cherokee Indians' forced removal from their lands in Georgia and the resulting civil war that ravaged the Cherokee Nation. With Joseph Cotten, William Redfield, John Randolph, Pat Hingle, and introducing Paulette Smart. NET Playhouse - "The Trail of Tears" is an NET production. Written, produced, and directed by Lane Slate. Associate producers: Ann Delaney and Peter Scarlet. Film editor: David Hanser. Additional Information from NET Press Release from 2/12/70: Paulette Smart is a policeman's wife and former "Miss Cherokee." Remembering her own childhood, she laments the fact that "my grandfather wouldn't teach Cherokee to his children or grandchildren. In school, he'd been whipped because he couldn't speak English. And he didn't want that to happen to any of us." Instead, her grandfather would "talk it to his wife when he didn't want us to understand." But the filming of NET's "Trail of Tears" in Cherokee, N.C., enabled Paulette to tap her own Cherokee roots. "They needed about 200 Indians to play in the stockade scene," Paulette recalls. "And my daughter Diane wanted to be in the film." NET had run an ad in One Feather, the Cherokees' local paper, notifying all prospective actors to appear at the newspaper office for auditions. Ann Delaney, associate producer for the production, was on hand to take Polaroid photos of each applicant. When the photographs were studied, producer Lane Slate then selected Paulette -- a woman with fine features and classically pronounced cheekbones -- to play the role of Quatie Ross, wife of Chief John Ross. The drama, based on an original script by Slate, features singer Johnny Cash in the role of John Ross. It will be seen ___ at ___ on Channel ___. "I was delighted when they gave me the part of Quatie," says Paulette. "I hadn't even thought about being in the play, but Diane wanted me to be with her when she auditioned." The nine-year-old Diane was chosen as one of the 200 Cherokees who are herded into the stockade prior to their removal from Georgia to Oklahoma. Paulette appears in several scenes, always stately and silent, at her husband's side. The drama recounts the Cherokees' betrayal by the U.S. government and their eventual death march during the harsh winter of 1839. It is during this march that Quatie dies. Until recently, Cherokee was Paulette's full-time home. She was employed there as receptionist in the OEO-sponsored Cherokee Community Action Program. At present, however, she spends most of the year in Mulberry, Fla., where her husband is a member of the police department. "When the chief learned I was going to be in the play, he sent me a nice letter of congratulation," Paulette notes proudly. During each summer, Paulette and her family return to Cherokee, visiting her lifelong friends and reviving their heritage. "Now, more than ever, I wish my grandfather had taught the Cherokee language to me," she concludes recognizing, the influence of her acting experience. Additional Information from NET Press Release from 4/1/70: He doesn't have the gravel-textured voice of Johnny Cash or the macabre expressions of Jack Palance - but Arthur S. Junaluska will never suffer an identity crisis. That's because Junaluska, who appears with Cash and Palance ___ at ___ over Channel ___ in the NET Playhouse production, "The Trail of Tears," is the world's only professional full-blooded Cherokee Indian actor. For that matter, he's also the only professional full-blooded Cherokee playwright, producer, director, composer, and choreographer. And, by the way, he's a medical researcher who is credited with helping to perfect a blood test for venereal disease. Just in case any further distinctions are required, Junaluska is a descendant of two great chiefs of the Cherokee Nation, Junaluska and Yonaguska. "They were half brothers," explains the present-day Junaluska, a six-foot, 180-pounder, who displays all the austere mannerisms that his namesake might have possessed. "Junaluska saved the life of (Andrew) Jackson," he relates. "It was at the Battle of Horseshoe Bend and some of the Cherokees who were fighting on the same side as Jackson were plotting to kill him. But Junaluska put a stop to that." The story is ironic because Jackson was to become the President who collaborated in throwing the Cherokees off their Southeastern homelands. "The Trail of Tears," in fact, is about that Program in American history, when the U.S. government turned its back while the State of Georgia stripped the Cherokees of their legal rights, confiscated their farms, and eventually forced their migration to the Oklahoma Territory. The play dramatizes these events, with Junaluska in the role of an influential Cherokee tribesman who unwittingly helps precipitate a civil war among his people. Cash, who is part Cherokee in real life, makes his dramatic debut in the role of Chief John Ross, and Palance plays President Jackson. Of course, this will not be the first time Junaluska will be seen on TV in the role of an Indian. You may have caught him on the Ed Sullivan Show with Rex Harrison and Lili Palmer in a skit mocking the traditional American Indian stereotypes. If not, you may have seen him in small roles on any number of programs, including "Studio One," "'You Are There," "Armstrong Circle Playhouse," "Kraft Theater," "The Phil Silvers Show," "GE Theater," "To Tell the Truth," "The Big Story," and "Frontiers of Faith." He's also been on stage in several plays, including two which he produced and directed off-Broadway, "The Arrowmaker" and "News on the Wind," and he's had some small movie roles. But the creation he is most proud of is his ballet, "Dance of the Twelve Moons," which was presented at the 1963 Indian Festival in La Grande, Oregon, "It includes dances probably never seen before by white men," he says, "and maybe, some never seen even by Indians (of today). I think it's the best piece of work I've done." Junaluska, who is married, was born in Cherokee, North Carolina, some 50 years ago. He earned an A.B. degree at Maryville College in Tennessee. During World War II he served in the Medical Corps attached to air and ground forces in Europe, and when the war was over he stayed in England and worked as a researcher at the South London Blood Transfusion Centre in Sutton Surrey. It was there that he contributed an important modification for the serological test to spot VD. But in 1955 Junaluska gave up medical research and returned to the U.S. to pursue his primary interest, the theatrical arts. He launched his professional career with a part in director Margaret Webster's Broadway play "The Wrong are Lonely." In fact, says Junaluska, "It was two great ladies of the theater, Margaret Webster and Eve La Gallianne, who inspired me to continue my career." That same year, 1956, Junaluska organized the American Indian Drama Company and began writing and directing Indian dramas for radio and television and for presentation on college campuses and in Indian communities. In the summers of 1960 and 1961 he was director and coordinator of the Indian village at New York City's mammoth "Freedomland" amusement center, where he presented tribal dances and songs and dramatized Indian legends. During that same period he founded the American Indian Society of Creative Arts, which subsequently became dormant, but which he says may soon be reactivated in line with his overriding ambition. "Eventually I want to have an American Indian repertory company," he explains. "That is what I want most." Additional Information from NET Press Release from 4/8/70: Percussionist and composer Max Roach has written an all-drum score for the NET Playhouse production "The Trail of Tears," a drama starring Johnny Cash and Jack Palance which will be telecast ___ at ___ over Channel ___. "The Trail of Tears" dramatizes the plight of the Cherokee Indians, who were thrown off their Southeastern homelands in the 1830s and forced to migrate westward during a winter in which some 4,500 tribesmen died from disease and exposure. Roach, who has been leading his own ensemble since the late 1940s, is ranked among the greatest jazz drummers of all time. While still in his teens he was playing alongside such giants as Dizzy Gillespie, Bud Powell, Thelonious Monk, Charlie Parker, and Lester Young. Among the better-known artists who formerly played in Roach's ensemble are Sonny Rollins, Charlie Mingus, Freddie Hubbard, Donald Byrd, and Cedar Walton. His wife, actress-singer Abbey Lincoln, has been a vocalist with the group since 1962. She also writes lyrics for many of her husband's songs. Roach's larger compositions include the suites "Freedom Now!" "It's Time," and "Sweet Love," all of which are written for chorus, solo vocalist, and ensemble, and the musical "Another Valley."

From NET microfiche, file J: Program Description: Shakespeare makes a contribution to the "NET Playhouse Biography" series with this BBC production of "Julius Caesar," starring Robert Stephens, Maurice Denham, Frank Finlay, and Edward Woodward. The play is Shakespeare's historical tragedy about the conspiracy to murder Caesar, the great Roman statesman-warrior, and the conflict of interest following the assassination which led to the deaths of the conspirators. Caesar (100 BC to 44 BC), who formed and became part of the ruling First Triumvirate in 60 BC, became dictator of Rome in 49 BC. Of the four starring player, three are well-known to NET Playhouse audiences. Stephens, who directed the film "The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie," has starred on NET Playhouse in "Much Ado About Nothing" and in Chekhov's "The Seagull." Finlay co-starred in the same "Much Ado About Nothing" production as the comic Constable Dogberry. And Denham played the role of the father in John Hopkin's tragic four-part series "Talking to a Stranger." The Cast: Julius Caesar - Maurice Denham Mark Anthony - Robert Stephens Brutus - Frank Finlay Cassius - Edward Woodward Portia - Ann Castle Casca - Anthony Bate Calpurnia - Gwen Cherrell Octavius - John Alderton "Julius Caesar" is a presentation of NET Division, Educational Broadcasting Corporation, produced by the British Broadcasting Corporation. Producer: Cedric Messina. Director: Alan Bridges. Executive producer: Jac Venza.

From NET microfiche, file B: The last stormy years in the brief, flamboyant life of Byron, English poet and satirist, are recounted in this BBC production starring British television star Keith Barron. The film begins when Byron settles in Venice with two mistresses, leaving behind him his many scandals in England. It is 1818; six years later, at the age of 36, he will die of illness while involved in the revolution in Greece. In the years that take him from Venice to the Greek battlefields he will make a final tormented choice between the lifestyle of a playboy and of an idealist. While in Venice Bryon is approached by his friends, Percy and Mary Shelley, who want to know how he intends to raise his illegitimate daughter, Allegra. They want the child to live with them, but Byron decides to place her in a convent. Meanwhile, Byron has become involved with the 20-year-old wife of an elderly count. The poet is in deep despair; he loves the Countess Teresa, but suspects that he will always be a philanderer, incapable of giving lasting happiness. She flees with him to Pisa, but their joy is short-lived. Byron meets an English adventurer named Trelawney, who chides the poet for his outspoken support of revolution in Greece which has amounted only to talk. Trelawney's words profoundly affect Byron. Two tragedies - first his child Allegra dies in the convent, then Percy Shelley drowns - convince him that anyone he comes close to is destined for ruin. He abandons Teresa and heads for Greece. George Gordon (Lord) Byron, 6th baron of Roschdale, was born January 27, 1788, to a Scottish mother and an English army captain, who died when Byron was three. Byron was lame all his life with a club foot; his sensitivity to this is thought to have affected the development of his personality. As a writer his reputation is of a romanticist and a political liberal. He travelled extensively, and a sojourn in Greece (1810-1811) has a lasting influence on his work and his behavior. Among Byron's best known poetry is "Don Juan," Isles of Greece," and the autobiographical "Childe Harold." He is also renowned as a clever satirist; and his letters to friends and associates are considered among the most entertaining and witty private letters published in the English language. Partial cast: Byron Keith Barron Count Guiccoli Raf de la Torre Trelawney Anthony Ainley Credits "NET Playhouse Biography: Byron" is a presentation of the national programming division of WNET/13. The film "Byron" produced by the British Broadcasting Corporation. Producer: Mark Shivas Director: John Glenister Written by: Ian Thorne NET Playhouse executive producer: Jac Venza Transmitted nationally by PBS, the Public Broadcasting Service.

From NET microfiche, file L: Italian director Roberto Rossellini's "The Rise and fall of Louis XIV" makes its American television debut in this series. With Jean-Marie Patte in the title role, heading a French cast, the film depicts the years of Louis' reign immediately following the death of Cardinal Mazarin, during which the young king established a monarchy of enormous power and dazzling opulence out of the chaos he inherited. Louis xiV (1638-1715), known as the Sun King and le Grande Monarque, acceded to the throne at the age of five, under the regency of his mother. At the time most of the power was in the hands of Cardinal Mazarin, who shrewdly guided the country's foreign affairs and mustered what little royal authority there was to resist the internal rebellions of the Fronde. When Mazarin died in 1661, Louis was 23 but had negligible experience in the affairs of state. Nevertheless, his reign was to last 73 years - the longest in European history - and France was to reach its zenith while Louis' court became the most magnificent in Europe. Rossellini's film gives careful attention to details of history, costuming, and court protocol. It begins with Mazarin's last days and the final counsel he gives to Louis form his death bed. Among other things, the king is told to trust in the loyalty and abilities of a young aide named Colbert, who later became financial minister and a key figure in Louis' reign. The film stresses the importance that Louis attaches to Mazarin's impending death. The king realizes that his power will be divided among countless noblemen, aides and other conspirators unless he acts swiftly. Scarcely a few hours after Mazarin dies Louis assembles his ministers of state and orders them to take no official action without his approval - he personally will oversee all affairs of government. At first the ministers are skeptical of Louis' resoluteness. But the king takes Colbert into his confidence and before long Colbert's enemy, finance minister Nicolas Fouquet, is exposed as an embezzler of royal funds. The skepticism disappears, and Louis rules with an iron hand. The film then recreates the king's pursuit of international power and self-aggrandizement. Abroad, Louis' armies are victorious, while at home he begins construction of the magnificent palace of Versailles, encourages the arts to flourish within his court, and establishes among his courtiers the most frivolous standards of etiquette and dress - all to enhance his glory as the king of France. Cast of principal characters: Louis - Jean-Martin Patte Colbert - Raymond Jourdan Mazarin - Silvagni Le Tellier - Fernand Fabre Credits: Produced by L'Office de Radiodiffussion-Television Francaise Directed by Roberto Rossellini Script by: Philippe Erlanger Adaptation and dialogue by: Jean Gruault "The Rise of Louis XIV" is a presentation of the national programming division of WNET/13. NET Playhouse executive producer: Jac Venza

From NET microfiche: Ludwig van Beethoven (1770-1827) is the subject of NET Playhouse's third "Biography" in its 15-week series. Depicting a crucial period in the great composer's life, the program focuses on the time between his departure from Bonn for Vienna at age 22 and the subsequent first recognition of his genius by the public. Three themes are developed: Beethoven's coming to terms with his growing deafness; his gradual disillusionment with Napoleon and the "Age of Enlightenment"; and his acceptance of the fact that loneliness would be the price of his brilliance. Michael Jayston, who starred as Siegfried Sasson in the opening "Biography" program, plays the role of the composer. Other major characters are: Josephine Deym - Judy Parfitt Franz - Edward Hardwicke General Kugelgen - John Loder Miss Parfitt is a well-known stage and television performer in England; Hardwicke is a member of the National Theatre Company of England and has appeared in several films, including "The Battle of Britain" and "Otley"; and Loder is known for his film roles during the thirties and forties. "NET Playhouse Biography: Ludwig von Beethoven" is a presentation of NET Division, Educational Broadcasting Corporation. Written by Ian Curteis. Producer: Mark Shivas. Director: Mark Cullingham. NET Playhouse executive producer: Jac Venza.

From NET microfiche: NET Playhouse begins a 15-week series of biographical dramas with this film portrait of anti-war poet Siegfried Sassoon (1886-1967). Under a different title ("Mad Jack"), the program won the Grand Prize at this year's International Television Festival at Monte Carlo for its contribution to the ideal of international peace. The film, produced by the BBC and nationally transmitted by the Public Broadcasting Service, explores the thoughts of a young soldier in the First World War whose protest against that conflict met with virtually total public disapproval and misunderstanding. As a second lieutenant in the Royal Welsh Fusiliers, Sassoon had seen action on the western front and was awarded the Military Cross by the time he returned to England on leave in 1917. While on leave he defied military authorities by writing a statement against the vested interests he considered responsible for the war. It was published in a periodical, and that was the beginning of a torturous episode in Sassoon's life. Sassoon was summoned by authorities, who requested that he spend a week re-thinking his protest and its consequences for him. There was no mass peace movement to which he could attach himself, no element of public opinion to provide support. He was alone with his opinions; he would be thought insane, and ostracized. Finally a friend dissuaded him from standing aloud in Parliament, but dismissed due to Sassoon's hospitalization in a clinic for shell-shocked officers. Some of Sassoon's poetry is used in the program to dramatize the crucial week of self-examination which ended in his decision not to sacrifice himself further in an ineffectual gesture. British author and journalist Tom Clarke wrote the screenplay for "Sassoon." Starring as Sassoon is Michael Jayston, a veteran member of the Royal Shakespeare Company, currently seen in the film "Cromwell." The Cast: Sassoon - Michael Jayston Cromlech - Michal Pennington Adjutant - Clive Swift Ormand - David Wood Bertrand Russell - Charles Lewson Lady Ottoline - Anna Barry Hugh Massingham - John Boxer Lytton Strachey - Jonathan Cecil Barton - Roger Ostime Wilmot - Donald Sumpter Mansfield - Barry Savage Col. Jones-Williams - James Cossins Music hall artist - Ann Beach "NET Playhouse Biography: Siegfried Sassoon" is a presentation of NET Division, Educational Broadcasting Corporation. Producer: Graeme McDonald. Director: Jack Gold. Music by Carol Davis. NET playhouse executive producer: Jac Venza. FILLER INFORMATION: Title: The Days of Wilfred Owen In this color film selections from the works of English poet Wilfred Owen are read by Richard Burton and illustrated with watercolors by Robert Andrew Parker. The poems relate the heartbreaks of war as Owen witnessed and experienced them. The poet was killed in France during World War I, just one week before the Armistice was signed. He was 25. Owen gained posthumous recognition after his poem were edited and published in 1920 by Siegfried Sassoon, whom he met in an army hospital. Parker has been termed "one of three or four great artists in America" by the renowned critic Dwight MacDonald. Whitney Museum, both in New York City, and in the Museum of Fine Art in Raleigh, North Carolina. This film was produced by Bob Bach and Richard Lewine.

From NET microfiche, file S: Scottish actor Bill Gavin portrays the Nobel Prize-winning bacteriologist Sir Alexander Fleming, who discovered penicillin but was frustrated in his attempts to refine the drug into a practical medicine. Fleming (1881-1955), a shy and unobtrusive person, to some extent made his discovery by accident while working as a bacteriologist at St. Mary's Medical School at the University of London in 1928. It wasn't until 1945, after a group of bio-chemists at Oxford had managed to refine penicillin, that Fleming was named a co-winner of the Nobel Prize for medicine. He had been knighted the previous year. At the time of his momentous discovery, Fleming was already respected in his field and was working under Sir Almroth Wright, who pioneered with vaccines. Fleming was interested in anti-bacterial substances that would not be injurious to animal tissue. While conducting research with bacterial culture plates, he discovered one day that a mold had accidentally formed on one of the plates containing staphylococcus, and that the staphylococcus surrounding this mold had apparently been destroyed. Further experiments with the mold, which he named penicillin, showed that it was highly potent in preventing the growth of bacteria. Unfortunately, Fleming was not to have Sir Almroth's cooperation in developing penicillin for practical use. Brilliant but somewhat rigid in his methods and philosophy towards science, Wright tended to dismiss Fleming's discovery as "mere accident" and failed to acknowledge its potential. Fleming's own personality prevented him from openly campaigning against his superior, and for years he was unable to make any significant advance in refining penicillin. What small recognition he gained for his work was achieved for him largely by his wife, Sareen. Partial cast: Fleming - Bill Gavin Sir Almroth Wright - Rupert Davies Sareen Fleming - Nancie Jackson John Freeman - Richard Warner Nicholson - David Cuilter Hedley - Larry Dann Mrs. Watson - Mary Holder "Sir Alexander Fleming" is a presentation of NET Division, Educational Broadcasting Corporation, produced by the British Broadcasting Corporation. Producer: Mark Shivas. Director: John Glenister. Written by Ian Curteis. NET Playhouse executive producer: Jac Venza.
