General Description of Series: The "NET Playhouse Biography" series continues with the story of English novelist Marian (or Mary Ann) Evans, (1819-1880) who wrote under the pen name of George Eliot. The name is probably best known in America for the novels "Silas Marner" and "Adam Bede." This BBC film relates the story of an extraordinarily gifted woman who suffered through nearly 40 years of frustration and loneliness before achieving happiness in love and success as a writer. In her middle years she became one of the most famous writers of nineteenth-century England. Her works also include "Middlemarch," "The Mill on the Floss," "Romola," "Felix Holt the Radical,' and Daniel Deronda." As a homely girl with a very high intellect Marian Evans was a misfit in the petty bourgeois society into which she was born. Her relations with her family also were strained because she rejected religion. When her father died she left home and went to London and began writing articles for intellectual quarterlies. In London Marian achieved some modest success but her personal life remained one of misery. After an unhappy affair with a philandering publisher she became attracted to philosopher Herbert Spencer. But his egotism and total involvement with his own work precluded a genuine relationship here also. She was in her mid-thirties and had become co-editor of 'Westminster Review' when she met theater and literary critic George Henry Lewes. He was married but his wife had left him. Lewes and Miss Evans fell in love and, with Victorian divorce laws making marriage impossible, they defied convention and lived together openly. For this they were ostracized but apparently they did not care. It was Lewes who persuaded Marian to attempt fiction writing, in part because he was financially responsible for two families and needed the extra income badly. Published in Blackwood's magazine 918570 her first story, "The Sad Fortunes of the Rev. Amos Barton," won great success. Her second novel, "Adam Bede," became a best seller in Europe and America and made her and Lewes rich. Suggested Newspaper Listing: "NET Playhouse Biography: George Eliot" The story of how Marian Evans, under the pen name George Eliot, became one of England's best-known novelists after half a lifetime of despair and frustration. Starring Sheila Allen. Followed by filler : "Virginia Woolf: The Moment Whole" with Marian Seldes. Two programs on one tape.
NET playhouse biography. The confessions of Marian Evans--A portrait of George Eliot.

Filler following NET playhouse biography. George Eliot. Two programs on one tape. "Virginia Woolf: The Moment Whole" features Marian Seldes (winner of a Tony Award for her Broadway performance in "A Delicate Balance') giving life to the thoughts of writer Virginia Woolf as expressed in her essay "A Room of One's Own" and her novel "The Waves." With these and other works Mrs. Woolf (1882-19410 became a champion of women's self-assertion in the arts. 'This aspect of her writing has been rediscovered by women who are now trying to define themselves both as women and artists,' says producer Janet Sternburg. This film was shot in and around an old windmill house at Montauk, N.Y., on the eastern tip of long Island. The setting is similar to Mrs. Woolf's country home and the English landscape of her writing.
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche, file B: "The Boss's Son" is one of a series of dramatized documentaries the French journalist Danielle Hunabelle made especially for French television. The series (of ten programs to date) is called "Jeux de Societe" or games of society. Each program in the series investigates some aspect of present-day French society and uses the device of a fictionalized plot to heighten the documenting of that film's particular social climate. The story line of "The Boss's Son" is a simple one. Bruno, the son of a textile magnate in a small French town, falls in love with Yvette, one of the girls in his father's factory, but the social pressures on both of them succeed in terminating their romance. Through the use of this plot, coupled with straight film documentary techniques (film footage depicting the actual environments of the rich boy and of the working-class girl, interviews with real townspeople from those two social classes), Mme. Hunabelle has drawn a picture-in-depth in "The Boss's Son" of human relationships between bosses and workers in an industrial province north of Paris. The viewer is shown graphically those obstacles of class, customs, and tradition which the lovers find it impossible to overcome. None of the people who appear in the film is an actor. The amateur "actors" in the plot portray roles similar, if not identical to those roles they play in actual life. The young girl is a real factory worker. The rich boy is really the son of an industrialist. All the people who are shown being interviewed, and whose opinions propel the dramatic action, expressed their own ideas and prejudices. At the close of the film there is a short segment filmed in a Westinghouse elevator factory in New Jersey. "The Boss's son" was shown to a group of workers, and their reactions and opinions filmed in order to give an "American postscript" to it. A specially-prepared American sound track has been superimposed over the original French track to allow both the French dialogue and sound effects to run effectively under the English-language translation. Background of the filmmaker Mme. Danielle Hunabelle is a correspondent and senior editor of the French magazine "Realities." She has been a foreign correspondent for various French, English, and American newspapers and magazines since 1948 and has covered stories as far away as Indochina. She began her work in television documentaries in 1962. NET Playhouse: "The Boss's Son" is a National Educational Television presentation, produced by Danielle Hunabelle for ORTF, Paris Producer for NET: Kay Chessid

From NET microfiche: Brandon Thomas, English dramatist, actor and manager, who died in 1914 at the age of 57, is remembered today mainly as the author of the classic Victorian Farce "Charley's Aunt." This intricately contrived piece of sublime nonsense about an aristocratic Oxford undergraduate trying to sustain the impersonation of an elderly aunt first appeared at London's Royalty Theatre in 1892, where it played for four years, a fantastic run in those days. It has been revived constantly ever since, and a musical version called "Where's Charley?" (Book by George Abbott with music by Frank Loesser) had a successful run on Broadway in 1948) The plot concerns an Oxford student, Jack Chesney (madly in love with Kitty Verdun) and his friend, Charles Wykeham (equally enamored of Amy Spettigue). Because the girls would never consent to visit them in their rooms unchaperoned, the young men take advantage of the impending visit of Charley's rich and widowed aunt from Brazil ("Where the nuts come from") to invite the young ladies to tea to meet her. But alas, just as the girls arrive, the aunt sends word that she will be delayed. What is to be done? The dear young things must not be compromised - no, never! But neither will the youths give up the opportunity of receiving the ladies and declaring their love. The problem is solved by forcing another friend, young Lord Fancourt Babberley (Babbs) into old lace, bombazine bugle-beads, and elastic -sided boots, to become the world's most famous "mock aunt." Then all at once the plot thickens. Unexpectedly the real aunt arrives (accompanied by her beautiful ward), and Jack's father, Sir Francis Chesney, along with Mr. Spettigue, Kitty and Amy's fatuous old guardian, also come upon the scene unannounced. Both older men try to improve their fortunes by proposing to the false aunt while Charley's real aunt looks son in amusement. At the final unmasking, the real aunt turns out to be an old love of Sir Francis, her ward Is the missing love of Babbs, the long-suffering masquerader, Kitty and Amy admit they are anxious to wed their young hosts, and old Spettigue is sent packing. British television star, Richard Briers heads the cast of "Charley's Aunt" playing the role of Lord Fancourt Babberly. With him are the English actors Pauline Jameson (the 'real' aunt), Diana Beevers (Charlet's sweetheart Amy), Ann Davies (Kitty), Derrick Sherwin (as Jack Chesney), and Raymond Clarke (as "Charley"). Frank Pettingell, England's distinguished character actor, plays Mr. Spettigue. NET Playhouse -"Charley's Aunt" is a National Educational Television presentation, produced by Graeme Muir for the British Broadcasting Corporation. It was adapted for television by John Wraith. Scenic design by Roy Oxley, costumes by Mary Woods. Producer for NET: Kay Chessid.

From NET microfiche: Description of series: "Confrontation" - The anatomy of a student rebellion is dramatized in this experimental play based on events that took place at Columbia University and Berkeley. The cast includes actual students and professional actors. "Confrontation" is set on a fictitious college campus, but the events depicted are based on events that took place during recent student rebellions at Columbia University and the Berkeley campus of the University of California. In fact, film footage (black and white) from disorders at those two schools are woven into the drama and in some cases, actual dialogue spoken by persons involved in those disorders is contained in the script. The trouble is set off when the college decides to build a new laboratory on campus. Student demonstrations begin, centering on two principal issues: defense work on campus, and the loss of black community property that is to result from construction of the lab. However, the focus of the drama is on human relationships rather than on the political issues. As the atmosphere becomes more charged, students take over a key building on campus. Soon conflicts develop not only between students and administration, but also between faculty and administration, between black and white students, and even between student leaders. A variety of production techniques were employed in this drama. Some scenes were filmed with television cameras, others with hand-held equipment. Some spontaneously improvised segments have been interwoven with the planned scenes. The cast is composed of a few professional actors, headed by Richard Dysart, along with students from the Carnegie-Mellon University Drama Department, and a group of Pittsburgh area youngsters brought together for the production by director Larry Kornfeld.
WQED, Pittsburgh ; producer, Mat Von Brauchitsch ; producer for NET, David Loxton ; director, Larry Jornfield.

From NET microfiche, file C: It is Imperial Russia in the 1860s and Private Postnikov is on guard in his sentry box outside the Czar's palace in St. Petersburg. A drunken peasant foolishly begins to make his way across the river and falls through a crack in the melting ice. Postnikov, member of a crack guard's regiment, is faced with a dilemma: shall he stay at his post or shall he rescue the man and so risk getting shot. Humanity wins. He pulls the peasant out of the Neva and hastily gets back on guard. Lt. Kirov, a passing officer from another regiment, claims the rescue as his own and reports it to the local Police Headquarters. Postnikov's immediate commanding officer, Capt. Miller, discovers the sentry's "crime," and ashamed that a member of his regiment should have left his post, reports him to the colonel of the regiment, Svinin. The latter, even more jealous of the honor and reputation of the regiment (and sensing jeopardy to his own reputation and prospect of promotion) sees clearly that the sentry should have shot the struggling peasant rather than leave his post. Trembling with rage and indignation, he consults the Chief of Police, Gen. Kokoshkin. The general brings pressure to bear on the local station and they dig out of the wastebasket, Kirov's statement of his claim to the rescue. Although everyone knows Kirov is a liar, the honor of a famous regiment is at stake, and he gets a medal for bravery. To make sure that Postnikov thinks twice the next time he is tempted to rescue drunken peasants, the real hero gets two hundred strokes of the birch. Capt. Miller has liberal views and a troubled conscience. He appeals to Svinin and to the Archbishop but both tell him to leave well enough alone. He is still troubled and visits Postnikov, recovering from his punishment in the military hospital only to find that the happy private is relieved that he got off so lightly. From NET microfiche: Oliver Reed, whose principal credits include co-starring roles in the films "Oliver!" and "Women in Love," portrays the tormented and erratic painter-poet Dante Gabriel Rossetti (1828-1882) in this film buy Ken Russell ("Women in Love" and "The Music Lovers"). Rosetti was co-founder of the "pre-Raphaelite" school of painting, an English offshoot of nineteenth century romanticism. Although he lived his life in London, he was an Italian whose father had fled Naples as a political refuge (the elder Rossetti was a poet who supported a revolution in 1820 and had to flee when King Ferdinand was restored to power). The title of this film alludes to the private hell in which Rossetti is depicted as having suffered, largely because of an inner-conflict which he never resolved. Although Rossetti imparted a spiritual idealism to women in his art (puritanism is a part of the pre-Raphaelite image), his life away from the canvas revealed a different nature. His marriage to Elizabeth Siddal, who had been his model for hundreds of idealized portraits and his chaste fiance for 10 years, did not prevent him from continuing relationships with other models. These included Jane Burden, with whom he maintained a tortured relationship long after her marriage to his friend William Morris. The death of Elizabeth two years after her marriage to Rossetti filled the artist with such grief and remorse that he decided to bury his manuscripts with her body. Seven years later he had the body exhumed and recovered his poems, but not his peace of mind. He spent his declining years shut up in his Chelsea home, addicted to alcohol and drugs. Suggested Newspaper Listing: "NET Playhouse Biography: Dante Gabriel Rossetti" -- Oliver Reed recreates the tormented life of the pre-Raphaelite painter and poet in this film by Ken Russell.

From NET microfiche: NOTE: Please note that after the NET Playhouse logo, this program begins with a special effect. The first scene is shown in negative, but reverts to positive very soon. Do not think that you have received the programing negative tape instead of positive. Description: This play states its theme in its opening lines. "A traitor is a man who goes over to the other side. When he comes over to our side, of course, the case is -- different?" The country: Australia, land of sunshine and cricket. The time: from 1945 to 1953. The people involved: still alive. To Michael Bialoguski, a Russian-born Pole, Australia spelt freedom and opportunity, as it did to thousands of other migrs. But when pressures from behind the Iron Curtain penetrated the serenity of his new life, his efforts to combat them involved him directly in that world of intrigue, subterfuge, and somersaulting ethics which is the reality of espionage. He found himself an Australian intelligence agent assigned to a Soviet diplomat named Vladimir Mikhailovich Petrov, an old Beria man and security officer of the Soviet Embassy in Canberra. "Defection! The Case of Colonel Petrov," is the play by Donald Bull based on Michael Bialoguski's remarkable book about Petrov's defection to the West. Petrov had a smart wife, too fashionable for the dowdy Soviet colony in Canberra. He had acquired an Alsatian dog, as well. And he had bed eyesight, which got worse when he was threatened with recall to Russia. His activities among the "sentimental" Australian fellow-travelers had been supported by his rigid party discipline, but he had few illusions. "What do they know?" he asked. "They think Communism is made with cream cakes. I know what it is. I worked. I built it. I made it." And he left it. He defected. The large cast of "Defection! The Case of Colonel Petrov" is headed by Lee Montague (who plays Bialoguski and is said to look uncannily like him in real life), Nigel Stock as Petrov, and Madge Ryan as Mme. Petrov. Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET Playhouse - "Defection! The Case of Colonel Petrov" -- Donald Bull's play about the famous case of a Soviet diplomat and security officer who defects to the West. The play is based on the book by Michael Bialoguski, the Australian intelligence agent assigned to Petrov.

From NET microfiche: Kalikikar Roy is a man of deep religious convictions and a great devotee of the goddess Kati (called "Ma"). His elder son, Taraprasad, is weak-willed and anxious not to displease his father lest he be deprived of his inheritance. Taraprasad has a wife, Harasundari, and a five-year-old son, Khoka, the pet of the entire household. The younger son, Umaprasad, whose new wife, Doya, is a great favorite of the old man, has little in common with his brother. He studies in a Calcutta university, has converted to Christianity, and regards his father's religious convictions as unenlightened and old fashioned. Doya looks forward to joining her husband in Calcutta, but will be sorry to leave her nephew. The child is devoted to her to a degree which has aroused the jealousy of his mother. One night old Kalikikar dreams that Doya is an incarnation of the goddess Kali. He proclaims the vision and the helpless Doya find herself installed as deity. When Umaprasad is summoned home from Calcutta by his sister-in-law, he is shocked by the spectacle of his wife being worshipped as the goddess Kali, a sick peasant child laid at her feet in the hope of a miraculous recovery. He seeks out his father, has a serious quarrel with him, and threatens to stop the meaningless ritual. But he is unnerved by the news of the sick child's recovery However, Umaprasad convinces Doya to run away with him. During the night as they are fleeing the house, however, Doya suddenly stops. "What if I am a goddess?" she asks. "After all, the child did survive." Umaprasad gives up in despair. He leaves and returns alone to his studies in the city, but Doya has no peace. She is torn between love and longing for him and her duties as the goddess incarnate. But one day her beloved nephew falls ill. His mother, who never believed in Doya's divinity, pleads for medical help despite the opposition of her husband and father-in-law. The goddess Kali, in the form of Doya, will intervene again. The boy is brought to Doya and dies in her lap. When Umaprasad returns once more, this time determined to free his wife from her bondage, he discovers that he is too late. The shock of Khoka's death has been too much for Doya an she has lost her mind. Background Information: Still only in his 40s, Satyajit Ray is internationally acknowledged as the master of serious Indian films. Satyajit was born in Calcutta in 1922 into a distinguished and educated family. His grandfather was a painter, poet, scientist and editor, and his father was a well-known writer who authored, among other works, Bengal's classic book of nonsense. Young Ray graduated from the University of Calcutta with honors in physic and economics. At the urging of the late Rabindranath Tagore, Nobel Prize winning poet and writer, Ray entered Santiniketan, Tagore's "world university" where the young student immersed himself in the history of art and developed a skill in drawing. After Tagore's death, he left eh school and went to work as are director for a British advertising firm in Calcutta. During this time he met the French filmmaker, Jean Renoir, who became a major influence on Ray's film work. Later, when his firm sent him to England for three months, he had an opportunity to learn the new trends in filmmaking first hand. It was after he had illustrated an edition of the popular Indian novel "Father Panchall" that Ray started to consider making a film of it. Seven years were to elapse between the beginning of his work on this first film and the completion of the whole "Apu Trilogy." But since that acknowledged masterpiece and the production of "Devi," his second and some consider equally great effort, Ray has produced some two films each year. Based on a story written by Prabhat Kmar Mukherjee, on a theme suggested by Rabindranath Tagore.
a National Educational Television presentation ; NET producer, Kay Chessid ; producer, director, adapter, Satyajit Ray.

From NET microfiche, file D: Jules Romains, novelist, poet and dramatist, was born in 1885 and still reigns as one of France's great men of letters. Although his fame rests in the main on such serious works as his multi-volume "Men of Good Will" series an d his novel on the life of a composer, "Jean Christophe," this farce, which he wrote in 1923 and called simply "Knock" in the original French version, has become a modern French classic. For years after it was first produced, it was performed every year in Paris and throughout the French provinces. The play has been translated into nearly all languages, and produced worldwide. It is in the repertoire of the Comedie Francaise, and its leading role, that of Dr. Knock himself, came to be identified with the late Louis Jouver, one of the most renowned French actors of modern times, who performed the role with phenomenal success both on the stage an in the films. The English version of the play was translated from the French by the late British dramatist and Shakespearean scholar Harly Granville-Barker. "Doctor Knock" Dr. Parpalaid gets rid of an unprofitable general practice in the French countryside to a man who looks gullible -- Dr. Knock. Knock realizes he has been taken in, but because he is a fanatical devotee of medical science, he plans to reincarnate the dying district. First he has posters printed with offers of free consultations every week. The inhabitants flock to him merely out of curiosity, or the desire to get something for nothing. But Knock convinces each one of them that he is unwell and needs treatment. He gets the local schoolmaster to give hygiene lectures, and enlists the sympathy of the chemist, Mousequet, by promising prosperity from the number of prescriptions he will be called on to make up. When Dr. Parpalaid comes back three months later, to collect the first installment on his selling price to Dr. Knock, he is astounded to find the local hotel turned into an efficient and overflowing hospital and to learn from regular treatment. He is about to collect his money and leave, when Knock convinces even him that he is not well enough to travel and suggests that he should stay for a medical examination. British actor Leonard Rossiter and John Le Mesurier head the cast. The Cast: Madme Parpalaid -- Mavis Villiers Dr. Knock -- Leonard Rossiter Dr. Parpalaid -- John Le Mseurier NET Playhouse - "Doctor Knock" -- is a National Educational Television presentation, produced for the British Broadcasting Corporation by Cedric Messina and directed by Herbert Wise. Designer: Eileen Diss NET Producer: Kay Chessid

From NET microfiche: "Dublin One" was adapted by the Irish playwright Hugh Leonard from James Joyce's collection of short stories "Dubliners." Joyce himself said: "My intention was to write a chapter of the moral history of my country, and I choose Dublin for the scene because the city seems to me the center of paralysis. I have tried to present it to the indifferent public under four of its aspects ... childhood, adolescence, maturity and public life." These aspects are represented in the five stories from the collection which Hugh Leonard has adapted for "Dublin One." Childhood is represented in "An Encounter"; adolescence by "Two Gallants"; maturity by "Counterparts"; and public life by both "Ivy Day in the Committee room" and "Grace." These five stories are then arranged into three parts. Part One shows the Dubliner in his private and social life and consists of "Counterparts" and "An Encounter." Part Two, showing his religious attitudes, consists of "Grace." The Dubliner as a political animal is seen in Part Three, which is made up of "Ivy Day in the Committee Room" and "The Two Gallants." James Joyce's father -- never at a loss for retort, fearfully sentimental and acid by turns, drinking, singing, talking, reckless, and talented -- is echoed through all his son's books, and in "Dubliners" appears in many disguises. In the "Dublin One" adaptation, he is presented as the pivotal character in each part under the name of Mr. Tom Kernan: Mr. Kernan at work and drinking with his friends is Part One; Mr. Kernan and his friends deciding to make a retreat together and confess their sins is Part Two; Mr. Kernan canvassing an election in Part Three. The celebrated Irish theater company The Abbey Players perform "Dublin One."
a Telefis Eireann production ; presented by National Educational Television ; producer, director, Louis Lentin ; adapted by Hugh Leonard.

"El Teatro Campesino: b/w (ca. 1968; Net Playhouse) political film advocating the rights of migrant workers in the San Joaquin Valley--good POV shots through the San Joaquin Valley; farmhouses and abandoned farmlands and Mexican ghettos w/ poor living conditions--Chicano plays guitar w/ political rights theme--interview w/ producer of political drama team El Teatro Campesino, which performs skits to bring awareness of the plight of migrant workers and promotes social change--good shots of migrant workers on strike; Cesar Chavez shown encouraging strike and using bullhorn to speak to migrant workers--skit performed in Santa Barbara; stereotypes docile Mexicans (racism)--mural, "La Raza"--good shots of unemployed Mexican men idly on street corners--Chicano recites poem w/ civil rights theme--interview w/ man who praises Pancho Villa 2000' Z-1A "--Summary from J. Fred MacDonald and Associates TV inventory. From NET microfiche, file E: In September 1965 the then three-year-old National Farmworkers Association headed by Cesar Chaves (now known as the United Farmworkers Organization Committee) voted in Delano, California, to strike California vineyards. The union, composed chiefly of Mexican-Americans, continues the walkout today against grape growers who have not agreed to a contract. Since 1967 the strike has been aided by a partially successful consumer boycott of California-grown table grapes. Two months after the strike began, Luis Valdez, a former laborer who worked his way through San Jose State College and then joined the San Francisco Mime Troupe, returned to his native Delano and founded El Teatro Campesino, which means the theater of the farmworkers. The original purpose of El Teatro were the boosting of strikers' morale and the conversion or non-strikers to "la causa" - the cause. Gradually, however, the group has broadened its objectives, using its satire to attack the full range of problems faced by Mexican-Americans. Its avowed purpose now is to reawaken a sense of cultural identity among Mexican-Americans and help lift them from what Chavez has termed "society's cellar." In 1967 El Teatro went on a national fundraising tour and performed, among other places, at the Newport Folk Festival and in New York City's "East Village" and gave a special performance in Washington, DC before the Senate Subcommittee on Migratory Labor. This NET program traces the evolution of El Teatro. There are interviews with Valdez, who directs the company and writes much of the material. At times he talks on camera about "Chicano" (Mexican-American) culture and at other times his voice is heard over other visual material. The group performs: musical numbers; an "acto", which is a satirical skit; a puppet show using historical Aztec figures; an excerpt from a full length play which it performs at universities in the Southwest; and an ancient ceremony of rebirth performed at dawn in Mendocino Cemetery in Fresno, California. NET Playhouse #190 -- "El Teatro Campesino" is a National Educational Television production, with portions produced by station KQED, San Francisco and other portions produced through the facilities of station KCET, Los Angeles. Producer: Janet Sternberg and Victoria Hochberg Executive producer: Jac Venza Description #2 "El Teatro Campesino" -- the theater of the farmworkers -- came into being during a period of trial, La Huelga -- the strike of the migrant farmworkers against the California grape growers. But soon, those who wrote the songs and the plays for the theater realized they were dealing with something that went beyond the immediate concerns of the strike. "We knew we had to separate from 'la huelga' ... so that we could develop as a unit, an organization of our own," recalled Luis Valdez, director, poet and playwright of "El Teatro." The story of the development of a theater of social conscience is told on NET Playhouse. Teatro tells its own story eloquently, through the "actos" or short, satirical skits, through songs, such as "The Ballad of Richard Campos," a Mexican-American killed in Vietnam. Did he die for a country which will do nothing for him, the ballad asks. The comedy in teatro is a comedy close to tears -- it expresses the realities faced by the Spanish-speaking American, Valdez explained. There is also pageantry and a proud past as portrayed in a puppet play about Montezuma. Sometimes in the "actos" the humor is broad satire. The program includes, for example, "Los Venidos" or "Used Mexican Lot" in which an "Anglo" woman comes to a "used-car lot" where the description of each model matches stereotypes of Mexican-Americans. Valdez related how in the earliest days of El Teatro, actos were performed on the picket line; it was guerilla theater in that the performances were reactions to the grape growers -- ridiculing their audience which was composed of the very men they opposed. Over the five years of its existence, El Teatro has become more complex in terms of costumes, makeup, rehearsal and, above all, subject matter. Speaking of the theater's development in comparison with the earliest days, Luis Valdez said, "You can't just come into someplace, set up in two minutes, wham, do it and then get out of there before the police arrive. And so we've had to sacrifice, at points, a certain immediacy." The new Teatro productions characterize the history of "la raze" -- the Spanish-American race -- as well as problems of discrimination and exploitation. The program includes songs of identity, such as "I Am A Chicano (Mexican-American)" and political songs such as "Che." In 1966 El Teatro Campesino began performing across the nation. They even gave a performance before the Senate Subcommittee on Migratory Labor. San Francisco Chronicle columnist Ralph J. Gleason called the troupe's performance "vital, earthy and vividly alive theater ... an impressive demonstration of what can be done when men work together in a common cause."

National Educational Television ; with portions produced by station KQED, San Francisco and other portions produced through the facilities of station KCET, Los Angeles ; executive producer, Jac Venza ; producers, Janet Sternbert, Victoria Hochberg.
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche: During the dark ages following the death of classical civilization, there was no drama, as such, in Europe. But by the 14th and early 15th centuries, mainly as a kind of elaboration or by-product of church ritual, there began a revival of play performance. The most popular form of medieval play was the mystery or miracle play, based exclusively on biblical themes. Toward the end of the 15th century, however, a new dramatic form began to take hold of the popular imagination, the morality play, an allegorical piece in which personified virtues and vices grappled for the soul of man. The most famous of these medieval morality plays, "Everyman," has no known author, although it is believed to have been the "Elckerlijk," written by a Dutch monk, Peter Dorlandus, sometime in the 15th century and to have been translated almost immediately into English. The play was originally performed, sometimes as part of the Lent observances, on a farm wagon parked outside the village church. The actors all wore the normal dress of the period and locality , and the characters, all symbolic, were related to familiar, everyday figures. In keeping with tradition, this television production is in modern dress and the characters have equally modern guises ("Five-Wits" is a card shark; "Discretion" is a lawyer; and "Death" variously a beggar, barman and manservant). The language, however, is still that of the 15th century. In a series of simple scenes, the play tells the story of man's journey through life with Death attending him at every step, and how he triumphs over evil, weakness, and vanity to attain salvation when Death finally claims him. When God calls Death and orders him to take Everyman, Everyman seeks someone to accompany him to the grave. He turns to Fellowship, Kindred, Cousin, and Goods but is rejected by each. At first it appears that Knowledge, Confession, Discretion, Strength, Beauty or Five-Wits may agree to go with him, but all forsake him on the last journey. Only Good-Deeds is prepared to enter the grave with Everyman and help him to salvation. Alan Dobie, as Everyman, heads the large cast which includes: Fellowship -- Edward de Souza Kindred -- Geoffrey Chater Knowledge -- Wendy Gifford Strength -- Jack Watson Beauty -- Sue Lloyd Good-Deeds -- Ann Bell Voice of God -- Jack May Voice of the Angel -- Annie Ross NET Playhouse -- "Everyman" is a National Educational Television presentation, produced for the British Broadcasting Corporation by Peter Luke, directed by Michael Hayes. Music by Tubby Hayes, photo montage by Bernard Lodge, and design by Eileen Diss. Producer for NET: Kay Chessid.
See contents tab for content descriptions of segments.

From NET microfiche: NET Playhouse #139: Everyman (Filler information) The filler material for NET Playhouse #139 ("Everyman") is a black and white documentary, running a little over 22 minutes, entitled "Young Filmmakers," by David Hoffman. Hoffman is himself a young filmmaker and is co-director of the feature film "King, Murray," which just completed a run at The Little Carnegie theatre in mid-Manhattan. The film revolves around a conference, given by Fordham University in February 1968, on the new generation of filmmakers, ranging in age from a five-year-old girl to highly articulate teenagers. (One of the teenagers is interviewed on camera and excerpts shown from his modernized version of "Macbeth.") The film also contains an experiment which grew out of the conference involving two groups of teenagers, one group from a Philadelphia private school and one group from New York's Lower East Side. Each group was given the same equipment, the same amount of film, the same time and the same location (the interior of a film production company) and asked to make a one-minute film. The results of this experiment are included together with a "bull session" between the two groups. What emerged from the private school group was a rather formal, abstract statement starting form the idea of the function of a film production company, shots of editing, equipment, etc. The group from the Lower East Side made a plotted melodrama, a kind of gangster film, responding, they said, to the big office, the kind of office none of them thought they would ever have. The premise of the film is to show that this generation of kids is being given a new tool -- the movies -- with which to perceive their world, and to illustrate how they are making free and articulate statements with that tool.
Amram Nowak Associates ; NET presents ; by David Hoffman.
National Educational Television and Radio Center
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche, file F: Program Description: The five film dramas, shown under the title "Five Tomorrows," focus on man's anxiety about his immediate future. Kurt Vonnegut, Jr., noted author whose books ("Slaughterhouse Five," "Cat's Cradle," "Player Piano") are largely concerned with this subject, is interviewed by producer Jac Venza. Locale: the high flux beam reactor in Brookhaven (NY) National Laboratories, center for advanced experimental research. Vonnegut talks about his concerns and about the films. The world wide, pervasive nature of this anxiety is reflected by the film product of the countries contributing these dramas: Italy, France, Australia and Belgium. Each film deals with a different aspect of the same theme: the shape of our daily lives should the present trend toward conformity, violence and mindless motion continue unabated; should the manufacture of atomic arms remain unchecked; and should the vigilante concept of "law and order" be carried to its illogical extreme. The Films: The Scream," by Camillo Bazzoni and Vittorio Storaro (Italy) Dramatizes the hero's struggle to maintain his identity in a super-state which demands total suppression of the individual for the sake of society. English soundtrack. "The Other Side," by Herman Wuyts (Belgium) If 'law and order" is carried to its ultimate point does man's desire for freedom still remain? The viewer is free to interpret this powerful visual metaphor of an entire town reduced to complete sub-mission by an unseen, overwhelming force. "Siljo" by Gregory Marton (Australia) Produced for Australian television by Grahame Jennings. A drama of two men, trapped in an underground missile silo, who have the power to flick a switch and destroy the world. They discover that the weapon they have created now controls them. "The Fall of Varema," by Camillo Bazzoni and Vittorio Storaro (Italy) With poetry and quiet terror, "The Fall of Varema" projects a city of the future where violence and irrational hate have finally destroyed its life. English soundtrack. "Faster, Faster!" by Peter Foldes (France) A witty, fast-paced animation depicts speed without direction, motion for motion's sake. English dialogue.
NET ; executive producer-director, Jac Venza ; producer, Perry Miller Adato ; associte producer, Janet Sternburg.
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche: Program Description: "Flowering Cherry" was Robert Bolt's first major success. It is a delicate study of Jim Cherry, an insignificant insurance clerk who has long dreamed of owning an apple orchard and living from the land. The dream, which has sustained him and his family through many hardships, becomes obsessive, making him deceitful. And Cherry, it seems, has already lost his job, is drinking hard cider, and even resorts to stealing from his wife's pure when his money is gone. Only at this point does his family realize that his dream is a hoax and that he is a failure as well as a faker. Attempting to salvage some self-respect, he tries to show his determination by bending a bar of iron that simply won't bend, and dies of a heart attack. The play is a study of just how destructive a man's dream can be. About the Author: Robert Bolt was born August 15, 1924, in Sale, Manchester, England. He served in the Royal Air Force and the Royal West African Frontier Force before attending Manchester University. He received his BA in history in 1960. "Flowering Cherry" was Bolt's first produced play in the United States. It appeared on Broadway in 1959 and was followed by "A Man for All Seasons" in 1961. "Flowering Cherry" won the playwright the 1957 London Evening Standard Award. The New York Drama Critics' Circle Award was given to him in 1962 for "A Man for All Seasons." Bolt also received an Academy Award nomination in 1962 for his screen play of the motion picture "Lawrence of Arabia." The Cast: Jim Cherry - Bernard Lee Isobel Cherry - Margaret Tyzack David Bowman - John Paul Tom Cherry - Simon Ward Gilbert Grass - Redmond Phillips NET Playhouse - "Flowering Cherry" is a National Educational Television presentation, produced by Bernard Hepton for the British Broadcasting Corporation. It was directed by Joan Craft. Suggested Newspaper Listing; NET Playhouse - "Flowering Cherry" - a drama by Robert Bolt ("A Man for All Seasons") about an insignificant insurance clerk whose dream of owning an apple orchard and living from the land becomes obsessive and eventually destroys him and his entire family.

From NET microfiche, file F: Program Description: A group of modern-day playwrights, including Israel Horovtiz and Megan Terry, express their feelings about pollution in a collection of brief plays collectively titled "Foul!" In addition, Playhouse #215 presents "Actor's Choice: Lewis Carroll," featuring Gwen Verdon and Cyril Ritchard reading selections from Carroll's works. The 10 plays comprising "Foul!", none of which is more than several minutes long, are in order of performance: "Take a Deep Breathe" by Jean-Claude van Itallie, "Tsk" by Anne Burr, "Kissing Sweet" by John Guare, "The Most Beautiful Fish" by Ronald Ribman, "One More Little Drinkie" by Megan Terry, "Stoop" by Lanford Wilson, "Promontory Point Revisited" by Arthur Kopit, "Puck! Puck! Puck!" by Leonard Melfi, "Paly for Trees" by Israel Horovitz, and "Last Gasps" by Terrence McNally. Best known among the cast are Charlotte Rae, Sam Waterston, Frances Sternhagen and Barbara Cason. "Actor's Choice: Lewis Carroll" is from a series of half-hour programs titled "Actor's Choice" and produced by Channel 13 in New York. Hal Holbrook is host for the series. In the Lewis Carroll program Ritchard and Miss Verdon read "The Hunting of the Snark," "Jabberwocky" and selection from "Alice in Wonderland." From NET microfiche, file G: General Description of Series: Described by its author as "a parable play,' "Glory! Hallelujah!" explores, in highly theatrical terms, the nature of war and its effect on people. The central characters are members of a Louisiana family named Bowden, who are deeply involved in the conflict between the states. The American Conservatory Theatre (ACT) assembled a cast of nearly 50 actors to appear in the 27 scenes of the play, providing a Kaleidoscopic contrast between the grim realities of the battlefields with the romantic view of the war held by those back home. The world premiere of "Glory! Hallelujah!" took place on May 28, 1969 at the Geary Theatre in San Francisco, the home base of the ACT. The play was staged by Edwin Sherin, director of the Broadway hit "The Great White Hope," winner of the New York Drama Critics Circle Award, the Pulitzer Prize, and three Tony Awards. Mr. Sherin is currently at work directing his first film, "Valdez is Coming," a big-budget Western Starring Burt Lancaster. The Play in Brief: The entire action of Act I takes place on July 21, 1861, the date of the first battle of Bull Run, shifting back and forth between scenes at the battlefield in Virginia, at a home in rural Louisiana on the Mississippi River, and at the Bowden home in New Orleans. Soldiers at the front prepare for war. Among them are Sli (Sligo) Bowden, scion of the New Orleans family, and his comrades-at-arms, Chewey, Thibaut, Preacher, Hugo and Allen. At home in New Orleans, his sister Nantalle is being wooed by George Blanchard, soon to become a surgeon in the Confederate Army. Sli fires a shot at a buzzard and brings fire on the entire Southern contingent from the nearby northern troops. Two years later. The action during this act shifts between the Bowden home and the battlefields at Cashtown and Gettysburg in Pennsylvania, George Blanchard has gone to war. Young Clayton Bowden runs off to war, even though he is under age, leaving behind his younger brother, Salt, his sister, Nantelle, his mother, Margaret, and his uncle, Will. At Gettysburg, preacher loses a leg. Clayton never gets to join the Army but dies on the way. Nearby, unknown to either of them, his brother Sli, also lies wounded. George, who now heads the field hospital at Gettysburg, amputates Sli's leg (off camera). During the confederate retreat from Gettysburg, George is compelled to evacuate his hospital. Four months later: New Orleans. George and Nantelle have just been married. Sli is home for the wedding. There is talk that some Southerners are selling cotton to the north. Sli returns to the front, although he is an amputee and is killed a year later at Petersburg. His comrades continue fighting. Nantelle has a baby. George must evacuate his field hospital, once more, for retreat. During the evacuation, he is killed in a struggle with a northern soldier. Salt discovers that his mother's suitor, Mr. Fredericks, has been delivering cotton to the enemy and murders him. News of the South's surrender comes to the soldiers in the field. General Lee bids farewell to his defeated troops and back in New Orleans, what is left of the Bowden family joins in welcoming home the shattered remnants of the Confederate Army. About the Author: A.M. Barlow was born in New Mexico, spent the first eight years of their life in Stockton, CA, and then moved with her family to Shreveport, Louisiana. She is a graduate of Louisiana State University where she studied both drama and journalism. Working as an actress before turning to playwriting, Ms. Barlow appeared in such Broadway productions as "Festival" with Betty Field, and 'Top man," with Ralph meeker. In addition to "Glory! Hallelujah!" she has written seventeen one-act plays, several of which have been performed in New York and in theaters throughout the nation. Her first full-length play, "Cold Christmas," was presented by the late Margo Jones at the Dallas Theatre Center, at the university ofDelaware and later on nationwide television. Ms. Barlow and her husband, advertising executive S. Brooke White, with their two daughters, live in New York City. She is a winner of the John Golden Playwriting Award and is a member of the new Dramatists Committee. About the Company: The American Conservatory Theatre (ACT) was founded in 1965 in Pittsburgh, by William Ball, the General Director of the Company. From the beginning it has emphasized a training program in connection with performance which has resulted in one of the finest ensemble repertory groups in the country. The company settled in San Francisco in 1966and has since become a San Francisco institution which, in three years, has made a great cultural and economic impact in the entire Bay Area. The diversity and range of the ACT repertory requires artistic versatility and skill in many different performance styles. In addition, the large repertory provides unparalleled opportunity for actors in the company to make practical use of the methods and techniques learned in each performer's daily training sessions. Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET Playhouse-"Glory! Hallelujah!" - from San Francisco, the American Conservatory Theatre production of a new Civil Was drama contrasting the grim realities of the battlefield with the romantic view of the war held by those back home.

NET, KQED ; producer, Jac Venza ; associate producer, David Loxton ; adapted for the television camera by director Sterling Johnson with Eugene Barcone, associate stage director ; writer, A. M. Barlow.

HAMILE (Ghana Film Industry Corp., Ghana, 1964). Dir., Terry Bishop. Adapt., Joe de Graft. With Kofi Middleton-Mends (Hamile/Hamlet), Joe Akonor (King/Claudius), Frances Sey (Queen/Gertrude), Ernest Abbeyquaye (Ibrahim/Polonius), Mary Yirenkyi (Habiba/Ophelia), Kofi Yirenkyi (Laitu/Laertes), Martin Owusu (Karim/Horatio). Film version of the stage production by the Institute of African Studies at the University of Ghana. Set in the town of Tongo, among the Frafra people of northern Ghana, the adaptation retains the English text, but conforms the props, costumes, geographical locations, and certain gestures and action to the local setting. Cast was selected from students completing a 3-year course in drama and theater studies. Not released theatrically in the U.S. From NET microfiche, file H: Program Description: Shakespeare's fame as a great dramatist has to some extent been due to the universality of the themes and situations in his plays. As a result, his play "Hamlet" lent itself readily to adaptation by Joe de Graft, a Ghanaian playwright of the Institution of African Studies at the University of Ghana. The play, retitled "Hamile," is set in Tongo, a Frafra town in the Upper Region of Ghana. The text remains unaltered except in passages where a word is decidedly archaic or its meaning has become obscured with time. On the other hand, as would be expected, items of props, costumes, and certain gestures and actions do conform to the adaptation. The swordplay between Hamlet (Hamile) and Laertes (Laitu) for instance becomes a typical Ghanaian wrestling match. The cast was selected from the students of the Institute of African Studies who were completing a three-year diploma course of drama and theatre studies, and the performance of "Hamile" formed part of their practical work on stage production. After many years of teaching at Mfantispim School, Cape Coast, Joe de Graft was invited to lecture in English at the Kumasi University of Science and Technology. He later became director of the Ghana Drama Studio in Accra before taking up an appointment as a research fellow of the Institute of African Studies and a lecturer in the School of Music and Drama at that Institute. The State Film Industry Corporation of Ghana made this feature film of the production and presented it for the Commonwealth Arts Festival in Britain in 1965. Dialogue is in English. Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET Playhouse - "Hamile": The story of Hamlet, retold in Ghanaian dress, a feature film of the stage production as originally performed by the Institute of African Studies at the University of Ghana. NET Playhouse - "Hamile" is an NET presentation, produced by the State Film Industry Corporation of Ghana. Director: Terry Bishop Director of photography: R. O. Fenuku Executive Director: Sam Aryeetey

From NET microfiche, file H: Program description: National Educational Television and WNDT, New York's Channel 13, are joining forces to produce a new play, "Home," written especially for television by Megan Terry, author of "Viet Rock." Commissioned by WNDT's New York Television Theater, the play will premiere on NET Playhouse, Friday, January 19, 1968 at 8:30 pm on WNDT/Channel 13. Production on the 90-minute color special begins this week at WNDT's facilities in New York. Miss Terry's "Viet Rock," a controversial musical play, was presented by the Yale University School of Drama two seasons ago and subsequently produced for off-Broadway in New York. She was one of five playwrights the New York Television Theater commissioned this year to write original works for presentation on this, its third season. The idea of a co-producing project had long been under discussion between NET and WNDT programming heads and when the script for Miss Terry's play was ready, it appeared to be the ideal vehicle for such a venture. This is the first time National Educational Television has entered into co-production with any of its affiliates. It is also the first commissioned play to be presented by NET Playhouse. "Home" is a comment on the effects of overpopulation on the world. The action takes place in the future, in a world whose entire surface is covered with a honeycomb of small rooms where people must live out their lives in the same room into which they were born. The entire action takes place in one of these rooms and among the nine people who inhabit it. Cast: Marcia - Jenn Ben-Yakov Sharon - Jacque Lynn Colton Ruth - Irene Dailey Roy - Roger Davis Bert - Dennis Patrick George - Edward Winter Intruder - Clement Fowler Program Credits: "Home" is a co-production between National Educational Television and WNDT. Executive producer: Jac Venza Directed by Glenn Jordan Co-produced by Jac Venza and Glenn Jordan Associate producer: Virginia Gray Costumes designed by Frank Thompson Sets designed by Ed Wittstein
Tapes sent to deep storage since content has been preserved from another higher-quality source. J. Sidley 4/10/2014

These are three plays by young playwrights whose work has been performed at La Mama Experimental Theater Club. La Mama ETC has been one of Broadway's busiest centers for experimentation in theater, and Ellen Stewart, its founder, has presented a different program each week. During its five-year existence, many of the leading new "underground" playwrights in the United States have had their first confrontation with an audience at La Mama. The three works selected for "NET Playhouse" are among Ellen Stewart's most popular. They have been presented in other theaters off-off-Broadway, as well as in other cities and at festivals throughout the country. Each of the three playwrights has also had his plays performed abroad by the now well-known La Mama acting company. The first play on the program is "Pavane" by Jean-Claude van Itallie, which was taped in the lobby of the First National City Bank on Park Avenue. Echoing the formal movements of the old dance from which the play gets its name, the characters move through a set ritual of human responses in our society. The second play on the program is "Fourteen Hundred Thousand" by Sam Shepard, set in an apartment, involving a young couple, presents of one of them, and a friend. The third is "The Recluse" by Paul Foster. It was taped in an abandoned hospital on Welfare Island in New York's East River, and deals with a demented old lady. The Cast: Pavane: 1st Interviewer - Cynthia Harris 2nd Interviewer - Alvin Epstein 3rd Interviewer - Shellie Feldman 4th Interviewer - James Coco 1st Applicant - Joe Chaiken 2nd Applicant - Ruth White 3rd Applicant - Paul Dooley 4th Applicant - Sudie Bond Fourteen Hundred Thousand: Ed - Kevin O'Connor Tom - Joe Chaiken Donna - Joyce Aaron Mom - Ruth White Pop - Albert M. Ottenheimer The Recluse: The Recluse - Ruth White Jezebel - Bryarly Lee LA MAMA PLAYWRIGHTS is a National Educational Television production. Producer: Brice Howard Staged by: Tom O'Horgan Directed for television by: Don Hallock Information on Filler Material: After years on hand-to-mouth, and loft-to-basement existence, on April 2, 1969, Caf La Mama moved into its own permanent home, a four-floor building in new York's East Village. Although the building is still being renovated, and only two of the four floors are in use so far, the opening-night festivities were a great joy and triumph to this plucky troupe, and especially to its founder and guiding genius, Ellen Stewart. Along with the nation's press, NET covered the opening, interviewed Miss Stewart and playwrights Jean-Claude van Itallie, and Paul Foster among others. Some of what the NET cameras recorded that night is used as the filler in a new introduction to this "La Mama Playwrights" program.
National Educational Television ; producer, Brice Howard ; director, Don Hallock.
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche: The Theatre de la Mandragore was founded by the well-known mime Wolfram Mehring and the actress and mime Grillon, who is also a designer of masks and dcor. Their Paris based company has provided Mehring with the opportunity to illustrate his personal concept of the theatre by synthesizing spoken drama and the ancient art of mime. From its repertoire is a filmed performance of "La Marmite" - in French with English subtitles. "La Marmite" (in Latin "Aulularia" and in English "The Pot of Gold") was written 2,000 years ago by Plautus, the Latin poet who inspired Moliere. Coordinating Plautus' text with masks and mime, the play follows the fortunes of a disagreeable old miser, Euclion, who lives in fear of losing his treasured pot of gold. Euclion's daughter is in love with the young Lyconides, but the greedy old miser gives her hand in marriage to a wealthy old neighbor, Megadore. To prepare for their wedding feast, Megadore provides food and sends his cooks to the "poor" Euclion. Their presence so worries the miser that he takes out his pot of gold for safer hiding. But he is observed by a slave of his daughter's lover, who manages to steal the pot of gold, give it to his master, Lyconides, who returns it to the miser and in exchange gets to marry his daughter. Costumes, masks and scenery by Grillon.
A National Educational Television presentation ; producer, Marie-Joseph Dubergey ; adapted and directed by Wolfram Mehring ; writer, Plautus.
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche: This program, featuring Pat Hingle and a host of New York-based players, marks the world premiere of 14 lighthearted but penetrating vignettes by William Saroyan performed under the title "Making Money and 13 Other Very Short Plays." This is the first of four consecutive NET playhouse presentations produced by the New York Television Theatre at Channel 13. In "Making Money and 13 Other Very Short Plays" Saroyan uses his characteristically gentle humor to sketch human frailties. The pace is rapid for none of these sketches in more than five minutes long. With Pat Hingle in the cast are Sudie Bond, Lou Gilbert, Kevin O'Connor, Edgar Stehli, Jean Stapleton, Lenny Baker, Tony Lo Bianco, Marcia Jean Kurtz, and others, including a number of talented child performers. The plays, in order of their performances, are: "God, Jesus, Man an Women," "The Haircut," "The Reader and the Writer," "A Life is a Life," "The Conversationalists," "Making Money," "The Writers of Great Novels, Plays, Poetry and Philosophy," "Teeth," "The New Drama," "Medical Care," "Talk," "The Waiting Room," "Courtesy is Possible at the Corcers Even," an "Waiting for the N Car." NET Playhouse #213 - "Making Money and 13 Other Very Short Plays" and "A Slight Accident," is a production of the New York Television Theatre. Produced and directed by Glenn Jordan. Associate producer: Virginia Gray. NET Playhouse executive producer: Jac Venza.

From NET microfiche: This program, featuring Pat Hingle and a host of New York-based players, marks the world premiere of 14 lighthearted but penetrating vignettes by William Saroyan performed under the title "Making Money and 13 Other Very Short Plays." James Saunders' one-act play "A Slight Accident," with Carrie Nye, accompanies the Saroyan works. This is the first of four consecutive NET playhouse presentations produced by the New York Television Theatre at Channel 13. In "Making Money and 13 Other Very Short Plays" Saroyan uses his characteristically gentle humor to sketch human frailties. The pace is rapid for none of these sketches in more than five minutes long. With Pat Hingle in the cast are Sudie Bond, Lou Gilbert, Kevin O'Connor, Edgar Stehli, Jean Stapleton, Lenny Baker, Tony Lo Bianco, Marcia Jean Kurtz, and others, including a number of talented child performers. The plays, in order of their performances, are: "God, Jesus, Man an Women," "The Haircut," "The Reader and the Writer," "A Life is a Life," "The Conversationalists," "Making Money," "The Writers of Great Novels, Plays, Poetry and Philosophy," "Teeth," "The New Drama," "Medical Care," "Talk," "The Waiting Room," "Courtesy is Possible at the Corcers Even," an "Waiting for the N Car." Saunders' play is about "slight accident" that violently upsets the rigid lives of two young married couples who live in the same apartment building. With Carrie Nye are James Ray, Carole Shirley, Tom Martin, Judith McGilligan, George Taylor, and Angela Wood. From NET microfiche, file N: Sir Arthur Wing Pinero died in 1934 at the age of 79, one of the English theater's most brilliant craftsmen and dramatic innovators, and the author of some forty plays, most of them unqualified "hits" in their time. He began his professional life at nineteen as an actor at the Theatre Royal in Edinburgh and a few years later went to London to play at the historic Globe Theatre where his first piece, "Two Hundred a Year," was performed. For five years he was a member of Henry Irving's famous company at the Lyceum. It was for Irving that he wrote his first short plays, eventually giving up acting for playwriting. A leading exponent of the "well-made play," Pinero won his early reputation by writing successful farces and comedies. But his real place in theatrical history rests mainly on his later, serious dramas, in which he fused his craftsman's skill with telling social problems of the day. Among these later plays the best known is "The Second Mrs. Tanqueray," but many of them, including "Trelawney of the Wells," (which was done just last season by England's National Theatre Company) and "Mid-Channel," continue to be revived successfully. Pinero wrote "Mid-Channel" in 1909, the year he was knighted. It was first produced in September of that year at the St. James Theatre in London. The play gets its title form a shoal in the English Channel, midway between Folkestone and Boulogne and a danger-spot for shipping. The subject of the drama, however, is not the sea. It is the story of a childless marriage, shipwrecked after fourteen years. Theodore, a middle-aged husband, and his young wife, Zoe, are torn relentlessly apart by their very desire to remain together. After their early, blissful years, selfishness finally succeeds in foundering their marriage, and the embittered husband causes the death of the young wife he loves so much. Co-starring in this production are Bernard Archard as Theodore Blundell and Pauline Jameson as Zoe, his wife. NET PLAYHOUSE: "Mid-Channel" is a National Educational Television presentation, produced by Granada Television, London. Producer for NET is Kay Chessid.
Granada Television, London ; National Educational Television presentation ; [by Arthur Wing Pinero] ; producer for NET, Kay Chessid.
ITV play of the week. The Edwardians. [No. 2], Mid-channel.

From NET microfiche: "Misalliance" caused more annoyance than any other play by George Bernard Shaw. The frivolity outraged his friends and the general audience, though the rough and tumble in the play is there to give relief from its more serious elements. The main theme of the play is love, interwoven with the relationships of husbands and wives and parents and children, with some interesting observations on the rapidity with which advanced ideas become out of date. The play is a comedy with elements of farce, but being typically Shaw, "Misalliance" goes beyond the merely comic, Shaw's plays do not end in a joke but in a vision of life which provokes more than mirth. The plot concerns a group gathered at the country home of the Tarleton's. Mr. Tarleton is a wealthy underwear manufacturer who feels that he receives no respect from his son and daughter. He believes in practical education, but finds that his children are impractical and that his daughter laughs at his ideas. Tarleton suspects that even his wife in her own placid way is in league against him. Visiting the Tarleton's are Lord Summerhays, a diplomat, and his son Bentley - a spoiled weakling who takes calculated advantage of his puniness to get his own way and throws tantrums on the floor when all else fails. Bentley is engaged to Tarleton's daughter, Hypatia. Suddenly into the midst of this group and their interrelationships, crashes a Polish aviatrix, Lina Szczepanowska. In her stimulating presence, the audience begins to discover why Mr. Tarleton and Lord Summerhays receive so little respect from their children: they deserve very little. Both the elderly men try to makes love to Lina, followed by the younger men, equally without success. To add to the confusion, the son of a woman with whom Mr. Tarleton once had a mild affair tries to shoot him to avenge "wrongs" done to his mother. Between Lina's unsettling presence and the threat of assassination, all the members of the group come to some understanding of their situation. Tarleton's son comes to his father's defense. The would-be assassin is cajoled into submission by Mrs. Tarleton; the daughter breaks her engagement and catches instead the occupant of the crashed plane, proving she has some sense about men after all; and Lina decides to carry of the spoiled Bentley to make a real man of him. The play was produced on location in Woodside, California, and performed by the American Conservatory Theater.
NET playhouse. Misalliance. Act III. [producer's original].

The plot concerns a group gathered at the country home of the Tarleton's. Mr. Tarleton is a wealthy underwear manufacturer who feels that he receives no respect from his son and daughter. He believes in practical education, but finds that his children are impractical and that his daughter laughs at his ideas. Tarleton suspects that even his wife in her own placid way is in league against him. Visiting the Tarleton's are Lord Summerhays, a diplomat, and his son Bentley - a spoiled weakling who takes calculated advantage of his puniness to get his own way and throws tantrums on the floor when all else fails. Bentley is engaged to Tarleton's daughter, Hypatia. Suddenly into the midst of this group and their interrelationships, crashes a Polish aviatrix, Lina Szczepanowska. In her stimulating presence, the audience begins to discover why Mr. Tarleton and Lord Summerhays receive so little respect from their children: they deserve very little. Both the elderly men try to makes love to Lina, followed by the younger men, equally without success. To add to the confusion, the son of a woman with whom Mr. Tarleton once had a mild affair tries to shoot him to avenge "wrongs" done to his mother. Between Lina's unsettling presence and the threat of assassination, all the members of the group come to some understanding of their situation. Tarleton's son comes to his father's defense. The would-be assassin is cajoled into submission by Mrs. Tarleton; the daughter breaks her engagement and catches instead the occupant of the crashed plane, proving she has some sense about men after all; and Lina decides to carry of the spoiled Bentley to make a real man of him. The play was produced on location in Woodside, California, and performed by the American Conservatory Theater.

a National Educational Television production, produced through the facilities of KQED, San Francisco ; NET executive producer, Brice Howard ; staged by Michael Howard ; directed for television by Gerald Marans.

From NET microfiche: Academy Award-winner Maggie Smith ("The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie") and British actor Robert Stephens star with England's National Theatre Company in this TV adaptation of Franco Zeffirelli's production of "Much Ado About Nothing." (TV version directed by Alan Cooke.) This is the third program in the NET Playhouse series of world-renowned theater companies in some f their most memorable productions (following the Stratford National Theatre of Canada's "Three Musketeers" and the Royal Shakespeare Company's "Marat/Sade"). The Zeffirelli production of "Much Ado" stirred a great deal of excitement and controversy in 1965 among English critics and theater-goers because of its free-swinging highly theatrical interpretation of Shakespeare's original. "Zeffirelli wanted the audience to go out after the play feeling that they had, had a holiday," said Stephens, who plays the leading male role and also assisted Cooke in directing the TV adaptation. Cederic Messina produced the television version for the British Broadcasting Corporation. "Much Ado About Nothing' is Shakespeare's farce about a quarrelsome young couple, Beatrice (Maggie Smith) and Benedick (Stephens), who, though they manage to exchange some of English literature's wittiest and most caustic dialogue, nonetheless are capable of calling a truce to their "merry war" long enough to come together. They unite when a villainous plot against Beatrice's young cousin, Hero, threatens the young girl's happiness and honor. One of the outstanding performances amid the general buffoonery is Frank Finlay's portrayal of the hapless Constable Dogberry. The Cast: Beatrice - Maggie Smith Benedick - Robert Stephens Hero - Caroline John Dogberry - Frank Finlay Don Pedro - Derek Jacobi Don John - Ronald Pickup Claudio - Michael Byrne Antonio - Harry Lomax Leonato - Gerald James Margaret - Carolyn Jones Conrad - Edward Petherbridge Borachio - David Hargreaves Friar Francis - Paul Curran Verges - Graham Crowden Ursula - Wynne Clark NET Playhouse #230 and #231 - "Much Ado About Nothing" is a presentation of NET Division, Educational Broadcasting Corporation, produced by the British Broadcasting Corporation. Producer: Cedric Messina. Director: Alan Cooke. Music by Nino Rota. Dances arranged by Romayne Girgorova. NET Playhouse executive producer: Jac Venza.

From NET microfiche, file N: Program Description: This BBC production about Australian prisoners in a Japanese war camp in Singapore is adapted from the novel "Naked Island," written by Russell Braddon, who was himself a war prisoner in the same camp. The story centers on the tensions that develop among five men who are using makeshift radio equipment to monitor the news secretly each night and pass it on to the other prisoners. Getting the news is considered vital to their survival because the men figure they must know when the war is about to end so they can be prepared to attempt a mass breakout. Otherwise, they will be executed by the guards when the Japanese government surrenders. The Cast: Jacko - Ray Barrett Robbie - Barry Lowe Magpie - James Bolam FILLER: En Face NET Playhouse #193 - "Naked Island" is a National Educational Television presentation, produced by the British Broadcasting Corporation. Producer: Bernard Hepton. Director: John Gorrie. NET Playhouse executive producer: Jac Venza.

From NET microfiche: Irene Dailey stars in Lanford Wilson's "The Sand Castle," a moody story about a widow and her children and the delicate personal relationships that threaten to shatter their family life. Its companion piece is Australian authoress Pat Flower's "The Tape Recorder," starring Inga Swenson and Michael Tolan. In the Wilson play, Miss Dailey portrays Irene Reynolds, who lives with her daughter and two sons in a ramshackle house in a sparsely populated area on the California coast. Irene, an author, teaches writing at a nearby college. Irene is in here middle-aged years; she is anxious about raising her young son Kenny, while coping with the problems created by her restive daughter, Joan, who is weary of isolated rural life, and her older son, Owen, an extremely sensitive boy who shows ominous signs of mental instability. The play depicts one tense evening in their lives. In the roles of the children are Don Warfield (Owen); Jean Fowler (Joan) and Barry Symonds (Kenny). William Andrews plays Irene's boyfriend; Lee Lawson is Joan's girlfriend; and George Cackman plays a friend of the family. In "The Tape Recorder" Inga Swenson plays an author's young secretary who endures an evening of terror when she arrives at her boss' empty apartment to take dictation from a tape. Michael Tolan portrays her boss.

From NET microfiche: Program Description: This play by the English author James Saunders was suggested by a theme from the book "A Hermit Disclosed" by Raleigh Trevelyan. Adapted for the television medium, the play takes us into the television studio without a formal set. Like the book, it is concerned, in the words of Mr. Trevelyan, with "the exploration and acceptance of man's inescapable solitude." The play develop its theme through a study of the famous hermit of Great Canfield, Essex, England, who shut himself away for 36 years. The play opens with a pseudo-improvisation. Three actors - presented simply as actors who will portray characters in the hermit's story - await the arrival of two other performers and chat brightly and humorously about all sorts of things, including bad jokes, the audience, and the matter of repeating the same speeches night after night. The two other actors, including the one who is to play the hermit, arrive and they are presumably ready for business. This last actor to arrive has removed his beard. But he puts it back on again and later when he finds he is unable to remove it once more, the viewer realizes that the actors have already launched into the story. In this transition from acting to living, the characters remain as before, performing in a barren studio with lines, ladders, and other television equipment exposed, and they continue their energetic cavorting and joking - sometimes to each other, sometimes to the audience. Their purpose is to investigate the meaning of existence, the anatomy of isolation, and the immediate environment (the studio, itself) as a microcosm. The play offers no solutions but presents in a witty, poetic way the riddle which each inquiring mind attempts to solve for itself. As Richard Watts Jr. of the New York Post says: "Mr. Saunders has two major problems of striking interest on his hands. What is the relationship to his fellow men of the alienated Jimmy Mason, who cut himself off from the world and lived in solitude for half a century, but left a diary behind? And how is the playwright to bring into dramatic focus his examination of a story and implications of the secret creature who has determined to sever all connections with human society and remain in brooding loneliness? It is the second question that provides the author with his most effective ideas." James Saunders, born in London in 1925, is a chemistry teacher by profession who took up dramatic writing as a spare time hobby while studying for a science degree at Southampton. His play "The Ark" was given a West End production and a subsequent grant to him by the Arts Council enabled him to pursue a full time career as a playwright. Originally produced at the Questers Theatre, Ealing, "Next Time I'll Sing to You" was subsequently given in London and on the Continent. His other plays include "Poor Fred," "A Scent of Flowers," and "Neighbors." The play is performed by members of The Theatre Group of UCLA, which has since become a resident company of the Los Angeles Music Center, under the name of the Center Theatre Group. The Cast: Meff - Nigel McKeand Dust - Patrick Horgan Lizzie - Carol Booth Rudge - James B. Douglas Hermit - Robert Casper NEXT TIME I'LL SING TO YOU is a production of KCET, Los Angeles. It was produced by Gregory Heimer with assistance from Malcolm Black, Theatre Group stage director.

From NET microfiche, file O: "Ofoeti," (oh-FOE-tee) the first television play written by poet and Bucknell University, Lewisburg, PA, professor John Wheatcroft, was one of six winners in the Alcoa - WQED TV Playwrights' Contest. The play, now having its national premiere in "NET Playhouse," is described by its author as a "modern folklore tale." Produced under the director of William Francisco, a director of the American Conservatory Theatre, with members of the American Conservatory Theatre in the cast, the play concerns a boy's search for a troll. An Edgewood (Pittsburg) Junior High School student, John O. Tragard, makes his acting debut as the youth - spellbound by imaginative myths and confused by the adult world around him. He searches for the troll - under and over bridges, over rooftops, hilltops, and highways, up the aisles of libraries and down steps and alleyways - finds the troll, and loses it again, as the play explores the boy's indecision between a make believe world and the true world. OFOETI is a National Educational Television presentation, produced by WQED, Pittsburgh, under the direction of William Francisco. Producer: Jay Rayvid. Associate producer and television director: Sam Silberman. Music written by Joe Negri and played by Mr. Negri and The Silhouettes. From NET microfiche, file N: A drama about a boy spellbound by imaginative myths and confused by the adult world around him, is described by its author, John Wheatcroft, as "a modern folklore tale." Cast of this prize-winning play includes members of the American Conservatory Theatre, under the direction of William Francisco. John Tragard stars as the boy.
