From NET microfiche, file O: "Olive Latimer's Husband," a kind of Edwardian murder mystery, is the tragic story of a beautiful woman of a passionate nature who hastens the death of her rich husband so that she will be free to marry his best friend. British actor Barbara Jefford stars as the tragic Olive Latimer. Robin Bailey plays opposite her as her lover. Sir Charles Weyburn and the suspicious doctor, James Morpeth is play by Sebastian Shaw. The British dramatist, Rudolph Besier, was born in Java in 1878 of Dutch descent, and died in England in 1942. He is best remembered for his play "The Barretts of Wimpole Street," but "Olive Latimer's Husband," which starred the famous English actress, Mrs. Patrick Campbell, when it was first produced in 1909, was a great success. Besier also collaborated with HG Wells on a stage version of Wells' novel "Kipps" (on which the current musical "Half a Sixpence" is also based), and with Hugh Walpole on "Robin's Father."
Granada TV, London ; a National Educational Television presentation ; producer for NET, Kay Chessid.

From NET microfiche: General Description of Series: Eli Wallach and Jo Van Fleet star in Clifford Odets' portrait of a decaying middle class in America during the 1930s, "Paradise Lost." Produced and directed by Glenn Jordan (winner of two local Emmy Awards this year), this production is presented in two parts and conclude the series, "NET Playhouse on the Thirties." Literary critic Harold Clurman, who staged the original production of "Paradise Lost" and who once referred to the work as "one of the six or seven really important contemporary American plays," describes the kind of people it depicts as dwelling "between the upper and lower classes, fooled by the one, ignorant of the other, removed from the plain facts of both - nave, puzzled, frustrated." The story centers on the family of Leo and Clara Gordon and a seris of misfortunes that culminates in the loss of their house. Leo is a sympathetic, idealistic man, somewhat vacillating and slow to take action. Clara is tougher and more realistic than her husband, less tolerant of people who wrong them, and yet a sympathetic character in her own way. They have three children: Ben, an older son who marries at the start of the play; Julie, the younger son, who is afflicted with encephalitis: and Pearl, an introverted girl devoted chiefly to her piano studies. Also living in the Gordon house are Leo's hard-nosed business partner, Sam Katz, and his wife, Bertha (they own a small handbag manufacturing concern), and Gus Michaels, father of Ben's bride, Libby. Despite the tragedies of the play, including Ben's violent death and the progression of Julie's disease, the mood is not one of unbroken gloom and depression. In Clurman's words: "The love which the author feels for all his characters his deep physical attachment to the middle class paradise, gives the play a subtle but constant exaltation." Supporting the stars is a fine cast which includes the attractive young Broadway and television performer Bernadette Peters ("Dames at Sea"); Fred Gwynne, known for his roles in "Car 54, Where Are You?" and "The Munsters," and winner of a New York City Emmy Award under Glenn Jordan's direction (New York Television Theater - "The Lessons"); and Czechoslovakian-born Broadway actor George Voskovec.
a production of the NET Division, Educational Broadcasting Corporation ; NET Playhouse executive producer, Jac Venza ; producer-director, Glenn Jordan ; play by Clifford Odets.
Special of the week. Paradise lost.

Carrier container names two segments as filler content, Kinosuke's puppets and Play Bach. From NET microfiche: Program Description: "Past Intruding" is a Japanese film (with English subtitles). Set against the exciting background of the Olympic Games in Japan, it concerns a psychiatrist who has now in his past a horrible war experience of which he has no recall. In the course of treating a patient, his own memory of the dreadful past is restored - and he finds that his wife who was involved in his buried experience has known the truth all the time. As the film ends they are confronted with the problem of reconstructing their relationship in the face of the now acknowledged past. The Cast: Nobuku (Muroi's wife) - Yoko Minamida Prof. Baba - Nobuo Nakamura Fukutomi (a patient) - Jan Hamamura PAST INTRUDING is a National Educational Television presentation. Written by Koichi Otsu. Music by Naozumi Yamamoto.
National Educational Television and Radio Center
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche, file R: Many people know the story of Rembrandt's life only from Carl Zuckmayer's movie made in 1936, in which Charles Laughton played Rembrandt; Gertrude Lawrence, Geertje; and Elisa Lanchestrer Hendrickje. This new production, adapted essentially from Zuckmayer's original script, is deigned to update that film script and to refocus the treatment of dramatic events in the light of subsequent historical research. It is intended to serve as a companion piece to the NET Festival documentary "In Search of Rembrandt," commemorating the 300th anniversary of Rembrandt's death in 1669. This program about Rembrandt gives us a picture of the artist's life beginning at the height of his success in 1642, when he was happily married to Saskia and was eagerly sought by the wealthy and famous for portrait commissions. After Saksia's death that year, a change comes over Rembrandt. He seems to lose interest in painting the fashionable citizens of Amsterdam on commission. However, at the urging by his townsmen he consents to paint a group portrait of the officers of the Civic Guard. At the unveiling of the painting in the Town Hall, the burghers are outraged at Rembrandt's unconventional portrayal of the group. (This is the painting later known as "The Night Watch.") They ridicule the artist, who replies that their fine clothes are more beautiful than they themselves. Ten years later. Rembrandt has been painting beggars in the marketplace, and also his friends and neighbors, the Jews. No one will buy these pictures. Rembrandt's finances are at a low ebb and he is given and order of restraint by the Court of Bankruptcy. He, his 12-year-old son Titus, and the shrewish, tenacious housekeeper Geertje, are threatened with eviction. Rembrandt returns briefly to his father's home in Leyden. But the life of a simple miller is by now too far removed. In 1653, Rembrandt is back in Amsterdam. For the first time, he meets Hendrickje, the young country girl whom Geertje has hired as a maid, and by the next year, they are living together as common-law man and wife. The jealous Geertje has a summons issued on charges of concubinage, and Hendrickje is called to appear before court. She chooses to stay with Rembrandt, and is excommunicated. There is a forced sale of Rembrandt's goods, furniture and paintings, and he signs everything over to the court to hold until his debts are clear. Hendrickje becomes an "art dealer," as a device to save Rembrandt's paintings and drawings from the bailiff. But soon, Hendrickje dies. Titus has already died, shortly after his own marriage, and Rembrandt is alone again. He continues painting, living among the humble people of Amsterdam. In 1669, on October 4, his old friend, the Jew, Menassah, finds him dead. The cast: Rembrandt - Richard Johnson Geertje - Jill Bennett Hendrickje - Terri Stevens Beggar Saul - Wilfred Brambell Doctor Manasseh - Cyril Shaps Banning Cocq - Derek Aylward Ludwick, Rembrandt's agent - David Cargill Heertsbeeke, Rembrandt's lawyer - Richard Bebb Fabrizius, a pupil - Howard Rawlinson Flinck, a pupil - Drew Wood Bol, the new pupil - Timothy Peters Titus - Robin Stewart Titus, as a boy - Paul Griffiths Rembrandt's father - John Baskcomb Rembrandt's brother - Terry Duggan Jan Six - Brian Oulton Townspeople, shopkeepers, and officers Designer: Tony Abbot

From NET microfiche: Program Description: Like Shakespeare's, Rembrandt's name is a household word. Similarly, the myths surrounding his life are myriad, but the authenticated facts are incredibly few. We know where Rembrandt lived and with whom. Beyond that, romantic conjecture is rife. Only seven of his letters exist, and these are essentially about business matters. What we do have is a body of works of measureless richness and variety. Last May an NET crew went to Amsterdam and spent three days and nights in pursuit of the elusive truth about Rembrandt the man as well as Rembrandt the painter. The cameras traveled the length of Amsterdam - Rembrandt's house, the Rijksmuseum, Jodenbree Straat in the Jewish quarter - and visited The Hague and Rembrandt's school in Leyden. The resulting film is a kind of portrait of Rembrandt, himself, seen through his own work and through film footage of contemporary Holland, scenes which are echoes of the settings of the Rembrandt paintings and drawings. For instance, when the young Rembrandt moved permanently from Leyden to Amsterdam (during his whole life he never left Holland, claiming that he was too busy to travel), his first commission was "The Anatomy Lesson of Dr. Tulp," now hanging in The Hague. The portrait made such a great impression in the city that the young artist was inundated with commissions for portraits. Although we are not aware of his actual feelings, it appears that painting commissioned portraits did not satisfy his curiosity sufficiently, for he continued to turn out countless genre and historical and Biblical paintings for which there was little market. Again, why did he spend some fifteen years painting landscapes after the death of his wife, Saskia? Could it have been simply because he liked to walk in the countryside? Or was it because of some deeper, emotional need? All in all, the film embraces some sixteen categories of Rembrandt's work, close to 700 pictures (from 100 museums) and includes drawings which have never before been seen on film. And, of course, the film shows the famous paintings: "The Night Watch," "Self Portrait" (indeed there are forty self-portraits), "The Anatomy Lesson," etc. Many of his most renowned paintings were filmed where they hang in the museums themselves. Throughout the film, the pictures are intercut with live footage of today's Amsterdam and Holland: i.e., the Dutch skies and low, fast-moving clouds as the camera sees them, as Rembrandt saw them, and as other painters, Vermeer, for instance, saw them. The program was produced with the cooperation of the National Gallery of Art in Washington, DC. Advisor for the film was Dr. Seymour Slive, chairman of the department of the fine arts at Harvard University and director of the Fogg Art Museum in Boston. Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET Festival - "In the Search of Rembrandt" - For this documentary, filmed on location in Holland, some 700 pictures from 100 museums were photographed in pursuit of the elusive truth about Rembrandt's personality. NET Festival - "In the Search of Rembrandt" is a National Educational Television production, produced in cooperation with the National Gallery of Art, Washington, Dc, under a grant from Cordelia S. May. Produced and written by RF Siemanowski Associate producer: Marina Wandzilak Film editor: Don Feldstein Narrator: James Mason Composer: George Kleinsinger Executive producer: Lane Slate
NET ; in cooperation with the National Gallery of Art ; executive producer, Lane Slate ; producer-writer, RF Siemonowski ; associate producer, Marina Wandzilak.

From NET microfiche: Rosmersholm is the name of the gloomy, ancestral home of John Rosmer, a cultured and distinguished man who was once a clergyman but is now an idealistic "freethinker." The play "Rosmersholm" is about the strange, intense bond between Rosmer and his housekeeper, Rebecca West, who came to the house when Rosmer's wife, Beata, was ill and who stayed on after her death. The nature of this relationship is the core of the play and reflects Ibsen's concern with social problems as well as his growing interest in psychological conflict. Written in 1886, "Rosmersholm" was in fact the last of Ibsen's dramas based on social themes and the first of his profound psychological studies. It has been called his starkest tragedy. When the play opens, John Rosmer has turned away from his past conservative ways and, encouraged by the passionately-involved, socially-militant Rebecca, is ready to take on active part in the liberal and progressive movements of his day. In this he is fiercely opposed by his dead wife's brother, Dr. Kroll, who is also suspicious of Rosmer's relationship with Rebecca. Although Rosmer, in his innocent high-mindedness, had regarded Rebecca only as an idealistic friend, through Kroll's suspicious probing and accusations, he gradually becomes aware of her driving will and of her desperate love for him. When Kroll reveals the ugly truth about Rebecca's past - that she had had an illicit relation with her guardian without knowing that he was her father - it becomes clear to Rosmer that Rebecca had been the moving force behind his wife's suicide. In his distraction at the collapse of his ideals, Rosmer can find no way to reassert the value of life and the proof of love but by asking Rebecca to follow Beata into suicide. When she accepts this, he joins her and together they leap from the same foot-bridge into the millrace that had earlier borne away his wife. The cast of "Rosmersholm" is led by Britain's distinguished actress Dame Peggy Ashcroft as Rebecca and Knut Wiggert, one of the leading players of the Norwegian National Theatre as Rosmer. The new English translation was made by Ann Jellicoe, one of England's brilliant young playwrights and the author of the stage and screen success "The Knack." The Cast: Rebecca West - Dame Peggy Ashcroft John Rosmer - Knut Wigert Kroll - Mark Dignam Mrs. Helseth - Angela Baddeley Mortensgaard - Morris Perry Ulric Brendel - John Laurie NET Playhouse - "Rosmersholm" is a National Educational Television presentation, produced for the British Broadcasting Corporation by Cedric Messina, directed by Michael Barry. It was designed by Jack Notman. Producer for NET is kay Chessid. FILLER INFORMATION: Mamako's Baggage

From NET microfiche, file S: When young Maurice arrives as a postulant at a Trappist monastery, the Prior explains to him that henceforth he must keep a vow of silence and turn his back on the world. But Maurice finds that even monks have weaknesses. For example, there is Brother Michael, once a jockey, who, with a secret supply of racing papers, studies form and tries to pick the winners. His friend Brother Arnold, loves a glass of Guinness. Then they discover their respective vices, they begin to drink and gamble together, their stakes being paid in the only currency available in the monastery, Hail Marys. One day Maurice discovers them and before long he, too, is tempted - to play his harmonica which he smuggled in on the day he arrived. When suddenly, for all Maurice decides that the monastic life is not for him, and he returns to the world that he has missed so much. His two "companions-in-crime" forswear the happy company they have been keeping and return to their strict vows: the strictest of which they have never broken, that of silence. For all their worldly communications have been conducted in pantomime. All the exteriors for "Silent Song," which won the 1967 Prix Italia, were shot on location in Ireland. PLEASE NOTE: This is a drama without dialogue. Notes on the playwrights: Hugh Leonard is a young writer for British theater, films and television. For the past few years, he has had a play produced each year at the Dublin Festival, two of which have been seen in the United States, "The Poker Session" and "Stephen D." Frank O'Connor, who died last year at the age of 64, was perhaps the best known Irish short-story writer of this century. He was also a journalist, playwright and author of books on travel and the arts in addition to being a distinguished Irish scholar and translator of poetry. The Cast: Maurice - Tony Selby Prior - Leo McCabe Brother Arnold - Milo O'Shea Brother Michael - Jack MacGowan NET Playhouse - "Silent Song" - is a National Educational Television presentation produced by Peter Luke for the British Broadcasting Corporation. It was written by Hugh Leonard and Frank O'Connor for television. Director: Charles Jarrott; Designer: John Cooper; music by Norman Kay. Producer for NET: Kay Chessid.

From NET microfiche, file S: This CBC drama written by Paul St. Pierre tells the story of a Cowichan Indian nun sent to teach at a newly built school for Indian children, located in the Yukon Territory. She is Sister Veronica (pronounced Sister "Balonika" by the children) and her familiarity with Indian ways and modern teaching methods brings her closer to her charge than her two colleagues, the Sister Superior Mary Agnes and Sister Grace. In comparison to Sister Superior, who is tied to the rigidity of traditional teaching methods who guides her own and the children lives by the bell - ten minutes to wash, ten minutes to play, -- Sister "Balonika" is less disciplined and a bit more frivolous. She loves to sing with the children and yield to her "sporting blood" by going fishing with "Telegraph Jim," one of the older girls. Eventually her "frivolity" leads her to neglect one of her duties - checking Sitkum Memaloos, an emotionally disturbed child, for matches. While Sister Belonika goes fishing, Sitkum sets fire to the school, resulting in the death of one child and injury of others. (PLEASE NOTE: A boy's very badly burned arm is seen on film several times.) Overcome by guilt, Sister Belonika goes away. But she is later ordered back to the school by the Sister Provincial who does not want Sister Belonika's guilt to prevent her from teaching the children and from offering them her laughter and song. Cast: Sister Belonika - Vi Powlan Sister Superior - Christine Greene Sister Grace - Susan Ringwood Forty Horse Johnson - Merv Campone Mother Provincial - Diane Wassman Bishop - Robert Clothier Priest - Terence Kelly Seahorse Johnson - Ivor Harries RCMP Corporal - Lloyd Barry Nans - Ramona McBean - Joy Metcalfe - Betty Tufts FILLER INFORMATION: A ten minute, black and white Polish short film, entitled "Little Sorrows," will accompany NET Playhouse: "Sister Belonika." This study of a child's attempt to befriend various barnyard animals presents a sensuous picture of innocence striving to cope with the world at large.

From NET microfiche, file S: Mildred Dunnock and Alvin Epstein star in this Yale Repertory Theatre Company production of five fairy tales by the Brothers Grimm staged for adult by Paul Sills, co-founder and director of the original Second City troupe in Chicago. "Story Theatre" represents a concept developed by Sills - the use of imaginative staging and improvised gestures and mime to give theatrical life to traditional fables, while retaining the original narrative and dialogue of those fables. The titles in this production are: "The Golden Goose," "The Blue Light," "The Clever Gretel," "The Goose Girl," and "The Bremen Town Musicians." From NET microfiche, file T: Program Description: "Story Theatre" is not just one production, but a theatrical conception. Conceived and originally produced by director Paul Sills in his theater in Chicago, the idea of Story Theatre is an outgrowth of the games theater technique developed by his mother, Viola Spolin, the famous children's educator. Mr. Sills was co-founder and director of the original Second City Troupe, which was also based essentially on the improvisation concept embodied in the games theater technique. Mike Nichols, Elaine May, Alan Arkin, are among the many illustrious "Second City" alumnae. Robert Brustein, dean of the Yale School of Drama, described the Story Theatre idea thus: "It takes narrative fables and stories - either from the Brothers Grimm, Hans Christian Andersen, or medieval legend - and provides them with a life in the theatre through the actor's transforming imagination. Like the Oriental theatre, and the works modeled on this theatre by Yeats and Brecht, 'Story Theatre' is designed to be a pure and naive art. Gestures, mime, and transformation accompany spoken narrative in order to establish the circumstances of each fable; and by discouraging satirical or modernist interpretation of the techniques manages to uncover the dream like, universal reality of the great traditional tales." The dialogue and narrative of each story is as it appears in the original story. Nothing in re-written. It is the way it is staged which brings the story to theatrical life. The five stories chosen for this television version of Yale School of Drama Repertory Theatre production of "Story Theatre" are all taken from Grimm's Fairy Tales: "The Golden Goose;" "The Blue Light;" "The Clever Gretel;" "The Goose Girl;" and "The Bremen Town Musicians." The cast of this production includes professionals, two were in residence at Yale at that time (as was Mr. Sills), graduate (new professionals) and students. Musicians for all five stories: David Ackroyd, Jim Brick, David Clennon, Barbara Damashek. Brief background on the Yale School of Drama Repertory Theatre: A new training program was instituted at the venerable Yale School of Drama three years ago with the advent of its present clean, former theater critic Robert Brustein. The School has always been a conservatory for theater training in the heart of a great university, but Dean Brustein made some basic changes, most visible of which was the founding of the Repertory Theatre. The Yale Repertory Theatre is meant to serve as a model of theater activity, as a training ground for advanced student work, and as a channel for employment upon graduation. In effect, the training at the School of Drama is oriented toward its theater company. The co-company provides constant opportunities for observation and participation, as well as a continual flow of teachers from the professional world. The emphasis of company work is on the production of new plays and fresh interpretations of the classics. By thus establishing close connections between professional and student activity, the Yale School of Drama hopes to build a fund of theatrical talent upon which it can draw freely in future years, functioning as a home base for those who wish to work immediately with the company upon graduation, or to return at some future date after acquiring additional experience elsewhere. Filler material: During a break in the production, the actors discussed their feelings and thoughts about "Story Theatre," about Paul Sills and about the Yale Repertory Theatre Company. This taped discussion is broken into two segments - the first 3 minutes long and the second 5 minutes long - which will be used as filler between stories 3 and 4, and stories 4 and 5. NET Playhouse - "Theatre America: Story Theatre" is a National Educational Television production. Produced by Jac Venza. Associate producer: David Loxton. It was directed for television by Christopher Sarson. Original stage production conceived and directed by Paul Sills, directed in association with Larry Arrick. Costumes: Carl Michna Michell. Music by Barbara Damashek. Produced through the facilities of WGBH, Boston. The program was made possible in part by grants from the National Endowment for the Arts and the Rockefeller Foundation.

National Educational Television ; produced through the facilities of WGBH, Boston ; producer, Jac Venza ; associate producer, David Loxton ; directed for television by Christopher Sarson ; original stage production conceived and directed by Paul Sils.

Mike Nichols, Elaine May, Alan Arkin, are among the many illustrious "Second City" alumni. Robert Bruestein, dean of the Yale School of Drama, describes the Story Theatre idea thus: "It takes narrative fables and stories - either from the Brothers Grimm, Hans Christian Andersen, or medieval legend - and provides them with a life in the theatre through the actor's transforming imagination. Like the Oriental theatre, and the works modeled on this theatre by Yeats and Brecht, 'Story Theatre' is designed to be a pure and nave art. Gestures, mime, and transformation accompany spoken narrative in order to establish the circumstances of each fable; and by discouraging satirical or modernist interpretation, the technique manages to uncover the dreamlike, universal reality of the great traditional tales." The dialogue and narrative of each story are as they appear in the original story. Nothing has been re-written. The way that it is staged brings each story to theatrical life. From NET microfiche, file T: Filler Information for NET Playhouse #165 - Theatre America: Story Theatre The filler for "Story Theatre" will be a 20-minute, black-and-white film entitled "Mamako's Baggage." This is the first film by Alexander Neel, a British filmmaker and features Mamako Yoneyama, the Japanese mime who is at present serving as mime coach at the American Conservatory Theatre in San Francisco. "Mamako's Baggage" blends music, dance, drama, photographic imagery and architecture, without dialogue. The action of the film is backed by a musical score by Howard Blake which calls for only three instruments: flute, harp and English horn. Mamako's Baggage" is an allegorical piece of luggage representing the burden of conscience and man's struggle to free himself from psychological and emotional restrictions. In a series of vignettes - in front of a row of homes, in a church, at an office plaza, a baggage locker, at an airport - the young girl wrestles with her burden. When she manages to rid herself of it, she feels lost. Reunited with it, she accepts it with grateful resignation, for although she cannot exist without it, it prohibits her from enjoying the world around her. In the final sequence of the film, the young girl finally surrenders her "baggage" in death, a death perhaps of the spirit crushed by the mental burden.

From NET microfiche, T: General Description of Series: "Talking to a Stranger" is the overall title of four plays which tell the story of a weekend in the lives of the four members of the Stephens family, each from a different angle adding to the understanding of the whole situation. The telling is not consecutive. Each play concentrates on the same incidents but from the particular viewpoint of one of the four members of the family. The Stephens mother and father live alone now since their son Alan and daughter Terry have left home. Alan is married but pays regular visits to his parents and is a dutiful and "respectable" member of the family. Terry is "the wild one." She married a Negro man, more or less as a protest against her parents' respectability. Since her marriage broke up, she has been searching for some meaning to her life. Through her defiant promiscuity, she has become pregnant. On this particular weekend, Terry decides to go home to visit her parents in spite of the strains and tensions she knows such a visit imposes on all of them. Alan has been offered a job in Australia. He has chosen this weekend to discuss it with his parents who would probably never see him and his family again if he accepts the job. The tensions of the weekend lead to the suicide of the mother, apparently almost without reason. Talking to a Stranger #1: Anytime You're Ready, I'll Sparkle This is Terry's play with all her restless energy and exasperated honesty. Terry Stephens wakes up one Sunday morning to a day of difficult decisions. She decides to break off her affair with a married man and she is going to make one of her infrequent visits to her parents in the suburbs. She arrives there to be greeted by the unchanging rituals of an elderly couple whose life has run out of meaning. Terry is not the sort of person to let sleeping parents lie, and with an honesty which is almost ruthless, she forces them to face their own self-deceits. Her brother Alan also comes for Sunday tea, and it is Alan who gets from her the admission that she is pregnant. A blazing row springs up over tea about a new job which Alan has been offered in Australia. Terry's mother says she wishes never to see her again. Terry goes to a club in search of her former husband. She finds him and they spend their last time together, for she had to know that she could do without him. She intends to live without needing anyone and to bring up her child unaided. The telephone keeps ringing the whole night long, but in her intense self-preoccupation and self-pity, Terry refuses to answer it.
NET playhouse. Talking to a stranger. Anytime you're ready, I'll sparkle.

From NET microfiche, T: General Description of Series: "Talking to a Stranger" is the overall title of four plays which tell the story of a weekend in the lives of the four members of the Stephens family, each from a different angle adding to the understanding of the whole situation. The telling is not consecutive. Each play concentrates on the same incidents but from the particular viewpoint of one of the four members of the family. The Stephens mother and father live alone now since their son Alan and daughter Terry have left home. Alan is married but pays regular visits to his parents and is a dutiful and "respectable" member of the family. Terry is "the wild one." She married a Negro man, more or less as a protest against her parents' respectability. Since her marriage broke up, she has been searching for some meaning to her life. Through her defiant promiscuity, she has become pregnant. On this particular weekend, Terry decides to go home to visit her parents in spite of the strains and tensions she knows such a visit imposes on all of them. Alan has been offered a job in Australia. He has chosen this weekend to discuss it with his parents who would probably never see him and his family again if he accepts the job. The tensions of the weekend lead to the suicide of the mother, apparently almost without reason. Talking to a Stranger #3: Gladly My Cross-Eyed Bear This third play in the Hopkins' quartet covers the day following the mother's suicide. As the day proceeds, the father and the two children go over the events that led up to the suicide and hammer out a way of going on living afterwards. In a sense, this is the key play to all four in that the characters are forced to explain to each other. It ends with the father leaving his house for the last time to go and live with Alan.

From NET microfiche, T: General Description of Series: "Talking to a Stranger" is the overall title of four plays which tell the story of a weekend in the lives of the four members of the Stephens family, each from a different angle adding to the understanding of the whole situation. The telling is not consecutive. Each play concentrates on the same incidents but from the particular viewpoint of one of the four members of the family. The Stephens mother and father live alone now since their son Alan and daughter Terry have left home. Alan is married but pays regular visits to his parents and is a dutiful and "respectable" member of the family. Terry is "the wild one." She married a Negro man, more or less as a protest against her parents' respectability. Since her marriage broke up, she has been searching for some meaning to her life. Through her defiant promiscuity, she has become pregnant. On this particular weekend, Terry decides to go home to visit her parents in spite of the strains and tensions she knows such a visit imposes on all of them. Alan has been offered a job in Australia. He has chosen this weekend to discuss it with his parents who would probably never see him and his family again if he accepts the job. The tensions of the weekend lead to the suicide of the mother, apparently almost without reason. Talking to a Stranger #2: No Skill or Special Knowledge Required The second play is really about the father. It begins with the great tea-time row from the previous play. But we see through the father's eyes how it reminds him of the other rows and difficulties involving himself, his wife, and his daughter Terry, whom he loves more than any other member of the family. He now lives almost entirely in his memories: of a picnic when Terry was only four; football matches when Alan was a schoolboy; and one unwelcome memory of the first night of his marriage, when he was selfish and thoughtless with his new bride. This latter memory afflicts him in all his dealings with Terry and her emotional affairs. He prefers to remember her as the little girl for whom he was able to take away pain and fright. In any real crisis, he slides into the past, and on this critical day, he keeps trying to find an old photograph of Alan's football team. While he searches, the row between Terry and her mother reaches its climax, and over supper, after their children have gone, the two parents accuse each other of their failures. The mother realizes that the father blames everything on her and that all her self-sacrifice and efforts have gone for nothing. When he finally tells her that he hates her because she is younger and will be alive when he is dead, there is nothing left for her. Late that night, when the father comes downstairs from another daydream, while searching for the photograph, he finds all the crockery in the kitchen smashed and his wife dead in its midst.
NET playhouse. Talking to a stranger. No skill or special knowledge required.

She married a Negro man, more or less as a protest against her parents' respectability. Since her marriage broke up, she has been searching for some meaning to her life. Through her defiant promiscuity, she has become pregnant. On this particular weekend, Terry decides to go home to visit her parents in spite of the strains and tensions she knows such a visit imposes on all of them. Alan has been offered a job in Australia. He has chosen this weekend to discuss it with his parents who would probably never see him and his family again if he accepts the job. The tensions of the weekend lead to the suicide of the mother, apparently almost without reason. Talking to a Stranger #4: The Innocent Must Suffer In the fourth play of the quartet we go again over the events of the first play on the Sunday when the son and daughter come to visit their parents, but this time we see it from the viewpoint of the mother and we follow her through the day from the mental black-out which she experiences to the final annihilation of any purpose to her lite. We see that her death is the only logical ending for her. The Cast: Mother - Margery Mason Mrs. Hayter - Maryann Turner Father - Maurice Denham Terry - Judi Dench Alan - Michael Bryant

From NET microfiche, file T: Program Description: Tennessee Williams' "Ten Blocks on the Camino Real," is the original one-act play on which he subsequently based his full-length play "Camino Real." Mr. Williams has called this play an allegory made up of "the continually dissolving and transforming images of a dream outside of time in a place of no specific locality," evoking the atmosphere of such places as Tangier, New Orleans, Casablanca, or Vera Cruz. Into this setting, the Camino Real with its dusty plaza and dried-up fountain wanders a young American, Kilroy, the prizefighter with a weak heart, who encounters an extraordinary group of Williams' characters - drawn from life, literature and half-legend - who are trapped in the Camino Real, trying to ignore the inevitable visit of the Street Cleaners: Death's uniformed emissaries. Williams says of the play "... the construction of another world, a separate existence its people are mostly archetypes of certain basic attitudes and qualities with those mutations that would occur if they had continued along the road to this hypothetical terminal point." The Cast (in alphabetical order): Baron de Charlus and Instructor - Tom Aldredge Officer - Michael Baseleon Mr. Gutman - Albert Dekker Jacques Casanova - Hurd Hatfield The Gypsy - Lotte Lenya Esmeralda - Janet Margolin La Madrecita - Patricia Neway Marguerite Gautier - Carrie Nye Kilroy - Martin Sheen Guitar Player - Jackie Washington NET Playhouse - "Ten Blocks on the Camino Real" is a National Educational Television production. Executive producer: Jac Venza. Producer by Jac Venza and Jack Landau. Directed by Mr. Landau. Associate Producer: Virginia gray. Set Designer: Ed Wittstein. Choreographer: Donald McKayle. Music: Howard Roberts. Costumes: Noel Taylor. From NET microfiche, file T: "The 39th Witness," a play written especially for television by TV producer and writer Sol Stember, is the fictionalized account of a murder, drawn from the real-life homicide of Kitty Genovese in Queens in New York City. The play was one of six original television dramas chosen for production by NET Pittsburgh affiliate WQED in a contest for new television scripts underwritten by the Aluminum Company of America at WQED two years ago. It was the Genovese case, with its shocking suggestion about the failure of responsibility in contemporary society, which moved author Sol Stember to write his drama. The action of the play takes place in a middle-class neighborhood in a large city, at night. A smartly-tailored young woman is chased by a young man in sneakers armed with a switchblade, and stabbed by him over and over again. Thirty-nine of her neighbors see her murder and hear her screams but only one takes action to bring in the police. And that man, who finally lifts the telephone to call the police, refuses to give his name. Although the actual murder took only eight minutes, it is stretched in "flash-ins" through the entire run of the teleplay, which is primarily concerned with the 39 witnesses to the murder. The drama was filmed entirely on location in Pittsburgh, with the camera crews, working in the middle of the night, carrying out their assignments in small crowded rooms, parking lots and city intersections. The role of the murdered girl is played by Pittsburgh actress Christi Hatcher. Her murderer is played by James Sweenie (who is also associate producer for the television production). The two principal detectives are portrayed by Broadway actors Alan North (as Lt. Brent) and Tom Lignon (as Detective Goldman). NET Playhouse - "The 39th Witness" is a National Educational Television presentation, produced for WQED, Pittsburgh, by Jay Rayvid, and directed by William Francisco. NET producer: Kay Chessid.

From NET microfiche: Program Description: This program is part of NET's "Theatre America" series, dealing with the regional, resident, repertory, and experimental theaters across the United States. The project, which includes documentary as well as dramatic programs, was made possible in part by grants from the National Endowment for the Arts and the Rockefeller Foundation. "New Theatre for Now" is the over-all title for a program of five dramatic pieces: four dramatic vignettes varying in length from three to ten minutes each; and one two-character, one-act play. The name of each play (in order of its appearance on the program), its cast and a brief description of each follows: "Wandering" by Lanford Wilson The life story of a man is told in three minutes. Like a series of still photographs, in tiny flashes, this play catches the telling relationships of a whole life. Cast: Boy - Philip Proctor She - Gail Kobe He - Ed Flanders "Chuck" by Jack Larson A young magazine salesman knocks on a door. He offers bargain rates, but the housewife is angry because she has had to leave the "real" world of her television set. It is only when the plight of the young man becomes more exciting and interesting than her television program (he has an epileptic fit) does she react to him. Cast: Mrs. Wilcox - Marge Champion Chuck - Joseph Reale "Thoughts on the Instant of Greeting a Friend on the Street" by Jean-Claude van Itallie and Sharon Thie Two friends meet on the street. They say "Hello, how are you?" and "Fine, thank you." But what is going on in their minds during their ten-second exchange reveals the sort of thing that could be behind every automatic response. Cast: Man - Anthony Zerbe Woman - Beverlee McKinsey "Camera Obscura" by Robert Patrick The time is the not-too-distant future. Two young people are brought together by a computer. But the mechanized world is between them. They can communicate only by means of microphones and cameras. Cast: She - Marge Champion He - Ed Flanders "The Golden Fleece" by A. R. Gurney, Jr. Betty and Bill, a modern suburban couple -- very average young people - have two most extraordinary friends: Jason and Medea. Through their friends, they have gotten to see, and even touch, the Golden Fleece. At the time of the play, Betty and Bill have decided to share the Fleece and to introduce Jason and Medea. They have chosen a TV studio in order to display the Golden Fleece. But Jason and Medea are delayed. And, as the audience waits for news of when -- or if - they will show up, they begin to hear reports from their host and hostess of the off-stage tragedy which is even now taking place. Cast: Bill - Tim O'Connor Betty - Helen Westcott The Center Theatre Group at the Mark Taper Forum Although productions, under the aegis of the Center Theatre Group, are also given at the large (2,100 seat) Ahmanson Theatre in the Los Angeles Music Center, for the purposes of the "New Theatre for Now" program, NET has focused on the Center Theatre Group's theatrical activities in the Mark Taper Forum, a smaller (750 seat), arena-shaped playhouse in the Music Center cultural complex. These activities are designed to encourage new American playwrights, provide an outlet for their talents, and deepen audience participation. During its initial two seasons at the Forum under the artistic direction of Gordon Davidson, the Center Theatre Group has presented the work of 27 new playwrights, avoided the standard and safe in its choice of plays, and taken the lead in the production of new plays outside New York City. "New Theatre for Now: Mondays at the Forum" is the name of the Group's Monday-night experimental play series at the Mark Taper Forum. All the plays on the NFT Playhouse: Theatre America - "New Theatre for Now" program (with the exception of "Camera Obscura") were first presented on these Monday-night showcase performances. After their premieres in Los Angeles on the Monday night series, "Wandering," "Chuck" and "Thoughts on the Instant of Greeting a Friend on the Street" went on to success as part of an evening of short plays entitled "Collision Course." "The Golden Fleece," the last and longest play on the NET Playhouse program, has a success story of its own. After its two initial Monday-night performances, it was brought into the Group's regular repertory season at the Forum for sixty-eight performances. The segment consisting of Lanford Wilson's play, "Wandering" was submitted to the 1969 Atlanta Film Festival by Group One, the Los Angeles film production company which shot the play for the NET program. It received a Golden Medal in the experimental category. Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET Playhouse - "Theatre America: New Theatre for Now" - The Los Angeles Center Theatre Group at the Mark Taper Forum in a bill of four dramatic vignettes and a two-character, one-act play, all by new American playwrights. NET Playhouse - Theatre America: "New Theatre for Now" is a National Educational Television production, produced through the facilities of KCET-TV in Los Angeles. Producer: Jac Venza. Director: Richard Dunlap. Stage direction for "The Golden Fleece" was by Jered Barclay. Stage direction and television conception for "Wandering," "Chuck," "Thoughts," and "Camera Obscura" by Edward Parone. All of the plays on "New Theatre for Now" were originally presented during the Monday night experimental play series of the Center Theatre Group at the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles. The director of the Center Theatre Group is Elliot Martin. Artistic director of the Mark Taper Forum is Gordon Davidson. The Monday night series is under the direction of Edward Parone.

From NET microfiche: Program Description: Set in South Africa, "The Blood Knot" explores, in a heightened near poetic style, the relationship between two brothers - one black and one who could pass for white. The dark brother wants a pen pal and unwittingly writes to a white girl, who replies, thinking him white. In discussing the situation, the two brothers bring to the surface some turbulent emotions aroused by the racial dilemma in which they find themselves. They spend all their meager savings to buy a suit for the white-skinned brother to wear to meet the girl. Finally, even this meeting is dismissed as a hopeless ambition. Passing as white would mean accepting the white man's values and abandoning his black brother. The ties of blood are too strong. Notes on the playwright: Athol Fugard is one of South Africa's leading playwrights and a member of the country's community of concerned intellectuals engaged in combatting South African apartheid policies. Fugard lives with his wife and child in a small village outside Port Elizabeth and until last year, he was free to travel to and from South Africa for theater and television commitments abroad. In June of 1967 the South African government relieved him of his passport with no reason given for their action. He is now permitted freedom of movement within South Africa, but were he to leave the country he would not be allowed to return. "The Blood Knot" was first performed in a small, crude theater workshop in Johannesburg and subsequently in theaters all over the world. It enjoyed a successful run in New York in 1964 with James Earl Jones of "The Great White Hope" portraying the black brother, Zach and J.D. Cannon as Morris. The Cast: Morris - Athol Fugard Zach - Charles Hyatt NET Playhouse - "The Blood Knot" is a National Educational Television presentation, produced by Michael Bakewell for the British Broadcasting Corporation. It was directed by Robin Midgley. Producer for NET: Kay Chessid

From NET microfiche (C): History Originally produced in London in 1623, "The Changeling" was given its first professional revival after 300 years' neglect (in a production mounted by Tony Richardson, director of the film "Tom Jones") at London's Royal Court Theater in 1961. The play is considered among the finest of the Jacobean period, an era of political intrigue, moral foment, and social violence which produced some of the most memorable studies of evil in the history of drama. "The Changeling," written by Thomas Middleton in collaboration with William Rowley, is a story of lust, deceit, murder, and retribution. The action of the play takes place in Spain, which (together with Italy) the Elizabethans consider the proper setting for intrigues, poisoning, stabbings, and other villainous deeds. In outline, the plot borders on the outrageous, even by today's morally tolerant standards, but the play is a powerful study of crime and its psychological effects and is reputed to have had a profound effect on the audiences of its day. The title of the play is derived from a comic subplot, credited to Rowley. This action is set in a madhouse and concerns the efforts of two counterfeit or "changeling" patients to seduce the wife of the doctor and keeper of the madhouse. Ironically, if crudely, this action echoes the main theme of the play. The Plot The proud and beautiful Beatrice-Joanna has conceived a passion, which is returned, for the handsome young Valencian, Alsemero. Seeking to rid herself of her undesired fianc, Alonzo, she turns to her father's ugly servant, De Flores, who has a secret passion for her but whom she has scorned. De Flores willingly undertakes her charge and kills Alonzo, but refuses the reward and demands that she submit to him in payment for the deed. Although appalled, Beatrice sees no other choice. "Vengeance begins; Murder, I see, is followed by more sins." Her loathing for De Flores now turns to a kind of fascination as they pursue their path of intrigue and murder. Thinking that Alonzo has dishonorably fled the castle, Beatrice's father, Vermandero, gives her hand instead to Alsemero and they are married. But Beatrice is fearful that, on their wedding night, Alsemero will discover that she is not a virgin. She bribes her maid, Diaphanta, to take her place in Alsemero's bed, with the injunction that the maid leave by midnight so Beatrice can replace her. When Diaphanta does not return, Beatrice, mad with anxiety and jealousy, again turns to De Flores. He sets fire, rouses the castle, and kills Diaphanta as she finally emerges from Alsemero's bed. Meanwhile, Tomazo, the brother of the murdered Alonzo, and Jasperino, the best friend of the betrayed Alsemero, arrive at the castle both highly suspicious of the situation there. At last, Beatrice boldly confesses to Alsemero that she hired De Flores to kill Alonzo - for Alsemero's sake - but denies that De Flores is her lover. But De Flores, seeing that the game is up, tells the whole story, stabs Beatrice and then kills himself.

From NET microfiche, file C: Description of series: Shakespeare's "The Comedy of Errors," performed by the Royal Shakespeare Company, has been one of the most successful productions ever staged by this internationally famous theater and has toured the United States, Canada and Eastern Europe. It was the first of the company's productions to be televised direct from its London headquarters at the Aldwych Theatre before an audience. The play is a comedy of mistaken identity. To Ephesus, a town known for black magic comes Antipholus, a young gentleman of Syracuse and his servant, Dromio. Unknown to them, there live in Ephesus their long-lost twin brothers who bear the same names. The plot consists of a number of ingeniously contrived situations in which either of the brothers from Syracuse is mistaken for those of Ephesus, and vice versa. Deeply involved in these tangles is Adriana, wife of Antipholus of Ephesus, who even has to go so far to engage one Pinch, schoolmaster and conjuror, to help her apparent husband regain his wits. The Cast: Solinus, Duke of Ephesus - Donald Sinden Aegeon, a merchant of Syracuse - John Welsh Antipholus of Ephesus - Ian Richardson Antipholus of Syracuse - Alex McCowen Dromio of Ephesus - Clifford Rose Dromio of Syracuse - Barry MacGregor Baltnazar, a merchant - Michael Murray Angelo, a goldsmith - Ken Wynne First merchant - Philip Brack Second merchant - John Hussey Pinch - Derek Smith An Officer - John Corvin A Messenger - Ronald Falk A Goaler - Martin Jenkins Aemilia, an abbess at Ephesus, wife to Aegeon - Madoline Thomas Adrianna, wife to Antipholus of Ephesus - Diana Rigg Luciana, her sister - Janet Suzman Luce, servant to Adrianna - Caroline Maud A Courtezan - Susan Engel With: Barbara Barnett, Shaun Curry, Valerie Cutts, James Falkland, Peter Geddis, Brian Harrison, Marshall Jones, Robert Jennings, Philippa Urquhart, Tim Wylton The Comedy of Errors is a National Educational Television presentation, a production of BBC. From NET microfiche: Chekhov was entirely concerned with people and their relationships and the subtlety of his character observation has seldom been matched. The setting for "The Duel," one of his most brilliant short stories, is a seaside town in the Crimea; the story is the decay of a love affair between Laevsky, a young civil servant, and Nadia, a married woman. Laevsky is sick of what he calls exile from Moscow. He is bored with himself and with Nadia, who is drifting into another affair with the chief of police. Watching from the sidelines are Dr. Samolienko and his friend, Von Koren, an idealistic scientist on holiday. Von Koren sees in Laevsky all the rottenness of the old regime, a despicable creature who should be exterminated. Their mutual antipathy explodes; there is a challenge and a duel. But this meaningless charade in the chilly hours of the early morning solves nothing. Laevsky's affair with Nadia goes on and Von Koren returns to his work. The Cast (in order of appearance): Samolienko -- Paul Rogers Laevsky -- John Wood Nadia -- Katharine Blake Von Koren -- Philip Madoc Deacon -- John Quentin Scheduled to run with "The Duel," is a Polish short, in color, entitled "Pyramid," which runs 4 minutes, 53 seconds. There is no dialogue. It is a fable in highly stylized, Rousseau-like animation about a turn-of-the-century circus. A group of top-hatted men are carefully trying to build a human pyramid. Watching them languidly is a lovely lady. Struggling to impress her, they finally complete the perfect pyramid, whereupon she throws a rose into their midst. There is a moment of tension and then the top man dives for the rose. Their pyramid dissolves into chaos while the circus music plays on. NET Playhouse -- "The Duel" is a National Educational Television presentation, produced for the British Broadcasting Corporation by Peter Luke. It was directed by Charles Jarrott and designed by Natasha Kroll. Producer for NET is Janet Sternburg. NET Playhouse Executive Producer: Jac Venza

From NET microfiche: The distinguished Swedish dramatist, August Strindberg (1849-1912), said of his play "The Father": it "is the realization of modern drama, and as such, is something very curious, because the struggle takes place between souls. It is a battle of brains, not a dagger fight or a poisoning with raspberry juice ..." But the play is far more than a "battle of brains." it deals with the psychological antagonism between men and women, the struggle between husband and wife which obsessed Strindberg throughout his literary lifetime. The Captain is a man respected in society with a reputation for original scientific research. But he is incapable of preventing the female members of his family from subjugating him. He disagrees with his wife, Laura, about the proper education of their daughter, and she torments him with hints that the child is not his. With complete ruthlessness, she fosters doubt of her husband's sanity in the minds of everyone -- her brother, the Pastor, the doctor, and even the Captain's old nurse, Old Margaret. She persuades Bertha to turn against her father. And finally she succeeds in driving her husband mad in fact. The role of the Captain is played by Robert Shaw the brilliant English actor and playwright ("Man in the Glass Booth"). The Cast (in order of appearance): The Captain Robert Shaw The Pastor John Moore Svard Philip Howard Nojd Peter Jesson Laura Daphne Slater The Grandmother Kathleen Saintbury Dr. Ostermark Denis Quilley Old Margaret Wynne Clark Bertha Michele Dotrice NET Playhouse -- "The Father" is a National Educational Television presentation produced by Alan Bridges for the British Broadcasting Corporation. It was translated by Peter Watts, designed by Barry Learoyd, with music arranged by Wilfred Josephs. Producer for NET is Janet Sternburg.

From NET microfiche, file L: "The Lady with the Dog," a Russian feature film, is adapted from Anton Chekhov's short story of a love affair in the last century between a married bank official on holiday in Yalta and a young and beautiful girl - also married - who is always accompanied by her white Pomeranian dog. The man, Gourov, is something of a middle-aged rou, and the girl, Anna Sergeyevna, is unhappily married - but out of what both intend to be merely a brief encounter, grows a great love. They leave Yalta, he for his home in Moscow, she for hers in a small provincial town, but after a few months Gourov feels compelled to see Anna again, and seeks her out in her home town. Thereafter they continue to meet clandestinely in Moscow every two or three months, and come to the realization of their great love for each other. "The Lady with the Dog" won the Prix de la Meilleure Participation at the 1960 Cannes Film Festival for its "lofty humanism and high artistic standard. Critics at the Festival praised the film's warm and human qualities and the manner in which the atmosphere of the period had been perfectly recaptured. Made to celebrate the centennial of the birth of the famous Russian writer in 1960, it is considered to be one of the best interpretations of a Chekhov work on the screen. New York Critics found the film "immensely Chekhovian and immensely good." The background and people were portrayed "so realistically that they have the appearance of newsreels of sixty years ago, miraculously well photographed and clear." In the performance of the actors there is "an unfailing sense of artistic perfection." The film has Russian dialogue and English subtitles. The Cast: Anna Sergeyevna - Iya Savvina Gourov - Alexei Batolov "The Lady with the Dog" is a National Educational Television presentation. Produced by Lenfilm Studios. Josef Heifetz directing. Screenplay by Josef Heifetz. Music: N. Simonyan. Photography: Andrei Moskvin and Dimitri Meskhiev.

From NET microfiche: The Madras House is a great London Bond Street fashion house owned and operated by the Huxtable and Madras family combination. For twenty-six years the Madras House has clothed the most brilliant and aristocratic women in London society. Now it is to be sold to an American millionaire, Mr. Eustace Perrin State, who plans to turn it into a chain of provincial ladies' fashion stores. Although the action of the play revolves around this sale, the development of the story concerns the lives of the members of the Huxtable and Madras families, and their reactions to the social and economic changes of Edwardian England. Granville-Barker has embodied in his characters, the clashing attitudes of that rapidly-changing time toward sex, women's rights, labor, etc. The major characters include: Henry Huxtable, "titular" head of his household (and Madras House) since an illness, is a well-meaning but stuffy and prosperous businessman. Katherine, his church-going, self-righteous wife, is the "very model" of a Victorian, middle-class matron. They have six unmarried daughters in various stages of frustration and boredom. Constantine (Charles) Madras is Henry's brother-in-law, the creative force (he was a celebrated dress designer) and founder of the Madras House. He is married to Henry's tearful, self-pitying sister, Amelia. Constantine embodies the "Turk in every man." He left Amelia (whom he betrayed over and over) to settle in Arabia. There embraced Mohammedianism and apparently many other wives, never bothering to divorce Amelia. He has now come back to Europe for the last time to participate in the sale of the Madras House. Philip Madras, only son of Amelia and Constantine, is the director of Madras House. He is in opposition to the divergent convictions of both his father and his uncle. Appalled at poverty and social inequities, he is looking toward government service. He is so involved with the problems of his time that he fails to see the problem in his own marriage. Philip's wife, Jessica, is a perfect Edwardian beauty of education and breeding without enough responsibility to occupy her very considerable gifts of intelligence and talent. Neglected by Philip, she has started to flirt with his friend and business partner, Major Hippisly Thomas. About the Playwright Harley Granville-Baker (1877-1946), English critic, dramatist, director and actor. In the early part of the 20th century he was chiefly known for his portrayals of roles in plays by Bernard Shaw, many of which he also produced. In addition to "The Madras House," he is also remembered as the author of "The Voysey Inheritance." His best known contributions to the stage however, are his critical works on the staging of Shakespeare, which set new standards for his time and are still used today. Followed by filler program, Parade, a short film by Derek Hill and Kevin Brownlow.
Great Britain--Social life and customs--20th century

From NET microfiche: Using the device of a British parade, the film juxtaposes selective documentary footage from scenes of British public life (i.e., dignified wigged judges, the Changing of the Guard, political figures, etc.) against footage which exposes the hypocrisy of public life hiding behind the easy acceptance of gay marching music and colorful formations.
Triangle Film Productions ; producer, Theodora Olembert ; director, writer, Derek Hill.

From NET microfiche: Driving her ancient motor scooter through a posh neighborhood in London, a young girl pauses for a traffic signal on her way to Dover and thence to the Continent. At the same corner, and for the same traffic signal, a luxurious, chauffeured Rolls-Royce also stops. As it starts up again, the vast limousine casually knocks over the tiny heap of scrap iron and smashes its headlight. Chauffeur and passenger scarcely notice the incident. But the scooter's young owner is in a state of furious indignation. Her headlight is smashed, she has to reach Dover by dark, and she is broke. So she pursues the Rolls until it disappears through the gates of a huge Mayfair mansion. Although the mansion is ingeniously and expensively rigged to keep out intruders, the determined girl, in her blue jeans and helmet, manages to defy all the devices. She gets inside the citadel, to find herself fact to face with the millionaire himself, in his bath! They are the most unlikely pair to meet anywhere or anytime: the odd, scruffy, disconcerting girl owning little more than what she appears in; and the great tycoon, lord of a thousand companies, owner of a dozen Rembrandts, "old Adam Capitalist in his Golden garden." The girl only wants him to pay her the 25 shillings it will cost to fix her headlight. But the cynical rich man is amused by her tenacity and, if truth be told, by her novelty. He decides to teach her a lesson for breaking into his heretofore impregnable fortress and parries her demand for payment. But in her innocence and earnestness, she proves his equal and piques his real interest. When his dinner engagement with the sophisticated Ambassadress is cancelled, he decides to try to seduce the pretty young "upstart." But something goes wrong during the champagne, caviar, and soft-music-low-lights. Her very youth and vulnerability penetrate his tough old personal defenses, just as she got past all his complicated residential barriers. And she, in her turn, falls in love with him. But she is wiser in her innocence than he, with all his knowledge of the world. She knows that an alliance with him could only turn to bitterness and, above all, expose him to mockery. So, what was to have been a night of dallying becomes a short, sweet while of tenderness - she asleep in his enormous bed and he cramped in the very bathroom where they first saw each other. And in the morning, she continues on her motor-scooter way to Dover, while he settles wistfully back into the plush, inner seclusion of his Rolls Royce to begin his day's money-making once again. Heading the cast are Sir John Gielgud as the rich man, Gabriel Quantara, and Felicity Kendall (star of the film "Shakespeare Wallah") as The Girl. The Cast: Sir John Gielgud - Gabriel Quantara Felicity Kendall - The Girl Barnet - Timothy Bateson Mario - David Stoll Madame Roo - Isa Maranda Lt. It was directed by Robin Midgley, designed by Sally Hulke. Music by Richard Addinsell. Writer: Jack Russell. NET producer is Kay Chessid.

From NET microfiche: With the help of Bette Davis, Edward G. Robinson, Joan Blodell, Pat O'Brien, Olivia de Havilland, and other important figures from the American movie industry, NET Playhouse continues its series on the 1920s with an entertaining look at Hollywood during that era. Recently-filmed interviews with these stars and with directors William Wellman and Mervyn LeRoy, producer Hal Wallis, and writers Dalton Trumbo and John Bright, are interwoven with excerpts from many of the films that made them famous. The specific aims of this programs, according to producer David Loxton, are to illustrate the development of the Hollywood industry during the 1930s, to "capture in dramatic terms the feeling of what it was like to be a part of the Hollywood scene in those days, and examine the role that movies played in the lives of Americans." The show focuses on the Warner Brothers studio. Film excerpts are from "Jezebel," "Juarez" and "Dangerous," starring Bette Davis; "Little Caesar" and "Confessions of Nazi Spay" with Edward G. Robinson; "Public Enemy," featuring James Cagney and Jean Harlow; "I Am a Fugitive from a Chain Gang" starring Paul Muni; "Captain Blood" and "Charge of the Light Brigade," with Errol Flynn and Olivia de Havilland; and "Gold Diggers of 1933," with Ruby Keeler, Dick Powell and Joan Blondell. All interviews in this program took place within the past two months and with two exceptions were conducted in Hollywood by Life magazine film reviewer Richard Schickel. Miss Davis is scheduled to be interviewed in New York January 18 by Schickel, and Miss de Havilland was interviewed in London for NET by independent producer Robert Graef. "The Movie Crazy Years" is a production of NET Division, Educational Broadcasting Corporation, transmitted nationally on the Public Broadcasting Service. Producer: David Loxton. Associate producer: Janet Sternburg. NET Playhouse executive producer: Jac Venza.

From NET microfiche: Program Description: This program of selections from the repertory of the National Theatre of the Deaf consists of two sections: the first part is devoted to the "reading" of poetry (acted out by the actors in mime, sign language, dance to the simultaneous narration of the works); the second to the performance of a version of Giacomo Puccini's comic opera "Gianni Schicchi," performed in pantomime, in commedia dell'arte style. It is accompanied by music played on instruments especially designed by French sculptor Francois Baschet, which produce vibrations discernable to the deaf. The poems, in order of performance, are: " "Breeze" by Marie Hourigan, aged 11, from Australia " "I Live the World" by Paul Wollner, aged 7, USA " "Flowers and Moonlight on the Spring River" by Yang Ti, Emperor of the Sui Dynasty (605-617 AD) " "Jabberwocky" by Lewis Carroll " "How Do I Love Thee?" by Elizabeth Barrett Browning " "Nice Boy" by Martin O'Conner, aged 10, from New Zealand " "Tyger! Tyger!" by William Blake " "The Train" by Roger Mortime, aged 7, from New Zealand " "November" by Charles Gluck, aged 10, USA " "On His Deafness" by Robert T. Panara (who was deaf, himself) " "Gianni Schicchi" is about a rogue, named Gianni Schicchi, hired by the family of a just-deceased rich man to forge a new will, because they have just discovered that he left his money to a monastery. Schicchi goes along with the family's plans to pretend the dead man is still alive, but dying. Impersonating the "dying" man, Gianni dictates a new will to the notary, but in a last-minute double cross, he names himself as the beneficiary. Background on the Company: The National Theatre of the Deaf was launched during the summer of 1967 by the Eugene O'Neill Memorial Theatre Foundation at its headquarters in Waterford, Connecticut, and since then has made two tours across the United States, appearing in more than 40 cities. The company was formed not just to give deaf people - on both sides of the footlights - an outlet unique to themselves. Rather it was designed to create a new theater form. The deaf actors are drawn from all over the country, and their talent in body communication, which ordinary actors must learn, comes naturally from their everyday manner of "speech." The finished theatrical performances, therefore, combine mime, dance, manual sign language, and music with simultaneous narration. Audiences who have seen the NTD quickly realize that its actors are not in any way "handicapped" by their inability to hear.

From NET microfiche: Program Description: The program opens with Bernard Bragg and Lou Fant, who shows 16 youngsters from Boston elementary schools how sign language is used. They then persuade the children to make up their own signs and use them to "talk" poetry with their hands. Following this demonstration, members of the company present two selections from their repertoire: "On the Harmfulness of Tobacco" by Anton Chekhov (a monologue): A subtle psychological study of a man who reveals, during the course of the monologue, his own fine qualities, qualities that have been distorted and wantonly destroyed over the years by a selfish and domineering wife. Cast: Nyukhin - Lou Fant "The Tales of Kasane" by Tsurya Namboko (a Kabuki play): This Japanese drama takes place during the 17th century, on the shores of the River Kine, where Kasane has gone to meet her lover, Yoemon. Unknown to her, Yoemon has killed her father. When the lovers meet, Kasane begs Yoemon to let her come with him so that she will not be left alone to bear his child. In the river, Yoemon finds the father's grave-marker. Afraid that Kasane will see it, he breaks the marker, a symbolic destruction that leaves its mark on Kasane. She becomes lame and her face disfigured. Gradually the father's ghost possesses Kasane's body and begins to haunt Yoemon. A police officer appears but is chased away by Yoemon. Finally the crazed lover stabs his beloved. Rain begins to fall. Kasane's ghost appears, drawing Yoemon back - ever closer to her. --- MISSING PAGE 2 --- FILLER: NET Playhouse -- "The National Theater of the Deaf Encore" is followed by a short feature, "So where are you, God?"

From NET microfiche (N): "So Where Are You, God?" is a short feature, 29:33 in length. It is an original essay written especially for television by Robert Larson. Designed as a modern-day parable and written in the form of a drama documentary, the film tells the story of a young man - the eternal doubter - and his search for God, a search which takes him down many of the traditional avenues of contemporary beliefs and persuasions. The film, which received the 1969 National Conference of Christians and Jews Brotherhood Award, was produced with the aid of a grant from The Ford Foundation by NET's Hershey, PA affiliate WITF TV. Executive producer and writer Robert Larson received the NET Community Service Award in 1967 for "Sons and Daughter" and again in 1968 for "Time to Act." He served as executive producer for both of those projects. Barry Nye, film director and editor of "So Where Are You, God?" received the NET distinguished award for his contribution to "Time to Act."

From NET microfiche, file R: Patrick Magee, Ian Richardson, Glenda Jackson, and the Royal Shakespeare Company perform Peter Weiss,' "Marat/Sade" in the United Artists film directed by Peter Brook. The motion picture is adapted from the successful and highly acclaimed 1965 play which also starred the Royal Shakespeare Company and was directed by Brook. "Marat/Sade," the full title of which is "The Persecution and Assassination of Jean-Paul Marat as Performed by the Marquis de Sade," is an unconventional work of extraordinary impact. It is a play within a play, set in the Asylum of Charenton, an actual French institution at which inmates sometimes gave theatrical performances as a type of therapy during the early 1800s. The Marquis de Sade, who was confined to that asylum for the last 11 years of his life, directed those performances. In "Marat/Sade" Patrick Magee portrays de Sade, who has been asked to direct his fellow inmates in a dramatization of the murder of Jean-Paul Marat (Ian Richardson), a leader of the French Revolution who was stabbed to death by a young girl of the gentry, Charlotte Corday (Glenda Jackson). As the play progresses, a fierce philosophical battle develops (outside the basic framework of the inmates' performance) as de Sade's fatalism and concern for self-gratification clash with Marat's quest for social reform through violent revolution. The warden of the institution, observing with his wife and daughters, objects to these clashes but nevertheless seems oblivious to the ominous undercurrent that pervades the performance. He lets the play continue until finally the inmates rage completely out of control. Giving the work added force are an array of compelling visual and musical effects which help reinforce the oppressive atmosphere of the asylum. The music is by Richard Peaslee. This is the second of several program this season in which NET Playhouse will present great theatre companies from around the world.

From NET microfiche: Jack Richardson's "The Prodigal" is based on the Greek legend of Orestes, son of Agamemnon, King of Mycenae, and commander of the Greek army which waged the victorious war against the Trojans. After ten years at war, Agamemnon returned home only to be murdered in his bath by his wife Clytemnestra and her love Aegisthus. Orestes is sent into exile but returns after many years to avenge the death of his father by killing his mother and Aegisthus. "The Prodigal" beings on the morning of Agamemnon's return from the war. Anticipation of his victorious homecoming, however, is charged with apprehension. Agamemnon's cousin, Aegisthus, the man he left to protect he kingdom in his absence, not only has usurped Agamemnon's bed but his throne as well. Clytemnestra awaits her husband's homecoming with vengeance in her heart, for she has never forgiven him for sacrificing their daughter, Iphigenia, to gain favorable winds for the Greek fleet on its way to Troy. Electra, Orestes' sister, idolizes her father and anticipates his return with the innocent adoration of a teenaged girl for a famous and glamorous father. None of the political and emotional machinations of her mother and Aegisthus have touched her yet. Richardson's Orestes, however, is another matter. He is a young man out of step with his time - uncommitted, skeptical, sophisticated, and disaffected with war. He is as removed emotionally from the power plays of the politician Aegisthus as he is from the myth-building of his warrior father. He would have been more at home in the 20th century. When, after his father is murdered, Aegisthus and his mother send him and his friend Pylades on a journey to get them out of the way, he is delighted to go. He doesn't consider the bloody affairs of his elders of much concern to him. All he wants is a simple, loving girl to marry and a peaceful, contemplative life. But in the end, Orestes cannot remain outside his time nor deny his destiny. Although his convictions remain the same, his views of killing unchanged, he is unable to resist the pressures of his society and of his time. "The world demands that we inherit the pretensions of our fathers, that we go on killing in the name of ancient illusions about ourselves, that we assume the right to punish, order, and invent philosophies to make our worst moment seem inspired. Who am I to contradict all this any longer? I will return to Argos. I belong no other place." About the playwright: Jack Richardson is a native New Yorker, educated at Columbia University (BA) and at the University of Munich in Germany. He wrote "The Prodigal," his first play, when he was 24 years old. It won for him both the Vernon Rice Award and the 1960 Obie Award. "The Prodigal" was first produced off-Broadway in New York City in 1960. Mr. Richardson's play "Gallows Humor" had a successful run off-Broadway in 1962, and a third drama, "Lorenzo," was produced on Broadway in 1963 The cast: Orestes - Peter Galman Agamemnon - Roy Poole Electra - Pamela Payton-Wright Aegisthus - John Heffernan Clytemnestra - Kim Hunter Pylades - Walker Daniels Cassandra - Cavanda Humphrey Penelope - Aline MacMahon Praxithia - Meg Foster Soldiers and Priest NET Playhouse - "The Prodigal" - is a National Educational Television production. Producer: Jack Kuney; director: Tom Donovan; sets by Lloyd Evans; costumes by Gene Coffin; original musical score by Ezra Laderman; art by Ken Rockefeller.

From NET microfiche: Motion pictures, in addition to providing entertainment and information, are generally assumed to represent a lasting record of the achievements of Hollywood's earliest great stars and directors. But in fact, according to the New York Museum of Modern Art publication "Lost Films," a great many old films - even those of such notables as Greta Garbo, Lon Chaney, Lillian Gish, Howard Hawkes, and Josef von Sternberg - "have been lost through ignorance or indifference." The Museum of Modern Art houses one of the nation's few motion picture archives. "The Rediscovered Film: Once in a Lifetime" is one of two programs in the series "NET Playhouse on the Thirties" devoted especially to the Hollywood film industry. This particular program seeks to publicize the problem of Hollywood's disappearing films and to present a fine motion picture that has been preserved, though it has never before been seen on television. "Once in a Lifetime," acquired for NET by the American Film Institute, is a delightful spoof of the foibles and excesses of Hollywood, starring Jack Oakie, ZaSu Pitts, Aline MacMahon, and Gregory Ratoff. Based on the play of the same name by George S. Kaufman and Moss Hart, this 1932 film features Jack Oakie as a zany supervisor who brings something less than foresight and expertise to a motion picture studio trying to adjust to the advent of talking pictures. Seton I Miller ("Here Comes Mr. Jordan") wrote the screenplay, and Russel Mack directed the film for Universal Pictures. The introduction of the film includes a sequence of stills from the Museum of Modern Art exhibition, "Lost Films."

"Based on the stage comedy by Moss Hart and George S. Kaufman, Once in a Lifetime is a satire of Hollywood's early-talkie era. A down-and-out vaudeville trio (Jack Oakie, Aline MacMahon, and Russell Hopton) takes advantage of the confusion attending the talkie revolution by heading to Hollywood and posing as voice experts. George (Oakie), the team's dimwitted straight man, falls in love with a pretty young miss (Sidney Fox) who has come to Hollywood to become an actress -- and won't let her utter lack of talent get in the way. Fast-talking themselves into jobs at the Glogauer Studios, the phony vocal specialists eventually wear out their welcome and are on the verge of being fired. But George, who has been listening to the complaints of a disillusioned screenwriter, suddenly spouts those complaints word for word to Mr. Glogauer (Gregory Ratoff) -- and is lauded as a genius for being the first man to stand up to the despotic studio head. George is made a producer, and immediately sets about filming an expensive movie vehicle for his girlfriend. Unfortunately, George had found the script for his film in a wastebasket, and winds up shooting the wrong picture. He and his vaudeville chums are fired, but when his picture (an incomprehensible farrago shot in darkness because George forgot to turn on the klieg lights) is previewed, it is hailed as a daringly original masterpiece. George is made the supervising producer of Glogauer Studios, and all ends happily for himself and his friends. An interesting precursor to the Singin' in the Rain school of Hollywood kidding itself, Once in a Lifetime has tarnished a bit over the years but is still well worth seeing"--Allmovie.com, 2014-03-28.
Universal Pictures ; director, Russell Mack ; producer, Carl Laemmle Jr. ; adaptation, Seton I. Miller.
