From NET microfiche: Anton Chekhov's third full-length play, "The Seagull," was first produced at the Imperial Theater in St. Petersburg in 1896. The young playwright's new dramatic concepts were so totally misunderstood by the directors and actors of that traditionalist institution that this original production of "The Seagull" was a disastrous failure. In fact, its reception was so bad that Chekhov was almost persuaded to give up playwriting. However, two years later, when the drama was revived by the newly-formed Moscow Art Theater, its success was so triumphant that the production was largely responsible for establishing the reputation of the new repertory group itself. Indeed, "The Seagull" eventually became identified with the Moscow Art Theater, an image of the bird even appearing as the Theater's symbol on the curtain and programs. The Play: Madame Arkadina is a popular, but middle-aged actress. Her lover is Trigorin, a famous novelist. Arkadina's son, Konstantin Treplef, wants to be a writer but despises the popular theater and yearns to create new forms. He is in love with Nina, an aspiring young actress. When he writes a play for her, a symbolic drama about the end of the world, his mother and Trigorin laugh at it. Added to this humiliation, Nina is seduced by Trigorin and falls in love with him. As a symbol of his ruined hopes, Konstantin kills a seagull ("that fresh, free, happy creature") and lays it at Nina's feet. He tries unsuccessfully, to kill himself, but Nina follows Trigorin to Moscow. Two years later Konstantin has become a capable writer. But when a destroyed Nina returns, having been deserted by Trigorin, all his old feelings of grief and despair comes back. This time, Konstantin succeeds in his suicide attempt. The cast of "The Seagull" is headed by Britain's distinguished actress Pamela Brown as Arkadina, and Robert Stephens as Trigorin. Mr. Stephens is one of the leading actors of the British National Theatre.

From NET microfiche, file S: Background Information of the Trilogy "The Seekers": Playwright Ken Taylor spent a year working on these three plays on the subject of man and his creeds. Each play looks at the nature of human belief at a different stage of history. The first is set in the medieval "Age of Faith," the second in the eighteenth century "Age of Reason," and the last in modern, almost nihilist society. Each is based on some actual historical event, although the characters are fictitious. The central character throughout remains the same. In the first he is Gerard, leader of a group of Flemish heretics of the twelfth century, exiled in Oxford. In the second pitted the supporters of the old beliefs against the rationalists of the French Revolution; and in the last he is Gerhard, a political prisoner of 1942 confined in Auschwitz. The play is set during the French Revolution, and deals with the rising of La Vendee (a counter-revolutionary insurrection) against the Republican government. A young captain, Gerard, has a terrible decision to make about the 200 prisoners under his surveillance. He is an idealist who cannot square his conscience either with the decisions of the Republic or with the principles of his time, the "Age of Reason." On the other hand, his lieutenant, Edmonde, while supremely loyal to his doubting captain, is utterly convinced by the actions of the Republic. On his own initiative, Edmonde rides to the nearby provincial center, Nantes, and brings back orders from Carrier, who is in charge there. The prisoners are to be packed on barges, pushed out to the open water and drowned. Gerard refuses to obey, using as his excuse the fact that there is a spy among them. The only person who knows the identity of the spy is Marguerite de Bouvet, wife of the owner of the chateau where the soldiers are billeted. Not realizing Gerard's purpose, although they are in love, she feels herself divinely guided to reveal the name of the man. Gerard no longer has any excuse for not sending the prisoners to their deaths, and has to carry out the order. The Cast: Gerard - Michael Bryant Edmonde - Patrick Allen Marguerite - Suzanne Neve Charles de Bouvet - John Robinson Coutant - Brian Haines Sergeant - Peter Welch Dying Man - David J. Grahame Priest - Vernon Dobtcheff Soldiers - Jack Smethurst - Brian Vaughan Raped Girl - Paula Jacobs Boys - Alan Kemp - Darryl Read Mother - Brenda Duncan NET Playhouse - "The Seekers: The Idealists" is a National Educational Television presentation produced by Cederic Messina for the British Broadcasting Corporation. It was directed by Alvin Rakoff, designed by Tony Abbott. Music was composed and conducted by Carl Davis. Producer for NET is Janet Sternburg.

[no play description available] Filler Information: Filler for "The Materialists" is a black and white short from West Germany entitled "Iris on the Bench," which runs 8:57. It is a light, gay film about a young man who, while sitting on a park bench, caressing his girlfriend - whose eyes are closed - flirts with an attractive model also sitting on the bench. He asks a passerby to take his place on the bench and goes after his elusive model, who disappears. He returns to discover that his girlfriend has opened her eyes, is perfectly content with the substitution, and he is left alone. There is very little dialogue, but what there is has subtitles and English.

From NET microfiche: In 1963 the Open Theatre Company was formed in New York by a group of actors, directors, and playwrights who were dissatisfied with conventional theater and wanted to experiment with new forms of expression. Today, under director Joseph Chaikin, the Open Theatre is perhaps the leading avant-garde ensemble on the American stage. Walter Kerr, drama critic of the New York Times, has called it "the finest company of its kind;" and another Times critic, Mel Gussow, termed the Open Theatre players "superbly disciplined artists." "The Serpent" is not so much a play as it is a "ceremony," according to its author, Jean-Claude van Itallie, who is probably best known for his 1966 off-Broadway play "America Hurrah," which ran for nearly two years. With "The Serpent" he has constructed a ceremony, he says, "which can be used by the actors to come together with their audience." Van Itallie was born in Brussels, Belgium, but raised on Long Island, NY. He is a 1958 graduate of Harvard, and a member of the Open Theatre. "The Serpent" recreates the story of Genesis, but not in the conventional sense. In Chaikin's words: "The premise of the piece is that Man made God in his own image, and held up this God to determine his own, Man's, limits." And, he explains: "The text follows the narrative of Genesis, and is at the same time a repudiation of its assumptions, this forming a dialectic." Recreating their own early concepts and images of Adam and Eve, the serpent, the Garden of Eden, Cain and Abel, etc., the actors use a variety of spellbinding techniques to give force to the work. These include rhythmic body movements, chanting, counter-pointed dialogue, and at times, almost hypnotic repetition. "The creation of this piece was an exploration of certain ideas and images that seem to dominate our minds and lives," says van Itallie. "And we don't think such in linear fashion. Ideas overlap, themes recur, archetypal figures and events transform from shape to shape as they dominate our minds." The Cast: Adam - Mark Samuels Eve - Tina Shepard Cain - Raymond Barry Abel - Ralph Lee Chorus - Lee Worley and Shami Chaikin Others - James Barbosa - Brenda Dixon - Ron Faber - Jayne Haynes - Peter Maloney - Ellen Schindler - Barbara Vann - Paul Zimet Following "The Serpent," which runs about 50 minutes, will be a documentary about the Open Theatre. It will include two scenes from another of the company's productions - "Terminal" (text by Susan Yankowitz). Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET Playhouse - Joseph' Chaikin's avant-garde Open Theatre players recreate the story of Genesis as they perform Jean-Claude van Itallie's "The Serpent." Followed by a short documentary about the Open Theatre, including scenes from the play "Terminal." From NET microfiche: Richard Wagner (1813-1883), the nineteenth century's greatest musical innovator and certainly its most controversial figure, influenced the course of musical theater perhaps more than any other composer. He was extravagant, ruthless, egotistical, and a hypnotic personality. His private life - if such it can be called since his romantic exploits made him a legend in his own time - was motivated by his apparently bottomless need for a women's unquestioning love. And since for him music was the externalization of his inner being, this thread - the salvation of man by a woman's "pure" love - runs through is entire body of works: "Rienzi," "The Flying Dutchman," "Tannhaueser," "Lohengrin," "Tristan and Isolde," the great "Ring des Niebelungen," "Parsifal," "Die Meistersinger." "The Sigfried Idyll," Wagner's only important chamber work, was composed, composed for small orchestra in 1870 to celebrate the birth of his son Sigfried. It was also a tribute to the domestic happiness he had shared with Cosima von Buelow, his mistress of eight years, the mother of his four children, and the wife of his best friend and disciple, the conductor Hans von Buelow. The composition was first performed on Christmas Day, 1870, Cosima's birthday, on the staircase outside her bedroom at their home in Switzerland. (He and Cosima finally been married in August of that year.) Although there was a difference of 27 years in age between Wagner and Cosima, theirs was a radiant relationship. Wagner died in Cosima's arms in 1883 and she then pledged to devote the rest of her life to building a monument to and preserving the works of, "her master." She stood jealous guard over the Wagner legend at the festival theater at Bayreuth in Germany for 47 years and died at the age of 93 in 1930. The program "The Siegfried Idyll" tells the story of Wagner's love affair with Cosima from 1862 to 1870, years which took him from poverty in Vienna and 'exile' in Switzerland, to living off the bounty of the mad King Ludwig of Bavaria The film was shot on the authentic locations: in Switzerland at Wagner's villa with its magnificent setting on Lake Lucerne; and in Germany at Lake Starnberg. The Cast: Richard Wagner - Alan Badel Cosima von Buelow - Barbara Leigh-Hunt Hans von Buelow - Richard Pasco King Ludwig II - John Quentin Hans Richter - Timothy West Cornelius - Timothy Bateson Pfistermeister - Peter Stephens Friedrich Nietzsche - David Spestis Maid at Triebschen - Ina de la Haye Maid at Biebrich - Bella Emberg Priest - Henry Bartlett Painter - Michael Bretton The Musicians - The Academy of St. Martin-in-the Fields Director: Neville Marriner NET Playhouse - "The Siegfried Idyll" is a co-production of NET, the British Broadcasting Corporation, and the Canadian Broadcasting Company. It was produced and directed by Anthony Wilkinson of the BBC, written by Mr. Wilkinson and John Wiles, photographed by Ken Westbury. Costumes by Joyce Macken and designs by Spencer Chapman. FILLER INFORMATION: Filler material running 8:42 has been added to "The Siegfried Idyll" to bring it to the full 90 minutes. Entitled "Color Music Opus 5, No. 1" the filler material is an animated color film produced by Edward Carlton Snyder, and consists of abstract and electronic color images choreographed to the first movement from Beethoven's Symphony No. 8 in F major.

From NET microfiche, file S: Background Information: Igor Stravinsky wrote "The Soldier's Tale" in Switzerland after the outbreak of World War I. The newly-won Communist Revolution in Russia had cut off his financial resources and he had formed a circle of artist-friends, many of whom were also affected economically by the war. To find some way of alleviating their straightened circumstances, Stravinsky, the writer CF Ramuz, conductor Ernest Ansermet and the painter Rene Auberjonois, hit upon the idea of a small traveling theater for which they would produce a suitable stage work. Although the traveling theater project never came to fruition, the little stage work did - "The Soldier's Tale," music by Stravinsky, libretto by Ramuz, dcor and costumes by Auberjonois. At its first performance, on September 28, 1918, at the Lausanne (Switzerland) Theatre, Ernest Ansermet conducted. "The Soldier's Tale" was based on a cycle of Russian folk legends dealing with the adventures of a soldier who has deserted army and is pursued by the Devil who wants to possess his soul. In his "Chronicles of My Life," Stravinsky explains that these folk tales came out of a cruel period of enforced recruitment under Czar Nicholas I, a period which also produced many songs of lamentation by women left bereft of their menfolk by the wars. He says that although the character of these tales and songs is specifically Russian, "it was this essentially human aspect of the tragic story of the soldier destined to become the prey of the Devil that attracted Ramuz and myself." Because it was intended to be a portable stage work, Stravinsky wrote the work for a small group of solo instruments: violin, double bass, clarinet, bassoon, cornet, trombone, and various percussion. There are two speaking parts, one of which is mimed and danced, one non-speaking part, and a narrator. The French musicologist and critic Andre Hodeir writes "The Soldier's Tale" that it "might have been written by some circus juggler turned composer; in it Stravinsky accomplished a genuine tour de force [the work] containing, helter-skelter, a fake and a discordant chorale, but the total effect is one of extraordinary unity." This production of "The Soldier's Tale" was filmed mainly on location. The plot: On his way home from war, a soldier-deserter is playing his violin beside a sunlit pool. The Devil, in the guise of an elderly lepidopterist, is attracted by the Soldier's playing and asks the Soldier for his violin. When the Soldier refuses, the Devil offers him a book of riches in exchange. The Soldier accepts. But the Devil finds he cannot play the violin and persuades the solder to come back to his splendid mansion to give him lessons. In the mansion, the Soldier is overwhelmed by a kind of luxury he has never known: a wide, soft bed, incredibly wonderful things to eat. The next morning, the Soldier resumes his journey home. When he finally arrives at his native village, he is treated like an evil presence. Friends disappear behind shuttered windows; his mother screams at the sight of him; his fianc, married to another, hugs her children close to her as if to protect them from a forbidding stranger. The Devil has tricked him. What seemed to be only one night was actually ten years. Long presumed dead, the Soldier was taken for his own ghost. But he still has the book of riches, and in time grows enormously wealthy. However, his riches bring him no joy and he longs to lose what he has gained in order to become himself once again. So, during a cared game, he tricks the Devil into taking his last money and so wins back his violin. And then with his violin, he wins the beautiful Princess as his wife and finds happiness beyond his imagination. But this happiness will remain his on one condition. He must never cross the border to go home again. And then the Devil plants the seed of curiosity in the Princess' mind. She pleads with the Soldier to take her to see the village where he was born and to meet his mother. Since the Soldier truly loves the Princess, he cannot refuse her. He takes off at last down the road to the frontier where the Devil is waiting to claim his soul. The cast of "The Soldier's Tale" is headed by the world-famous character dancer Robert Helpmann, who appears in eight different disguises as the Devil. Brian Phelan plays the part of the Soldier, and Svetlana Berlosova, prima ballerina of Britain's Royal Ballet Company, is the Princess. Narrator is Anthony Nicolls. The Melos Ensemble is directed by Derek Hudson. NET Playhouse - "The Soldier's Tale" is a National Educational Television presentation, produced by Leonard Cassini and Dennis Miller for British Home Entertainment, Ltd. Directed and adapted by Michael Birkett. Photographer: Dennis Miller. Choreography by Robert Helpmann. NET Producer: Kay Chessid. FILLER INFORMATION: "The Uniform" is approximately 7 minutes in length and is a color animated cartoon from Poland. FILLER INFORMATION (December 26, 1969 broadcast): To be seen with "A Soldier's Tale" will be a 36-minute (approximately) color documentary entitled "Talisman: Barra," from the film unit of the Vermont Educational Television network. "Talisman: Barra," is the story of Robert Lister Macneil, an American by birth, who discovered when he was a boy that he was the Chief of the Scottish Clan Macneil. He visited his ancestral home on the tiny island of Barra in the Outer Hebrides and found the castle a total ruin, owned by a land-holder in London - not a Macneil. The young Chief spent 40 years and his savings to acquire the Macneil estate and then spent over 30 years in restoring the castle. The film was shot on location at this remote settlement in the Outer Hebrides. "Talisman: Barra" is a National Educational Television presentation, produced by Dr. Raymond Phillips for Vermont Educational Television. Writer-director: Gary Simpson. Cinematographer: Louis Phillips. The film was made possible by a grant from the MacNeil Foundation as a gift to the Clan.

Produced by Leonard Cassini and Dennis Miller ; for British Home Entertainment, Ltd. ; National Educational Television presentation ; directed and adapted by MIchael Birkett ; [by] Igor Stravinsky ; NET producer, Kay Chessid.

From NET microfiche, file S: Looking back from the vantage point of maturity, it seems to Stephen Minch, an inventor, and his crony, Hanus Wicks, that much of the unhappiness they are experiencing in the present might have been avoided by different choices in their youth. Minch's invention of a time machine provides them with an opportunity to see what the consequences of other choices might have been. Stephen and his wife, Martha, are the chief characters, and it is these two who are brought to realize that the life they have lived is fuller and richer than it would have been if each had chosen another mate and another way of life. In short, Stephen has achieved success of a more real and lasting kind than if he had pursued money and fame, and Martha has won greater happiness that if she had married the "go-getter." What playwright Maxwell Anderson seems to be saying was expressed in a review of the original Broadway production in 1937: " People achieve the most happiness for themselves by making their choices in life, not for deliberate advancement, but for peace of spirit." THE STAR WAGON is a fantasy concerning itself with the question "If I had my life to live over again, would I do it differently?" The Cast: Orson Bean - Stephen Minch Joan Lorring - Martha Minch Eileen Brennan - Hallie Arlington Dustin Hoffman - Hanus Wicks Charles MacPhee - Park Chet Doherty - Ripple Marion Seldes - Angela (also Herb Woman) Ben Yaffee - Apfel Ed Zimmermann - Charles Duffy Richard Castellano - Thug #1 MacIntyre Dixon - Thug #2 Arthur Hughes - Misty Hal Burdick - Mr. Arlington Jo Hurt - Mrs. Rutledge Ian Jenkins - Reiger Beverly Luckenbach - Christabel Shelly Gale - Della Russell Horton - Oglethorpe THE STAR WAGON is a National Educational Television production. Producer-director: Karl Genus. From NET microfiche, file N: Program 3: The Star Wagon Orson Bean, Eileen Brennan, Dustin Hoffman, and Joan Lorring in a full-length production of Maxwell Anderson's comedy-fantasy about the absentminded inventor of a time machine and the foolish notion: as it turns out: of wanting to live a life over again. Television premiere.
a production of National Educational Television ; produced and directed by Karl Genus.

From NET microfiche, file T: The setting is Greenfield, a western Pennsylvania town in which a large neighborhood may soon be torn down to make way for a highway. The residents are bitter. Many feel the price they will be offered for their property will not nearly cover the cost of finding a new home and moving, others, chiefly the older citizens, simply don't want to leave the neighborhood they've known all their lives, no matter what price they get. The civic meetings are stormy. There is talk of everything from legal action to lying down in front of the bulldozers. The above is not a fictional setting. It was the actual circumstance in the summer of 1969 when cameramen from public TV station WQED Pittsburgh, went to Greenfield to film the meetings at which the residents gathered to plan their strategy. Into this charged atmosphere, WQED producer Mat von Brauchitsch inserted an actor and an actress who play their roles in part by interacting with the townspeople. Jewel Walker portrays Jules Renick, a quiet, apathetic man who dwells in the past when his wife was alive. Gilmer Mccormick plays his daughter, Karen, a girl who grows progressively more restless. She is struggling against the conventional mentality of the community, which dictates that a girl's only reason for leaving home is getting married. Karen feels trapped, wanting desperately to go off on her own, but she is fearful of hurting her father. Then, along comes the highway project, and in her father's reluctance to join the fight against it, Karen sees a chance to break the hold which Hie community has over her. So unfolds "The Taking," which, for want of a better term, ' is referred to as a "docu-drama" because- it is both- drama and documentary. There is the drama of Jules' crumbling relationship with his daughter, and the documentation of people who feel their lives are being unjustly disrupted by the state. The combined two elements create greater authenticity and spontaneity. Jules and Karen are both going against the grain. The father, true to his apathetic nature, dislikes the idea of fighting the government, even in legal terms, and definitely opposes civil disobedience. Karen, of course, rejects the traditional attitudes of the townspeople. Therefore, when Jules and Karen are interacting with the people of Greenfield, the results a.Te uniquely authentic and spontaneous, on both the documentary and dramatic levels. There is a third professional performer in this production, Craig Bovia, who appears as Karen's boyfriend. Bovia was recently seen on NET Playhouse in "Stopped Running." Gilmer McCormick, incidentally, will appear on NET Playhouse three times in a four-week period: "The Taking" (May 21), "Confrontation" (May 28), and "The Ceremony of Innocence" (June 11). PLEASE NOTE: WQED will be mailing a press kit to stations for this program. NET Playhouse - "The Taking" is a National Educational Television presentation, produced by WQED, Pittsburgh, under a special grant for experimental drama from the Ford Foundation. Producer and director: Mat von Brauchitsch. NET executive producer: Jac Venza. Filler for NET Playhouse #189 - The Taking This is to announce that there will be a 14 minute (approx.) black and white filler entitled "The Grandfather" for NET Playhouse #189 - The Taking Suggested Newspaper Listing: An aroused community threatened by a highway project provides an authentic setting for this experimental "docu-drama" about a widower and his daughter who face a crisis in their relationship.
WQED, Pittsburgh ; National Educational Television presentation ; producer-director, Mat von Brauchitsch ; NET executive producer, Jac Venza.
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche: General Series Description: "The Tale of Genji," an eight-program series, follows the adventures of the charming and irresistible Prince Genji. The series is based on the novel "The Tale of Genji," long considered one of the greatest works of fiction In Japan, and widely known In the Western world through the translation by Arthur Waley (published by George Allen and Unwin). "The Tale of Genji" was written at the beginning of the eleventh century by the Japanese authoress Murasaki Shikibu. Her voluminous romantic novel has been compared to those by Proust and Virginia Woolf, and is said to have something in it of the Irony of Jane Austen. The novel covers three generations and has more than 500 characters, but the television version, originally produced as 26 half-hour episodes, while covering the whole story, focuses on its hero, Genji. Through backdrops in the tradition of the classic Japanese theater and carefully authenticated costumes, the television plays recreate the best known Incidents In his life. Synopsis: The highly complicated plot is as follows: The second son of the emperor - born to his mistress Kiritsubo- is given an Inferior title through the empress's machinations and receives the surname of "Minamoto" (Genji). But the prince is so intelligent that he is nicknamed "Hikari-No Kimi (The Prince of Brightness). At the age of twelve, Genji is married to Princess Aoi, his older cousin. He is not happy with this canny but motherly spouse. An attractive girl named Fujitsubo one day comes to the court to serve the emperor and Genji and she fall deeply in love. One reason he is attracted to her is that she resembles his dead mother. The emperor remains unaware that his concubine is having a clandestine relationship with Genji, and is able to die peaceably. His heir apparent, Genji's older half-brother, the son of the Empress Kokiden, is enthroned as the Emperor Sujaki. The number of romantic adventures a nobleman of the times had was not held against him so long as he conducted them with suitable refinement, and now Genji has relations with Utsusemi, the flirtatious wife of a provincial governor; Yugao, another roan's mistress; and Princess Suet jumu-Hana. But he remains depressed because none of them is as desirable as Fujitsubo, who has become a nun after the death of the father of the present emperor. He then falls for Fujitsubo niece, a young girl named Murasaki, while on a short visit to another town, and in order to keep her with him, he adopts her. When his wife Aoi dies after giving birth to a boy, Genji weds Murasaki. But he also has a relationship with Princess Oboro-zukiyo, the younger sister of the Empress Kokiden. Complications arise and, with remorse at parting from her, Genji is sent away to Suma. While in Suma, he is requested by the powerful clan of Akashi-Nyudo to care for Akashi-Nyudo's daughter, Princess Akashi, and she soon gives birth to a daughter. Sometime later Genji Is allowed to return to Kyoto. Fujitsubo's son becomes emperor and Genji becomes very powerful politically. Genji weds Onna Saimo-Mlya, the spoiled daughter of the Emperor Sujaku. His wife Murasaki then becomes ill and dies. However Onna Sanno-Miya has been having an affair with an aristocrat named Kashiwagi, and when she gives birth to a son soon after the wedding, Genji recoils as he recollects the similar incident in his own affair with Fujitsubo. Kashiwagi, however, is stricken with conscience, falls ill, and dies. Hearing that he is dead, Onna Sanno-Miya decides to become a nun. And Genji, too, decides to become a monk. The Authoress: Lady Murasaki was born in 978 A.D., daughter of Fujiwara-Tametoki, the governor of Echigo. From her childhood, she was in privileged circumstances as she had distinguished scholars and poets among her relatives. In 999, she married a relative, Fujiwara-Nobutaka, an officer in the Imperial Guard. She gave birth to two daughters and her husband died in 1001. During the ensuing five years she experienced hard times as she had " support her daughters while working on "The Tale of Genji" which she began to write after her husband's death. In 1004 her father was appointed Governor in Echizen, and to avoid having to take her away with him to the provinces, which would end all chances of a respectable second marriage, he arranged for Murasaki to enter the service of the Empress Akiko. She penned her experiences at court in the book "Murasaki Shikibu's Diary." It is supposed that the earlier "The Tale of Genji" was revised by various persons in later years, but it is certain she was the creator of this world-famous saga. The Director: Kon Ichikawa is world-famous for his documentary film "Tokyo Olympics," and many other films by this versatile director have been hailed by the critics and have received prizes at various international film festivals. The Players: Playing the title role is Ichizo Itami, known internationally through his roles in "55 Days at Peking" with Charlton Heston and "Lord Jim" with Peter O'Toole. First-ranking Japanese film actresses Akimo Koyama, Satomi Oka, Tamao Nakamura, Shiho Fujimura, and Junko Ikeuchi appear. Making a guest appearance is Kyoko Kishida, star of "The Woman in the Dunes", and "Kwaidan." Individual cast credits will be sent with each Program Information sheet. THE TALE OF GENJI is a National Educational Television presentation. A production of the Mainichi Broadcasting System. Executive Producer: Kazumi Takagi. Chief Director: Kon Ichiwaka. N.E.T. Producer: Lane Slate. Additional Program Information distributed August 3, 1967 "The Tale of Genji", written by Lady Murasaki Shikibu in 1008 AD, concerns a handsome Japanese prince who as later writers would have said had a definite Don Juan complex. In fact much of "The Tale of Genji" is about the Prince's amorous pursuits. Our 11th Century authoress explains (anticipating Freud by several hundreds of years) that Genji is prompted by his desire to replace his mother who died when he was young. The Prince is successful in his conquests almost without exception. We are sure you would want to be aware that the programs contain many episodes of this nature. The relationships between Genji and his ladies are frankly discussed in narration and dialogue. These facts have been set forth in the individual program descriptions, but you may also find it helpful to preview one or two samples. Additional Program Information distributed August 31, 1967 Please note that this series employs a new and unusual technique with a specially prepared English language sound track superimposed over the original Japanese track. Both tracks are audible with the English one dominating so that America viewers can follow the story and at the same time experience the unaltered performances of the Japanese actors. Program 1 NET First Showing: Week of September 3, 1967 Running Time: 01:15:51 This first of eight programs about the adventures of an 11th-century Japanese prince opens when Prince Genji is 17 years old. In the manner of his times, he has already been married and has had at least one major romantic attachment. Married at 12 to his older cousin Lady Aoi, who treats him with propriety but no affection, Genji becomes enamored of a widow, Miyasundokoro. After a year or two, his ardor cools, but she is a vengeful and jealous woman whose destructive possessiveness is to affect much of his future restless search for true affection and love. Although Genji never completely breaks with Miyasundokoro, he leaves her to set forth on the series of romantic experiences which are to characterise his life's travels. Primary among these is Fujitsubo, a lovely girl of the Court, who resembles his dead mother. He falls deeply in love with Fujitsubo, but unhappily she is a wife of his father, the Emperor. Another is the beautiful, frightened Yugao, whom he finds in the poor section of a town, and rescues. At the end of Program 1, Prince Genji takes her under his protection, and again, in accordance with the customs of his time, brings her - although secretly - into his large retinue of family and mistresses. The Cast (in alphabetical order): Yuago - Shiho Fujimura Nokiba no Ogi - Masumi Harukawa Narrator - Chieko Higashiyama Genji - Ichizo Itami Fujitsubo - Akiki Koyama Utsusemi - Tamao Nakamura O-no-Myobu - Natsukawa Koremitsu - Shiro Ohtsuji Ukon - Chicko Sakurada To-no-Chujo - Manabu Yamamoto TALE OF GENJI is a National Educational Television presentation, a production of Mainichi Broadcasting Systems. Executive Producer for Mainichi: Kazumi Takagi. Production Supervisor: Kenkichi Takagi. Writer: Sumie Tanaka. Executive Producer for National Educational Television: Lane Slate. Associate Producer for NET: Kay Chessid.
NET playhouse. The tale of Genji. [Part 1].
Mainichi Broadcasting System ; director, Kon Ichikawa ; writer, Sumie Tanaka.

THE TALE OF GENJI is a National Educational Television presentation. A production of the Mainichi Broadcasting System. Executive Producer: Kazumi Takagi. Chief Director: Kon Ichiwaka. N.E.T. Producer: Lane Slate. Additional Program Information distributed August 3, 1967 "The Tale of Genji", written by Lady Murasaki Shikibu in 1008 AD, concerns a handsome Japanese prince who as later writers would have said had a definite Don Juan complex. In fact much of "The Tale of Genji" is about the Prince's amorous pursuits. Our 11th Century authoress explains (anticipating Freud by several hundreds of years) that Genji is prompted by his desire to replace his mother who died when he was young. The Prince is successful in his conquests almost without exception. We are sure you would want to be aware that the programs contain many episodes of this nature. The relationships between Genji and his ladies are frankly discussed in narration and dialogue. These facts have been set forth in the individual program descriptions, but you may also find it helpful to preview one or two samples. Additional Program Information distributed August 31, 1967 Please note that this series employs a new and unusual technique with a specially prepared English language sound track superimposed over the original Japanese track. Both tracks are audible with the English one dominating so that America viewers can follow the story and at the same time experience the unaltered performances of the Japanese actors. Program 2 NET First Showing: Week of September 10, 1967 Running Time: 01:12:38 In Program II, Prince Genji has brought the fragile, abandoned Yugao to one of his estates in a remote locale, where their idyll is shattered by the wrath of his insanely jealous mistress, the widow Miyasundokoro. In a chilling murder scene, Miyasundokoro's living spirit kills the younger Yugao by psychic remote control. Fallen ill with grief, Genji returns to the Imperial Court. After still another polite and cool visit with his wife. Lady Aoi, he seeks out his unrequited, true love, Fujitsubo. She has gone to her country estate to recover from a brief illness. There, during this, their only intimacy, the future Crown Prince and eventual Emperor of Japan is conceived. The final Program in this second program is a charming and tender interlude in which Prince Genji dallies with an unwanted, unattractive "wallflower," and pledges his protection of her for ever and ever. The Cast (in alphabetical order): Yugao - Shiho Fujimura Narrator - Chieko Higashiyama Genji - Ichizo Itami Suetsumuhana - Atsuko Kawaguchi Kokiden - Michiyo Kogure Fujitsubo- Akiko Koyama Myobu - Tetsuko Kuroyanagi O-no-Myobu - Natsukawa Koremitsu - Shiro Ohtsuji Aoi - Satomi Oka Ukon - Chieko Sakurada Udaijin - Asai Uchida To-no-Chujo - Manabu Yamamoto Sadaijin - Eijiro Yanagi TALE OF GENJI is a National Educational Television presentation, a production of Mainichi Broadcasting Systems. Executive Producer for Mainichi: Kazumi Takagi. Production Supervisor: Kenkichi Takagi. Writers: Sumie Tanaka and Maro Hayashi. Executive Producer for National Educational Television: Lane Slate. Associate Producer: Kay Chessid.

National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche: General Series Description: "The Tale of Genji," an eight-program series, follows the adventures of the charming and irresistible Prince Genji. The series is based on the novel "The Tale of Genji," long considered one of the greatest works of fiction In Japan, and widely known In the Western world through the translation by Arthur Waley (published by George Allen and Unwin). "The Tale of Genji" was written at the beginning of the eleventh century by the Japanese authoress Murasaki Shikibu. Her voluminous romantic novel has been compared to those by Proust and Virginia Woolf, and is said to have something in it of the Irony of Jane Austen. The novel covers three generations and has more than 500 characters, but the television version, originally produced as 26 half-hour episodes, while covering the whole story, focuses on its hero, Genji. Through backdrops in the tradition of the classic Japanese theater and carefully authenticated costumes, the television plays recreate the best known Incidents In his life. Synopsis: The highly complicated plot is as follows: The second son of the emperor - born to his mistress Kiritsubo- is given an Inferior title through the empress's machinations and receives the surname of "Minamoto" (Genji). But the prince is so intelligent that he is nicknamed "Hikari-No Kimi (The Prince of Brightness). At the age of twelve, Genji is married to Princess Aoi, his older cousin. He is not happy with this canny but motherly spouse. An attractive girl named Fujitsubo one day comes to the court to serve the emperor and Genji and she fall deeply in love. One reason he is attracted to her is that she resembles his dead mother. The emperor remains unaware that his concubine is having a clandestine relationship with Genji, and is able to die peaceably. His heir apparent, Genji's older half-brother, the son of the Empress Kokiden, is enthroned as the Emperor Sujaki. The number of romantic adventures a nobleman of the times had was not held against him so long as he conducted them with suitable refinement, and now Genji has relations with Utsusemi, the flirtatious wife of a provincial governor; Yugao, another roan's mistress; and Princess Suet jumu-Hana. But he remains depressed because none of them is as desirable as Fujitsubo, who has become a nun after the death of the father of the present emperor. He then falls for Fujitsubo niece, a young girl named Murasaki, while on a short visit to another town, and in order to keep her with him, he adopts her. When his wife Aoi dies after giving birth to a boy, Genji weds Murasaki. But he also has a relationship with Princess Oboro-zukiyo, the younger sister of the Empress Kokiden. Complications arise and, with remorse at parting from her, Genji is sent away to Suma. While in Suma, he is requested by the powerful clan of Akashi-Nyudo to care for Akashi-Nyudo's daughter, Princess Akashi, and she soon gives birth to a daughter. Sometime later Genji Is allowed to return to Kyoto. Fujitsubo's son becomes emperor and Genji becomes very powerful politically. Genji weds Onna Saimo-Mlya, the spoiled daughter of the Emperor Sujaku. His wife Murasaki then becomes ill and dies. However Onna Sanno-Miya has been having an affair with an aristocrat named Kashiwagi, and when she gives birth to a son soon after the wedding, Genji recoils as he recollects the similar incident in his own affair with Fujitsubo. Kashiwagi, however, is stricken with conscience, falls ill, and dies. Hearing that he is dead, Onna Sanno-Miya decides to become a nun. And Genji, too, decides to become a monk. The Authoress: Lady Murasaki was born in 978 A.D., daughter of Fujiwara-Tametoki, the governor of Echigo. From her childhood, she was in privileged circumstances as she had distinguished scholars and poets among her relatives. In 999, she married a relative, Fujiwara-Nobutaka, an officer in the Imperial Guard. She gave birth to two daughters and her husband died in 1001. During the ensuing five years she experienced hard times as she had " support her daughters while working on "The Tale of Genji" which she began to write after her husband's death. In 1004 her father was appointed Governor in Echizen, and to avoid having to take her away with him to the provinces, which would end all chances of a respectable second marriage, he arranged for Murasaki to enter the service of the Empress Akiko. She penned her experiences at court in the book "Murasaki Shikibu's Diary." It is supposed that the earlier "The Tale of Genji" was revised by various persons in later years, but it is certain she was the creator of this world-famous saga. The Director: Kon Ichikawa is world-famous for his documentary film "Tokyo Olympics," and many other films by this versatile director have been hailed by the critics and have received prizes at various international film festivals. The Players: Playing the title role is Ichizo Itami, known internationally through his roles in "55 Days at Peking" with Charlton Heston and "Lord Jim" with Peter O'Toole. First-ranking Japanese film actresses Akimo Koyama, Satomi Oka, Tamao Nakamura, Shiho Fujimura, and Junko Ikeuchi appear. Making a guest appearance is Kyoko Kishida, star of "The Woman in the Dunes", and "Kwaidan." Individual cast credits will be sent with each Program Information sheet. THE TALE OF GENJI is a National Educational Television presentation. A production of the Mainichi Broadcasting System. Executive Producer: Kazumi Takagi. Chief Director: Kon Ichiwaka. N.E.T. Producer: Lane Slate. Additional Program Information distributed August 3, 1967 "The Tale of Genji", written by Lady Murasaki Shikibu in 1008 AD, concerns a handsome Japanese prince who as later writers would have said had a definite Don Juan complex. In fact much of "The Tale of Genji" is about the Prince's amorous pursuits. Our 11th Century authoress explains (anticipating Freud by several hundreds of years) that Genji is prompted by his desire to replace his mother who died when he was young. The Prince is successful in his conquests almost without exception. We are sure you would want to be aware that the programs contain many episodes of this nature. The relationships between Genji and his ladies are frankly discussed in narration and dialogue. These facts have been set forth in the individual program descriptions, but you may also find it helpful to preview one or two samples. Additional Program Information distributed August 31, 1967 Please note that this series employs a new and unusual technique with a specially prepared English language sound track superimposed over the original Japanese track. Both tracks are audible with the English one dominating so that America viewers can follow the story and at the same time experience the unaltered performances of the Japanese actors. Program 3 NET First Showing: Week of September 17, 1967 Running Time: 01:11:42 Prince Genji's position at the court has been imperiled by the machinations of Kokiden, one of his father's wives, whose son, not Genji, is to become Emperor. Genji's beloved, Fujitsubo is pregnant with their child, although she denies, for her own reasons, that Genji is the father. In his distraction, he turns for comfort to the beautiful Misty Moon, Kokiden younger sister, and so thoughtlessly becomes involved with a member of the opposing political faction. Meanwhile, his wife, the Lady Aio, la delivered of their son, but once again, the jealous widow, Miyasundokoro, exerts her evil spell, this time causing Lady Aio's death. Returning from his wife's funeral, Prince Genji becomes aware of the fresh charm of Fujitsubo's niece, Murasaki, and overcoming his grief over the loss of his wife and Fujitsubo's unaccountable rejection, he succumbs to Murasaki's beauty and marries her. The Cast: Murasaki - Manami Fuji Genji - Ichizo Itami Myasundakoro - Kyoko Kishida Kokiden - Michiyo Kogure Fujitsubo - Akiko Koyama Oborozukiyo (Misty Moon) - Yumiko Nogawa Aoi - Satomi Oka THE TALE OF GENJI is a presentation of National Educational Television, a production of Mainichi Broadcasting Systems. Executive Producer for Mainichi: Kazumi Takagi. Production Supervisor: Kenkichi Takagi. Writers: Sumi Tanaka and Maro Hayashi. Executive Producer for National Educational Television: Lane Slate. Associate Producer: Kay Chessid.

Program 4 NET First Showing: Week of September 24, 1967 Running Time: 01:10:29 The old Emperor, Genji's father, has abdicated and been succeeded by Kokiden's son, Sujaku, at last making Kokiden the all-powerful Empress Dowager. After sending her son to the court to be raised as befits a Crown Prince, Fujitsubo retires from the world to become a nun, but leaves the boy in the protection of Prince Genji, thereby finally admitting, albeit tacitly, that Genji is indeed the boy's father. Despite the political atmosphere, Genji persists in seeing Misty Moon, the Empress Dowager's younger sister. In fact, he allows himself to be caught with Misty Moon in Kokiden's own home. As a consequence, Genji is exiled to the Bay of Sumi, far to the north. But before he sails into exile, he bids a loving goodbye to all his lady friends, leaving his wife Murasaki and his aad Lady Aio's son, Yugiri, with the boy's grandfather, Sadaijin. Program 5 NET First Showing: Week of October 1, 1967 Running Time: 01:13:58 A fortune teller has predicted that Genji would father three children: a daughter, who would become Empress; a son, who would become Emperor; and another son, who was to become Prime Minister. At the beginning of Program No. 5, Genji has been in exile in the North for several years. His long exile has given him an opportunity to reflect on his past life end misdeeds, and he comes to feel that all of his life has been mysteriously cursed. However, his exile has not been spent solely in contemplation, for a young lady of Akashi, the accomplished, but refreshingly tomboy daughter of a nobleman-turned-monk from a neighboring village, was able to comfort his loneliness. During a family celebration of the forthcoming birth of a child to Genji and the young lady of Akashi, a messenger arrives to recall the Prince to the capital. The Emperor, Genji's older brother, is ill. He wants to abdicate in favor of Fujitsubo's son, the Crown Prince Reizei, and appoint Genji as Regent. Of course unknown to all but a privy few, Reizei's true father Is Genji, himself. Arriving at the capital, Genji finds much fear and apprehension, for the country has been afflicted by many disasters which everyone blames on the appearance of a strange comet. Genji, however, is afraid his "accursed destiny" is the real cause. Meanwhile, his wife Murasaki has found out about Genji's liaison-in-exile, and invites the Lady Akashi to send hers and Genji's young daughter to the Palace to be raised in the proper atmosphere. The child Emperor's mother, Fujitsubo, now on her deathbed, sends for Genji and once again pleads with him not to reveal that he is the Emperor's real father. But the young Emperor Reizei finds out the truth from an old Monk and threatens to abdicate and relinquish his throne to Prince Genji. Once again, Genji despairs of the curse on his fortunes. Cast: Genji - Ichizo Itami Lady of Akashi - Jitsuko Yoshimura Murasaki - Manami Fuji Fujitsubo - Akiko Koyama The Tale of Genji is a National Educational Television presentation, a production of Mainichi Broadcasting Systems. Executive Producer for Mainichi: Kazumi Takagi. Production Supervisor: Kenkichi Takagi. Writer: Sumi Tanaka. Executive Producer for NET: Lane Slate. Associate Producer for NET: Kay Chessid.

While in Suma, he is requested by the powerful clan of Akashi-Nyudo to care for Akashi-Nyudo's daughter, Princess Akashi, and she soon gives birth to a daughter. Sometime later Genji Is allowed to return to Kyoto. Fujitsubo's son becomes emperor and Genji becomes very powerful politically. Genji weds Onna Saimo-Mlya, the spoiled daughter of the Emperor Sujaku. His wife Murasaki then becomes ill and dies. However Onna Sanno-Miya has been having an affair with an aristocrat named Kashiwagi, and when she gives birth to a son soon after the wedding, Genji recoils as he recollects the similar incident in his own affair with Fujitsubo. Kashiwagi, however, is stricken with conscience, falls ill, and dies. Hearing that he is dead, Onna Sanno-Miya decides to become a nun. And Genji, too, decides to become a monk. The Authoress: Lady Murasaki was born in 978 A.D., daughter of Fujiwara-Tametoki, the governor of Echigo. From her childhood, she was in privileged circumstances as she had distinguished scholars and poets among her relatives. In 999, she married a relative, Fujiwara-Nobutaka, an officer in the Imperial Guard. She gave birth to two daughters and her husband died in 1001. During the ensuing five years she experienced hard times as she had " support her daughters while working on "The Tale of Genji" which she began to write after her husband's death. In 1004 her father was appointed Governor in Echizen, and to avoid having to take her away with him to the provinces, which would end all chances of a respectable second marriage, he arranged for Murasaki to enter the service of the Empress Akiko. She penned her experiences at court in the book "Murasaki Shikibu's Diary." It is supposed that the earlier "The Tale of Genji" was revised by various persons in later years, but it is certain she was the creator of this world-famous saga. The Director: Kon Ichikawa is world-famous for his documentary film "Tokyo Olympics," and many other films by this versatile director have been hailed by the critics and have received prizes at various international film festivals. The Players: Playing the title role is Ichizo Itami, known internationally through his roles in "55 Days at Peking" with Charlton Heston and "Lord Jim" with Peter O'Toole. First-ranking Japanese film actresses Akimo Koyama, Satomi Oka, Tamao Nakamura, Shiho Fujimura, and Junko Ikeuchi appear. Making a guest appearance is Kyoko Kishida, star of "The Woman in the Dunes", and "Kwaidan." Individual cast credits will be sent with each Program Information sheet. THE TALE OF GENJI is a National Educational Television presentation. A production of the Mainichi Broadcasting System. Executive Producer: Kazumi Takagi. Chief Director: Kon Ichiwaka. N.E.T. Producer: Lane Slate. Additional Program Information distributed August 3, 1967 "The Tale of Genji", written by Lady Murasaki Shikibu in 1008 AD, concerns a handsome Japanese prince who as later writers would have said had a definite Don Juan complex. In fact much of "The Tale of Genji" is about the Prince's amorous pursuits. Our 11th Century authoress explains (anticipating Freud by several hundreds of years) that Genji is prompted by his desire to replace his mother who died when he was young. The Prince is successful in his conquests almost without exception. We are sure you would want to be aware that the programs contain many episodes of this nature. The relationships between Genji and his ladies are frankly discussed in narration and dialogue. These facts have been set forth in the individual program descriptions, but you may also find it helpful to preview one or two samples. Additional Program Information distributed August 31, 1967 Please note that this series employs a new and unusual technique with a specially prepared English language sound track superimposed over the original Japanese track. Both tracks are audible with the English one dominating so that America viewers can follow the story and at the same time experience the unaltered performances of the Japanese actors. Program 6 NET First Showing: Week of October 8, 1967 Running Time: 01:10:35 Prince Genji's first-born son, Yugiri, now a young man, baa been raised on the estate of his grandfather, Sadaijin, along with his cousin Kari, daughter of Chujo, Genji's old friend. The two young people have grown to love each other, but Chujo, who has long been jealous of Genji, opposes the match. A family servant, Ukon, on a visit to a temple in the country, discovers the whereabouts of Tamakazura, the now-grown daughter of Genji's secret mistress, the fragile, murdered Yugao. Tamakazura was the offspring of a clandestine alliance between Yugao and Chujo, and Genii had been searching for her ever since Yugao's untimely death (Program 2). Fearing that Chujo would be embarrassed by her sudden appearance, Genji offers to raise the beautiful maiden as his own daughter. But having the girl in his household proves somewhat complicated, for although she has many suitors, Genji finds himself also attracted to her. In addition, Chujo, hearing of the beauty of Genji's new "daughter," grows even more jealous of his friend, while the girl, disturbed by Genji's unwelcome attentions, wishes to meet her real father. Finally, Genji overcomes Chujo's refusal to participate in Tamakazura's coming-of-age ritual party. In a moving scene, Genji reveals quietly and secretly to his old friend, that Tamakazura is Chujo's very own daughter. Cast: Genji - Ichizo Itami Tamakazura - Chiyoko Honma Murasaki - Manami Fuji Chujo - Choichiro Kawasaki Yugiri - Masakazu Tamura Kari - Yumiko Tokonoe Ukon - Chieko Sakurada THE TALE OF GENJI is a National Educational Television presentation, a production of Mainichi Broadcasting Systems. Executive Producer for Mainichi: Kazumi Takagi. Production Supervisor: Kenkichi Takagi. Writer: Sumie Tanaka. Executive Producer for NET: Lane Slate. Associate Producer for NET: Kay Chessid.

From NET microfiche: General Series Description: "The Tale of Genji," an eight-program series, follows the adventures of the charming and irresistible Prince Genji. The series is based on the novel "The Tale of Genji," long considered one of the greatest works of fiction In Japan, and widely known In the Western world through the translation by Arthur Waley (published by George Allen and Unwin). "The Tale of Genji" was written at the beginning of the eleventh century by the Japanese authoress Murasaki Shikibu. Her voluminous romantic novel has been compared to those by Proust and Virginia Woolf, and is said to have something in it of the Irony of Jane Austen. The novel covers three generations and has more than 500 characters, but the television version, originally produced as 26 half-hour episodes, while covering the whole story, focuses on its hero, Genji. Through backdrops in the tradition of the classic Japanese theater and carefully authenticated costumes, the television plays recreate the best known Incidents In his life. Synopsis: The highly complicated plot is as follows: The second son of the emperor - born to his mistress Kiritsubo- is given an Inferior title through the empress's machinations and receives the surname of "Minamoto" (Genji). But the prince is so intelligent that he is nicknamed "Hikari-No Kimi (The Prince of Brightness). At the age of twelve, Genji is married to Princess Aoi, his older cousin. He is not happy with this canny but motherly spouse. An attractive girl named Fujitsubo one day comes to the court to serve the emperor and Genji and she fall deeply in love. One reason he is attracted to her is that she resembles his dead mother. The emperor remains unaware that his concubine is having a clandestine relationship with Genji, and is able to die peaceably. His heir apparent, Genji's older half-brother, the son of the Empress Kokiden, is enthroned as the Emperor Sujaki. The number of romantic adventures a nobleman of the times had was not held against him so long as he conducted them with suitable refinement, and now Genji has relations with Utsusemi, the flirtatious wife of a provincial governor; Yugao, another roan's mistress; and Princess Suet jumu-Hana. But he remains depressed because none of them is as desirable as Fujitsubo, who has become a nun after the death of the father of the present emperor. He then falls for Fujitsubo niece, a young girl named Murasaki, while on a short visit to another town, and in order to keep her with him, he adopts her. When his wife Aoi dies after giving birth to a boy, Genji weds Murasaki. But he also has a relationship with Princess Oboro-zukiyo, the younger sister of the Empress Kokiden. Complications arise and, with remorse at parting from her, Genji is sent away to Suma. While in Suma, he is requested by the powerful clan of Akashi-Nyudo to care for Akashi-Nyudo's daughter, Princess Akashi, and she soon gives birth to a daughter. Sometime later Genji Is allowed to return to Kyoto. Fujitsubo's son becomes emperor and Genji becomes very powerful politically. Genji weds Onna Saimo-Mlya, the spoiled daughter of the Emperor Sujaku. His wife Murasaki then becomes ill and dies. However Onna Sanno-Miya has been having an affair with an aristocrat named Kashiwagi, and when she gives birth to a son soon after the wedding, Genji recoils as he recollects the similar incident in his own affair with Fujitsubo. Kashiwagi, however, is stricken with conscience, falls ill, and dies. Hearing that he is dead, Onna Sanno-Miya decides to become a nun. And Genji, too, decides to become a monk. The Authoress: Lady Murasaki was born in 978 A.D., daughter of Fujiwara-Tametoki, the governor of Echigo. From her childhood, she was in privileged circumstances as she had distinguished scholars and poets among her relatives. In 999, she married a relative, Fujiwara-Nobutaka, an officer in the Imperial Guard. She gave birth to two daughters and her husband died in 1001. During the ensuing five years she experienced hard times as she had " support her daughters while working on "The Tale of Genji" which she began to write after her husband's death. In 1004 her father was appointed Governor in Echizen, and to avoid having to take her away with him to the provinces, which would end all chances of a respectable second marriage, he arranged for Murasaki to enter the service of the Empress Akiko. She penned her experiences at court in the book "Murasaki Shikibu's Diary." It is supposed that the earlier "The Tale of Genji" was revised by various persons in later years, but it is certain she was the creator of this world-famous saga. The Director: Kon Ichikawa is world-famous for his documentary film "Tokyo Olympics," and many other films by this versatile director have been hailed by the critics and have received prizes at various international film festivals. The Players: Playing the title role is Ichizo Itami, known internationally through his roles in "55 Days at Peking" with Charlton Heston and "Lord Jim" with Peter O'Toole. First-ranking Japanese film actresses Akimo Koyama, Satomi Oka, Tamao Nakamura, Shiho Fujimura, and Junko Ikeuchi appear. Making a guest appearance is Kyoko Kishida, star of "The Woman in the Dunes", and "Kwaidan." Individual cast credits will be sent with each Program Information sheet. THE TALE OF GENJI is a National Educational Television presentation. A production of the Mainichi Broadcasting System. Executive Producer: Kazumi Takagi. Chief Director: Kon Ichiwaka. N.E.T. Producer: Lane Slate. Additional Program Information distributed August 3, 1967 "The Tale of Genji", written by Lady Murasaki Shikibu in 1008 AD, concerns a handsome Japanese prince who as later writers would have said had a definite Don Juan complex. In fact much of "The Tale of Genji" is about the Prince's amorous pursuits. Our 11th Century authoress explains (anticipating Freud by several hundreds of years) that Genji is prompted by his desire to replace his mother who died when he was young. The Prince is successful in his conquests almost without exception. We are sure you would want to be aware that the programs contain many episodes of this nature. The relationships between Genji and his ladies are frankly discussed in narration and dialogue. These facts have been set forth in the individual program descriptions, but you may also find it helpful to preview one or two samples. Additional Program Information distributed August 31, 1967 Please note that this series employs a new and unusual technique with a specially prepared English language sound track superimposed over the original Japanese track. Both tracks are audible with the English one dominating so that America viewers can follow the story and at the same time experience the unaltered performances of the Japanese actors. Program 7 NET First Showing: Week of October 15, 1967 Running Time: 01:13:34 Rivalry continues for the hand of the beautiful Tamakazura who has meanwhile secured the highest position at court a lady can attain. Henji persists in pressing his unwanted attentions on her. At last, fearing that eventually she will be forced to submit to Genji, Tamakazura consents to be the second wife of the uncouth but powerful General Higekuro (Blackbeard). However, it is only after Blackbeard's first wife leaves him, taking their children with her, that Tamakazura agrees to join him as his formal wife. The new generation attains maturity. Genji's daughter, Akashi, has been introduced at court and at last, having overcome Chujo's opposition to marriage between their children Yugiri and Kari, Genji has also succeeded in ending their own old rivalry. Genji feels old age approaching and once more, as he has before in moments of despair, is tempted to retire and become a monk. As Lady Murasaki is trying to dissuade him, a message comes from the Emperor announcing that Genji is to be awarded the unprecedented honor of the title: Honorary Ex-Emperor. The cloud of his mother's commoner background is to be lifted. He shall no longer be considered a commoner, but a true son of his late father, the old Emperor. Now, yet another marriage is arranged for the aging Genji: This time with the spoiled, pampered Princess Sannomiya, favorite daughter of Genji's older brother, the ex-Emperor Sujaku. Genji is the only male of sufficient rank to become her husband, and this time, it is truly against Genji's wishes. The over-indulged, petulant young girl refuses to fit into his household and, indeed attracts the attention of Kashawagi, a married son of Chujo. When Genji takes the ailing Murasaki to the country to try to recover her health, Kashawagi takes advantage of his absence to visit the spoiled but still innocent Sannomiya. The Cast: Genji - Ichizo Itami Tamakazura - Chiyoko Honma Higekuro (Blackbeard) - Jiro Ishizaki Yugiri - Masakazu Tamura Kari - Yukimo Kokonoe Ex-Emperor Sujaku - Mashahiko Arima Princess Sannomiya - Mariko Kaga Murasaki - Manami Fuji Kashiwagi - Choichiro Kawarazaki The Tale of Genji is a National Educational Television presentation, a production of Mainichi Broadcasting Systems. Executive Producer for Mainichi: Kazumi Takagi. Writer: Sumi Tanaka. Executive Producer for NET: Lane Slate. Associate Producer for NET: Kay Chessid. Program 8 NET First Showing: Week of October 22, 1967 Running Time: 01:15:24 In the country, Genji's ailing wife, Lady Murasaki, who uncomplainingly has born all his adventures with other women, pleads with him to let her become a nun. Suddenly he is called back to the Palace by news that his new wife, the Princess Sannomiya, is ill, to find on his arrival that the pampered girl just wanted attention and wasn't sick at all. But then news comes that Murasaki has died in his absence. In grief, he rushes back to the country only to find her spirit battling for life. The evil spirit of his dead mistress Miyasundakozo had reached out from beyond her grave to wreak revenge on Genji's formal wife, but his prayers defeat the evil ghost of Miyasundakozo and restore Murasaki to life. Meanwhile, back at the Palace Princess Sannomiya finds she is going to have Kashawagi's child, a result of their illicit meeting while Genji was away with Murasaki. Genji is aware of the compromising situation and who is responsible for it. Although he feels that somehow this, again, is retribution for his forbidden affair with Fujitsubo, he cannot forgive Kashawagi. Unshriven, Kashawagi dies of remorse. When Sannomiya''s son is born, she is totally uninterested in him, and unprepared for life as she has been, she becomes a nun. Murasaki's health continues to fail and, in a last farewell scene, blind and dying, she says goodbye to her beloved Genji. At her death, Genji realizes at last that in all the women he has known throughout his life, he has been searching for a dream woman in the Image or his mother, the irresistible and beautiful mistress of the old Emperor, his father. He acknowledges the error of his life in a scene with the ghost of the dead Fujitsubo, his first love. Finally, recognizing that he is old and at the end of his life, Genji dismisses all his servants, and his old friend, Chuji, finds him alone burning all his old love letters. In the spring of his 41st year, Prince Genji disappeared. Some people say he went into seclusion at Sagano. Others say he went to the North. And still others say he became a monk in the remote regions. There are other rumors, too - one, in fact, that he became immortal. The Cast: Genji - Ichizo Itami Princess Sannomiya - Mariko Kaga Murasaki - Manami Fuji Kashiwagi - Choichiro Kawarazaki Fujitsubo - Akiko Kayama The Tale of Genji is a National Educational Television presentation, a production of Mainichi Broadcasting Systems. Executive Producer for Mainichi: Kazumi Takagi. Writer: Sumie Tanaka. Executive Producer for NET: Lane Slate. Associate Producer for NET: Kay Chessid.

From NET microfiche: Twelve-year-old Martin Palmer, the only child of a minister and his wife, has stumbled on an ancient book of witchcraft. The youth who is unusually bright seems to be courting the attention of his busy, preoccupied parents, as he turns to the realms of sorcery. But he is gradually consumed by fantasies of the power promised by the conjuring up of evil spells, and he sets out to put a curse on two of his teachers at school who have attempted to discipline him. A tin whistle becomes a symbol to him of his increasing evil powers. "The Tin Whistle" was written especially for television and was the third of six plays chosen for production by NET Pittsburgh affiliate WQED in the station's contest for new television scripts underwritten by the Aluminum Company of America. The part of young Martin is played by John Tragard, who also took the lead part in the second WQED-ALCOA play, "Ofoeti," which was broadcast by NET Playhouse several seasons ago. "The Tin Whistle" was directed by William Francisco who was responsible also for the direction of "Ofoeti." The Cast: Martin Palmer - John Tragard The Rev. Tom Palmer - Edd K. Gasper Harriet Palmer - Ann Gladmon George Putnam - Jerry Smith Lucy Conner - Donna Knauber Margaret Rice - Barbara Bosson Wilbur D. Carmichael - Vic Mangan Melvin Barkley - Will Disney Wilma Hennessey - Ann Muffly Producer and director: William Francisco Musical score: Joe Negri Cinematographer: Joseph Pytka Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET Playhouse - "The Tin Whistle" -- Richard S. Burdick's prize-winning play about an adolescent boy who uses ancient witchcraft to put a curse on two of his teachers at school. NET Playhouse - "The Tin Whistle" is a National Educational Television presentation. It was produced and directed by William Francisco for WQED, Pittsbsurgh. Producer for NET for January 9, 1969 original broadcast: Kay Chessid. Producer for NET for December 4, 1969 rebroadcast: Janet Sternburg. Filler Information: 10 minute fill which will bring "The Tin Whistle" up to the announced program length. Eugene Atget (1856-1927): A short film showing a selection of the famous photographs by Atget, the French photographer who documented Paris during the turn-of-the-century and whose photographs of "La Belle Epoche" became famous only after his death in 1927. The soundtrack consists of music from the "Trois Gymnopedies" by Erik Satie, a contemporary and compatriot of Atget's.
WQED ; producer-director, William Francisco ; writer, Richard S. Burdick.

From NET microfiche, file T: Filler information for NET Playhouse #186: The Trail of Tears: Filler material accompanying "The Trail of Tears" will be 19 -minute (approx.) black & white film entitled "Redwoods," produced by the Sierra Club, a noted conservationist group. This documentary, directed by Trevor Greenwood and Mark Harris, won the 1967 Academy Award for best short subject documentary. From Wikipedia: The Redwoods is a 1967 American short documentary film produced by Trevor Greenwood and Mark Jonathan Harris. It was produced for the Sierra Club as part of their campaign for a national park to protect the redwood forest. In 1968, it won an Academy Award at the 40th Academy Awards for Documentary Short Subject.
Sierra Club ; directors, Trevor Greenwood, Mark Harris.

From NET microfiche, file W: The Play: "The Walls of Jericho" was first staged in London in 1904 and established its author, Alfred Sutro, as a leading playwright of the time. It is the story of a self-made man of integrity who marries into Edwardian high society and finds it shallow and lacking what he considers to be proper values. Fighting Jack Frobisher made his fortune at sheep farming in Australia and with his wealth, bought his way into London society, and married the highborn but extravagant and vain Alethea, who amuses herself with flirtations, gambling, and scandal. After three years, he finds himself utterly bored with both his wife and with high society, and he determines to return to Australia. In a final effort to reform his wife, he threatens to take their small son with him. Faced with the awful prospect of losing her child as well as her husband, Alethea regains her seemingly lost sense of honor and fidelity and she departs for Australia with Jack and their boy. The Cast: Jack Frobisher - Patrick Allen Alethea Frobisher - Diana Fairfax Lady Lucy Derenham - Nerys Hughes Lady Westeby - Barbara Couper Hankey Bannister - Fulton Mackay The Marquis of Steventon - Austin Trevor Harry Dallas - Barrie Ingham Kiss Tina Mornington - Mary Webster The Author: Alfred Sutro was born in London in 1863, the son of a doctor. His grandfather was a chief Rabbi, who brought up a family of eight on an income of 30 pounds (about $150) a year. After fourteen years in a London office, he gave up business and went to Paris with his wife, an artist, to concentrate on full-time writing. His first plays were rejected and he lived by doing translations and writing for newspapers and magazines. It took him only six weeks to write "The Walls of Jericho" but it took him another two years to get it on the stage, for it was considered rather "daring." When he finally opened at the Garrick Theatre in London in 1904, it was an immediate success and ran for fifteen months. "I have written better plays," wrote Sutro, "but there is none I hold so dearly as the old 'Walls.' It went to the heart of the people." Sutro died in 1933 at the age of 70. NET Playhouse - "The Walls of Jericho" is a National Educational Television presentation, produced for Granada TV by Stuart Latham. It was directed by Howard Baker and designed by Peter Phillips. Producer for NET is Kay Chessid. Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET Playhouse - "The Walls of Jericho" a drama by the Edwardian playwright, Alfred Sutro, about a self-made man who buys his way into London high society and discovers that he is bored with it and with his selfish, high-society wife.
NET playhouse. The walls of Jericho.

From NET microfiche, file W: Lotte Lenya is joined by actor George Voskovec to pay tribute to her late husband, the great composer Kurt Weill. Together in words and music they recreate the story of his life. Weill (1900 - 1950) was born in Germany. He spent the first part of his career studying and writing symphonic and chamber music. In the mid-1920s he turned his talents to the theater, the beginning of a prolific career as a successful and often controversial composer of opera, ballet, and musicals. Weill and Lenya left Germany in 1933, and after a brief stay in Paris, came to the United States. In Germany, Weill's most famous collaborations had been with Bertolt Brecht ("The Rise and Fall of the City of Mahagonny, " "The Three Penny Opera"). In the United States he collaborated with Paul Green, Moss Hart, Maxwell Anderson and other great librettists, and his output included the Broadway hits "Lady in the Dark," "One Touch of Venus," and "Lost in the Stars." In the program Miss Lenya sings: "Alabama Song," "Havana Song," "Mac the Knife," "Pirate Jenny," "Bilbao Song," "Surabaya Johnny," "To Potsdam," "Song of the Goddess," "Greenup Time," "September Song," "Saga of Jenny," "Lonely House," "Foolish Heart," and "Lost in the Stars." THE WORLD OF KURT WEILL, a production of WGBH, Boston for National Educational Television. Producer-Director: David M. Davis. Musical Director: Gershon Kingsley. Narrative: George Tabori. . Music: Cambridge Festival Orchestra. Suggested Newspaper Listing: N. E. T. PLAYHOUSE -- THE WORLD OF KURT WEILL: Lotte Lenya pays tribute in words and music to her late husband. Kurt Weill. Songs include "Mac the Knife," "September Song" and "Lost in the Stars." With actor George Voskovec.
NET playhouse. The world of Kurt Weill.

From NET microfiche: Jennette Dowling and Francis Letton, two American writers, chose the momentous years in English history, 1547 to 1558, from the death of Henry VIII to the accession of his daughter, the young Elizabeth, for the setting of their play, "The Young Elizabeth." Power politics in the sixteenth century were such that loyalties changed at the drop of an axe, and the successful politician was the man who could keep his head while all about him were literally losing theirs. The events of the play focus on Elizabeth who is shown to be, even as a girl, imperious, high-spirited, and with a touch of ruthlessness that would see her through the dark days when she was shut away in the Tower of London. The uncertainty of the political situation on Henry VIII's death forces his widow, Catherine Parr, to move from court to take up residence in Chelsea. With her she takes her new husband, Thomas Seymour, brother of the Duke of Somerset, who becomes Protector of the Realm during the reign of his sickly nephew Edward VI. When Elizabeth joins them at Chelsea, her passionate nature leads her into an affair with Thomas which ends, after a vicious scandal, with Thomas' death on the Tower block. With the accession of her half-sister, "Bloody" Mary, Elizabeth again finds herself the center of intrigue as factions at court try, by open rebellion, to unseat the fanatical Queen who would marry a Spaniard (Phillip II) and burn her subjects as heretics. In spite of Elizabeth's own personal ambition, the glory of England remains uppermost in her mind, and it is her resolution and courage in the face of personal danger that equip her finally for her illustrious reign as Elizabeth I. The cast of British actors is headed by Valerie Gearon (as Elizabeth Tudor), Katharine Blake (as Mary Tudor), Gwen Cherrell (as Katherine Parr), Scott Forbes (as Thomas Seymour), and Cyril Luckham (as Bishop Gardiner). The Cast: Lord William Howard - Rolf Lefebvre Guard - Robert Croudace Page - Guy Ross Thomas Seymour - Scott Forbes Lord Robert Tyrwhitt - Hugh Paddick Katherine Parr - Gwen Cherrell Mary Tudor - Katharine Blake Bishop Gardiner - Cyril Luckham William Cecil - Douglas Milvain Amy - Patricia Samuels Katherine Ashley - Madeleine Christie Elizabeth Tudor - Valerie Gearon Robert Dudley - Michael Johnson Thomas Parry - Newton Blick Lady Tyrwhitt - Margaret Denyer Sir Thomas Wyatt - Victor Winding Sir Francis Verney - Michael Graham Sir Peter Carew - Michael Lynch Gaoler - Michael Allaby First gentlewoman - Vickie Climas Second gentlewoman - Ellen Sheean NET Playhouse - "The Young Elizabeth" is a National Educational Television presentation, produced by Cedric Messina for the British Broadcasting Corporation. It was directed by Charles Jarrott, designed by Marilyn Taylor. Costumes were created by Joyce Hammond. Producer for NET: Kay Chessid.

From NET microfiche, file T: Jean Anouilh is one of France's most popular living playwrights, although few of his plays are known in the United States. "Antigone," "Ring around the Moon," "The Rehearsal," and "Madmoiselle Colombe," were produced in New York City during the 50s, and "Thieves' Carnival" had a successful off-Broadway production in 1955. "Traveller without Luggage" enjoyed a brief run in New York City in 1964, with Ben Gazzara in the starring role of Gaston. Concealed beneath a witty, satiric, and facile style, all of Anouilh's large body of dramatic works gives expression to a recurrent theme - the purity and innocence of youth is fragile and unreal, actual human existence is ugly, corrupt, and sordid. Frequently disguised or pretended identity symbolizes this conflict between unreality and reality, between beauty and ugliness. "Traveller without Luggage," was written in 1936 and first performed at the Theatre des Mathurins in Paris in February, 1937. This TV version was translated from the French by the late British dramatist John Whiting ("The Devils") and adapted for television by the actor and writer, Peter Donat. Unlike the stage play, which is set entirely in the home of the wealthy Renaud family, the TV adaptation opens in the French asylum where a young man, suffering from amnesia, has been since he suffered a head wound in World War I. "Gaston," as he is called, leads an eventless existence in his prison-like surroundings, an existence interrupted only by the demands of the asylum staff and the unwelcome visits of people who claim he is their long-lost son or husband. He resists these pressures by withdrawing deep into himself, showing no desire to learn who he really is and thus be forced to return to life. But he is "rescued" by La Duchesse, the aristocratic lady, bountiful, who introduces him into the Renaud family. The Renauds believe him to be their son Jacques and they try every means they know to awaken his memories of the past. Gradually "Gaston" begins to realize that Jacques was something of a monster. Although he says he can remember nothing, he continues to explore Jacques' past with growing horror. Whether "Gaston" is in fact Jacques is never made clear, for in the end he accepts the identity of nephew to a young boy who was left a fortune providing he could find his long-lost, much older nephew. Gordon Pinsent, who stars as "Gaston," has appeared in a variety of dramatic roles for the Canadian Broadcasting Company and provided the commentary for many of their documentaries. He was the star of a long-run, successful dramatic series for the CBC. Mr. Pinseat played a feature role in the film "The Thomas Crown Affair" and will be seen in the soon-to-be-released movie "The Colossus." The Cast: "Gaston" - Gordon Pinsent Madame Renaud - Hilary Vernon Georges - Hugh Webster Valet - Kenneth Dight Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET Playhouse - "Traveller without Luggage" - Peter Donat's television adaptation of Jean Anouilh's drama about a man with no past and no identity. Gordon Pinsent stars as the amnesia victim, Gaston. NET Playhouse - "Traveller without Luggage" - is a National Educational Television presentation, produced and directed for the Canadian Broadcasting Company by Herbert Roland. It was translated by John Whiting and adapted for television by Peter Donat. Executive producer: Robert Allen. Producer for NET is Janet Sternburg.
