From NET microfiche, file T: an eight-minute Polish animated black and white short entitled "The Kidnappers." There is no dialogue. Using a skillfully animated puppet technique, the film tells the story of four little boys spirited away from their mothers in the park by dark-cloaked kidnappers. Once the kids are installed in the hideout, they bang on the table, refusing to eat anything but cake. They play rock music at a deafening pitch. They pretend that they are asleep, and then begin wailing. In short, they make life absolutely miserable for their captors. In despair the kidnappers bundle them up again and return them to their mothers. And when the kidnappers return to their hideout, they find a patrol wagon waiting for them. The kids have outwitted them still another time.
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche: Laurence Olivier's production of Anton Chekhov's "Uncle Vanya" was originally performed at the Chichester Festival Theatre, Sussex, England. Considered one of the finest drama productions of the 20th century, it has been recorded for television in its entirety with the original stage cast. "Uncle Vanya" is the tragic story of people thwarted and broken by their sensitivity and the perception of their own unrealized potentialities. A play in four acts set on the estate of a retired professor, "Uncle Vanya" concerns: " The professor himself, Alexander Serebryakov, a selfish, demanding man who has returned to the estate to write his masterpiece. " His beautiful young second wife, Ilyena, who "married him for love. I was attracted by him as a learned, celebrated man. It was not real love, it was all made up, but I fancied at the time it was real " " His first wife's mother, Marya Voynitsky. " His first wife's brother, Uncle Vanya, who for 25 years has selflessly administered the estate, made is solvent, and sent money to the professor in return for a "beggarly wage." " The doctor, a regular visitor to the estate. " And Sonya, the professor's plain daughter by his first wife, who has assisted her Uncle Vanya on the estate, and who is in love with the doctor, though he does not return her feelings. The return of the professor and his young wife disrupts the quiet routine of the household and the feelings of the characters. Uncle Vanya, and the doctor to a lesser extent, fall in love with Ilyena. The professor's overbearing inconsiderate ways become increasingly difficult to bear by all. Uncle Vanya in particular realizes that he has held illusions about the professor that "he is utterly unknown, he is nothing - a soap bubble. And I have been cheated ." Matters are brought to ahead when the professor announces he intends to sell the estate, without considering the feelings of, or the future of, those who have given their lives to it. Uncle Vanya takes two shots at the professor, but misses. This action causes the professor and Ilyena to leave. The doctor, in order to spare Sonya's feelings, professor and Ilyena to leave. The doctor, in order to spare Sonya's feelings will no longer come to call, and the lives of those remaining go on without change, with the characters looking forward to a time when, at last, they may rest. The Cast: Marina (the nurse) - Sybil Thorndike Astrov (the doctor) -Laurence Olivier Voynitsky (Uncle Vanya) - Michael Redgrave Serebyakov (Professor) - Max Adrian Telyegin (a landowner reduced to poverty) - Lewis Casson Sonya (Professor's daughter) - Joan Plowright Ilyena (Professor's second wife) - Rosemary Harris Marya Voynitsky (Maman) - Fay Compton UNCLE VANYA is a National Educational Television presentation, produced by British Home Entertainment, Ltd., in association with the Chichester Festival Theatre. Directed for television by Stuart Burge. Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET PLAYHOUSE - UNCLE VANYA: Laurence Olivier's production of this Chekhov classic, as performed at the Chichester Festival Theatre, England. Considered one of the finest drama productions of the 20th century, it stars Olivier himself, Sybil Thorndike, Michael Redgrave, Joan Plowright, and other well-known actors.
British Home Entertainment, Ltd.; in association with the Chichester Television Theatre ; National Educational Television presentation ; directed for television by Stuart Burge.
National Educational Television and Radio Center

"Unman, Wittering & Zigo," a sinister comedy by the late British playwright, Giles Cooper, will be given its American television premiere on NET Playhouse ____ at ____ on Channel ____. At his untimely and accidental death last year, Cooper was one of England's most prolific writers and was widely known in the worlds of radio, television, and the stage as a master craftsman and a dramatist much concerned with contemporary problems. His play "Everything in the Garden" has been adapted for Broadway by Edward Albee and is currently running in New York. When "Unman, Wittering & Zigo" first appeared before television audiences in England, the London Times described it as "hilariously sinister crisply lucid literate writing." The Daily Mirror wrote: "For tension, writing, acting and direction, I give this play ten out of ten," and the Daily Mail called Giles Cooper "a master of creating tension and menace below dialogue brimming over with high spirits." The title of the play is taken from the last three names on the roll of a class of English schoolboys, whose school master has just died in a mysterious accident. When young and idealistic John Ebony arrives as the replacement teacher and tries to discipline the strangely unruly lot, he quickly learns who is real master of the class. They tell him that when his predecessor also tried to punish them, he was pushed off of a cliff. Although the cast of "Unman, Wittering & Zigo" is headed by professional British actors Peter Blythe (John Ebony), John Sharp (Cary Farthingale), Peter Howell (Headmaster) and Tamara Hinchco (Nadia), the real "stars" of the play are the 17 school boys themselves. These naturally inexperienced young actors were handpicked by director Donald McWhinnie (who staged both the London and New York productions of Pinter's "The Caretaker"), and welded into such a dramatically effective unit that, despite complications of so many over-lapping lines and so many diverse scenes, the entire play was recorded without a single break and with no re-takes. NET Playhouse - "Unman, Wittering & Zigo," a National Educational Television presentation, was produced for the British Broadcasting Corporation by Cedric Messina. Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET Playhouse - "Unman, Wittering and Zigo" - a sinister comedy by the late British playwright Giles Cooper, about a young teacher who arrives to take over the class of schoolboys whose former schoolmaster has just recently died in a mysterious fall over a cliff.
NET playhouse. Unman, Wittering and Zigo.

From NET microfiche (U): Nearly an hour of amusement in the urbane company of Peter Ustinov, the well-known and versatile actor-writer-director. Mr. Ustinov is joined by Dudley Moore (of "Beyond the Fringe" fame), Antony Hopkins, and Bernard Keeffe, in the fun of improvising on musical themes. Totally unrehearsed and unprepared, they invent whole musical items on the spot, perform satires of instrumentalists, and do a collection of hilarious "interviews" with composers of different nations. Bernard Keeffe is the interviewer, while Peter Ustinov becomes a Russian composer, a German composer of electronic music, an American composer, and a doddering English composer. As a finale, Ustinov and Dudley Moore collaborate on an "instant" commercial opera, "Madame Chatterfly," based on "Lady Chatterley's Lover." Followed by filler program: Play Bach with Jacques Loussier's Play Bach trio, performing Johann Sebastian Bach's chorale "Sleepers wake." (approximately 7 minutes)
a production of the British Broadcasting Corporation ; a National Educational Television presentation ; executive producer, Stephen Hearst ; producer-director, Francis Coleman.

From NET microfiche (V): General Description of Series: "Victoria Regina" - a four-play series about one of the western world's most influential women - will have its American television premiere in "NET Playhouse" this fall. Based on the dramatic biography by Laurence Housman, himself a subject of Queen Victoria, these television plays trace the great English monarch's reign from her accession to the death of her uncle and predecessor, William IV, through her marriage to Prince Albert, his death, and the last years of her long reign. The four plays are "Spring," "Summer," "Autumn," and "Winter." Patricia Routledge plays the part of Victoria, a demanding role in which the actress has to age from 18 to 77. Miss Routledge, well-known English stage and television star, will also be seen by American audiences this fall in the Broadway presentation of the London hit "How's the World Treating You?" It will be her legitimate stage debut here. German actor Joachim Hansen plays Albert. Veteran international actor Max Adrian plays Disraeli. "Victoria Regina" was banned by the English censor when first written, because it contained so sacred a character as the late queen. But it was finally presented in 1937 at London's Lyric Theater and became an immediate hit. The author wrote about the plays: "Though I have sometimes used satire, I never once used it without some measure of affection or respect for that quiet, wonderful little lady who is the main subject. I have made her a figure of comedy, but not a figure of fun. The plot is not a plot of incident, but of character; and what happens to that character is truly dramatic." Of Queen Victoria's relationship to the "foreigner" Prince Albert, the author said: "A self-willed, obstinate, imperious and passionate little person is taken in hand by the man she meant to make her adorable puppet and he, wisely and patiently, tames her, trains her and rules her for her own and her country's good." NET Playhouse #7: Victoria Regina: Autumn Program Description: Disraeli, prime minister and diplomate, is persuasive with Queen Victoria in "Autumn," the third play in "Victoria Regina." The Queen wants to become known as a patron of the arts by including a poet in the next Honors List. Disraeli knows the poet she has in mind - and tactfully changes her mind for her. The lighthearted atmosphere of the early part of the play is suddenly shattered by the illness and death of Prince Albert. (NOTE: Followed by filler--Play Bach with the Jacques Loussier Trio.)
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche (V): General Description of Series: "Victoria Regina" - a four-play series about one of the western world's most influential women - will have its American television premiere in "NET Playhouse" this fall. Based on the dramatic biography by Laurence Housman, himself a subject of Queen Victoria, these television plays trace the great English monarch's reign from her accession to the death of her uncle and predecessor, William IV, through her marriage to Prince Albert, his death, and the last years of her long reign. The four plays are "Spring," "Summer," "Autumn," and "Winter." Patricia Routledge plays the part of Victoria, a demanding role in which the actress has to age from 18 to 77. Miss Routledge, well-known English stage and television star, will also be seen by American audiences this fall in the Broadway presentation of the London hit "How's the World Treating You?" It will be her legitimate stage debut here. German actor Joachim Hansen plays Albert. Veteran international actor Max Adrian plays Disraeli. "Victoria Regina" was banned by the English censor when first written, because it contained so sacred a character as the late queen. But it was finally presented in 1937 at London's Lyric Theater and became an immediate hit. The author wrote about the plays: "Though I have sometimes used satire, I never once used it without some measure of affection or respect for that quiet, wonderful little lady who is the main subject. I have made her a figure of comedy, but not a figure of fun. The plot is not a plot of incident, but of character; and what happens to that character is truly dramatic." Of Queen Victoria's relationship to the "foreigner" Prince Albert, the author said: "A self-willed, obstinate, imperious and passionate little person is taken in hand by the man she meant to make her adorable puppet and he, wisely and patiently, tames her, trains her and rules her for her own and her country's good." NET Playhouse #5: Victoria Regina: Spring Program Description: "Spring" is the first of a series of four plays forming a biography of Queen Victoria, form her accession to the throne in 1837 to her Diamond Jubilee in 1897. This play opens at Kensington Palace at dawn in 1837 when the 18-year-old Princess is awakened by the Archbishop of Canterbury and the Lord Chamberlain with the news that King William IV, her uncle, is dead, and that she is Queen. At Buckingham palace her friend and adviser, Prime Minister Lord Melbourne, raises the question of her marriage and suggests a list of possible husbands, steering her away from her cousin Prince Albert of Saxe-Coburg because of his family's hereditary disease: hemophilia. There is a hint of future conflict when, as Lord Melbourne leaves the room, she kisses Albert's portrait. The four-part "Victoria Regina" is based on Laurence Housman's dramatic biography. Housman (1865-1959) wrote 42 short plays about Queen Victoria which were published in book form in 1934. Originally banned by the censor because they depicted the late Queen, the work was eventually staged in London in 1937, and the following year in New York with Helen Hayes as Victoria. (NOTE: Followed by filler--Play Bach with the Jacques Loussier Trio.)
National Educational Television and Radio Center

Miss Routledge, well-known English stage and television star, will also be seen by American audiences this fall in the Broadway presentation of the London hit "How's the World Treating You?" It will be her legitimate stage debut here. German actor Joachim Hansen plays Albert. Veteran international actor Max Adrian plays Disraeli. "Victoria Regina" was banned by the English censor when first written, because it contained so sacred a character as the late queen. But it was finally presented in 1937 at London's Lyric Theater and became an immediate hit. The author wrote about the plays: "Though I have sometimes used satire, I never once used it without some measure of affection or respect for that quiet, wonderful little lady who is the main subject. I have made her a figure of comedy, but not a figure of fun. The plot is not a plot of incident, but of character; and what happens to that character is truly dramatic." Of Queen Victoria's relationship to the "foreigner" Prince Albert, the author said: "A self-willed, obstinate, imperious and passionate little person is taken in hand by the man she meant to make her adorable puppet and he, wisely and patiently, tames her, trains her and rules her for her own and her country's good." NET Playhouse #6: Victoria Regina: Summer Program Description: Conflict develops between the young Queen Victoria and her consort Prince Albert in the second play in the "Victoria Regina" series: "Summer." The play opens with the newly-wed Victoria admiring her German prince shaving on the morning after their wedding. But this bliss is not to last, and soon the rows begin. After each, they make up again, but Victoria's desire to submit to Albert's wishes as a wife succumbs gradually to her wish to control him as Queen. She excludes him from affairs of state because he is a foreigner. She choose a private secretary for him - with the job of reporting to her. But, quietly and firmly, Albert goes his own way. Writing about his "Victoria Regina" plays author Laurence Housman said: "A self-willed, obstinate, imperious and passionate little person is taken in hand by the man whom she meant to make her adorable puppet and he, wisely and patiently tames her, trains her and rules her for her own and her country's good." (NOTE: Followed by filler--Play Bach with the Jacques Loussier Trio.)
National Educational Television and Radio Center

The author wrote about the plays: "Though I have sometimes used satire, I never once used it without some measure of affection or respect for that quiet, wonderful little lady who is the main subject. I have made her a figure of comedy, but not a figure of fun. The plot is not a plot of incident, but of character; and what happens to that character is truly dramatic." Of Queen Victoria's relationship to the "foreigner" Prince Albert, the author said: "A self-willed, obstinate, imperious and passionate little person is taken in hand by the man she meant to make her adorable puppet and he, wisely and patiently, tames her, trains her and rules her for her own and her country's good." NET Playhouse #8: Victoria Regina: Winter Program Description: It was Queen Victoria's Diamond Jubilee and the crowds lined the processional route. "Go it, old girl. You've done it well," shouts one of her subjects. Laurence Housman conveys the feelings of the British people about their queen in "Winter," the final play in the "Victoria Regina" series. Even in old age, Victoria was capabale of resolute action. When she was irritated by a canon's overbearing wife she made him a bishop - in Australia. The play ends with the old queen, surrounded by her family, being wheeled onto the balcony at Buckingham Palace to acknowledge the cheering jubilee crowd. (NOTE: Followed by filler--Play Bach with the Jacques Loussier Trio.)
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From the NET microfiche: The great English playwright Ben Jonson wrote "Volpone" in 1605 as an attack upon the evils of his time. Exposing the various faces of the same vice - avarice - the play is about a rich Venetian nobleman, Volpone, who has no heirs. He pretends he is dying in order to draw gifts from those who pay court to him in hope of becoming beneficiaries of his estate. The same greed that leads Volpone stirs the various potential "heirs," who are each persuaded by Mosca, Volpone's knavish servant and confederate, that they will be the inheritor. Voltore, the advocate, would make out the will in his own favor; Corbaccio would betray his own son; and Corvino would yield his own wife to Volpone's lust. But in the end Volpone is betrayed, his property is forfeited, and he is disgraced. Cast: Volpone - Jack Creley Mosca - Brian Petchey Voltore - Joseph Shaw Corbaccio - Chris Wiggins Corvino - Leo Leyden Celia - Diana Barrington Bonario - Brian Russell Advocates - Donald Ewer, Don McManus, and Sydney Brown Nano - John Ferguson Castrone - Gino Marrocco Androgyno - Mark Anders NET PLAYHOUSE - "Volpone" is an NET presentation, produced by the CBC. CBC Executive producer: Robert Allen. Producer-director: Mario Prizek. Producer for NET: Janet Sternburg. Executive producer: Jac Venza. PLEASE NOTE: Technical difficulties have forced the substitution of "Volpone" for "Lay Down Your Arms," which was originally scheduled as NET Playhouse #221. "Volpone" was first telecast as NET Playhouse #171 in January of 1970. Filler Information: Accompanying "Volpone" is an animated short film, in color, from Poland, entitled "The Composer and his Muse." The eight-and-a-half minutes film is a satire on the creative process. Sitting at his piano, bereft of inspiration, the composer is visited through his window by an angelic, harp-bearing muse. Hovering in the air about his piano, she is a continual source of inspiration to the composer and he quickly becomes famous. But he is afraid his ethereal muse will slip out of the window as mysteriously as she entered. He plies with her presents: a negligee, candy, miniskirts. One day he discovers to his horror that his muse has become a frowsy housewife who spends her days watching television. Although he coaxes her, she is even too fat to rise up on her wings and flutter around him. And the harp couldn't interest her less! The composer has seduce his muse into domestic tranquility, and now he's stuck with her. There is no dialogue.
National Educational Television and the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation ; producers, Mario Prizek and Janet Sternburg ; director, Mario Prizek.
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche: Background Information: The English dramatist Thomas Middleton was born around 1580 and died in 1627. Little is known of his origins or life, but enough examples of his work survive for him to be considered one of the major dramatic writers among Shakespeare's contemporaries. Although he wrote many comedies of contemporary manners, primarily in collaboration with others, "Women Beware Women," one of the few plays he wrote alone, is considered the most important of his serious works. It has been called his most powerful play. In spite of its Italian setting, "Women Beware Women" reflects Middleton's keen observation of London society of his time, his civic consciousness (he served for a time as City chronicler), and his awareness of the social changes of the England of his period (the rise of the moneyed class to prominence among the landed aristocracy). Middleton had an almost total preoccupation with depraved types, but his dramatic gifts turned this fascination to artistic force. His finest efforts are triumphant studies of the pathology of morality and evil, powerful enough to warrant revival for over 300 years. A complicated and bloody play, "Women Beware Women" is described by the contemporary British drama critic John Russell Taylor as "a savagely witty tragedy of court manners." It was first performed in London around 1612. "The Changeling," which Middleton wrote with William Rowley, was shown on NET Playhouse last season. The Plot: The setting is Florence, Italy, in 1620. The ambitious and wealthy citizen Fabricio, is determined that his daughter, Isabella, marry the moronic but rich ward of his old friend Guardiano. But Isabella is the object of the guilty love of her uncle, Hippolito. Fabricio's and Hippolito's sister, Livia, is an embittered, middle-aged woman, who lives in a villa with her brothers and niece. To help her brothers, she tells her niece, Isabella, that she is not related by blood to her father's family and thus paves the way for Isabella to take her uncle as her lover and to agree to marry the ward as a cover for the affair. Meanwhile, Leantio, a young merchant, brings back to Florence his beautiful and nobly-born bride, Bianca, with whom he has eloped from Venice. When he leaves on a business trip, the Duke of Florence, having seen Bianca at a window and desiring her, commissions his friend Guardiano to get her for him. The corrupt Livia agrees to help Guardiano. She invites Leantio's mother, a neighbor, to come with Bianca to her house. While Livia distracts the mother by playing a game of chess with her, Guardiano shows Bianca around the house - and to a bedroom where the Duke is lying in wait for her. When Leantio returns to Florence he finds Bianca discontented and quarrelsome, and he soon discovers that she is the Duke's mistress. To spite Bianca, he agrees to become the lover of the middle-aged Livia. But the Duke decides to get rid of the troublesome young husband. He tells Hippolito that Leantio is Livia's lover and is boasting of that fact. To avenge his family's honor, Hippolito challenges Leantio to a duel and kills him. In a fury of revenge, Livia tells Isabella that Hippolito is her real uncle. She tells Guardiano and his ward, too, of the affair. Guardiano swears vengeance for his ward's honor. Despite the protests of his brother, the Cardinal, the Duke goes ahead with his plans to marry Bianca. Isabella has prepared a masque in honor of the wedding couple, and plans to kill her aunt Livia with fumes from a poisoned censer. At the same time, Bianca has planned to kill the interfering Cardinal with a goblet of poisoned wine. During the masque, however, Isabella, as well as Livia, is overcome by the poisoned fumes, and the Duke accidently drinks from the poisoned cup intended for the Cardinal. Bianca, seeing the Duke die, drinks from the goblet and dies herself. Guardiano is killed in a trap he has prepared for Hippolito, while Hippolito is killed with poisoned arrows shot by Livia's pages. Out of this carnage, only the Cardinal is left alive. NET Playhouse - "Women Beware Women" is a National Educational Television presentation, produced for Granada TV by Philip Mackie. It was adapted for television by Mr. Mackie, directed by Gordon Flemyng and designed by Roy Stonehouse. Dances were arranged by Pauline Grant. Producer for NET is Kay Chessid. The Cast: The Duke of Florence - Clifford Evans Livia - Gene Anderson Bianca - Diana Rigg Hippolito - Laurence Payne Leantio - Bill Gaunt Fabricio - Michael Barrington Guardiano - Godfrey Quigley The Ward - Derek Newark The Duke's Servant - Michael Blackham Leantio's Mother - Dorothy Edwards The Cardinal - Eric Dodson Isabella - Karin Fernald Livia's Servant - Derek Ware Ward's Servant - Adam Rowntree Ganymede - Peter McCann Hebe - Pauline Wingfield Hymen - Iona acrae Cupid - Kenneth Nash Leantio's - Clive Marshall 1st Man - Martin Dobson 2nd Man - Michael Burchill Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET Playhouse - "Women Beware Women" - Revenge tragedy by the 17th-century English dramatist Thomas Middleton, a savagely witty study of seduction, jealousy, intrigue, corruption, and murder.
Granada TV ; producers, Philip Mackie and Kay Chessid ; director, Gordon Flemyng.

From NET microfiche, file A; Suggested Newspaper Listing An examination of American foreign policy by historian Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., author and publisher Jean-Jacques Servan - Schreiber ("The American Challenge"), exiled Greek leader Andreas Papandreou, former Czech economist Eugen Loebl, and Soviet affairs specialist Zbigniew Brzezinski. Taped at the Princeton symposium of foreign policy, with moderator Robert Manning. Program Description The program features an analysis of American foreign policy in its ever-shifting balance with the Soviet Union. With American prestige at low ebb as a result of our involvement in the Vietnam War, the panelists assess Mr. Nixon's probable approach to foreign policy. They also add their personal insights into such recent crises as Czechoslovakia's invasion, the coup in Greece, and escalating dissent in America. Servan-Schreiber states that the revolt of youth against the war and social injustices has "done more for America's political prestige" than any other recent occurrence, since it proves that America is still a free society capable of tolerating opposing viewpoints. He noted earlier that world influence was no longer based on military strength, and accordingly the invasion of Czechoslovakia was "the greatest defeat for Russia." On idealistic grounds, Loebl questioned "whether the United States is for the principle of self-determination," based on its lack of involvement in the Czech liberalization struggle. Papandreou added: "Czechoslovakia and Greece are both victims of the two blocs. Greece is an American satellite . That democracy died in Greece is directly a result of American military thinking." He recalled a conversation with Robert Kennedy in which the late Senator indicated a desire to cut off aid to Greece's military government - "at that moment the military government will cease to exist." Schlesinger stressed, however, that the US is often "the great alibi" in countries with anti-democratic regimes, as exist in Latin American countries. Brzezinski said, "The United States is involved (around the world) because of the kind of society it is. We tend to search for foreign demons when a situation becomes unmanageable . The more upheavals, the less democratic system." Discussing the complexity of international involvements, Schlesinger recalled President Kennedy's embarrassment during the Cuban missile crisis when he learned that American Jupiter missiles had not been removed from Turkey and Italy - six months after he ordered such removal - thus weakening his own argument with Russia. He also recalled a conversation with an ominous ring between Charles de Gaulle and President Kennedy. De Gaulle indicated: "don't construe influence in Asia by military strength. We in France have more influence in South East Asia since we withdrew our forces."
National Educational Television and Raido Center ; producer, Ned Schurman ; director, Garth Dietrick.
National Educational Television and Radio Center
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche: The program will show former Vice President Hubert Humphrey meeting with his first students at Macalester College, St. Paul, Minnesota. Mr. Humphrey has accepted a shared professorship at Macalester College and the University of Minnesota in Minneapolis. He will divide his time between the two institutions and will take part in classroom discussion, lectures, and seminars in various disciplines for both students and faculty. Mr. Humphrey was graduate from the University of Minnesota in 1939, and taught political science at Macalester in 1943-44. His first class at Macalester, an undergraduate college with a student body of 1,700 will be in political science - decision making in the executive government. He will also participate in a "free-for-all" question-and-answer session with 250 students of the college, as part of the Political Emphasis Week at Macalester. In a heated question-answer session with his students at Macalester College, Mr. Humphrey's remarks as a follows: On the Chicago convention: "I was a victim of it .... The tragedy of Chicago could be characteristic of what will happen throughout the country." Mr. Humphrey cites one solution: better-paid, better-educated policemen. On Mayor Daley: "Daley didn't break his heart for me ... He may not be a very sensitive mayor, but he's not a crook." ON the crisis in the universities: "Many of the colleges and universities are very backward in practices and administrative structure and curriculum in terms of what is needed for a student today. In non-academic things, I think students ought to have the majority voice." On law and order as a campaign issue: "Law and order was a phrase for repression. It was really, 'Let's crack down on the Negro,' that's what they were really saying, and I refused to say it." On Negro rights: "I think that you have to have inequality of opportunity for those who have been denied it for a long time." On Administration policy and the Vice President: "Once you fix a course, it's very difficult to unfix it... I'll take my share of blame for whatever mistakes we've made in policy, even though you'll find the vice presidency isn't exactly the most powerful office in the world." On the draft: "The present Selective Service system is outrageous There's a great merit in a volunteer army." But the way to change the policy is "not by burning your draft card... that doesn't mean you're going to get out of the Army. On the upcoming semester: "Your tail will be dragging." On Mr. Humphrey's presence at the college: "If I had had all the answers, I wouldn't be here; I'd be president." On his running mate: "My vice presidential nominee wasn't from South Carolina or someplace else. He was Ed Muskie and I selected him, and I prefer to have the right to decide who are my friends." On the poverty program: "There's been more hue and cry about the mismanagement of the poverty program than about the fact that they build airplane engines that wouldn't lift an airplane off the ground, and they cancel the contract and say it was engineering experimentation." On the Nigerian civil war: "I helped get some cargo planes to bring food to the Biafrans." NET JOURNAL - "New Man on Campus" is a NET production. Executive producer: Ned Schnurman. Produced by Barbara Gordon and Edward Magruder Jones. Associate producer: Betty Paysner.
National Educational Television ; producers, Barbara Gordon and Edward Magruder Jones.

From NET microfiche, file F: The full-length play, the third in a trilogy by Robert Lowell marks the first of several forthcoming original NET-produced dramas. Featuring the original cast of the American Place Theater, this suspenseful and critical social dramatization of American attitudes towards race and class consciousness is set in the early Nineteenth Century abroad a Spanish ship. The protagonists include Lester Rawlins, Frank Langella, Roscoe Lee Browns, Jack Ryland, Michael Schultz, and Lane E. Lloyd. Brice Howard is executive producer. From NET microfiche, file O: "Benito Cereno," a full length play, is the third in a trilogy, "The Old Glory," by Pulitzer Prize-winning poet Robert Lowell. Adapted by Mr. Lowell from a Herman Melville novella, "Benito Cereno" is a work of deep historical and philosophical implication, particularly with respect to American race and class consciousness. The NET production of this literary masterpiece features the cast of the original stage production by the American Place Theater. The Story: Captain Amasa Delano, an American sea captain, harbored on his ship "The President Adams," comes across a drifting vessel. On mounting its deck, he meets its Spanish captain, Benito Cereno, and his obsequious and cunning servant, Babu. Delano, engagingly benign and blusteringly awkward, is taken in by the story that the ship's plight (a missing crew of Spaniards for one thing) was caused by disasters such as calms and plagues. Inexorably, it develops that the Spanish vessel is a slave ship upon which the African slaves have rebelled and compelled the captain to do their bidding. With great poetic and dramatic grandeur Mr. Lowell conveys all the horror of the strange events abroad the drifting ship, and how they affect the New England captain and his bos'n who try to set things right - to their final act of massacring the slaves. The play ends on a surprising - and prophetic - note. The Author: Robert Lowell, outstanding American poet, was a Guggenheim Fellow and Consultant in Poetry, Library in Congress, 1947-48; Winner of the Pulitzer Prize and American Academy of Arts and Letters Prize, 1947; and winner of the National Book Award in 1959. "The Old Glory" is his first dramatic work and was critically acclaimed: "The play was poet Robert Lowell's first but the light that rose from both occasion and drama spread far beyond the modest auditorium." (Richard Gilman of "Newsweek" after opening night) "Using Herman Melville's novella as his source, Mr. Lowell has employed a hard-hitting realistic style to create a work that at the end achieves tragic size." (Howard Taubman in the "New York Times") "The serious American theater, in desperate need, should give a prayer of thanks for the great gift of Robert Lowell." (Lillian Hellman) The Cast: The cast in this NET production is the original stage cast of the American Place Theater, a non-profit, church-based organization conceived" to offer a place, a staff and a broad program of practical work to American writers of stature: our poets, novelists, and philosophers who wish to use the dramatic form. "Benito Cereno" is the first example of their intentions. Captain Delano - Lester Rawlins Benito Cereno - Frank Langella Babu - Roscoe Lee Browne Perkins - Jack Ryland Francesco - Michael Schultz Atufal - Lane E. Lloyd American Sailors: Luke Andreas Thomas Denver John Kilb Richard Kjelland Roger Morden Negro Slaves: June Brown Ernest Baxter Ethan Courtney Nawana Davis Elizabeth Dunn Herman Fitzgerald Gene Forman Mary Foreman Nick La tour Fischer A. Patterson Aston Young Spanish Sailors: Howard Martin Jerry Matz Bill Tynan NET Credits: THE OLD GLORY: BENITO CERENO was produced in 1965 by National Educational Television in association with Station WNDT/Channel 13, New York Producer: Allan Miller. Executive Producer: Brice Howard. Director: Kirk Browning. Sets: Eugene Gurlitz. Music by Yehudi Wyner and costume by Willa Kim and costumes by Willa Kim, from the original stage production.

From NET microfiche: This is the first television production of Offenbach's light-hearted opera, adapted especially for television from the successful revival by the Sadler's Wells Opera Company, and featuring the original cast. "Orpheus in the Underworld" is an irreverent version of the Greek myth about Orpheus whose music was so beautiful that it could charm even wild beasts and who loved his wife so much that he was allowed to follow her into the Underworld. Taking liberties with characters and incidents, Offenbach creates an Orpheus who is so boring and such a bad violinist that his wife, Eurydice, is only too pleased to be abducted to Hell by Pluto, god of the Underworld. Orpheus is rather pleased to be rid of her, but his mother, Calliope, persuades him to go to Heaven to plead with the gods for Eurydice's return. He finds the gods bored - and on strike - and having heard that Hell is more exciting than Heaven, they welcome the chance to join Orpheus in a tumultuous search through the Underworld for Eurydice, which culminates in a spectacular can-can finale, as Orpheus happily fails the test to win back his wife and she becomes a Bacchante, with the Underworld as her permanent home. The Principals: Eurydice - June Bronhill Pluto - Jon Weaving Orpheus - Kevin Miller Jupiter - Eric Shilling Calliope - Anna Polish
Granada TV, England ; National Educational Television presentation ; director, Wendy Toye.

From NET microfiche (G): Program Description: The great comedians who made radio the top entertainment medium of the forties relive many of comedy's classic moments in this exploration of what producer-director Perry Miller Adato calls "the great lost art of radio comedy." Appearing in segments filmed especially for this program are Jack Benny, George Burns, Edgar Bergen and Charlie McCarthy, Bing Crosby, and Jim (Fibber McGee) Jordan, as well as Fred Allen's old "Allen's Alley gang, with Kenny Delmar as Senator Claghorn, Minerva Pious as Mrs. Nussbaum, Parker Fennelly as Titus Moody, and Peter Donald as Ajax Cassidy. In addition, old footage, sound tapes, and stills-some of which are quite rare-offer remembrances of late performers such as Gracie Allen, Marian (Molly McGee) Jordan, W.C. Fields, Fannie Brice, Eddie Cantor, and many others. "It's a show about the development and technique of the great lost art of radio comedy, and the story is told by the people who created this form of entertainment-the comedians themselves," says Mrs. Adato, whose WNET credits include such acclaimed programs as the Emmy-winning "Dylan Thomas: The World I Breathe" and "Gertrude Stein: When This You See, Remember Me." The stars of this show reconstruct the development of radio comedy out of vaudeville, explaining aspects of their own styles and techniques as well as those of others. With the audience they listen to tapes of many of the most memorable moments in American comedy. Example: Jack Benny explains how he became known as an absurd miser, after his traumatic encounter with a mugger: Thug - "Your money of your life!....I said your money or your life!!!" Benny-"I'm thinking it over!" Other memorable moments will be: skirmishes in the war between Jack Benny and Fred Allen; Benny's momentous descent into his vault, deep beneath the city of Los Angeles; Charlie McCarthy's insult-matches with Hollywood stars; an exasperating visit to the Fibber McGee home by Mayor Latrivia; and many of the daffy George Burns and Gracie Allen circumlocutions. An "Allen's Alley" skit with a script written especially for this show by one of Fred Allen's writers from the forties, Harry Bailey, will also be presented. The voice of Fred Allen is impersonated by Al Berney. (Below is a suggested program guide article for May. Appropriate art will follow.) OUT OF THE MOUTHS OF DUMMIES Charlie McCarthy Helps Public Television Explore the Golden Era of Radio - With Edgar Bergen's Aid by Bob Rumerman Charlie McCarthy, now the world's wealthiest dummy, remembers a day in the 40s when he got fed up with his 75-cents-a-week salary and decided to leave Edgar Bergen for a better-paying ventriloquist. Charlie went off to join "The Great Rudolph," but a few days later Edgar received a hurried call for help: "Hello, this is Charlie. I'm across the street where the hock shop is." "Oh - you're in front to of the hock shop?" "No, I'm in it. The Great Rudolph hocked me." Edgar graciously went to rescue his old pal, and for good reason. Together they had one of the most popular radio programs of all times and much of the credit belonged to Charlie--whose keen with and rich personality led many radio listeners of the 30s and 40s to believe that he was a real person. Edgar Bergen's success on radio was, in fact, an enigma to many who disparaged the idea of a ventriloquist on radio, where no one could see his art. But Bergen's success proved two things; that he was more than just a ventriloquist; and that the vast appeal of radio rested on its ability to prod the listener's imagination. This abiding memory of radio's great years has stirred the interest of Emmy-winning WNET producer Perry Miller Adato ("Dylan Thomas: The World I Breathe," "Gertrude Stein: When This You See, Remember Me"). She is now undertaking an idea new to television - a show about radio, exploring the years when radio was at its height and the voices of America's greatest entertainers held millions captive each night. The show, with such stars as Edgar Bergen, Jack Benny, George Burns, Jim Jordan (Fibber McGee), and others will be seen on a new series titled "Playhouse New York - the 40's" over the Public Broadcasting Service. To produce the show, Perry visited Edgar Bergen's West Hollywood home recently and briefly converted his living room into a film set. As he waited, Bergen, who's now preparing to re-enter show business, combined a performer's keen anticipation with the good-natured, easy-going mannerisms of everybody's favorite uncle. A look of relish came over his face when it was time to fetch Charlie from his special trunk. "Maybe it's because they couldn't see him, but many people just weren't sure he was a dummy," said Bergen, with a sense of wonder that was still fresh. "For years I got mail asking if I were really speaking for both of us." Bergen's success on radio established a whole new dimension for the art of ventriloquism. On radio the traditional talents of voice-throwing and suppressed lip movement became unimportant; what really counted was Bergen's ability to give the unseen Charlie a human character--one that people not only laughed at but believed in. With Charlie on his knee, Bergen and his friend reminisced together. They recalled how Charlie used to receive his own fan letters, which were answered on Charlie's own stationery, bearing the McCarthy clan crest. "And do you remember your family tree?" Edgar asked. "Sure," said Charlie, his head making that lovable 90-degree pivot while the rest of him hung limp, "it was oakie dokie-but a little shady." Bergen and McCarthy were a vaudeville act for 10 years before they made their radio debut as guests on Rudy Vallee's show in 1936. They were an instant hit and were invited for a 13-week run. Their own show began in May of 1937, with guests such as Don Ameche, Dorothy Lamour, and Bergen's all-time favorite, W.C. Fields. "Fields was such a wonderful character because he was a harmless villain, he had this synthetic hate that you could see right through," Bergen said. Then he didn't really hate children? "Of course not. Fields only hated phonies - and Hollywood was full of them." The trading of insults between Charlie and Fields, and in fact, between Charlie and many of the guests became one of the most popular aspects of the show. ("Is that your nose, Mr. Fields, or are you eating a tomato?") Here again, Charlie's personality played a very special role. "I could say things through Charlie that I could never say myself," Bergen pointed out, adding however, that "Charlie had to be punished whenever he was bad." Bergen and McCarthy found each other during Edgar's senior year in high school in Decatur, Michigan. Bergen recalls how in his school years he was always mimicking things. Then one day I imitated a distant voice and my mother went to see who was outside. That's when I knew I had something." After investing 35 cents in the "Wizard's Manual," Bergen began perfecting his art. He fashioned a dummy figure out of papier-mch, "but it had no character. So one day I sketched the face of an Irish newsboy I'd seen in the street." That sketch was the birth of Charlie McCarthy. Eventually, like the other great vaudevillians-turned-radio comics, Bergen (and Charlie) made the necessary move to television. Recently he has been making an occasional club appearance and is preparing a comeback. "I tried retiring, but it proved to be the most difficult thing I've ever done," he said. As for the still unsettled question of people confusing Charlie's identity, a little further insight can be gleaned from a story Bergen tells about his daughter, actress Candice Bergen, when she was a girl of only three. "She would sit on one knee, Charlie on the other, and they would have running conversations with each other. But I got to thinking, either I'm a great ventriloquist or my daughter's a little stupid. So I pressed my luck one time and said to Candy: "'Isn't it wonderful how Charlie can talk?'" "'Yes, daddy,'" answered Candy, "'but you do move your lips a little.'"
Playhouse New York--The 40s. The great radio comedians.
a production of the national programming division of WNET/13 ; produced and directed by Perry Miller Adato ; Playhouse New York executive producer, Jac Venza.

The Great Radio Comedians revives some unforgettable radio moments for example: the Jack Benny Show segment where a hold-up man says to the famously stingy Jack Benny: Your money or your life! long pauseI said your money or your life!pause Benny: Im thinking it over! Shared coast to coast, this exchange became a favorite joke in every household across America. In the Forties, Radio played the part in American life now played by television, video games and the internet combined. Radio was the first mass-media news and entertainment form that created a common experience, shared by people of all social classes. And of all the programs on the airwaves, it was the great radio comedians that captured the hearts and the ears of millions of listeners. How does one do a television program about an audio medium, radio? With luck, some imagination and unprecedented cooperation from its subjects, the comedians themselves. In 1972, some of the greatest stars of radio agreed to appear on-camera to talk about their days in radio and to comment on audio excerpts from their original programs. Each introduces clips from short movies shot during the 1940s that mirrored their radio comedy routines: George Burns, (The Burns and Allen Show), Jack Benny (The Jack Benny Show), Edgar Bergen, (Edgar Bergen and Charlie McCarthy), Jim Jordan (Fibber McGee and Molly). Members of the original Allens Alley cast remember Fred Allen and perform a contemporary re-creation of their Allens Alley routines. Bing Crosby remembers Bob Hope as star in vaudeville and radio before their memorable motion picture collaborations. All shared vintage photos from their personal collections. Some surprises include this moment: during our interview, famous ventriloquist Edgar Bergen unearths his feisty dummy, Charlie McCarthy and on-camera they perform a typical Bergen-McCarthy routine. In our research we asked people: What did you look at while listening to the radio? Most answered We looked at the radio. With this as cue, we filmed the reactions on faces of these great radio comedians as each listened to a recording of one of his old programs coming from a vintage radio. But The Great Radio Comedians is not a nostalgia trip; it is an in-depth look at an important and influential popular art form. In their close-up interviews, these performers go beyond nostalgia, giving penetrating analyses of their own comedy, what worked, what didnt and why. They describe the evolution of their radio characters and their jokes as years passed and times changed. When television arrived, each made a successful transition, becoming early stars of the new medium. These radio comedy shows created the basic form of most contemporary comedy on television. And you know what? The old jokes are still very funny.
WNET Production File Name: PMAAP_04.1972_Great Radio

From NET microfiche, file F: "Is Atheism the Religion of the Future?" is the topic of a debate between Mrs. Madalyn Murry O'Hair, an atheist whose lawsuit in Maryland led to the US Supreme Court's controversial decision to ban compulsory prayers in public schools, and Dr. Edward Bauman, a progressive theologian and pastor of the Foundry Methodist Church in Washington, DC. Dave Gilbert is host. The question -- whether atheism is the religion of the future -- is never quite answered in this debate because of the semantic disagreement on the definition of "religion" between the two debaters. Dr. Bauman contends that Mrs. O'Hair does, in fact, believe in religion because "that which is of ultimate concern to her is her God." Mrs. O'Hair answers, "I'm not at all interested in having an ultimate concern." Dr. Bauman concedes later in the discussion that the Christian Church is in decline. He says, "Religion is being very definitely secularized. If you mean the institution, the smell of death is everywhere, and I believe it's the work of God himself," who, he says, will destroy the Church and re-create it in a different form. Mrs. O'Hair levels some sharp attacks against the "Judeo-Christian Religion" and against Christ himself. "The essence of Christianity is intolerance of another opinion," she asserts. "We believe that religion is a private affair. But they (Christians) do not have the right to move up in the culture and saturate the culture." Appraising Christ, she says, "This man never talked once of the love of a woman; he never talked once about beauty. He never once used the word justice. This was a horrendous man; a despicable man." Dr. Bauman's rebuttal is, "You must be reading a different bible." To her attacks on the "intolerance" of Christians, he responds, "When Mrs. O'Hair lumps all Christians together ... she is being as intolerant as she is accusing Christians of being." To a member of the studio audience, who speaks of the satisfaction of "surrendering yourself to God," Mrs. O'Hair retorts, "Do not surrender your mind to someone else. Do not surrender your thoughts to someone else. Do not surrender your freedom. I'm surprised at you, young man!"

From NET microfiche: This program is an hour-long documentary on the causes and research into the nature of an illness that mentally cripples one of every hundred persons during a lifetime. This in-depth examination of the most common mental disorder will bring to television viewers an insight into the life of the schizophrenic - how the world appears to him and how he appears to it. This program was filmed largely on location inside mental institutions with actual patients appearing before the cameras, a policy consistent with NET and producer Harold Mayer. The program explores three basic avenues of research: biochemical, environmental and perpetual differences between normal and schizophrenic persons - questioning whether the differences are causes or the effects of schizophrenia. A segment of the program reports on experiments employing hypnosis, in which a normal subject's perception is altered to induce schizophrenic-like perception. As a result, schizophrenic symptoms are actually shown on film as they develop under hypnosis. As a thread to the program, "The Shattered Mirror" follows a pretty ballet student, Rene, recently released form a hospital, as she tries to live with her illness and walks a tightrope, teetering on the edge of a relapse. "Schizophrenia: The Shattered Mirror" was underwritten by a grant from the National Institute of Mental Health. Among those appearing on the program are Dr. Lyman Wynne and Dr. James Stabeneau, both of NIMH; Dr. Humphrey Osmond, chief of the Neuro-Psychiatric Institute of New Jersey at Princeton; Dr. Nathan Kline, chief of research at Rockland State Hospital, Orangeburg, NY; Dr. Robert Heath of Tulane Medical School; Dr. Abram Hofer, director of psychiatric research for Saskatchewan, Canada; and Dr. Lawrence Kubie, psychiatric consultant to the Sheppard and Enoch Pratt Hospital, Towson, MD. Last season, Mr. Mayer produced for NET's "America Crisis" series "The Troubled Family" which The New York Times described as "absolutely perfect" and "one of TV's most impressive evenings." Said the New York Herald Tribune "an outstanding TV contribution to man's understanding of man, quietly great." NET JOURNAL: SCHIZOPHRENIA: THE SHATTERED MIRROR is a production of National Educational Television. Produced by: Harold Mayer. Narrator: Jackson Beck.
National Educational Television ; producer, Harold Mayer.

From Wikipeda Web site: Sesame Street is an American children's television series, produced by Sesame Workshop (formerly known as the Children's Television Workshop) and created by Joan Ganz Cooney and Lloyd Morrisett. The program is known for its educational content, and images communicated through the use of Jim Henson's Muppets, animation, short films, humor, and cultural references. The series premiered on November 10, 1969, to positive reviews, some controversy, and high viewership; it has aired on the U.S.'s national public television provider (PBS) since its debut, with its first run moving to premium channel HBO on January 16, 2016

From NET microfiche: This two-hour experiment in group dynamics has been extracted form an 11-hour dialogue organized by NET in light of the growing issues of black anti-Semitism and Jewish racism. The program attempts to use television as a medium through which dissident groups can commonly approach their problems. And it also asks them to probe the extent to which black anti-Semitism and Jewish racism are real - or press-made - issues. Seated on the floor at a Washington, DC, television studio, the participants include moderates and radicals, members of organizations and private citizens from both the Jewish and black communities. The moderators are a black and white psychologist form the National Training League (a branch of the NEA), P. Bertrand Phillips and Charles N. Seashore. The black participants are John F. Hatchett, suspended NYU professor, who formerly directed the University's Afro-American Student Center; Sydney Finley, Chicago field representative for the NAACP; Lou Smith, president of Operation Bootstrap, a Los Angeles technical training center; Charlotte Robinson, Project Follow Through teacher in Grand Rapids, Mich.; and Loriman Rhodell, a grass roots worker, who is involved with the New York Urban Coalition. The Jewish participants are Richard Cohen, assistant executive director of the American Jewish Congress; Rabbi Murray Saltzman of Indianapolis, who has been active in civil rights and was jailed with Dr. Martin Luther King during a demonstration in St. Augustine, Fla.; Paul Jacobs, political activist and radical author ("The New Radicals," "Is Curly Jewish?"); Edward Solomon, principal of a Harlem junior high school; Mrs. Naomi Mandlebaum, Detroit teacher and housewife; and Milton Hoffman, a Washington merchant whose store was twice burnt out during the riots. NET Journal - "Some of Our Best Friends" is an NET production. Executive producer: Jack Willis ("Appalachia: Rich Land, Poor People"), producer: Edward Magruder Jones.
National Educational Television ; producer, Edward Magruder Jones.

From NET microfiche: An ancient country of rare beauty, Ethiopia has defied the progress principle of Western missionaries warlike and peaceful, and the sometimes clumsy revolts of its African neighbors. Its emperor, Haile Selassie, has ruled for more than 30 years, and its people have retained much of his regal presence. But Ethiopia is changing, and for Denis Mitchell of Rediffusion Television the change may be unflattering to the Ethiopian people. It is Mitchell, described by Variety as "an outstanding director and pioneer of tele-verite," who reports on Ethiopia, ranging the mountainous country and avoiding its few cities which he considers unrepresentative. He finds a people "of gentleness and courtesy. . . strength and dignity" despite the "horror and bloodshed that's gone before." Side by side, he finds "people who eat hippo, people who eat pancakes," and he asks how its emperor can "weld all this into one nation?" But the Italian invasion of 1935 "kicked Ethiopia into the 20th Century," and since then the invasion of money - from America and from Europe - has continued to prod the country forward. IT has created a world of "corrugated iron instead of thatch" which "keeps out the bugs" but which prompts Mitchell to ask "why is it that progress so often goes hand and hand with ugliness?" On his tour, Mitchell points out the markets and the mosques; the Falasha village inhabited by a clan of Ethiopian Jews; the American industrial fair and the royal pageantry; the hotel life and the tennis court - "symbol of progress." Among these appearing on the program are Dr. Aklilu Lemma, a scientist; Don Levine, an American sociologist; Dr. Carlson, an American who heads the Public Health College at Gondar; and Mrs. Burgoyne, widow of a British officer and spokesman for the old Ethiopia.
Rediffusion Television, Ltd. London; [director, Denis Mitchell].
National Educational Television and Radio Center

From NET microfiche: This play is a fictionalized portrayal of what occurs when Catholic cardinals convene to elect a new pope. When the program was originally shown in Great Britain, many viewers and critics noted a parallel in content and characters to the election of the late Pope John XXIII. After fourteen days, the cardinals are deadlocked in a choice of a new pope between the Cardinal of Palermo, head of the Church's Right wing, and Cardinal Ricci, the choice of the Left wing. A dying Cardinal of Toledo begs his colleagues to reconsider and choose a simple man as pope. Slowly, the cardinal's move towards a moderate, the Cardinal of Bologna, who protests that he is "too blind, too trusting, to uncritical." However, the move to select the Cardinal of Bologna grows. As the play draws to a conclusion, the Cardinal of Bologna is robed to say the final Mass, after which he is certain to be elected as the new pope. John Cogley, religious righter for The New York Times, introduces the play and comments. The Cast: Cardinal of Bologna - Rupert Davies Cardinal Dean - Cyril Luckham Ceremonialist - John Franklyn Robbins Father Bianchi - Jonathan Burn Cardinal of Palermo - Alan Wheatley Cardinal of Boston - Alan Gifford Cardinal Ricci - Peter Copley Cardinal of Paris - Tony Steedman Cardinal of Budapest - John Bailey Cardinal of Bombay - Marne Maitland Cardinal of Rio de Janeiro - Roger Delgado Cardinal of Toledo - Felix Aylmer Cardinal of Uganda - Thomas Baptiste Cardinal of Macao - Robert Lee Cardinal of Mexico - Christopher Benjamin Cardinal of Milan - John Welsh THE SUCCESSOR is a National Educational Television presentation, produced by Anglia Television Network. Authors: Reinhard Raffalt and Steven Vas. Adapted for television by Troy Kennedy Martin. Directed by John Jacobs. FILLER INFORAMTION: Mystery-Sonata No. 14 D-Major, the "Assumption" for violin, harpshichord and 'continuo' Composer: Franziskus Ignatius Biber Cast: Bruno Lenz Li Stadelman Wilheim Schneller This is a Bavarian Television production. NOTE: For the 1967 re-broadcast, the filler was removed.

From NET microfiche: Michel Molese, Geraint Evans, and Elizabeth Harwood are featured in this NET Opera Theatre presentation of Offenbach's operatic fantasy "Tales of Hoffman." Produced in English by the BBC, the opera tells the story of the three loves of the poet Hoffman. "Tales of Hoffman" is based loosely on three stories by the German romantic writer Ernst Theodor Hoffman (often known as T.A.E. Hoffman) who lived from 1776 - 1822. Hoffman himself is the protagonist of the opera, as he passes from one love to another in an amusing fashion. In each case there is a struggle between good and evil, with evil always winning, and Hoffman losing the girl. The prologue finds Hoffman in a tavern in Nuremberg waiting for his latest love to finish a performance of "Don Giovanni" at the opera house across the street. To pass the time Hoffman asks his comrades in the tavern if they would like to hear the tales of his other loves, and they eagerly gather about him. The first is the tale of Olympia, a life-like doll created by the clever Dr. Spalazani and his rival-in-science, Coppelius. Coppelius has sold Hoffman a pair of magic glasses which make Olympia appear real. Immediately Hoffman falls in love with her. Coppelius arrives to collect payment for Olympia's eyes, which he has made, and is given a bad check by Spalanzani. When Coppelius realizes he has been swindled he smashes Olympia to pieces. Hoffman, who has broken his magic glasses, sees that he has been duped. The second story finds Hoffman in love with the beautiful Antonia who wants to be a great singer. Antonia's father, however, forbids her to sing because he knows that she suffers from a strange malady, and the exertion of singing will hasten her death. The evil Dr. Miracle arrives, determined to claim Antonia's life. He conjures up the spirit of Antonia's late mother, and Antonia sings with all her heart, until she falls dead. The third story finds Hoffman in Venice pursuing Giulietta, a naughty courtesan who is protected by the wicked Count Dapertutto. Schlemil, another of Giulietta's admirers, challenges Hoffman to a duel. With the help of the Mephistophelean Dapertutto, Hoffman kills Schlemil and rushes to Giulietta's rooms only to find she has gone off with another paramour. Act 3 is followed by the epilogue, in which Stella enters the tavern, sees Hoffman in a drunken stupor, and leaves with Lindorf. The "evil" roles of Lindorf, Coppelius, Dapertutto, and Dr. Miracle are all played by Sir Geraint Evans, a baritone. Miss Harwood, a soprano, plays Olympia, Antonia, Giulietta, and Stella (a non-singing role). Michel Molese is a tenor. The remaining cast: Nicklaus - Gillian Ramsden Nathaniel, Spalanzani - Derek Hammond Stroud Hermann, Crespel, Schlemil - John Lawrenson Andreas, Cochinelle - Reginald Barratt Franz, Pitichinaccio - Graham Allum Antonia's Mother, Simonette - Margaret Lensky Luther - David Read Carlotta - Billie Hill Regisseur - Peter Sugden Dancers: Imogen Claire, Janie Kells, Nicholas Benton, Leon Lestocq, Yvonne Dragadze, Jennifer Layland, David Hepburn, Wally Michaels, Hermione Farthingale, Petra Siniawski, Michael Ingleton, Peter Newton "The Tales of Hoffman" is a presentation of NET Division, Educational Broadcasting Corporation. Produced by British Broadcasting Corporation. Producer: Cedric Messina. Director: John Gorrie. Designer: Eileen Diss. Costume designer: Juanita Waterson. Choreographer: Terry Gilbert. NET Opera Theatre music and artistic director: Dr. Peter Herman Adler. Transmitted nationally by PBS, the Public Broadcasting Service.
British Broadcasting Corporation ; NET Division, Educational Broadcasting Corporation ; producer, Cedric Messina ; director, John Gorrie; NET Opera music and artistic director, Peter Herman.

From NET microfiche: Program Description: "A Celebration for William Jennings Bryan" by Geoffrey Bush is a portrait of one of the heroes of American political folklore. The playwright follows Bryan's career from his first nomination as the Democratic candidate for President at the age of 36, through his three defeats (1896, 1900 and 1908); highlights his enormous popularity; takes the viewer along on his tours on the famed Chautauqua circuit and his lectures on "The Prince of Peace"; shows his unfortunate tour of duty as Wilson's Secretary of State (1913-1915); and his participation in the famous Scopes "Monkey" Trial. With humor and bite the play depicts Bryan's honesty, his essential innocence, his integrity, and the final pathos of a man who has not kept pace with a changing world. One of the most popular men in the political history of the United States, William Jennings Bryan is seen through the eyes of a narrator, who places in chronological sequence the events of his life; those of Clarence Darrow, first as his supporter and later as his antagonist; and those of his wife, who never flagged in her loyalty and devotion. Through all the turbulence of his career, Bryan never changes, but the world around him undergoes the radical change of the first two decades of the Twentieth Century. Geoffrey Bush's "A Celebration for William Jennings Bryan" is an original play first produced by the Theatre Company of Boston. The NET Playhouse production was made possible in part by grants from the National Endowment for the Arts and the Rockefeller Foundation and is performed by the players of the Theatre Company of Boston with three guest stars. Cast: William Jennings Bryan - James Broderick Mrs. Bryan - Nancy Coleman Clarence Darrow - Roy R. Scheider Narrator - Barry Primus Chorus: Larry Bryggman; Susan Channing; Terrence Currier; Audrey Ward; William Young About the Company: The Theatre Company of Boston was formed six years ago, moving from its original 95-seat playhouse into a 350-seat playhouse converted from a movie theater. It has presented many first American performances of contemporary English and European playwrights, including Harold Pinter, John Arden, Ann Jellicoe, Slawomir Mrozek, and a large number of premieres of plays by new American playwrights. Its artistic director is David Wheeler. NET Playhouse: Theatre America - "A Celebration for William Jennings Bryan" is a co-production of National Educational Television and its Boston affiliate, WGBH-TV. It was produced and directed by Christopher Sarson and staged by David Wheeler. The musical score was composed and conducted by Newton Wayland. Producer for NET is Kay Chessid.

From NET microfiche: General Series Description: A series of thirteen programs based on the novels of Georges Simenon. Noted for the sound psychology of his characters, Simenon's stories deal with many nationalities and are set in numerous European cities and villages. There are sequences filmed in these locations integrated into the programs. In each of the novels chosen for this series, Fate plays a leading role in the development of the story and the characters: Background on Georges Simenon: Georges Simenon was born into a middle-class family at Liege, Belgium, in 1903. He began his writing career at 16 when he bought himself his first pair of long pants and presented himself as a reporter to the publisher of the biggest local newspaper who, in amusement, hired him and assigned him to the police court beat. One month later the precocious young man was writing a column devoted to police reports and civic ceremonies. When he was 20 years old, he bought all the current magazines and novels and, using them as models, started to write stories of all kinds aimed at all sorts of readers. Under 17 pen names over the next seven years, he produced over 300 of these tales. By 1930 he was ready to start on larger works, and it was then that he began the famous Inspector Maigret series. Gradually, however, Simenon has increasingly become absorbed in writing serious, non-crime novels, although from time to time he still continues to bring out a detective novel. For ten years, Simenon lived in the United States - in Maine, New York, Florida, Arizona, California and Connecticut - eventually producing ten novels with an American background. Among them is "The Brothers Rico," which is considered among the finest of his novels. In 1955, Simenon returned to Europe and now lives in Switzerland with his wife and four children. Today, at the age of 65, Georges Simenon has the reputation of being "an author's legend." All told, he is credited with having produced nearly 500 books in 45 years. His latest serious novel, "The Confessional," was published this spring. "The Belles of Bictre," written in 1964, is perhaps his most widely-acclaimed large novel and has been called his greatest achievement. His books have been translated into more than 25 languages and more than 40 of them have been filmed. His psychological novels have had a great influence on the French cinema. Simenon has been admired by leading European and American critics, and he has a wide and enthusiastic following. Andre Gide, who at the end of his life was writing a study of Simenon's fiction, called him "perhaps the greatest" novelist of contemporary France. Thomas Lask, book reviewer of The New York Times, speaks of Simenon's "immaculate sense of form," and Thornton Wilder wrote about the novel "The Hitchhiker" that Simenon "has revealed a store of beauty and moral strength from the realm of suffering in the homely facts of daily life." NET Playhouse #99: Thirteen Against Fate #13: The Consul When young Adil Bey comes to take over the Turkish Consulate at the Russian town of Batum, he finds that port on the Black Sea rife with intrigue. It is 1933, during the time of the Stalinist purges and a period of great political and economic upheaval in Russia. The local population is near starvation and resents the food and luxuries - much of which have been smuggled, across the nearby Turkish border - which seem to lie within the means of those employed in the various foreign consulates. Adil Bey's predecessor had died under mysterious circumstances, and the new consul soon begins to feel that no one can be trusted, he even has uneasy feelings about his secretary, Sonia, who lives in the house opposite the consulate with her brother, an official in the secret police. He wonders still more when he begins to feel unwell and suspects even the doctor who tells him he is merely run down. Despite his distrust of Sonia, he finds himself falling in love with her. At the same time he has drifted into an affair with Nelia, an international beauty of easy virtue. But now the atmosphere of tension surrounding the consulate begins to prey on his nerves. He quarrels with Sonia and accuses her of trying to poison him. But at the same time he is sure she returns his love for her and realizes that, for both their sakes, the only thing to do is to get her out of Batum. In his innocence of the corrupt political situation in this starving port, Adil goes for help to John, a disillusioned American journalist who seems to know everyone and everything. A Belgian ship is in port, and the captain, an old friend of John's, agrees to help smuggle Sonia aboard. For himself, Adil can arrange a fake telegram announcing that his presence is urgently needed at home. But at the last minute Sonia disappears. Hoping desperately that she will be on the boat, Adil carries through his part of the plan. Only when it is too late does he discover that it is Nelia who has escaped; she is running away with the captain. To his horror, details that he had noticed but paid no attention to, now take on a sinister meaning; John's apparent immunity from police harassment and the fact that Sonia's brother now wears a black armband explain the story of Sonia's disappearance. Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET Playhouse - "Thirteen Against Fate: The Consul" - A fledgling Turkish diplomat arrives to take over his country's consulate at a provincial Russian seaport during the Stalinist purges and is plunged into a maelstrom of intrigue and violence.
a National Educational Television presentation ; produced by Irene Shubik for the British Broadcasting Corporation ; NET producer, Kay Chessid ; director, John Gorrie ; dramatization by Leo Lehman.

NET Playhouse #95: Thirteen Against Fate #8: The Friends In the south of France, Vladimir Dobranski, an expatriate Pole, is employed as the captain of a yacht "Electra," owned by the wealthy Madame Papelier. Vladimir's experience of the sea is negligible; his main function is as Madame's lover. His friend Blinis is also part of the crew and has become involved with Madame's daughter, Helene. But Vladimir, too, is attracted to Helene and is jealous of Blinis, in spite of the fact that both men are from Poland and have been lifelong friends. One day, Vladimir steals a diamond ring from Madame Papelier and hides it in Blinis' cabin. When it is found, young Blinis is dismissed. Blinis sets off for Marseilles and is no sooner gone when Vladimir has an attack of conscience and confesses all to Madame Papelier. They are too late to stop him from leaving the country, however, and further damage has been done by one of Madame Papelier's guests, who has informed the police of Blinis' "crime." Anxious to recompense his old friend, Vladimir sends him money. Then he learns that Helene is pregnant by Blinis when she begs him to help her get rid of the child. Realizing at last that Helene really loves Blinis and satisfied that when her mother dies she will inherit the estate, Vladimir kills Madame Papelier. He manages to evade the police and, under another name, goes to Warsaw where Blinis is in hiding. He tells him that Helene is going to have his child and the two friends are reconciled. Blinis leaves to return to France and Helene. But ironically, the Polish police have been waiting for the man whose name Vladimir has assumed, and he is arrested for "subversive activities" against the State." He has paid his debt to Blinis in full. Film sequences were shot on location in Cannes, France. Suggested Newspaper Listing: "Thirteen Against Fate" - Jealousy over a beautiful woman makes a man steal in order to frame his best friend.

a National Educational Television presentation ; produced by Irene Shubik for the British Broadcasting Corporation ; NET producer, Kay Chessid ; director, Michael Hayes ; dramatization by Anthony Steven.

Among them is "The Brothers Rico," which is considered among the finest of his novels. In 1955, Simenon returned to Europe and now lives in Switzerland with his wife and four children. Today, at the age of 65, Georges Simenon has the reputation of being "an author's legend." All told, he is credited with having produced nearly 500 books in 45 years. His latest serious novel, "The Confessional," was published this spring. "The Belles of Bictre," written in 1964, is perhaps his most widely-acclaimed large novel and has been called his greatest achievement. His books have been translated into more than 25 languages and more than 40 of them have been filmed. His psychological novels have had a great influence on the French cinema. Simenon has been admired by leading European and American critics, and he has a wide and enthusiastic following. Andre Gide, who at the end of his life was writing a study of Simenon's fiction, called him "perhaps the greatest" novelist of contemporary France. Thomas Lask, book reviewer of The New York Times, speaks of Simenon's "immaculate sense of form," and Thornton Wilder wrote about the novel "The Hitchhiker" that Simenon "has revealed a store of beauty and moral strength from the realm of suffering in the homely facts of daily life." NET Playhouse #92: Thirteen Against Fate #5: The Judge Xavier Lhomond, the President of the Assizes, is trying a case whose circumstances seem to parallel oddly those of his own life. Dieudonne Lambert, a young mechanic, is accused of murdering his wife, and although the evidence against him is pretty damning - he has both a mistress and three previous convictions - he pleads not guilty. Lhomond too has a wife whose presence is inconvenient to him. She is a querulous invalid, and Lhomond has fallen in love with Germaine Stevenard, the young widow who is his typist. The removal from the scene of Mme. Lhomond would prove most gratifying. One extra dose of her medicine, and all would be over. During the case Lhomond begins to feel ill. In the fever of an influenza attack he begins to imagine that it is be who is really in the dock, and that Lambert himself is sitting in judgment. He had thought of his own affair as over: but seeing Germaine sitting in the courtroom as a spectator, brings home to him the realization that his feeling for heris as strong as ever. Despite nights made sleepless by his wife's continual nagging, and his own uneasy conscience, Lhomond continues to preside at the trial. But now he begins to see Lambert in a different light. The evidence against him seems not nearly so conclusive. Mme. Bernet, the neighbor who has previously identified Lambert as the young man she saw running away from the scene of the crime, might conceivably be lying. And so, on closer questioning, it develops that she is the aunt of the young Joseph Pape who had been infatuated with the dead woman - and rejected by her. Mme. Bernet could very well be protecting her nephew with a made-up story. It is due mainly to Lhomond's summing up that Lambert is found not guilty. When the Judge returns home and discovers that his own wife has just died from a heart attack, he realizes now, more than ever, the truth of his summing up at the trial: "Murder is committed first of all in the heart." Alexander Knox, well known in British and American films and New York stages, plays Xavier Lhomond. The teleplay was dramatized by Hugh Leonard, young British dramatist who was represented in New York last season by his play about James Joyce, "Stephen D." Sequences of the film were photographed in the Norman town of Caen. Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET Playhouse - "Thirteen Against Fate: The Judge" -- Alexander Knox stars as a French judge whose own private life curiously parallels the murder case he is trying and affects his judgment of the accused man.
a National Educational Television presentation ; produced by Irene Shubik for the British Broadcasting Corporation ; NET producer, Kay Chessid ; director, Naomi Capon ; dramatization by Hugh Leonard.
