NET playhouse #88: Thirteen against fate #1: The Lodger A young Turkish Jew, Elie Nagear, lies miserably in a hotel bedroom in Brussels. He has a heavy cold and feels thoroughly depressed. To make matters worse, he has barely enough money to pay the bill: the carpets which he has come to Europe to sell have been held up in Customs. His luxury-loving companion, Sylvie Baron, decides it is high time she went to visit her family at Charleroi, and high-handedly takes six hundred of Eire's last thousand francs with her. Left alone after she has gone, he overhears a conversation in the next room. The occupant is a rich Dutchman who is being paid a hundred thousand French francs in cash. Elie goes out, buys a heavy wrench, follows the Dutchman onto a train to Paris, and kills him. With the police in pursuit, Elie again contacts Sylvie. She arranges for him to lodge with her parents in Charleroi. The other lodgers in the house consist mainly of penniless students who resent Elie because of the money he is able to throw around. But the young Turk soon becomes Mme. Baron's favorite, at first mainly because he is able to pay for full pension instead of the students' humble bed-and-breakfast. Even Antoinette, Sylvie's sister, and M. Baron, her father, the master of the house who works on the railways, fall for his charms. But when Sylvie comes to visit the house again, Antoinette begins to suspect that Elie and her sister are old friends. Sylvie is being hounded by the police, and when she finds out that they have connected Elie with the Dutchman's murder, she sends a letter to Antoinette begging her to persuade Elie to leave the house. When Mme. Baron finds the letter, she realizes that Elie is a murderer and tries to force him to go. By this time, however, Elie has conceived a neurotic attachment for his landlady and refers to her as "Mama." Torn by her own fondness for him in spite of what he had done, Mme. Baron doesn't have the heart to expose him. But the police are closing in and even when Sylvie dashes back from Brussels to warn him, Elie refuses to leave. After a panic-stricken struggle, he submits quietly to arrest. Zia Mohyeddin, the young Pakistani actor whose brilliant performance in "A Passage to India" has won him international acclaim, stars as Elie Nagear. Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET PLAYHOUSE - "Thirteen Against Fate: The Lodger" - One of this series by Georges Simenon, "The Lodger" is the story of a group of boarding house lodgers who know a murderer is in their midst but who cannot bring themselves to betray him.

a National Educational Television presentation ; produced by Irene Shubik for the British Broadcasting Corporation ; NET producer, Kay Chessid ; director, James Ferman ; dramatization by Hugh Leonard.

NET Playhouse #97: Thirteen Against Fate #11: The Murderer For some time. Dr. Hans Kuperus has suspected his wife, Alice, of being unfaithful to him. One evening, when he is supposed to be attending a meeting of the Biological Association in Amsterdam, he follows her as she makes straight for her rendezvous with Schutter, one of the most influential citizens in their little Dutch town of Sneek. Outside the bungalow, Kuperus lies in wait for the guilty couple, and as they emerge he slowly raises his revolver... With Alice and Schutter dead and their bodies hidden in a canal, Kuperus returns home to the maidservant, Nell, with whom he has been carrying on illicitly. However, he now discovers that Nell's lover, Karl, an itinerant waiter, has been living in the house for the past five months, unknown to Kuperus or his wife. This sudden knowledge of Nell's deceit begins the undermining of the doctor's confidence. When the bodies of Alice and Schutter are discovered and Kuperus is summoned to identify his wife, he finds that he is not as tough as he had thought. Hurriedly and foolishly, he offers Karl money to leave the house, when, later, Karl is picked up for questioning by the police and his criminal record is uncovered, his explanation as to why Kuperus gave him money is scarcely believed. During an uncomfortable interview with the police superintendent (who has deep suspicions of Kuperus although he possesses no concrete evidence to connect the "good" doctor with the double crime), Kuperus is warned to leave town to avoid scandal. Refusing to be intimidated, Kuperus seeks the help of an old friend, a lawyer, to institute action against the police for defamation of character. But, in keeping with the staid character of the town, the lawyer refuses to have anything to do with him. For in a stupid and futile gesture of defiance, Kuperus had publicized the fact that Nell was living with him in the house as his mistress. One by one his patients leave him. He faces social ostracism. At last, left alone with the knowledge of his own guilt and with the indifferent Nell as his only companion, Kuperus begins to disintegrate. Soon, the first anonymous letter arrives calling him "Murderer" ... Filmed sequences of the program were shot on location in Holland. Frank Finlay, of Britain's National Theatre Company, stars as Dr. Hans Kuperus. Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET Playhouse - "Thirteen Against Fate: The Murderer" - Frank Finlay stars as a respectable Dutch doctor who murders his wife and her lover and, although never convicted of the crime, pays for his freedom in an unforeseen way.
a National Educational Television presentation ; produced by Irene Shubik for the British Broadcasting Corporation ; NET producer, Kay Chessid ; director, Alan Bridges ; dramatization by Clive Exton.

NET Playhouse #93: Thirteen Against Fate #6: The Schoolmaster Jean-Paul Guillaume, a provincial schoolmaster, rules his students with a military discipline. His family, too, is expected to conform to his rigid way of life and has learned to accept it. Antoine, his son, has to face it both at home and at school, for he is taught by his father in class. But one fateful day, Guillaume's past, which has been lying dormant for so long, begins to stir uneasily. In the street he sees a woman he thought he had left behind many years ago, a certain Madame Mado. Although she does not see him, the careful facade he had built over so many years begins to crumble. That morning at school he loses his temper and assaults a boy, young Vial, whose father is a town counsellor. This is so serious and so out of character that if the incident were to become known, it could cause an ugly scandal. Convinced that Guillaume really must be ill, the headmaster compels him to take two days off. Meanwhile, at home too, his family notices a difference. Normally so painstaking in his appearance, so fastidious in his habits, he becomes a different person, surly and slovenly, and taken to drinking. His wife, thinking that Guillaume must be heading for a nervous breakdown, consults a doctor who urges him to go away for a complete rest, preferably to his native Jura where the mountain air can be relied upon to mend shattered nerves. But Jean-Paul Guillaume has become a man possessed. He must see Mado again. He takes money from his and his wife's joint bank account and confronts the woman. She still does not recognize him and thinks he must be mad, but he presses her to take the money. At last his odd behavior has aroused the interest of the police, particularly when his wife finds that he has taken money from their joint account. When at last Inspector Gournet, who himself comes from the Jura, comes face to face with the schoolmaster, he realizes that the man he sees in front of him is not Jean-Paul Guillaume. The man is an imposter! And the whole story is revealed. The schoolmaster is really Georges Vaillant, an educated man who became the lover of the prostitute Mado. When one of her clients became unpleasant, Vaillant had shot and killed him. Later, he had escaped from prison and returned briefly to Mado, long enough to steal some rings from her to aid in his escape. When the schoolmaster saw her after so many years, he knew that if she recognized him she would never keep still about his real identity and he had tried to bribe her. Although Mado failed to recognize him, it was too late. The police lead away a man who, for thirty years, has lived a lie, as his family stands in horrified bewilderment. Sequences of the program were filmed on location in the Norman town of Montreuil.

a National Educational Television presentation ; produced by Irene Shubik for the British Broadcasting Corporation ; NET producer, Kay Chessid ; director, Peter Potter ; dramatization by Alun Richards.

NET Playhouse #96: Thirteen Against Fate #10: The Son As 17-year-old Alain Malou is coming home from school, he sees a commotion in the street. His father, Eugene Malou, has just shot himself. Stunned and horrified, he determines to find out what could have driven his father to such an act. His family is of little help. His mother and brother, both shallow and selfish, seem incapable of any real feeling. His sister Corine, is almost entirely taken up with her own affair with a married man. It is evident that Alain must find out the truth for himself. The facts that he uncovers about the real Eugene Malou are not exactly what he expected. After the funeral, Alain decides to leave school and get a job. At the Three Pigeons Hotel, where he finds a room, the proprietress tells him that his father used to come often to the bar to meet a friend - a certain Joseph Bourgues. It appears that Bourgues and Malou belonged formerly to a left-wing extremist organization, and when Bourgues was sent to prison, Malou managed to get him released and gavehim money for a fresh start. Alain next discovers that his father had built a housing project, called Malouville, intended to house working people. But when the authorities found out how much the project was going to cost, they refused to advance Malou all the money he needed to finish the building. This had led to ill-feeling among the residents in the project, who felt that Malou had let them down with false promises. The project had been allowed to fall into disrepair, and Malou went bankrupt. Corine, bitter at the town's hostility, comes to see Alain and tells him that their father was a blackmailer. He had come into possession of certain facts about the town's leading citizens when he was writing a weekly gossip column for the Yellow Press. This is the real reason for the town's hostility toward the Malou family. Angry and unhappy, Alain doesn't know what to believe. Then Corine tells him that their father had cancer. For reassurance, Alain turns to his father's old friend, Bourgues. The old man tells him it is true that Eugene Malou made money through blackmail. But those he blackmailed were far more evil than he: they loved money for its own sake. Eugene used the money to help those in difficulty or in trouble. Bourgues tells the heartbroken son not to hate his father just because he was no saint. Satisfied that at last he understands what kind of person his father really was, Alain decides to go to Paris and make a new life for himself. Filmed sequences of "The Son" were shot on location in the Norman town of Caen. Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET Playhouse - "Thirteen Against Fate: The Son" - When 17-year-old Alain Malou sets out to find what drove his father to suicide, he uncovers some unpleasant facts about his family background.

a National Educational Television presentation ; produced by Irene Shubik for the British Broadcasting Corporation ; NET producer, Kay Chessid ; director, Waris Hussein ; dramatization by Jeremy Paul.

NET Playhouse #96: Thirteen Against Fate #9: The Survivor For many years old Madame Canut has hated Fevrier, sole living survivor of the wrecked trawler "Telemaque." She believes that he and the other survivors cannibalized her husband in order to live and has brought up her twin sons, Pierre and Charles, to believe this story. When Fevrier is found dead in the harbor, Pierre Canut, now captain of his own trawler, is arrested as the obvious suspect. His brother Charles is convinced of Pierre's innocence, Although Pierre had been with old Fevrier on the night he was killed, there are also other suspects. For one thing, there is Paumelle, a ne'er-do-well, whose father had been also one of the survivors. Paumelle was perfectly capable of blackmailing Fevrier and probably was doing so. Then there is Emma Martens, the local "easy woman" who is suddenly claiming Fevrier's estate on the grounds that she was secretly married to him. Charles decides to do a little investigating on his own, and going to Fevrier's villa, he is surprised to see a window open as though someone is still living there. Finding nothing, he decides to leave. He is not the only visitor, however, for Emma, too, goes there, hunting for the marriage certificate. Suddenly, the terrified woman is confronted with the apparition of the dead man, himself. Fevrier has faked his own death because he is sickened by Madame Canut's eternal persecution and wants to clear out. In a violent argument, Emma stabs him and makes her escape. Paumelle, thinking Fevrier dead, has picked this night to rifle the villa, and it is he who is discovered by Charles and the police. But in the ensuing scuffle he gets away. Knowing that Paumelle and Emma were having an affair, Charles follows Emma as she leaves town, hoping that she will lead him to Paumelle. When Paumelle is finally found by the police, he tells the whole truth. Emma, unable to escape Charles following her to Dieppe, where she had hoped to catch the boat for England, is convinced that he knows she murdered old Fevrier and commits suicide in despair. Pierre is released and the twin brothers are reunited. Filmed sequences of the play were shot on location in Brittany. Lila Kedrova, who won an Oscar award for her performance in "Zorba the Greek," stars as Emma Martens. David Buck, last seen on NET Playhouse as young Winston Smith in George Orwell's "1984,"' plays both the twin brothers, Charles and Pierre Canut. Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET Playhouse - "Thirteen Against Fate: The Survivors" - Lila Kedrova stars in this story of twin brothers who, raised to believe that their father was cannibalized by his fellow survivors of a shipwreck, are naturally suspected of murder when the last of those survivors is found dead.

a National Educational Television presentation ; produced by Irene Shubik for the British Broadcasting Corporation ; NET producer, Kay Chessid ; director, Rudolph Cartier ; dramatization by Stanley Miller.

NET Playhouse #98: Thirteen Against Fate #12: The Suspect Running Time: 1:00:06 Original broadcast: August 23, 1968 For many years M. Hire has lived a recluse's existence in a seedy Paris lodging house. He has no friends, receives no letters, goes out only to his office or to the cinema. One evening, a brutal killing occurs nearby. A young girl is murdered and her handbag is snatched. When Hire's landlady -- a shrill busybody and gossip - sees a towel in Hire's room, covered with blood from a shaving cut, she jumps to the wrong conclusion and suspects him of the murder. And when she recalls that very late during the night of the crime, she had to pull the cord by her bed to let someone into the house, she is doubly convinced of Hire's guilt. Hardly able to suppress her excitement and self-importance she informs the police of her suspicions. In his isolation, Hire had been in the habit of watching through his window into the room of another occupant of the house, Alice, who helps the concierge with the work. And so when the good-lookingyoung woman, consumed by curiosity, pushes her way into his room on the pretext of delivering an envelope to him, Hire finds it impossible to refuse her admittance. As soon as she sees the arrangement of his room, Alice realizes that Hire can see into her room. In panic, she begins to seduce the lonely man. She tells him that the man he must have seen visiting her, often late at night, is just a casual lover. And, certain that Hire saw the lover Emile visit her the night of the murder and give her the victim's handbag to hide, Alice confesses that Emile is indeed the real killer. She says both she and Hire are in danger for Emile is violent and will kill them both if they talk. Hire is now thoroughly infatuated with Alice and convinced that she loves him. And so when he receives a summons from the police for questioning, he resolves to take Alice away with him. Afterwards he will send a letter to the authorities telling them that Emile is the murderer. He does not know that he, himself, is the prime suspect. But the police have uncovered the prison record which turned Hire into a recluse, and the net is closing around him. Only one piece of substantial evidence is needed to convict him. To keep him quiet and happy, Alice agrees to go away with Hire and, while he is out, she plants the handbag in his room. Now the police follow him on his final errands, see him go to a jeweller's to buy a ring, and then to the railroad station where, just before the arrival of the train which will carry him and Alice away to Venice, he mails a letter. But the train comes -- and goes -- and bewildered, he wanders back to the house in search of Alice, who tries to hide from him. The truth about Alice's deceit slowly sinks into his consciousness. Then, pursued by the police, while a mob of avid, scandal hungry neighbors surround him, he rushes distractedly upstairs, onto the roof, and falls to his death. Film sequences of "The Suspect" were shot on location in the St. Denis area of Paris. Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET Playhouse - "Thirteen Against Fate: The Suspect" - A middle-aged recluse becomes involved in a young girl's murder when his landlady discovers a blood-stained hand towel in his room.

NET Playhouse #90: Thirteen Against Fate #3: The Traveller A ship's boat pulls alongside a quay in La Rochelle and a young man steps ashore. His name is Gilles Mauvoisin, and his parents have died tragically in Norway. Now he has arrived in the town they left before he was born. It seemed the only place to go. But La Rochelle has been waiting for him. Certain people knew that he would arrive one day, and when he is recognized they gather to take action. His uncle, a rich, self-made man who had found a way to make most of the town's influential citizens dance to his tune, has died and left everything to Gilles: his house, his business interests, and, locked in a safe with a combination the boy has to discover for himself, the means the dead man had used to run things his way. At first, his aunt, Madame Eloi, and certain men his uncle had under his thumb - Babin the importer, Hervineau the lawyer, and the ship-owner Plantel, who together are known to the town as the "Syndicate" - try to win the boy over and thus steer him away from finding the combination to the safe. But Gilles will not be manipulated and stubbornly tries to get at the root of the situation. When a doctor's wife dies of poisoning, the Syndicate tries to drive Gilles away by implicating old Mauvoisin's young widow, Colette, who still lives in the house Gilles inherited and who was known as the doctor's mistress. They try to prove that Colette poisoned both the doctor's wife and her husband, and have the old man's body exhumed. Although it is proved that old Mauvoisin did, indeed die of poisoning, Gilles refuses to believe that Colette is guilty. When at last he stumbles on the combination to the safe, Gilles finds that his uncle had been blackmailing the members of the Syndicate and also had been aware that his nephew, Madame Eloi's ne'er-do-well son, Robert, had been forging checks. Gilles now knows that it is his aunt who killed the old man to protect her son, and before telling the police, he makes amends with his inherited "blood" money to send his aunt and cousin out of the country. The filmed sequences of La Rochelle were done on location in that French town. Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET Playhouse - "Thirteen Against Fate: The Traveller" - A recently-orphaned young man returns to his parents' town to find that he had inherited his rich uncle's estate, as well as the results of the old man's corrupt stranglehold on the town.

a National Educational Television presentation ; produced by Irene Shubik for the British Broadcasting Corporation ; NET producer, Kay Chessid ; director, Herbert Wise ; dramatization by Stanley Miller.

NET Playhouse #91: Thirteen Against Fate #4: The Widower A marriage based solely on pity is built on disastrously insecure foundations, as commercial artist Bernard Jeantet discovers to his cost. He returns one day to his quiet Paris apartment to find that his wife, Jeanne, is missing. Neither the concierge nor the elderly dressmaker, Mile. Couvert, who lives upstairs with the little boy Pierre, can help him. He decides to report the disappearance to Inspector Gordes, who knows all about Jeanne, a former prostitute. When Jeanne is found dead in a hotel room and a verdict of suicide is brought in, Jeanet begins to discover how far self-delusion has taken him. Hankering for her old life, bored and unable to manage on Jeantet's meagre allowance, Jeanne had become the mistress of a rich industrialist, Beaudoin, who had booked the hotel room for her where they met once a week. Beaudoin has only contempt for Jeantet, calling him a hypocrite who had refused to acknowledge the past. When Jeantet insists on their meeting, the rich man tells him that Jeanne had been slowly suffocated by her husband's overwhelming kindness. Unwilling to hurt him, she had refused Beaudoin's pleas to break away. Then Jeantet discovers what Jeanne had been afraid to tell him: that the little boy Pierre was her own son. In a final attempt to make amends, Jeantet decides to bring the boy up as his own. The Paris sequences of "The Widower" were filmed on location in that city. Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET PLAYHOUSE - "Thirteen Against Fate: The Widower" - When Bernard Jeantet finds his wife dead in a strange hotel room, he discovers how very wrong he was about their "happy" marriage.

a National Educational Television presentation ; produced by Irene Shubik for the British Broadcasting Corporation ; NET producer, Kay Chessid ; director, Silvio Narizzano ; dramatization by Clive Exton.

NET Playhouse #94: Thirteen Against Fate #7: The Witness Weak, epileptic Jean Nalliers lives on the farm which his father bought for him with his wife Gilberte, his sister-in-law Hermine and his mother-in-law Madame Pontreau, a dominating, avaricious woman. He is worried, not only because of the continual struggle to make ends meet, but specifically because there is trouble among the laborers on the farm. Under severe nervous tension, he feels one of his epileptic fits coming on and staggers up into the hay loft. This is the chance Mme. Pontreau has been waiting for. She follows him and when he is unconscious, pushes him out of the window onto the cobblestones below. The police had been called to deal with the trouble with the angry farmworkers and it is while they are on the premises that young Nalliers's body is discovered. A verdict of accidental death is recorded. But old Madame Naquet, who is hired from the village to help in the kitchen, is not at all sure it was an accident. She takes it upon herself to go to the inn to tell oldNalliers about his son's death and while she is there, drops several hints. As there is no deed of settlement, Nalliers is entitled to half of the farm's value. He has always hated Mme. Pontreau and will communicate with her only through a third party. She informs him that the farm is to be auctioned. Meanwhile, old Mme. Naquet goes about the village saying that she knows where she can lay her hands on a great deal of money. Rumors are circulating and suspicion against Mme. Pontreau grows. When one rainy day the farm is sold to the highest bidder, Nalliers catches a chill and, thinking that he is going to die, makes a formal accusation to the police. Gilberte, convinced that her mother killed her husband, can bear no more and commits suicide. Smiling grimly at this act of divine vengeance, old Nalliers closes in for the kill. But Mme. Pontreau files a civil suit against him for slander and perjury. All hinges now on the one witness, Mme. Naquet, and what she actually saw. But she steadily refuses to talk to the police. She is a poor old woman who only wants security in her old age, and in the end she comes to a financial agreement with Mme. Pontreau. Sequences of the film were shot on location in Brittany. Starring as Mme. Pontreau is Pamela Brown, one of the British theater's most distinguished actresses and the winner of an American "Emmy" for her performance on the Hallmark Hall of Fame production of "Victoria Regina." Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET Playhouse - "Thirteen Against Fate: The Witness" - Pamela Brown stars as an avaricious Breton farm woman who murders her son-in-law for his farm and finds a way to silence the only witness to her crime.
a National Educational Television presentation ; produced by Irene Shubik for the British Broadcasting Corporation ; NET producer, Kay Chessid ; director, John Gorrie ; dramatization by John Hale.

NET Playhouse #89: Thirteen against fate #2: Trapped Life for Louis Bert has been a long series of minor ups and sordid downs - a precarious existence maintained on the edge of the criminal underworld by wit and charm. At the moment, however, everything seems to be set for a run of good living. He has won the heart of middle-aged Constance who has enough money to keep him, and he has even managed to persuade her to extend her patronage to his "sister," Loulou - who, in fact is a prostitute he stole from the leader of a gang he helped in a post-office raid. Louis has found comfort and security, and sees no reason why he should not be able to continue in his new life. But the past has been spent too recklessly, and soon destroys the good life in Constance's apartment in Nice. At a birthday party given for Constance by an old lover, Loulou notices some of the gang watching. Louis also sees a detective who has been showing an interest in him since the post-office robbery, andhe decides that the time has come to disappear for a while. That night, in an attempt to silence him, the gang raids Constance's apartment. And when Louis returns two days later, he finds the place a shambles, with Constance lying on the bed with her throat cut. Knowing that suspicion will certainly center on him, Louis panics, drags the body into the bathroom, and goes to work on it with a knife. Finally he tidies the apartment and then sets off to dispose of two heavy suitcases in the harbor. Two weeks later, Louis is arrested and charged with theft, forgery and murder. Although nobody has been found, he is sent to trial. During the proceeding no one produces any evidence in his favor. The record of his misspent life works against him and he is finally sentenced to twenty years penal servitude. Film sequences were done on location in Nice, France. Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET PLAYHOUSE - THIRTEEN AGAINST FATE - "Trapped" - Young Louis Bert has spent his life living off others. When he is arrested for a murder he did not commit, his sordid past convicts him.

a National Educational Television presentation ; produced by Irene Shubik for the British Broadcasting Corporation ; NET producer, Kay Chessid ; director, George Spenton-Foster ; dramatization by Julia Jones.

From NET microfiche: The Stratford (Ontario) National Theatre of Canada, famous for its annual Stratford Shakespeare Festival, brings to television one of the most highly acclaimed of its recent productions, introduced during the 1968 season at Stratford. This is the first of several programs in which NET Playhouse will present some of the great theater companies from around the world. The Stratford "Three Musketeers" was produced for television by the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, which calls it the "most complex and spectacular" dramatic production it has ever undertaken on its own. The play has 69 scenes and required 33 scenery changes. There are 14 separately staged fights and/or battles, says the CBC, "and the entire pace is lightning fast." The cast contains 44 performers, most of whom play the roles they had in the original Stratford production. Some performers play more than one part. The major roles: D'Artagnan - Kenneth Welsh Milady - Martha Henry Cardinal - Leo Ciceri Queen - Pat Galloway Athos - Powys Thomas Porthos - James Blendick Aramis - Colin Fox King - Eric Donkin Buckingham - Kenneth Pogue de Treville - Max Helpmann Constance - Mia Anderson "NET Playhouse Presents the Stratford National Theatre of Canada: The Three Musketeers" is a presentation of NET, produced by the CBC in Toronto. Producer: David Gardner. Director: John Hirsch. Adapted by Peter Raby. Original music composed and conducted by Raymond Pannell. Costumes by Desmond Heeley. Set Decoration by Alex Bowen and Frank Peets. Art Director: Trevor Williams. Editors: Jim Kitchen, Clyde Noftle, and Tom Stevenson. NET Playhouse executive producer: Jac Venza. Suggested Newspaper Listing: "NET Playhouse Presents the Stratford National Theatre of Canada- The Three Musketeers" - A colorful, elaborate staging of Alexandre Dumas' famed adventure story performed by one of the world's leading Shakespearean companies.
CBC ; presentation of NET ; producer, David Gardner ; director, John Hirsch ; adapted by Peter Raby ; NET playhouse executive producer, Jac Venza.

From NET microfiche: Filmed on the campus of Yale University in New Haven, CT, this program is devoted to "that journey of the mind we call education its desires, doubts, and discoveries." In the classrooms and dormitories, crossing the quadrangle and along the athletic field, it presents a fluid picture of today's college student as he learns that "one must live as a man." Mankind - and one's manhood - is the subject of this candid documentary. A biology professor talks of man, "another animal" in the evolutionary process. A member of the rowing team says, "You learn what you're made of when they ask you to take up the stroke in the last half mile." A spokesman for the University says its job is "to put out 1,000 questioning, self-critical young men." Freshmen are shown moving into the college, carrying chairs and beds across the quad, and pausing to talk about their new experience. Then the roving camera follows them into classes, where professors provide their initiation into knowledge. "The material is sacred," one professor notes parenthetically. "The damn well better listen." Interspersed with classroom shots are card games, informal sessions in the dorms, extracurricular work in the office of the student paper, a gathering at Mory's, and a game of "bladder ball" (a yearly event in which costumed students vie for an immense ball). And the music picks up the tempo - from the folk rock of Paul Butterfield's blues band to the traditional Yale songs. "The old clich is that you enter college as a boy and you become a man," says producer Murray Lerner. "Well, it's a difficult process. It's not easy to be a man. And that, I think, is what this film is about."
a production of National Educational Television ; producer, Murray Lerner.

From NET microfiche: Information about this series: This NET Journal program begins a series that will move to its own time slot on the Wednesday (December 10) following the Journal telecast. In other words, the first "To Save Tomorrow" program will be a 60-minute NET Journal on Monday, December 8, and eight succeeding 30-minute programs in the series will be seen Wednesday at 8 pm EST, beginning December 10. The entire series has been produced, over a period of nearly three years, by station WTTW, NET's Chicago affiliate. It was funded by a grant from the Social and Rehabilitation Service branch of the US Department of Health, Education and Welfare. Besides the Singer Zone Center in Rockford, locations represented in programs in this series are Wellmet House in Boston, Horizon House and Spruce House in Philadelphia, Chicago State Hospital, Fountain House in New York City, and Palo Alto (CA) State Hospital. Most of the filming was done in cinema verite style. Complete program content for each program in this series, including NET Journal #257, will be sent to you shortly. "To Save Tomorrow" is an NET presentation, produced by WTTW, Chicago. Executive producers: Robert Kaiser and Rudyard Propst Director: Robert Kaiaser Editors: Dave Shaw and James Bourgeois Cinematographer: Dale Sharkey NET Journal #257: To Save Tomorrow (Pilot) Initial Broadcast: December 8, 1969 The program begins with the arrival of nine mental patients at the David Singer Zone Center in Rockford, Illinois, a new facility operated by the state department of mental health. The patients, all adults, have been transferred from the state hospital. At the Singer center they will undergo intensive "confrontation therapy," and this program records their individual progress over a four-month period. The persons seen are actual patients and although their names are heard during the program we ask that no names be used in pre- or post- program publicity. In "confrontation therapy" the patients are continuously confronted with their problems and forced to deal with them. "We have no intention of making this place too comfortable," warns Marvin Benson, director of rehabilitation. "Don't get used to calling it home." The staff at the center does not permit anti-social behavior by the patients and uses as much verbal force as necessary for as long a period as necessary to break abnormal behavior. "Are you crazy?" one patient is asked by Benson. "Well ... I'm here," the man replies. "You don't look crazy. Can you say something in crazy for us?" Benson prods. After some six months at the center the man found a job in the outside world. In fact, seven of the nine persons found jobs six month after their arrival. But perhaps the most dramatic progress recorded by the camera is that of one man who spoke his first words after 23 years of silence. The man had been in mental institutions since the age of 17. NET Journal #257 - "To Save Tomorrow" (subtitle: "Come Out, Come Out, Whoever You Are") is an NET presentation, produced by station WTTW, Chicago. This program was filmed in cinema verite style. Executive producers: Robert Kaiser and Rudyard Propst Director: Robert Kaiser Editors: James Bourgeois Cinematographer: Dale Sharkey Suggested Newspaper Listing: This first in a series of programs about rehabilitating mentally ill adults chronicles four months of intensive therapy undertaken by a group of patients at the Singer Zone Center in Rockford, Illinois. Photographed in cinema verite style with actual patients and therapists.

The entire series has been produced, over a period of nearly three years, by station WTTW, NET's Chicago affiliate. It was funded by a grant from the Social and Rehabilitation Service branch of the US Department of Health, Education and Welfare. Besides the Singer Zone Center in Rockford, locations represented in programs in this series are Wellmet House in Boston, Horizon House and Spruce House in Philadelphia, Chicago State Hospital, Fountain House in New York City, and Palo Alto (CA) State Hospital. Most of the filming was done in cinema verite style. Complete program content for each program in this series, including NET Journal #257, will be sent to you shortly. "To Save Tomorrow" is an NET presentation, produced by WTTW, Chicago. Executive producers: Robert Kaiser and Rudyard Propst Director: Robert Kaiaser Editors: Dave Shaw and James Bourgeois Cinematographer: Dale Sharkey Program 2: Fountain House Initial Broadcast: December 17, 1969 This program describes through the eyes of John Beard, director of Fountain House, how this institution has become a part of Hell's Kitchen in New York and how it re-integrates patients returning from mental hospitals into functioning citizens. The program has already won the Silver Medal in the 1968 New York International Film Festival. It was photographed on location in cinema verite style with actual patients and staff. Beard relates the history of the house, comparing the old house to the new one which was designed to resemble an average house with such things as paintings, rugs, etc. The house is non-residential and approximately 200 people visit each day. Beard explains the fact that they have specific jobs to do, such as cleaning, running a switchboard, working in the assembly workshop area or the dining room, and forming their own businesses for personal income. The program shows the patients and staff in a meeting where the working patients explain what they have been doing. Viewers also see a discussion with a restaurant owner who employs several members of the house. Visits are also made to one of the Fountain House apartments that are rented out to house members, and to the Fountain House thrift shop where the patients work. Suggested Newspaper Listing: Winner of a 1968 New York International Film Festival award, this program takes its viewers to Fountain House in the Hell's Kitchen section of New York City where dedicated staff members attempt to rehabilitate patients returning from mental institutions. To Save Tomorrow #2 - "Fountain House" is a presentation of National Educational Television, produced by non-commercial station WTTW, Chicago. This program was filmed in cinema verite style. "To Save Tomorrow" is an NET presentation, produced by WTTW, Chicago. Executive producers: Robert Kaiser and Rudyard Propst Director: Robert Kaiser Editors: Dave Shaw and James Bourgeois Cinematographer: Dale Sharkey Program 5: Horizon House Initial Broadcast: January 7, 1970 Horizon House is a residential center which helps patients ease back into society with the understanding assistance of ex-patients and a trained staff. The house is voluntarily run by the community and receives no state funds. Dr. Irwin Rutman, executive director, and Dr. Daniel Lieberman, director of Jefferson Community Mental Center, narrate the program. They explain their belief that the most important place to work with disturbed people is in the community, not in the hospital. Viewers see community teams of four or five persons go to patients' homes to counsel them. In one instance, a 70-year-old man is seen being re-acquainted with Philadelphia as a worker takes him to a museum. The worker is depicted as a community person hired as an ombudsman or a liaison between Horizon House and the people. In one example of this, the film records an Program in which one ombudsman helps a woman got a needed pair of shoes from one of the local churches. As with most programs in this series, "Horizon House" was filmed in cinema verite-style using actual patients and staff members. Suggested Newspaper Listing: The first of two programs in this series devoted to Philadelphia's mental health program visits Horizon House, where ex-patients join trained staff members in rehabilitating mentally ill adults. Executive producers: Robert Kaiser and Rudyard Propst Director: Robert Kaiaser Editors: Dave Shaw and James Bourgeois Cinematographer: Dale Sharkey Program 8: One Day at a Time Initial Broadcast: January 28, 1970 This is the only scripted program in this series. It was filmed at Chicago State Hospital and illustrates the many dilemmas and responsibilities faced by key personnel in mental health rehabilitation facilities. Specific cases are used to demonstrate the functions of the rehabilitation counselor and other members of the rehabilitation staff. Counselors are shown working with a client during an interview, talking to a client in a sheltered workshop, and with the entire staff discussing particular cases. Appearing in the program are professional actors Gene Janson and Marshall Richey. Suggested Newspaper Listing: The final program in this series on mental health takes its viewers to Chicago State Hospital for a look at the problems facing the personnel who operate mental health rehabilitation facilities. "To Save Tomorrow" is an NET presentation, produced by WTTW, Chicago. Executive producers: Robert Kaiser and Rudyard Propst Director: Robert Kaiaser Editors: Dave Shaw and James Bourgeois Cinematographer: Dale Sharkey Program 4: Operation Re-entry Initial Broadcast: December 31, 1969 This program was shot entirely in the environs of Palo Alto, VA Hospital in California. It demonstrates the use of tokens for rewards in large mental institution and the transition from token use to sheltered workshop training which is followed by the beginnings of outside work for mental patients. In this work they actually operate a filling station and later rehabilitate houses in a good section of the city, occupy them, and set up their own communal living plan. Dr. John Atthowe and Dr. Joseph McDonough, who are the designers of the veteran's workshop of the hospital, narrate the program, showing viewers the wards, the workshop on the grounds (where patients are paid money) and the workshops off the grounds where the patients operate a gas station. This film shows an abandoned house which was bought on a GI loan, patients renovating the house and then moving in. Also shown is a group meeting with an ex-patient who acts as an advisor and with patients who are about to move into a house they renovated. Suggested Newspaper Listing: A look at special rehabilitation techniques for the mentally ill at Palo Alto Veterans Hospital in California, including projects in which patients operate a gas station and renovate houses for themselves to live in when they are released for the hospital. "To Save Tomorrow" is an NET presentation, produced by WTTW, Chicago. Executive producers: Robert Kaiser and Rudyard Propst Director: Robert Kaiaser Editors: Dave Shaw and James Bourgeois Cinematographer: Dale Sharkey Program 3: Spruce House Initial Broadcast: December 24, 1969 "Operant conditioning-behavior modification" methods are used extensively at Philadelphia's Spruce House as a means of returning patients to society. Through a "token economy" system, where "grickles" are exchanged in place of real money, the patients earn tokens as rewards for adequate behavior and have to pay grickles in order to obtain items and privileges one values in normal life. The program includes on location footage showing how this highly structured method of treatment and rehabilitation functions and its effectiveness with patients in rapidly returning them to the outside world. It was photographed in cinema verite style with actual patients and staff. Dr. John Henderson, executive director of Spruce House, explains the live-in residential arrangement and shows viewers the building, which is a townhouse with five stories and a workshop in the basement. Also shown are a staff meeting and different levels of patient meetings. On Level One, patients are paid grickles for talking; on Level Two they are paid only if what is said shows insight into their personal problems; on Level Three meeting patients are paid at the beginning and then give tokens to others for making contributions. Other scenes include a social dance where patients are paid for asking others to dance and for talking, a psychodrama session where patients are paid for participating, and at the local "Y" where patients have to pay to attend. Suggested Newspaper Listing: A grickle for your thoughts? That's the basic idea at Philadelphia's Spruce House where mental patients undergoing rehabilitation function in a model economy. The patients earn "grickles" for achievements and then spend them for special items and privileges. To Save Tomorrow #3 - "Spruce House" is a presentation of National Educational Television, produced by non-commercial station WTTW, Chicago. This program was filmed in cinema verite style. Executive producers: Robert Kaiser and Rudyard Propst Director: Robert Kaiser Editors: Dave Shaw Cinematographer: Dale Sharkey Project Supervisor: Edward L. Morris

Executive producers: Robert Kaiser and Rudyard Propst Director: Robert Kaiaser Editors: Dave Shaw and James Bourgeois Cinematographer: Dale Sharkey Program 7: The Guy Next Door Initial Broadcast: January 21, 1970 The premiere program in this series illustrated the Singer Zone Center helped rehabilitate long-term mental patients transferred from a state institution. This time viewers see how the center aids short-term patients and assists nearby communities in creating their own mental health centers. Program narration is by Dr. Harold Visotsky, director of the Illinois Department of Mental Health, and Dr. Norris Hansell, director of the Singer Center. Viewers see the work of the center's rehabilitation counselor who is in charge of 24-hour emergency service. They also see how staff members hold planning conferences with their patients in an attempt to find a solution other than hospitalization. The patients bring their families and/or their employers or ministers to such meetings. Also seen: a rehabilitation counselor visiting a client in jail; a sheriff discussing the training program for law enforcement officers given at the center; a non-professional group in Belvedere, Illinois; residents of Proviso Township, Illinois, debating tax referendum that would raise public funds for mental health facilities. Suggested Newspaper Listing: This series returns its attention to the Singer Zone Center in Rockford, Illinois, where this time we see how the center helps local residents develop their own community mental health facilities. "To Save Tomorrow" is an NET presentation, produced by WTTW, Chicago. Executive producers: Robert Kaiser and Rudyard Propst Director: Robert Kaiser Editors: Dave Shaw and James Bourgeois Cinematographer: Dale Sharkey Program 6: To Live and Move According to your Nature is Called Love Initial Broadcast: January 14, 1970 The second of the two programs of the series filmed in Philadelphia concerns an experiment at the Jefferson Community Mental Health Center which stresses going into the community and looking for problems to solve before those problems result in mentally disturbed residents. The program is narrated by Almanina Barbour, a black attorney who is director of the experimental project, and the Reverend James Bevel, well-known civil rights activist and member of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference. Viewers see Mr. Bevel at Martin Luther King's Village, a ghetto neighborhood, encouraging people to look at their problems. Once these problems are uncovered, Miss Barbour takes over and begins to organize the people around their particular community problems, such as urban renewal meeting and a freedom choir. She and Mr. Bevel are also seen at a meeting where they explain their program to the professional staff of Jefferson. Summing up the project the minister says: "Most of the time you've only paid attention to a man when he comes out of the house screaming and hollering when you ought to ask what the hell is going on inside the house that sent him out screaming and hollering." Suggested Newspaper Listing: Curing the social problems that can contribute to mental illness is the chief aim at Philadelphia's Jefferson Community Mental Health Center, which is spotlighted in tonight's program. To Save Tomorrow #6 - "To Live and Move According to your Nature is Called Love" is a presentation of National Educational Television, produced by non-commercial station WTTW, Chicago. This program was filmed in cinema verite style. It was funded by a grant from the Social and Rehabilitation Service branch of the US Department of Health, Education and Welfare. Besides the Singer Zone Center in Rockford, locations represented in programs in this series are Wellmet House in Boston, Horizon House and Spruce House in Philadelphia, Chicago State Hospital, Fountain House in New York City, and Palo Alto (CA) State Hospital. Most of the filming was done in cinema verite style. Complete program content for each program in this series, including NET Journal #257, will be sent to you shortly. "To Save Tomorrow" is an NET presentation, produced by WTTW, Chicago. Executive producers: Robert Kaiser and Rudyard Propst Director: Robert Kaiaser Editors: Dave Shaw and James Bourgeois Cinematographer: Dale Sharkey Program 1: Wellmet House Initial Broadcast: December 10, 1969 This program describes how Wellmet House, a Boston halfway house, achieves remarkable results with a live-in program which is staffed completely by students of Boston area universities. Eight mental patients are seen living with eight students in an environment free from traditional therapeutic structure. The main emphasis of Wellmet House is that relating to normal people in a natural, unstructured manner becomes for mentally ill people an important ingredient of rehabilitation. The program is photographed on location in cinema verite style with actual patients and staff. It is narrated by David Kantor, who was the house's first director and designer and who now acts as an advisor. He describes the background of the house, how his students inspected a hospital and saw there the deplorable conditions and went on to start the house. There are scenes of patients and staff at dinner, at a boisterous Friday night party at a local pub, at a big party in the house, and in a house meeting. The film also shows Jean Carmel, who was house mother when the film was made, and is now director of Wellmet House. It is Kantor's intention, and that of Miss Carmel, not to emphasize conformity but to stress individual ways of expressing one's self. "I didn't want to make people so well that in fact they are dead," Kantor says. Suggested Newspaper Listing: A visit with the residents of Wellmet House in Boston, half of whom are mentally ill adults and the other half are college students who live with the patients to help prepare them for re-entry into normal society. To Save Tomorrow #1 - "Wellmet House" is a presentation of National Educational Television, produced by non-commercial station WTTW, Chicago. This program was filmed in cinema verite style. Executive producers: Robert Kaiser and Rudyard Propst Director: Robert Kaiser Editors: Dave Shaw Cinematographer: Dale Sharkey Project Supervisor: Edward L. Morris

From NET microfiche: For the first time on American television, a documentary examines the judicial system through a detailed presentation of a single trial. The case is set in Denver (only Colorado and Texas allow cameras inside a courtroom). It pits The City and County of Denver vs. Lauren R. Watson. The charges: resisting a police officer (Officer Kobert C. Cantwell) in the discharge of his duty,' and interfering with a police officer in the discharge of his duty." The larger implications of the case involve the conflict between police and Black Panthers (Watson, a member of the Black Panthers at the time of the trial, has recently been purged from the Party), and the system of legal justice as it applies to blacks and other traditionally underprivileged groups. The other "principals" are Judge Zita Weinshienk, an attractive and sympathetic young woman; Defense Attorney Leonard Davies, a 28-year-old local lawyer; Wright Morgan, assistant city attorney, who offers a sharp contrast to Davies in both age and style; and police Officer Robert C. Cantwell, Watson's antagonist. Each of these principals comments on the trial and on critical factors involved in it during a series of interviews, which are interspersed into the trial. The charge against Watson stems from an incident that occurred on November 6, 1968 - the day after President Nixon's election. Cantwell contends that he attempted to stop Watson for speeding, but was repeatedly thwarted after twice entering his car and notifying him that he was under arrest. Finally, at a service station, Cantwell says he was able to subdue Watson with assistance from three other policemen. Watson's story conflicts in almost every detail with that of Cantwell. He states that the policeman had driven past his house early in the day, gloating about Nixon's victory, waving a fist at him and shouting "White Power." He also swears that Cantwell never formally arrested him and that he submitted in the service station without a struggle. Each of the four programs will contain legal analysis by James Vorenberg, professor of law, Harvard Law School. Vorenberg is also director of the Center for Criminal Justice at Harvard Law School. He was executive director of President Johnson's Commission on Law Enforcement and Administration of Justice (1964-67) and director, Office of Criminal Justice (1964-65). From 1954 to 1962 he was a member of the firm of Ropes and Gray, after clerking under Supreme Court Justice Felix Frankfurter from 1953 to 1954. He received his LL.B. from Harvard in 1951, after graduating from the same school in 1948. During each program, Vorenberg will comment on legal subtleties and legal protocol, as defined within the trial. The first day - selection of the jury. In the selection of a six-man jury, each attorney can make only three peremptory challenges. Davies, in the judge's chambers, has argued that Watson cannot receive a fair trial since he will not be judged by a jury of his peers - no blacks appear on the entire panel from which the jury is to be selected. (The panel consists primarily of people who differ from Watson not only in color but in age, economic standing, and environment.) Davies' argument is denied. Therefore, he utilizes his three peremptory challenges in an effort to eliminate jurors who he feels might be prejudicial to Watson; at the same time, he attempts to impress the jurors with the fact that "At this moment, without hearing more, you have made up your mind that this man is innocent." Watson, meanwhile, in one of several interviews interspersed throughout the trial, states that "people who are not white in a white nationalist country are subjects" and therefore "can't get justice." Additional Description from NET Press Release from April 2, 1971: NET's "Trial," a Saturday Review Television Award and Cannes Film Festival winner, which critics hailed as "excellent" and "precedent-shattering," will be repeated on PBS, Wednesdays, April 21, 28 andMay 5 and 12, at 8:30 p.m. (in New York on WNET/Channel 13). Fully titled "Trial - The City and County of Denver vs. Lauren R. Watson," the four-part program deals with the trial of a Black militant. It was produced by the Robert Fresco and Denis Sanders (co-makers of the Oscar-winning "Czechoslovakia '68) and when broadcast last March marked the first time on American television that the judicial system was examined through a detailed presentation of a single trial. Marvin Kitman of Newsday hailed it "as an exciting combination of education and entertainment...destined to be a landmark innovation in television programming." "A precedent-shattering television series (which is) excellent," said Lawrence Laurent of The Washington Post. And Norman Mark of the Chicago Daily News wrote that it offered "the best dissection of a public trial ever...on television." The four ninety-minute parts correspond with the trial's four days which took place in March 1969. The trial involves a charge of resisting a police officer in the discharge of his duty and interfering with a police officer in the discharge of his duty. Watson, the defendant - at the time of his arrest a member of the Black Panther Party - counters with charges that he is a victim of police harassment. On the day of Watson's arrest - November 6, 1968 - he testifies that Patrolman Robert Cantwell shook his fist at him and shouted "white power" - a reference to Richard Nixon's election victory. The antagonism between Watson and the Denver police forms an undercurrent within the trial and is a basis of attorney Leonard Davies' defense of Watson. "The issue has national implications, involving police and Panthers, the American system and the black man," says Don Dixon, NET's director of public affairs programming. "The case is really a microcosm, reflecting one of our country's most critical concerns." Within the program, the camera ranges freely from courtroom to judge's chambers. There are also interviews with all major participants in the trial - Watson, Davies, arresting officer Cantwell, Judge Zita Weinshienk, and City Attorney Wright Morgan.
Trial, the city and county of Denver versus Lauren R. Watson. [Part 1], The first day--Selection of the jury.

From NET microfiche: For the first time on American television, a documentary examines the judicial system through a detailed presentation of a single trial. The case is set in Denver (only Colorado and Texas allow cameras inside a courtroom). It pits The City and County of Denver vs. Lauren R. Watson. The charges: resisting a police officer (Officer Kobert C. Cantwell) in the discharge of his duty,' and interfering with a police officer in the discharge of his duty." The larger implications of the case involve the conflict between police and Black Panthers (Watson, a member of the Black Panthers at the time of the trial, has recently been purged from the Party), and the system of legal justice as it applies to blacks and other traditionally underprivileged groups. The other "principals" are Judge Zita Weinshienk, an attractive and sympathetic young woman; Defense Attorney Leonard Davies, a 28-year-old local lawyer; Wright Morgan, assistant city attorney, who offers a sharp contrast to Davies in both age and style; and police Officer Robert C. Cantwell, Watson's antagonist. Each of these principals comments on the trial and on critical factors involved in it during a series of interviews, which are interspersed into the trial. The charge against Watson stems from an incident that occurred on November 6, 1968 - the day after President Nixon's election. Cantwell contends that he attempted to stop Watson for speeding, but was repeatedly thwarted after twice entering his car and notifying him that he was under arrest. Finally, at a service station, Cantwell says he was able to subdue Watson with assistance from three other policemen. Watson's story conflicts in almost every detail with that of Cantwell. He states that the policeman had driven past his house early in the day, gloating about Nixon's victory, waving a fist at him and shouting "White Power." He also swears that Cantwell never formally arrested him and that he submitted in the service station without a struggle. Each of the four programs will contain legal analysis by James Vorenberg, professor of law, Harvard Law School. Vorenberg is also director of the Center for Criminal Justice at Harvard Law School. He was executive director of President Johnson's Commission on Law Enforcement and Administration of Justice (1964-67) and director, Office of Criminal Justice (1964-65). From 1954 to 1962 he was a member of the firm of Ropes and Gray, after clerking under Supreme Court Justice Felix Frankfurter from 1953 to 1954. He received his LL.B. from Harvard in 1951, after graduating from the same school in 1948. During each program, Vorenberg will comment on legal subtleties and legal protocol, as defined within the trial. Additional Description from NET Press Release from April 2, 1971: NET''s "Trial," a Saturday Review Television Award and Cannes Film Festival winner, which critics hailed as "excellent" and "precedent-shattering," will be repeated on PBS, Wednesdays, April 21, 28 and May 5 and 12, at 8:30 p.m. (in New York on WNET/Channel 13). Fully titled "Trial - The City and County of Denver vs. Lauren R. Watson," the four-part program deals with the trial of a Black militant. It was produced by the Robert Fresco and Denis Sanders (co-makers of the Oscar-winning "Czechoslovakia '68) and when broadcast last March marked the first time on American television that the judicial system was examined through a detailed presentation of a single trial. Marvin Kitman of Newsday hailed it "as an exciting combination of education and entertainment...destined to be a landmark innovation in television programming." "A precedent-shattering television series (which is) excellent," said Lawrence Laurent of The Washington Post. And Norman Mark of the Chicago Daily News wrote that it offered "the best dissection of a public trial ever...on television." The four ninety-minute parts correspond with the trial's four days which took place in March 1969. The trial involves a charge of resisting a police officer in the discharge of his duty and interfering with a police officer in the discharge of his duty. Watson, the defendant - at the time of his arrest a member of the Black Panther Party - counters with charges that he is a victim of police harassment. On the day of Watson's arrest - November 6, 1968 - he testifies that Patrolman Robert Cantwell shook his fist at him and shouted "white power" - a reference to Richard Nixon's election victory. The antagonism between Watson and the Denver police forms an undercurrent within the trial and is a basis of attorney Leonard Davies' defense of Watson. "The issue has national implications, involving police and Panthers, the American system and the black man," says Don Dixon, NET's director of public affairs programming. "The case is really a microcosm, reflecting one of our country's most critical concerns." Within the program, the camera ranges freely from courtroom to judge's chambers. There are also interviews with all major participants in the trial - Watson, Davies, arresting officer Cantwell, Judge Zita Weinshienk, and City Attorney Wright Morgan.

The prosecution's case rests on the testimony of two witnesses - Officer Cantwell and Frizzini. Davies, therefore, attempts to stress the discrepancies in their testimony and in an arrest report filed by Cantwell at the time of the incident. His "grilling" of Cantwell is relentless and highly dramatic. From NET microfiche: For the first time on American television, a documentary examines the judicial system through a detailed presentation of a single trial. The case is set in Denver (only Colorado and Texas allow cameras inside a courtroom). It pits The City and County of Denver vs. Lauren R. Watson. The charges: resisting a police officer (Officer Kobert C. Cantwell) in the discharge of his duty,' and interfering with a police officer in the discharge of his duty." The larger implications of the case involve the conflict between police and Black Panthers (Watson, a member of the Black Panniers at the time of the trial, has recently been purged from the Party), and the system of legal justice as it applies to blacks and other traditionally underprivileged groups. The other "principals" are Judge Zita Weinshienk, an attractive and sympathetic young woman; Defense Attorney Leonard Davies, a 28-year-old local lawyer; Wright Morgan, assistant city attorney, who offers a sharp contrast to Davies in both age and style; and police Officer Robert C. Cantwell, Watson's antagonist. Each of these principals comments on the trial and on critical factors involved in it during a series of interviews, which are interspersed into the trial. The charge against Watson stems from an incident that occurred on November 6, 1968 - the day after President Nixon's election. Cantwell contends that he attempted to stop Watson for speeding, but was repeatedly thwarted after twice entering his car and notifying him that he was under arrest. Finally, at a service station, Cantwell says he was able to subdue Watson with assistance from three other policemen. Watson's story conflicts in almost every detail with that of Cantwell. He states that the policeman had driven past his house early in the day, gloating about Nixon's victory, waving a fist at him and shouting "White Power." He also swears that Cantwell never formally arrested him and that he submitted in the service station without a struggle. A synopsis of the four days follows. "Trial - The City and County of Denver vs. Lauren R. Watson" is a production of NET Division, Educational Broadcasting corporation. A film by Robert H. Fresco and Denis Sanders. Editor: Harold Silver. Each of the four programs will contain legal analysis by James Vorenberg, professor of law, Harvard Law School. Vorenberg is also director of the Center for Criminal Justice at Harvard Law School. He was executive director of President Johnson's Commission on Law Enforcement and Administration of Justice (1964-67) and director, Office of Criminal Justice (1964-65). From 1954 to 1962 he was a member of the firm of Ropes and Gray, after clerking under Supreme Court Justice Felix Frankfurter from 1953 to 1954. He received his LL.B. from Harvard in 1951, after graduating from the same school in 1948. During each program, Vorenberg will comment on legal subtleties and legal protocol, as defined within the trial. The first day - selection of the jury. In the selection of a six-man jury, each attorney can make only three peremptory challenges. Davies, in the judge's chambers, has argued that Watson cannot receive a fair trial since he will not be judged by a jury of his peers - no blacks appear on the entire panel from which the jury is to be selected. (The panel consists primarily of people who differ from Watson not only in color but in age, economic standing, and environment.) Davies' argument is denied. Therefore, he utilizes his three peremptory challenges in an effort to eliminate jurors who he feels might be prejudicial to Watson; at the same time, he attempts to impress the jurors with the fact that "At this moment, without hearing more, you have made up your mind that this man is innocent." Watson, meanwhile, in one of several interviews interspersed throughout the trial, states that "people who are not white in a white nationalist country are subjects" and therefore "can't get justice." From NET microfiche: The two competing trumpeters at the St. Andrew's day festival serve as symbols of Malta's class rivalry - especially in its cloistered village life. Anthony Theura of the Union Club brass band is an industrial worker at the Malta dockyard; he is the father of ten children; and he is a member of the socialist Labour Party - the opposition party out of favor with the church. John Calleja of St. Andrew's Club brass band works at the British Air Force base; like the other members of St. Andrew's Club, his politics are conservative, and he supports the Church-backed Nationalist Party, which is presently in power. The documentary examines these two warring parties in terms of Malta's striving for progress since the island gained its independence from Britain. Malta is Europe's poorest country in terms of per capita income. A small country, it has little opportunity for industrial development. Even its prospects for tourism are limited by topographic considerations. Sir Sadler Forster, British industrial adviser, remarks: "You can't put too many hotels on it or too many industries, otherwise they'd all be toppling into the sea." But the alternate course, based on ties with other nations, is also dismissed by Dom Mintoff, leader of the Malta Labour Party: "We don't like NATO and the Soviet Navy coming here We're most eager to see that our people earn their living through tourism and industry and agriculture and fishing, not just by being stooges of some other nation who will use us for war purposes." For many, emigration has become necessary, and John Calleja raises this possibility for himself and his family. Meanwhile, village life remains virtually medieval. "Luqa is curiously remote, still part of the rural tradition, with goats and horses in the streets, with the stone-walled wheat fields just outside the town." And in the village of Luqa, the pervasive force of the Catholic Church asserts itself most patently. Mintoff recalls a meeting of the Labour Party which was made ineffectual by the ringing of the church bells- a political ploy directed against a party that is consistently critical of the Church. The program concludes with the question: "How long can it go on - the village rivalry which has absorbed the Maltese for generations? How long before events force them to look outwards and join the rest of the world in this uniform, metropolitan, industrial century?" Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET JOURNAL - "Two Trumpets for St. Andrew": The rivalry between the classes in a Malta village is personified by trumpeters of two contesting brass bands playing at a feast day for St. Andrew. Narrator: Max Meldrum.
Australian Broadcasting Commission ; for Intertel ; NET presentation ; executive producer, Ken Watts ; producer-director, Gill Brealey ; writer, Keith Adam.

From NET microfiche: General Description of Series: THE VICTORIANS series consists of eight one-hour plays reflecting life in England in the mid-1800s. The plays are: "The Rent Day" by Douglas Jerrold; "London Assurance" by Dion Boucicault; "Society" by T. W. Robertson; "The Ticket-of-Leave Man" by Tom Taylor; "Two Roses " by James Albery; "Still Waters Run Deep" by Tom Taylor; "The Silver Ring" by Henry Arthur Jones and Henry Herman; "Sweet Lavender" by Arthur W. Pinero. All the plays in the series were great successes when first produced and for many years afterwards, though they have now -- undeservedly -- vanished from the repertoire of the current English theater. Produced with complete respect for the intentions of the original dramatists, the plays range in date from the eighteen-thirties to the eighteen-eighties, and in style from high comedy to strong drama. Whatever the style, Victorian theatergoers found the plays excellent entertainment. For today's audience they provide, besides their entertainment value, a lifelike picture of the Victorian age. In sum, the plays show a vigorous bustling money-making society. Every other theme -- class, sex, marriage, crime -- is seen in relation to money. Poverty makes a man a criminal. Lack of money makes it impossible for a man to marry the girl he loves. Possession of money makes it impossible for the vulgarian to enter society. The old aristocracy is still trying to hold its own, but the middle classes progressively become the image of England. More and more, the plays become populated by merchants, lawyers, bill-brokers, dishonest company promoters and self-made men. This social ferment of a hundred years ago played a large part in creating the England of today. During these turbulent years, there appeared a number of young writers eager to write plays reflecting -- and commenting on -- the times in which they lived. The best of these, all produced on the stage at the time, make up THE VICTORIANS. The plays are performed by The Company of Seven, a group specially formed by Granada TV for the series. They are: Patricia Garwood, Charles Kay, Ingrid Hafner, Geoffrey Bayldon, Michael Barrington, Barrie Ingham, and John Wood. NET Playhouse #39: The Victorians: London Assurance "London Assurance," by Dion Boucicault, was first produced at the Drury Lane Theatre, Drury Lane in 1841. At that time, the 19-year-old Boucicault was something of a theatrical prodigy, with three other plays already to his credit and his own acting career well advanced, "London Assurance" is a stylish comedy about the sprightly but elderly nobleman, Sir Harcourt Courtly, who takes a fancy to the 18-year-old heiress niece of his friend Max Harkaway. Sir Harcourt's greatest ambition is to make himself look 20 years younger, so that the girl will agree to marry him. But he faces unexpected difficulties when his son Charles becomes involved. Program is followed by filler : Jacques Loussier's "Play Bach" trio plays jazz versions of Johann Sebastian Bach works. This week they play: Italian Concerto, Second Movement. Suggested Newspaper Listing: N.E.T. PLAYHOUSE -- THE VICTORIANS: "London Assurance," a sprightly comedy about an elderly nobleman who takes a fancy to an 18-year-old heiress, is the next play in this series of one-hour plays portraying life in Victorian England.
Great Britain--Social life and customs--19th century
Granada Television production ; a National Educational Television presentation.

Lack of money makes it impossible for a man to marry the girl he loves. Possession of money makes it impossible for the vulgarian to enter society. The old aristocracy is still trying to hold its own, but the middle classes progressively become the image of England. More and more, the plays become populated by merchants, lawyers, bill-brokers, dishonest company promoters and self-made men. This social ferment of a hundred years ago played a large part in creating the England of today. During these turbulent years, there appeared a number of young writers eager to write plays reflecting -- and commenting on -- the times in which they lived. The best of these, all produced on the stage at the time, make up THE VICTORIANS. The plays are performed by The Company of Seven, a group specially formed by Granada TV for the series. They are: Patricia Garwood, Charles Kay, Ingrid Hafner, Geoffrey Bayldon, Michael Barrington, Barrie Ingham, and John Wood. NET Playhouse #40: The Victorians: Society "Society," by T.W. Robertson, was first produced in 1865 at the Prince of Wales Theatre, London. The play concerns a well-bred but impoverished young journalist, Sidney Daryl, who is hired by a wealthy self-made man, Mr. Chodd, to run a new daily newspaper. But Daryl soon finds he has a second and less pleasing assignment -- to introduce Mr. Chodd's arrogant and boorish son, John, into society. Daryl's own good manners persuade him to continue to help Chodd Junior to meet the "right" sort of people, even when these efforts meet with no gratitude. But the time has clearly come to teach Chodd a lesson when he decides to "make a good marriage" with Maud, the girl Daryl intends to marry. A powerful battle of wills brings this story of the eternal triangle, Victorian version, to its climax. Lally Bowers, one of Britain's best known character actresses, makes a guest appearance as Lady Ptarmigant, Maud's aunt. Program is followed by filler : Jacques Loussier's "Play Bach" trio plays jazz versions of Johann Sebastian Bach works. This week they play: Chorale: Christ our Lord Came to Jordan. Suggested Newspaper Listing: N.E.T. PLAYHOUSE -- THE VICTORIANS: An eternal triangle -- Victorian style, -- is the plot of "Society," the next play in a series reflecting life in mid-nineteenth century England. Lally Bowers is guest star.

NET Playhouse #43: The Victorians: Still Waters Run Deep "Still Waters Run Deep," by Tom Taylor, was first produced at the Olympic Theatre, London, in 1856. One of the play's central characters is Captain Hawksley, an easy charmer, whose talk of moonlight elopements thrills the ladies while his "surefire" business deals impress the men. In comparison, young John Mildmay seems pretty dull. He does not talk as confidently or as often as the Captain. His easy-going personality and unassuming manner are easily mistaken for lack of will and character. But in a time of crisis, when honor is at stake, John proves himself a man to be reckoned with -- even by the most blustering regimental officers. Program is followed by filler : Jacques Loussier's "Play Bach" trio plays jazz versions of Johann Sebastian Bach works. This week they play: Chorale: May God be Merciful to Us, Part 1: Trio. Suggested Newspaper Listing: N.E.T. PLAYHOUSE - THE VICTORIANS: An officer who is by no means a gentleman is one of the central characters in "Still Waters Run Deep," the next in a series of plays depicting life in Victorian England.

NET Playhouse #45: The Victorians: Sweet Lavender "Sweet Lavender" by Arthur W. Pinero, first produced at Terry's Theatre, London, in 1888, is a romantic play concerning the fresh and gentle Sweet Lavender, daughter of Ruth Holt, housekeeper and laundress in the London Temple. Among the lawyers chambered there is Dick Phenyl, a rough old barrister who drinks. With him rooms an eligible student, Clement Hale, ward of the banker Geoffrey Wedderburn and in love with Lavender (although he is already engaged to someone else, Minnie Gilfillian). Geoffrey, disapproving this love, is about to cut Clement out of his will when he discovers that Ruth is his own early sweetheart, and Lavender his natural daughter. Ruth comes to nurse Geoffrey through an illness; his love is reawakened; and three marriages take place at the end of the play. Arthur Wing Pinero, an actor turned playwright, became something of an idol with Victorian audiences, and remained a leading figure of the British theater for many years afterwards. His first play was produced in London in 1877, and many of his plays became world famous in the years following, among them "Trelawny of the Wells," "The Magistrate" and "The Second Mrs. Tanqueray." He was knighted in 1909. Program is followed by filler : Jacques Loussier's "Play Bach" trio plays jazz versions of Johann Sebastian Bach works. This week they play: Jesu, Joy of Man's Desiring. Suggested Newspaper Listing: N.E.T. PLAYHOUSE -- THE VICTORIANS: Arthur Pinero's romantic play "Sweet Lavender," about a girl who falls in love with a young man already engaged to someone else, concludes this series of eight favorite Victorian plays.

NET Playhouse #38: The Victorians: The Rent Day This play by Douglas Jerrold, first produced at the Theatre Drury Lane in 1832, tells the story of a young farmer, Martin, and his wife, Rachel, who face eviction when they cannot pay their rent. Crumbs, the surly land agent, seems determined to destroy their happiness, and highwayman Silver Jack's interest in Rachel adds to their troubles. Then it is discovered that Crumbs has a guilty secret in his past. Program followed by filler : Jacques Loussier's "Play Bach" trio plays jazz versions of Johann Sebastian Bach works. This week they play: Italian Concerto, First Movement. The filler is approximately 10 minutes. Suggested Newspaper Listing: N.E.T. NET Playhouse #44: The Victorians: The Silver King "The Silver King" by Henry Arthur Jones and Henry Herman was first presented at the Prince's Theatre, London, in 1882. One of the best known Victorian thriller plays, it tells the story of a man who loses heavily to the bookmakers and takes to drink. One night he is involved in a brawl with another man, who is found murdered the next day. Suspicion falls inevitably on the gambler, who slips out of the country, leaving his wife and daughter to fend for themselves. Years later he returns, having made a fortune from silver mines in America, and using an assumed name. He is determined to clear himself of suspicion and rejoin his family -- but first he must complete a dangerous one-man pursuit of the real killer. Program is followed by filler : Jacques Loussier's "Play Bach" trio plays jazz versions of Johann Sebastian Bach works. This week they play: Prelude No. 2 in C minor. Suggested Newspaper Listing: N.E.T. PLAYHOUSE - THE VICTORIANS: "The Silver King," one of the best-known Victorian thriller plays, portrays another aspect of life in England in the mid-1800s.
