NET Playhouse #41: The Victorians: The Ticket-Of-Leave Man "The Ticket-of-Leave Man" was first produced at the Olympic Theatre, London, in 1863. This play by Tom Taylor tells of the adventures of a young Lanncashireman, Robert Brierly, who comes to London and falls victim to the schemes of a quick-witted crook. He is wrongly arrested and sent to jail. On his release--as a "ticket-of-leave" man, who has earned remission for good behavior-- he sets out to track down the crook, Jem Dalton, and settle accounts with him. Program is followed by filler : Jacques Loussier's "Play Bach" trio plays jazz versions of Johann Sebastian Bach works. This week they play: Air from Suite No. 3 in D Major. Suggested Newspaper Listing: N.E.T. NET Playhouse #42: The Victorians: Two Roses "Two Roses" by John Albery was first produced at the Vaudeville Theatre, London, in 1870. The play concerns Digby Grant, an impoverished gentleman accustomed to living by his wits, who discovers that he is within the reach of a 10,000-pound-a-year fortune. Only if a missing relative is found will he be deprived of it. Certain that the money will be his before long, Digby moves from his little cottage to a grand house and begins to live in grand style. But the money does not bring him peace of mind and contentment, nor does it help his relations with his family. He robs two young daughters -- the "two roses" of the title -- of happiness by refusing to allow them to marry the men they love. Meanwhile a determined solicitor is pressing on with the search for the missing relative. Program is followed by filler : Jacques Loussier's "Play Bach" trio plays jazz versions of Johann Sebastian Bach works. This week they play: Prelude No. 8 in E flat minor. Suggested Newspaper Listing: N.E.T. Julia Child hosts a documentary special that takes viewers behind the scenes as the Johnson White House prepares for a state dinner. She interviews key presidential staff members and explores the grand dining rooms and narrow stairwells. She meets White House executive chef Henri Haller and shows the kitchen preparations for the state dinner. Through the eyes of Mrs. Child, viewers see how the White House chef faces many of the same problems as the housewife in her own kitchen. The guest of honor is Japanese prime minister Eisaku Sato. The dinner for 190 guests is held in two rooms--the State Dining Room (140 guests) and the Blue Dining Room (50 guests). Guests included Vice President and Mrs. Hubert Humphrey, cabinet ministers, foreign ambassadors, deputy ministers, American governors and local politicians, the chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, the chairman of U.S. Steel, a poet, John D. Rockefeller IV, Professor S. I. Hayakawa, the president of CBS, the president of the International Union of Operating Engineers, General William D. Eckert, the commissioner of baseball, St. Louis Cardinals' pitcher Bob Gibson, George Steinbrenner, Maxwell Taylor, Kirk Douglas and Ida Lupino. As a guest at the dinner, Child provides commentary on the menu, the service and the decor. After dinner, Tony Bennett and his band perform in the East Room. Menu: seafood vol-au-vent; sauteed noisette (filet) of lamb, topped with a fluted mushroom cap, napped with a brown deglazed sauce; artichoke bottoms filled with a sauce Choron; white asparagus polonais ; garden salad ; ripened cheese and grapes; selection of small-batch American wines ; dessert: Bavarian cream mousde flavored with fresh strawberries (dessert prepared by pastry chef Ferdinand Louvat) Four days of filming in November 1967 were condensed into a 48-minute finished program, scheduled to air in April 1968.
Presented by National Educational Television ; produced by WGBH-TV, Boston ; producer, Ruth Lockwood ; director, Russ Morash.

From NET microfiche: This program provides a critical look at the United Nations, which was established almost 25 years ago as the world's collective conscience. It examines the body's action - and inaction - in such troubled areas as Czechoslovakia, the Middle East, Vietnam, and Biafra, and assesses the diminishing influence of the Secretary General in vital world affairs. There are films from the opening of the 24th General Assembly and unusual coverage of the Commission for Human Rights, with a penetrating study of its function. (The Commission hears reports by governments on human rights within their countries; however, individuals are unable to seek redress through the UN.) Against the formalism of the United Nations, a Columbia student's immolation forms a stark contrast. His suicide, in reaction to the suffering of Biafra, took place on UN grounds. The program contains exclusive interviews with observers, who relate his death to the UN's powerlessness in the face of world tragedy. There are also exclusive interviews with leading world figures at the UN. They include Abba Eban, Israel's foreign minister; Carlos Romulo, foreign minister of the Philippines, who is known as "Mister United Nations" for his continuing role from the preparation of the UN Charter to his term as president of the General Assembly; and Nobel Prize laureate George Wald, professor of biology, Harvard University. The narrator of this program is Robert Ryan, the noted actor now starring in the Broadway revival of "The Front Page." Ryan's career, which spans the past 28 years, includes such films as "Bad Day at Black Rock," "Billy Budd," and "The Wild Bunch." His legitimate theater roles have included "Clash by Night," "Anthony and Cleopatra," and "Mr. President." Since 1959, Ryan has been co-chairman of the Hollywood branch of the National Committee for a Sane Nuclear Policy. Suggested Newspaper Listing: NET Journal - "Who Speaks for Man?": A critical appraisal of the United Nations, established almost 25 years ago as the world's collective conscience, and still faced with war, famine, and oppression. With Abba Eban, George Wald, Carlos Romulo.
Who speaks for man. NET journal #254.
